author: {'steamid': '76561198083254755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 23676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1053, 'playtime_at_review': 22953, 'last_played': 1712205552}
review:
Played the first game. Loved it. Played the second game. Still love it. 

The changes to the grind system is nice especially for late game. The new combat system is fair if so you're not stacking as many villagers as you can to fight tier 5 threats and so forth like the first game. The chosen system provides a hero to the story rather than it just being your entire village up against the darkness, especially nice that you can pick your chosen out of your starting followers meaning you can pick a Rat to be the Chosen one to guide the world into the future. Unique events just like the first game and with the steam workshop mods can change up the game however you see fit and add some more content to it. only thing i would change if i could would be the rate of which you gain God Points but given that you can have multiple games saved at once rather than one playthrough like the original i guess that makes up for it. Games can get long and tedious occasionally but still a fantastic game with great lore, mystery and strategies. Really can't wait for a third game or some more dlc to see what they have in store for us. Thanks for being great developers MuHa Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007020720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3668, 'last_played': 1709988869}
review:
Хорошая игра.
Плюсы итак понятны, поэтому хотел бы упомянуть в 1ю очередь недоработки:
1)Очень много желтых и фиолетовых боев (при этом сложность может быть сильно высокой).
Да, есть палочка-выручалочка ввиде волшебных палочек (работают в 3х режимах, и зависят от 1й характеристики), но лучше бы просто желтые и фиолетовые бои были редки, как в 1й части
2)Слишком жесткие ограничения на найм персонажей в поселениях.
При том, что по ивентам детей орков, гоблинов и людей сыплет как "из рога изобилия", 
а вот эльфов и гномов считай ограничение в 1 персонажа на игру (и +1 матрешка у гномов по ивенту). Что очень мало
3)После победы над Горском в пиратской сюжетной линии, при отказе от превращения своего Избранного в Дракона - не хватает хорошей прибавки к характеристикам как альтернативы.
4)Неудобная рандомная система повышения уровней, особенно способностей. Сделали бы хотя бы выбор из 4-6 вариантов тогда. А то на выбор способностей предлагают один мусор.
5)Персонажи сданные в Славянской деревне отображаются в общем списке погибших. Зачем?
6)Бонус от "Детской Площадки" в Деревне НЕ ПЕРЕДАЁТСЯ выросшим персонажам. Т.е. просто временный бесполезный баф персонажам-детям.
7)Крутые портреты у эльфиек, особенно классов "Друид" и "Дикий деван", намного лучше всего добавляемого модами, но... к сожалению всего по 1 на класс. мало.

Для комфортной игры рекомендую данные моды:
1)https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1783054290&searchtext=
2)https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2080270868&searchtext=
3)https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1795158184&searchtext=
4)https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3013866852&searchtext=
5)https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2032101757&searchtext= 
(к сожалению, мод N5 не интегрирован с модами N 2, 3 и 4 в списке)

author: {'steamid': '76561198012807542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1707505777}
review:
Thea is based on slavic myths and folklore. While Thea: The Awakening introduce you slowly to those, Thea 2 does not and even makes less sense, with many things unrecognizable. World events make pretty much zero sense now... like I had all my people in the village for 30 turns, and did find 10 new hamlets by just gathering. Another thing that makes zero sense. And this adventure events seems to be not fleshed out, there were more events with different outcomes in Thea The Awakening. Next step down would be the story. In Thea the story was nothing world shaking, but nice and interesting and made sense and wanted you to find out more. Here in Thea 2, it is very unispired and uninteresting.

So lets talk a bit about game mechanics... I see no improvements from Thea to Thea 2... nothing at all improved or evolved in any sense, if anything, it got more complex without adding value. I thinke the character portraits got a small update, they have color now, for the price of not having as many as in Thea. You gather ressources, you research, you craft, you build, you equip, you explore... all quite straight forward in Thea... here, not so much, it all works like before, but with some hooks and buts.  Basicaly, I want to fast forward 500 turns to finish the game.

I have had a rought start with Thea until a few updates later and actualy liked it in the end. Here... cant get warm with the game... could never play it longer then a few minutes when it got released. Finaly played a few hours and have enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198820715138', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1705095469}
review:
думаю хороших отзывов вы итак уже начитались, так что поговорим о плохом. Сразу уточню: я года 3 назад прошёл игру ещё на пиратке,когда тут в стиме было порядка 150 отзывов и купил потому что она мне понравилась.Игра ХОРОШАЯ, но имеет  ГРОМАДНЕЙШУЮ кипу проблем, прямиком из первой части, из-за которой я её советовать не стану. Она не заслуживает той оценки, что сейчас у неё стоит.
Но прежде чем приступим к плохому, не могу не восхитится проделанной работой над ошибками по сравнению с первой частью. От сиквела можно получить сильно больше удовольствия, чем от первой части которая является неиграбельным говнищем. Таким образом теперь все ресурсы на карте видны сразу, а не когда ты их отрываешь,поселение можно основать в любом удобном вам месте,плюсом можно сделать несколько поселений. разделение на классы не делает ваших людей полностью бесполезными в других областях. количества навыков кратно уменьшили, так что шанс залутать кучу бесполезного говна сильно меньше, к тому же, при повышении уровня вам дают выбор из 3х статов или 2х навыков, что даёт вам хотя бы шанс выкачать поселенца по билду. снаряжение можно сделать таким, что оно будет давать вам преимущество не только непосредственно в физическом бою, но и в испытаниях. Да и сами испытания переработали и теперь имеет смысл не только бить по ebalьniky каждому встречному но и пытаться решить  вопрос другим путём.Плюсом и систему боя сделали совершенно другую, в которой рандом не имеет значения, только ваши статы и навыки планирования.
ТЕМ НЕ МЕНЕЕ
Не меньше работы работы было сделано чтоб насрать в геймплей в горой, таким образом теперь у нас есть биомы - а в классическом представлении разрабов так и вообще отдельные острова, на каждом из которых есть свой супер ресурс, которого по задумке нет в других биомах, а так же теперь у нас есть супер дупер ресурсы, которые делаются из из совмещения 2х супер ресурсов. Для чего я вам всё это объясняю. А для того, что бы вы поняли масштаб pizdeca. на стартовой локации у вас есть только бомжовские ресурсы, из которых сделать снаряжение, дающее преимущества во всех видах боя а не только в физическом нельзя(вообще то можно но это не будет иметь смысла), а что бы сделать снаряжение из 2х супер ресурсов вам нужно основать ещё 2 поселения на 2х разных островах, в условиях когда вам хватает людей только на 2 группы - группу сидящую в поселении и боевую группу с вашим избранными. А потом, вам надо будет ещё организовать перевоз ресурсов на километровые расстояния по морю, кишашему высоколевельными пиратами. То есть в общей сложности здоровенная такая жопа, на организацию которой в одной катке у вас уйдёт порядка 30-50 часов.Но слава богу разрабы добавили континентальное устройство мира, так что теперь хотя бы можно после 10-50 рестартов мира добежать до локи с супер ресурсом и начать добывать хоть что то хорошее уже в первом поселении. А потом сидеть  на жопе +-100 ходов фармя ресурсы и создавая первое снаряжение для ваших бойцов, что бы они могли в 4 человека справляться с противниками. 
Теперь к новой системе боя. Её нету.Вернее её не будет для вас. Почему? да всё просто, автобой играет лучше вас. И это не потому что я рукожоп, а потому что комп мухлюет. он знает какие у вас в руках карты, так что если у вас есть персонаж с дробящим уроном, ещё до того как вы выложили его на стол комп будет делать всё для того что бы вы не смогли его реализоватьА стоит только вам только убрать дробящее оружие из рук ваших войнов и комп он тут же будет штабелями ложить своих бойцов от горизонта до горизонта плечом к плечу.А в автобое комп играет с компом и они читерят друг против друга.
Прокачка.Да, как я и сказал выше, систему навыков сильно улучшили, но она всё ещё сильно зависит от рандома и полна кучи отстойных навыков. Так например вам может попасться в навыках томагавок, который зависит от одной характеристики - воскприятие, и который можно кидать во всех трёх видах боя. Ещё и коэффициент урона больше чем у навыков специализирующихся на одном конкретном виде боя. но опять же, даже если вам этот навык выпадет на персонажа, вкачанного в восприятие, а не в другую характеристику, то вам может просто резко перестать падать это восприятие.
Ну и на последок,поселенцы.Не помню, могли ли они умереть старости в первой части, но в этой могут.Причём это максимально кринжово, потому что у меня 2 человека сдохли меньше чем за год игры. У меня за это время родился 1 ребёнок, а сдохли 2 топовых прокачанных собирателя. Такие вот пироги.
Вот ещё чё забыл. Я думал что в прошлой игре каличный интерфейс, но тут он ещё неудобнее. Выглядит красиво, да, но пиздец неудобный. вот я в меню рапределения работы по сбору ресурсов. вижу что если челику собирающему дерево дать инструмент увеличивающий сбор, то он как раз будет собирать ресурс за 1 ход. вместо того что бы дать ему инструмент прям в этом меню, мне нужно запомнить что это конкретно за чел, перейти во вкладку снаряжения и уже там ему этот инструмент. может звучит и не так критично, но неудобно пиздец и так тут во всём.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033281040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1704103213}
review:
I was hoping this game had innovated on the first Thea, but it really hasn't. I was really disappointed with this. The first Thea was enjoyable at first, but quickly became tiresome as most of the game was just skipping days to gather resources, and as you became more familiar with the game you realised that you could just rush to better materials to get through the game. Also the materials system in the first Thea made a lot of the materials completely redundant. Thea 2 seems to be exactly the same. There is almost nothing new here, aside from being able to now create one or two villages of your own. So far as I can tell, that is all that is new. The encounters are mostly the same as the first, the story isn't terribly different, the crafting/gathering/materials system is seemingly the same, and the combat is more or less the same as well (though the combat in this version is mildly  improved). I bought this for nothing but I am still refunding it because it is so disappointing to see that this is literally just Thea 1 with like 4 or 5 tweaks which don't make it differ very much from the first game.

Most opening playthroughs are ruined within the first few days as some random event comes up and you try an option you don't know and then lose sanity or physical well-being, and then members of your starting party consequently die the next day. I understand the game is about exploring, learning and discovering, but this is not fun at all. I'm trying to get into the game and setting up a camp to gather some basic resources together and I just fucking die cos I wanna try something new and get brutally punished for it. So what's the point in exploring? The only thing that's going to happen here is that I'm going to restart until I know the outcomes of every encounter option before picking them, which totally ruins the exploration and discovery side of the game, and that is 90% of this game's appeal.

Here are some examples of what I have had to deal with:
 - Find Scavenger group around day 5. Try to discuss with them to split the loot. I win, but take some heavy damage. Some members of opening party die the next day.
 - Find village on day 3. Think "oh cool, maybe can engage in diplomacy in this version". Go to village, Try to speak with village, get vastly outclassed by local population. No escape. Lose sanity discussion option. Whole party dies next day.
 - Set up camp to gather resources on day 2. Get random event of floor collapsing under feet and a horde of rats carrying stuff. Find option to have my party rat speak with the rats here to see wtf is going on. My rat is vastly outclassed. I lose the sanity discussion and apparently a child who wasn't even involved in the event takes a massive hit to their sanity. Child dies the next day.

How is this supposed to be fun? I'm trying to enjoy the game and discover shit and I'm just dying on every fucking reasonable option. So it goes exactly the same as the first Thea. You avoid as much as you can, you skip the first 500 days just gathering good resources, you make gear that makes you totally unbeatable in physical challenges, and then you brute force your way through every encounter, and it totally ruins the fun of what this game is supposed to be doing.

Overall, extremely disappointed. No innovation on the first game. Actual game play points are not fun and best avoided or even wiki'd if you want to enjoy the game, and on top of that I bought this fucking game and you've locked like 80% of the starting options behind playing??? Are you serious? What have i paid for here? I paid to unlock 20% of the game and you're making me WORK to unlock the rest of the game? That's just a poor philosphy.  There's nothing here to make the game interesting for more than 1 playthrough while you need to do like 20 to unlock just the gods, never mind the starter cards. So what have I paid for here?

I'm honestly angry cos I was looking forward to playing this for over a year, and when I finally get around to it I find that that it's just garbage. The first Thea could be forgiven for some of it's flaws as it was the first attempt, but this is just a shitty re-skin. 100% refunding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080474419', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1914, 'last_played': 1708618867}
review:
Интересный крафт + карточные бои + 4x пошаговая стратегия + управление ресурсами + славянский сеттинг = формула игры моей мечты. К сожалению, в этой игре что-то пошло не так... 

- Тут нет городов в привычном понимании 4X стратегий (кроме стартовой деревни), 
- Тут нет противников, развивающихся параллельно с тобой,
- Дерево науки кажется искусственным ограничителем, а сама скорость научного развития нестерпимо медленной
- Чтобы что-то изучить или собрать достаточно ресурсов, нужно много раз пропускать ход, кликая на песочные часы. Не знаю как у других, но на моём компе время ожидания хода компа раздражало. Причём непонятно, что именно за это время происходит, так как кроме хаотично разбросанных по карте монстров, в игре нет никакого AI оппонента, отстраивающего свою деревню и ведущего разумную деятельность.
- В игре есть три типа боёв - физический, интеллектуальный и духовный. Если прокачивать только физическую силу (а не прокачивать её нельзя), то высоки шансы перезагружать сейвы после каждой неудачной защиты от духовного нападения. Если прокачивать всё вместе, то это займёт гораздо больше времени. В дополнение к и без того медлительному темпу игры и отсутствию какого-то драйва это ещё более убивает желание играть. 
- Интерфейс приятный на глаз, но он заставляет делать много лишних телодвижений при передаче предметов, например. Неудобная навигация на карте мира, также заставляющая делать лишние действия.

Резюме: игра заслуживает внимания и знакомства для любителей жанра или первой части, но в целом выглядит недоделанной. Не рекомендую. 

P.S. В части русской локализации я пользовался мастерской стима, спасибо нашим ребятам - переводчикам!

review: Öncelikli olarak görsel olarak oyun ilk oyunun üzerine baya eklemiş. Hikaye olarak ise ilk oyunun sonundan gri seçenek seçilmiş olarak devam ediyor. Bunun iyi tasarlanmış bir devam oyunu olduğunu belirtmek isterim. Kimi zaman ilk oyundaki karakterlere göndermeler yaparken kimi zaman ilk oyundaki hikayelerin neye evrildiğine dair teasler sunuyor. Oynanışına gelecek olursak ilk oyundan farklı bir yol tercih etmişler. Beğenip beğenmemeniz çok kişisel bir perspektif, o yüzden yorum yok. Ama geliştirme ağacındaki tercihleri beni hiç mutlu etmedi. Sadece oynanış süresini uzatmayı hedefleyen bir tercih olmuş. Öylesine havada kalmış ki bu tercih, sizi ilk oyundaki temel unsur olan köyü gereksiz görmenize sebep oluyor. Daha çok şey anlatabilirim ama kısa kesecek olursam: oyun her oynanışta size rasgelelilik ve RPG seçenekleriyle başka bir deneyim sunmayı başarıyor. Benim oyunu önerme ve 220 saat oynamamdaki temel sebepte bu.

review:
I was close to loving this game.  The mechanics are just a bit off.  The progression mechanics are WAY too slow.  I'm patient and can play games quite a bit.  The unlocks needs to occur at least twice as quickly to keep the gameplay interesting enough.  At the risk of sounding roguelite obsessed, which I don't consider myself, I would like to see this game set up a bit more like a roguelite.  Perhaps it could be a bit harder with more restarts, and far quicker progression mechanics. That would be a more satisfying gameplay loop imo.

I actually thought their battle system in this game was quite good. A bit complex and obtuse, but I was getting the hang of it. These devs truly are very talented and creative.  This has the potential to be a great series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030904505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 10653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10653, 'last_played': 1691516941}
review:
Summary: 8.5/10

Thea 2 is a longer game than Thea 1, per campaign. For the completionists, Thea 2 is a shorter game than Thea 1 for it removed the grinding annoyances. This game can easily be done if speedrun in 3 campaigns (due to needed godpoints to unlock all but Nyai and Triglav which get unlocked by finishing it once, divine and main quest). 

The multiplayer is broken. I never got to experience it and people never will be as it definetly won't be fixed anymore. Since I don't care about this mode in this type of atmosphere and experience game, I will not deduct points for it. Just be warned, it is not a multiplayer game and likely cause for recent negative reviews.

The game has a similar atmosphere and lore as Thea 1 and continues the story in a nice manner. It just lost some charm by not being fully voiced. The battle system has become more streamlined and follows closer to TCG rules than Thea 1's card battle order. Overall the game has improved in many area and has my full endorsement.

Atmosphere & Lore: 9.5/10

The lore and atmosphere is as dense as in Thea 1. A lot of slavic lore with their own worldbuilding charm and adaptations offers a wide variety of encounters.
Unlike Thea 1 the quests in Thea 2 are sparsely narrated. It happens mostly during the main quests and not in its beautiful entirety. This could be fine, but even the quests they added from Thea 1 to add more content did not get added with their former voicelines. This sadly lessenes the beautiful atmosphere of the side-stories quite a bit.

Beyond this sad mishap and downgrade to Thea 1, the stories and choices are as diverse and interesting as before with a new multitude of choices between the three new challenges (physical, mental, spiritual and double as concept variants). Each of these offers unique paths and rewards or punishments, depending on the factions, gods or domains involved.
The factions added in this game are wildly different and sometimes are in direct opposition to each other. This can lead to interesting storylines if one wishes to attain certain allies or to experience special events.
Some new settlements even get founded as an allied entity (better trading and more services) if the faction is aided in some quests. Examples of these are the "blood bone" Stinger event, the water demon event with the Kraken and the Siren and the night demons in the mines.

With only a slight detraction for the reduction in immersion from Thea 1 to Thea 2, this game still excels with its lore.

Gameplay: 8.5/10

Compared to Thea 1 the gameplay has become more diverse. For one the world size and shape is not part of the difficulty curve anymore and difficulty does not rely on making the game slow and tedious, just harder. As such the 200% challenge becomes an actual challenge without feeling like an intentional slowdown of the player. 

From the one town in Thea 1, Thea 2 expands to a playstayle of nomad with powerful ring artifacts but slow research and low productivity to one city + ring of power or two city gameplay. While two cities sounds limiting, the managing of gathering, refining and crafting in two of them is extremely taxing alongside your explorer's party. The best game mode is either one base working for you or a nomad group that is always together and safe but lacks carrying capacity and needs several fleet ships to carry all its loot. The nomad playstyle is also the strongest and easiest, counter to intuition. The start is slower, but the pace is faster.

Alongside this advancement of gameplay actions comes the boat. Oh how I loathed the maps that generated with a giant lake in the center in Thea 1. Now we can just sail through them once we build a carryable vessel whenever we want. Not only that, but sea travel is one of the most rewarding ways to engage with the world. From looting kraken den's to fighting pirates, the seas are were most of the important loot in the mid to lategame stem from.

The crafting system has been simplified and the equipment slots have been reduced. This is a good thing! Thea 1 had a hidden pseudo-meta - and so does Thea 2 - but its crafting system early on was confusing before it got streamlined in its later release patches. Thea 2 starts with a very clear and fair system. Essence sum decides the quality of a weapon and comes from items. Some got more essence but risk failing (losing 10% essence and 50% value), others got less essence but assure lighter equipment for the less strong in the party. Meanwhile essence combinations create different effects. In weapons metal gives "Armorbreak" and later "True Damage" attributes in Elemental and then Legendary essence ranges. Meanwhile stone gives shield leech of varying %. Meanwhile leather gives guaranteed base damage to ensure a weapon even held by a child strikes true. In armor the essence type then decides the bonus. Static HP or % HP etc. For magical equipment there are 3 variants possible each in spells and result depending on the primary essence used. It has enough depth to allow min-maxing but is perfectly viable on "Elemental". Legendary weapons never fill their essence bar, thus the trade-off for things like True Damage going through armor is the max damage etc. Shields sacrifice defense for mobility of the user, same with armor on legendary. It is a rewarding system.

The upgrade and downgrade system with coal that starts at the third tier of resources (and is needed to make any Tier 4+ resource outside of loot) is a bit tedious and has its main use in condensing your loot to more manageable weight. Refining wood to crystal wood takes tons of work and turns... that is never worth it. Be sure to use it when needed and for small quantities. Otherwise the system will feel like work and delay. The game can be beaten with Elemental weapons, even on 200%.

Battles are now played like a TCG on a board with zones and field effects, trigger spells etc. This means it has gotten more tactical depth and can't just be cheesed with a few sneak characters pushing two to three superbuffed characters to oneshot the enemy boss anymore. With a multitude of enemies from dracoliches which excel in armor to giant health sponges like krakens, this game has a lot of fun matches to test your planning and strategy against. Or you can autoresolve and let pure numbers fight for you. Note just like in Thea 1, what works best in battle does not necessarily work in autoresolve. Autoresolve uses cards 1v1 with their base values, regardless of field spells and effects. If you rely on auto, build stat monsters, not complex machines.

As always permadeath and consequences follow your decisions and add to the atmosphere, unless you use free saves. The old exploit of crashing the game to avoid losing in ironman still works, so if the 200% achievement is too hard, you can always rely on that.

This game is a clear improvement over Thea 1 gameplay.

Audio & Sound Design: 7/10

The game has a few different soundtracks for the gameplay in the background, which do not give or take from the general atmosphere. They are exchangeable but pleasant. The most dominant sounds are the weather effects, however, and alas they are qutie annoying. Loud howling winds in winter, the "loud" darkness and rain torrents are nice and novel for a time, but at some point several turns of loud weather noises did annoy me bit. If any of the sound design of the game starts grating on you, consider turning it off and putting on a nice music and instrumental on Youtube or other platform. Overall it is decent, but nothing to write home about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038639826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 12523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1939, 'last_played': 1706647224}
review:
I liked Thea: The Awakening a lot a while back and finally got around to getting Thea 2 a few days ago.

Pros: 
Multiplayer is great - when I play with my friend, I mostly ferry resources and craft while they explore, but we do joint ventures too during winter. The game is similar to Thea 1's, but different enough to keep things interesting. The stories and voice acting are riveting and the randomness in how the same events play out is great for replayability. They have a built in bug-reporting feature too which I haven't really needed to use.

Cons: 
There are some new icons for weapons and skill types that aren't exactly intuitive. I eventually figured it out with the help of the community section guide and a bit of experimentation. Some small bugs in multiplayer, but nothing super game-breaking (expedition flags lingering after expedition no longer there).

Other notes:
There seems to be a helpful Steam guides community for most of the questions I have about the game, so I'll be looking there more next. For instance, the guides explain differences between weapon types and how the material used to craft them affect their properties. The modding community also has some excellent tweaks so you can play how you like. I liked have at least one more cosmic seed early on to start a sister village nearby - it came with its own challenges (split forces = weaker), but was a fun way to mix things up.

Conclusion:
The game seems like an alternate reality version of Thea: The Awakening, a different way the game could have gone with the core being similar, but numerous changes. I have very much enjoyed the 32 hours spent over the last four days since purchasing the game, and I should probably stop doing that so much for my own good.

Latest edit: I just finished all the achievements for the game after a bit over 200 hours (at leisure) and I think I am done with the game for now. Great value and it was fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091314506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 9798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9132, 'last_played': 1689268722}
review:
Итак, что мы имеем - ролевая стратегия с заточкой  на крафт в квазиславянском сеттинге.
На мой вкус - в разы лучше первой части. 
Начну с минусов: игра не проста  и неинтуитивна. Во множестве мелочей придется разбираться и разбираться долго, даже при том, что вы пройдете обучение. Из простых примеров - никто не скажет вам, чтобы вы запретили своим остолопам использовать для отопления любой лес и редкие сорта древесины пойдут в топку. Также непроста и боевая система - придется какое-то время помучиться, прежде чем освоить сколько-нибудь вменяемый стиль боя (и это касается всех - так как дипломатия тоже идет через бой, только обмениваются при этом не ударами, а аргументами).
Также подкачал саундтрек. Нет звучит он, конечно, красиво и аутентично. Местами. Но слишком часто возникает вопрос - это все еще саундтрек или у меня игра зависла?
Также ощутимый минус - вам мало открыто. Боги, последователями которых мы становимся, стартовые бонусы (которые мы все равно покупаем за очки) открываются нам только за специальные очки, набрать, которые мы можем только по итогам прохождения игры (не обязательно полностью, но все же). Это оттягивает возможность поиграть тем, кем по-настоящему хочется, а к моменту накопления можно уже и перехотеть окончательно.

Но давайте разберемся, для чего стоит играть. Это, конечно, уникальный сеттинг. Здесь и славянская нечисть, и гномы-эльфы-орки-гоблины. Микс получился диким, но органичным. Также удался сюжет - по сути, у нас есть огромная песочница с сюжетом, который вас не торопят выполнять. Огромное колическтво квестов, которые по-разному выполняются в зависимости от следования тому или иному божественном ареалу и партийных предпочтений. Масса классов, которые могут освоить персонажи вашей партии. Да, еще у вас будут рождаться дети, подрастать и кем-то становиться. И если у ребенка, который решил стать собирателем, проблем не будет, то отправившийся проходить испытания на другую профессию может и совсем не то получить, что ожидалось. Хотел стать войном, а стал жалким разбойником, хотел стать берсерком, но не укротил дух медведя, поэтому стал медведем. Хотела стать ведьмой, стала ведьмой, получила себе проклятие психики.  И многое другое. 

Также многое завязано на крафтинге. Учимся собирать более редкие материалы (а некоторые невозможно собрать, только синтезировать), учимся крафтить все, что нам нужно, крафтим. Собираем еду, учим рецепты, готовим пищу. Собираем ингредиенты, проводим ритуалы. 
Игра предполагает и разнообраный игровой процесс - вначале вы получите  звездное семя. И это даст возможность или основать стабильное поселение и оно будет расти обустраиваться, выпускать экспедиции. Или семя можно потратить и создать кольцо, пусть не всевластья, но тоже неплохое. И странствовать всей ватагой по миру. Или, если ваш избранный еще ребенок, получить для него уникальный класс.

Если готовы через все это продираться - милости прошу, игра очень душевная.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109972473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 17616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 312, 'playtime_at_review': 16693, 'last_played': 1712262555}
review:
Wirklich schönes Spiel, dass durch die vielen Gottheiten einen hohen wiederspielwert hat. Es gibt viel zu lesen mit vielen unterschiedlichen Antwortmöglichkeiten und Ausgängen. Kein Spiel spielt sich gleich wie die vorherigen. Es gibt unterschiedliche Fraktionen und durch das Konzept, dass man zufällige Kinder zeugt, z.B. eine Kreuzung aus Zwerg und Orc ist jeder Charakter anders. Das Spiel hat hohen Suchtfaktor. Tolles Crafting Konzept und etwas Wissenschaft ist auch dabei, sodass man nach und nach immer stärker wird und weiter spielen will. 

Leider gibt es keine Einführung in das Spiel, sodass man erst spät lernt wo man seine Stadt am besten setzt und wie man die höherwertigen Rohstoffe selbst herstellt. Bspw. hatte ich erst spät gelernt wie man eine Stadt mit Reichweite 4 gründet. Auch, dass die Database sich ständig ändert und dadurch die Spielstände kaputt macht (auch im Multiplayer) ist wirklich nervig. Ich hoffe, dass die zukünftig anders gelöst wird (ohne die alten Spielstände unspielbar zu machen)

Ich denke mit 2 großen Updates könnte das Spiel von eine großen zu einem sehr großen Spiel werden. Immerhin kann man mittlerweile das Spiel im Multiplayer endlich spielen. Der Fix hat nur fast 3 Jahre gedauert.. Das neueste (kostenlose) Update hat das Spiel nochmal verbessert mit neuen einzigartigen Quests und nun der Möglichkeit, dass Spiel (halbwegs) stabil zu spielen.

Fazit: Einzigartige Spielmechanik mit hohem Suchtfaktor! Beendet das Spiel nicht nach dem Beenden des Hauptquest. Versucht auch die "Arena" Quest zu beenden! Es ist wirklich sehr befriedigend :-), wenn man es dann endlich schafft.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983763092', 'num_games_owned': 1299, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 3584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3280, 'last_played': 1688374580}
review: A very fun game in a lore rich world, there is a lot to do in game.  It's a mix of several genres to include party exploration/survival/village building/lore gathering.  Some of the gameplay mechanics can be a bit difficult to figure out when you first jump in so it might be worth checking out a beginners guide first.  There is also a ton of events and small stories/quests that you can encounter just wandering the world, I've done several runs and pretty much always find a new event each time I do a run.  There's also a meta progression in the form of choosing different gods to serve and they provide you different bonuses/playstyles.  Not a game for everyone but very fun if you are into this type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116179964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 28335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22004, 'last_played': 1706805092}
review: This is my favorite game at the moment. I played Thea 1 and I think after the first year of Thea 2 being released and getting the bugs worked out, it is better than the original. The best parts of the game are the awesome crafting mechanics, a difficult tactical combat card game and the replay ability of having multiple gods that lend themselves to different play styles that are super different and fun. I actually hated tactical card games before i started playing Thea. I picked it up because I really wanted to see fully fleshed out Slavic gods. Their take on Slavic mythology is done well and the story line related to the gods is entertaining. The combination of the difficulty, tactical combat, crafting and storylines pretty much checks all of my boxes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033081704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 19073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15368, 'last_played': 1688061994}
review:
If you're the type of person that gravitates towards save-scumming to get the perfect roll / upgrade for your characters, you'll end up putting a lot of hours into this game.

I'd strongly recommend you try out the demo to see if you're interested in the game, since it gives you a good idea of what the rest of the game will be like. Personally, I like the macro aspect of the game a lot - looking for the right place to plop down a village and planning a route to maximize exp for children so they can get as many levels as possible before their growing-up events. It's also really nice to be able to autocomplete battles since those can be pretty time-consuming.

My main gripe would be with the stuttering and lag that occurs later on during the game, especially when selecting a larger map.

In addition to the game and its DLCs, there's also a lot of great mods available for the game. They modify things like quests, races, skills, and complete overhauls to the game's systems (e.g. buildings & weapons). Many of the popular mods are also still being maintained (at the time of this review), and the modders also fix issues that people bring up, as well as fix compatibility issues with other mods.

The Thea 2 community on Discord has by far been the best part of this game for me. The modders themselves, other members, and devs have all helped me troubleshoot issues that I've run into while playing the game. It's made my experience playing the game so much better, and greatly contributed to the amount of hours I've put into the game thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014871344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1687428859}
review:
A similarly baffling game to the original, Thea 2 is an easy game to bounce off of for strategy gamers. For those with peculiar taste in such things, as well as an appreciation for a combination of Classic Fantasy, Slavic, and Nordic mythology you're in for a treat. The game has come a long way since it's first days of early access(aka, it's quite playable now). It's a turn-based hybrid of party-based exploration, colony/empire management, RPG, survival, and narrative storytelling game, pretty much exactly like it's predecessor. 

The combat system has changed significantly from the previous game's usage of card-game mechanics. There's been some adjustment to research, crafting, and leveling, all of which seem like improvements. The meta-progression and customizability of your runs seems vastly improved compared to the first game. Being able to unlock and implement finer elements of your starting party is really nice and helps you set up in the pre-game much better for the kind of run you're planning.

All that said, even with the tutorial, there is going to be a lot of restarting and trial-and-error before you get your balance with this game. Knowing what resources are good, what you can make decent use of, and how to plan for and adapt to situations, seasons, story events, gods, etc just plain take experience. That's going to ultimately decide whether you bounce off this game, but if you're anything like me and you get excited about optimizing and digging deep into systems, this game could well get its claws in you. I fear it may have gotten me.

review:
The game cheats like no others.
On normal difficulty at turn 192, when I barely have Tier 2 gear, my expedition got assaulted by 4 groups of enemies of difficulty 4 and 5 in physical or spiritual.  ALL IN ONE NIGHT.

Other than graphics, there is very little going on for this game.  I could have sworn that in the first game you could search for a resource after you researched it and it will show you the closest 2 locations.  They have either removed the option or  hidden it somewhere in a big mess of an interface.  Thus there is no point in research resources until you have found it on an expedition.  And there are way too many random events that almost kill you by removing all Health/Sanity/Spirit, just by walking around.  There is nothing you can do in some of these, no picking a right option to lessen the damage and keeping your characters alive.  You end up saving and reloading every few turns or it's game over.

Get Thea 1 instead.  It was better despite the simpler graphics which I did not mind.

review:
La partie survie redonne un peut d'air frais à la formule du traditionnel 4X façon civilization.
La réalisation est bonne et le contenu énorme, mais le point fort du jeu c'est avant tout la narration. Les événements sont denses, très bien écrits et pour ceux qui sont doublés avec un doublage d’excellente qualité.
On est vraiment plongé dans cet univers qui mélange des inspirations de contes germaniques, nordiques et d’Europe de l'est.

Je le recommande chaudement à tous ceux qui aiment les jeux avec une forte narration. Pour ceux qui sont du genre à passer les cinématiques ou qui n'aiment pas lire des pavés de texte, passez votre chemin, ce jeu n'est pas pour vous.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994327978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 14796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13069, 'last_played': 1709338008}
review:
Thea 2: The Shattering is a masterful blend of 4X strategy, RPG, and survival elements that creates a unique, compelling gameplay experience. The game's rich Slavic mythology setting, combined with a robust procedural world generation system, ensures a refreshing playthrough each time. The complexities of managing your village, as well as the depth of crafting and character progression systems, may be daunting at first but are deeply satisfying once understood. The card-based combat may not be to everyone's liking but it adds an interesting strategic layer that differs greatly from standard turn-based combat found in many games of the genre.

While the steep learning curve can be a hurdle for newcomers, those who take the time to learn Thea 2's intricacies will be rewarded with a deep, immersive experience. The game's artwork and sound design are beautifully crafted, complementing the setting and the narrative perfectly. The developers have also provided substantial post-launch support, addressing the technical issues and continuously improving the game, which is commendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033623422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 7364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1684242949}
review:
TL;DR: If you have never played the first game then I would recommend this instead of the first game but there isn't enough difference to recommend spending a lot of time playing both.

I'm reviewing this as someone who spent a lot of time playing the first game.

Compared to the first game this one has a lot more polish and much greater depth and yet it just doesn't feel like a significant improvement over the first. The game feels very familiar yet the UI is extremely complex and its only my previous experience that allows me to use it successfully. I'm reviewing this early but so far it just seems like "more of the same" which is not enough to make me want to spend more time with it given all the other great games out there.

This game is buggy. A few times I have gotten warnings saying that the game is in an unstable state and may not work properly. When loading a saved game the quest tracker is empty. When you are roaming with an expedition any loot you get from events magically teleports back to your village. Crafting failure rate seems to be buggy with 25% failure rate resulting in failures 3/4 times in some cases.

This game introduces the sanity mechanic which can cause your group to wipe. If you fail a mental challenge then members of your group will leave due to low (negative) sanity leading to cascading problems where the group gets overburdened and cannot return to the village without dropping stuff, and will lose more people before you return.

A few events are recycled from the first game, which seems lazy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030754741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2113, 'last_played': 1681277865}
review: It's not bad, the writing is entertaining and the underlying narrative and theology of the world shows a lot of creativity. The problem is that from a gameplay standpoint, it's... functional, but that's it. The problems of many world-building games (e.g. Civ) are all there in spades and there's just not enough upside to balance it out. The crafting and resource management system is pretty basic and gets cumbersome quickly. I appreciate the attempt at making a novel combat system, but I never felt like it added to the game and found myself auto-resolving almost everything because I never got the sense that I could do any better than the computer and it wasn't particularly fun to do it manually. After 35 hours over 3 games, I kept getting invested in the characters, but not enjoying the game enough to want to continue. I appreciate the efforts of an independent design team and hope they keep working to make the gameplay match the creativity they put into the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045141591', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1507, 'last_played': 1681663137}
review:
If you think a strategy-card game, that incorporates roleplay elements in a Slavic fantasy world could be interesting, then I recommend you go play Thea: The Awakening. Thea 2: The Shattering isn’t an awful game by any stretch, but it is far below the quality of the original in a few key ways. Disappointing sequels is nothing new in the strategy game genre, and while it is by no means as big a let down as C&C 4, it did disappoint me even more than Red Alert 3.

I bought this game years ago and tried on three separate occasions to get into it, but couldn’t, until I decided to power through this weekend and watch guides online to see if there was any gameplay style that was recommended to new players. And there is, [b]never build a city[/b]. The game is designed for you to be a wanderer, and make sure to save scum like there is no tomorrow, as the difficulty is all over the place.

The decision to design everything around a wandering group leads to way bigger negatives for me than the first game had:

-	Everything end up feeling very much the same throughout the game, as you are never really changing your playstyle. You are constantly one big army walking around the map from start to finish picking the fights you can handle.

-	Because every character is in your party you don’t feel the RPG elements as much in the text-based part of the game. Since you will be going around with all your different classes and races and you seem to start next to the same factions each time, it becomes very much the same experience and who your god is more a stat-thing, and this time more just a single stat, as there aren’t god-levels with passive upgrades the more you play with one. This made me stop caring pretty quickly, as I lost any connection to the story and I was instead driven by my unhealthy desire to finish for the sake of finishing and getting achievements. ☹ Which made it very clear that way too many quests are heavy on the exposition and loreinfo-dumps, as I skimmed over most of it, only really paying attention to enough to make sure I took the right options for my moral compass. 

And then the big one, the combat. I don’t know if they wanted to try to add complexity or what is the reason for the redesign, but it feels much worse than in Thea. Thea had the easy to learn difficult to master feel, this just felt like a big annoyance and made me play through with almost only auto combat, except for the fight where I got the achievement for winning one the auto combat couldn’t.

While Thea 2 probably looks better in a graphical/tech sense, I must say I just like the look of Thea more. It has a bit more flavor and charm to it, or maybe it is just something I am imagining because I dislike playing the sequel… It hasn’t soured my opinion on the franchise or the developers though, and I will check out Thea 3 if it becomes a thing, but I won’t be buying that on early access. :P

author: {'steamid': '76561198084470410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4040, 'last_played': 1677044610}
review:
Thea 2 is superior to Thea 1 in every way. It's depressing to see that 90% of the negative reviews exist because people believe 1 to be better. I don't really understand it, because the team working on this game clearly went all out with improving ALL aspects of the game. It's visually one of the most stunning games I've ever played and I find myself repeatedly coming back to it over the months since I've purchased it.

I play on the hardest difficulty setting there is and I love the challenge of it. Mind you that dwindles away really fast because I know all the nooks and crannies of this game. But the story is incredible, I've never seen a story where they make 'light' the bad guy. The creativity of such a decision was amazing and ties in so well with the story of Thea 1 which I enjoyed a lot, but I'm not blinded by 'nostalgia' when it comes to seeing something actually improved upon.

I love these games, I can't compliment it enough, but sadly I doubt we will ever get a Thea 3, and I imagine it's thanks to all the ungrateful people in the reviews here. As a developer, to pour my heart into something, only for the audience's response to be "I don't know what it is..........but yeah....thea 1 was like soooo much better." I'd never touch the series again because it's extremely discouraging.

My only real complaint would just be the lack of body diversity with the 'gods' the men look super epic and unique, but all the females minus 1 have the same body type and the lack of clothes to go with it. And on that topic why are most of the female species nude? But apparently a frost troll....has to have a cloth covering his sensitive bits? I'd like either the females to have MORE clothes, or the men to have none like the girls. What's the point in boobs hanging out all perky for the male eye, but to completely shy away from a guys junk. It just seems silly and sexist.

And that is my honest opinion. P.s I hope to heaven and hell there is a Thea 3!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198134842771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 19417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16283, 'last_played': 1704918951}
review:
When I first started this game to test it, I forgot to go to sleep and played for 10 to 15 consecutive hours. Yes, it can be that imersive.
Thea 2 is an improved version of their previous game, Thea: the Awekening, which I would also recomend. The merchanics are a bit more acessible here in my opinion. I would describe it as a mix between a 4X game and a RPG, in a fantasy setting heavly inspired by slavic myths. There is a lot of replayability, a lot of room for player discovery and I appreciated the possibility to try a game with my freind.

The music is absolutely incredible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060718434', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 2348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2348, 'last_played': 1660936009}
review:
I did not enjoy this game as much as the original and I don't know why. Everything was improved, even the repetitive missions/encounters were more tolerable this time around, and I liked the ample ways you had to deal with the story and approach it as you desire. So what went wrong?

My only conclusion is that, while a lot was made better, it failed to blend in together.

Still, an interesting title if nothing else.

I give it a 6/10.

review:
Yes this game has flaws, some of them pretty annoying (I won't linger on it since they are already well described in other comments). However I recently played another Hard difficulty campaign and really enjoyed my time despite these problems.

The game is way prettier than Thea 1, making the franchise more accessible to newer players. There are lots of quality quests and random events, you can feel there's been a lot of work and love given to the lore, writings, voice dub, etc...

We also got free expansions adding significant content. For a game sold under $25, it is appreciated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017269792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 3928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1348, 'last_played': 1675971951}
review:
I didn't play the first Thea.

Worldbuilding, events, and characters are all great. The races are interesting and shown with good portraits, like the characters. Events are fun and don't always go the way you think even if you've seen the same event before. Loot is RNG to a point, so you can't just optimize the perfect run unless save-scumming. Game is almost completely customizable which is perfect for breaking up the redundancy. 

Lots of quality of life improvement should have been addressed as it gets annoying to click multiple times to do the same thing over and over. Micro-managing 20+ people every turn can get boring, quick. Rogue-like progression is too slow. Each god you chose to follow should have changed the way you played your run each time, but it just doesn't accomplish this in any way that matters. Generated towns feels like big camps that you throw all the craftsmen and undesirables into so they don't bog you down while adventuring.

This game just could have been so much more. I can understand the criticism that those with 200+ hrs have, but the game is still good enough for me to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052430349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1524, 'last_played': 1674837967}
review:
Definitely a step slightly backwards from Thea 1.  Thea 2 is a longer game experience, and in theory should be more fun.  In reality, some aspects of the game are extremely limited and therefore annoying.

An example of this is the weapon system.  The vast majority of the weapons you can craft are utterly useless, as only a couple of types truly excel at utilizing character stats.  This is further wasted by giving characters abilities that are actually stronger than the weapons they're holding.

Overall the quest system is much worse than Thea 1.  It's common to not know which quest is where, and the quests seem disjointed and generally dissatisfying.  The quest chains themselves are far too simple and short.

The 'to build a village or not?' question is another annoyance.  Given how strong camping is, there really is no advantage to building.

It's a shame, because overall it's pretty great, but the negatives bring it right back down to mediocre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046617830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 40136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22631, 'last_played': 1706864905}
review:
A wonderful sequel to Thea: The Awakening. The Slavic pantheon and mythos is a sadly underutilized well of fantasy that these two games really do justice. 

Gameplay wise Thea is somewhat tricky to jump into, the tutorial does a well enough job explaining how the card combat goes down, though realistically you can brute force your way through if you build up enough (where's the fun in that?). As a resource management/exploration game a la 4X, the game feels good, the events are fun to encounter, you can also tweak the difficulty so that some aspects are more of a hurdle than others (though doing so effects the rewards you get for going through the game). 

The wide pantheon of gods to choose from gives the game exceptional replayability, as well as diversity in early-late game choices.

Overall, quite good, I recommend the pierogi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007095638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 43016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22698, 'last_played': 1704969797}
review:
Is this game an improvement on the first?

Customizing your God at the start of the game is a great addition. Leveling the Gods feels more worth it. It makes me want to play more so that I can unlock new cards I could start with.

I enjoy the new battlefield, the card battles now allow for strategic placement.

The ability to be a nomad and pick the location of my city is the best change for me. You can even roam forever and never settle at all, love it.

Now, be aware this game is a lot more buggy than the first. Some of the bugs can be fixed by going into the editor. Up to you if that is worth it or not, for me it was.

I cannot comment on the multiplayer, I have not tried it. It was highly requested by many players.

So is it an improvement? Yes, if you do not mind the bugs. I think it is worth buying, especially if you liked the original.

review:
Kedvenc játékaim egyike, amit fél kézzel lehet játszani(másik kézbe' cigi), körökre osztott stratégia. A civilizáció megsemmisült, gyűjtögető-vadászó pár emberkénket irányítva kell alkalmazkodni, egyszerűnek tűnik, de kell az élvezethez egy bizonyos recept - és így intelligenciát vár a játékosától. Steam Workshop modjai miatt érdemes megvenni, én nyitott voltam rá, és most van egy játék a talonban ami örökzöld marad, időnként leporolni, és elporolni az ellen se.gét(seregét). Különálló egyedi vonalú 4x játék, egyszer nyersz és már tudod is mit kell csinálni. Amikor az ork gyerekkatonám meghalt, mert nem akart gyűjtögető/kovács lenni, feláldoztam két gyereket, hogy visszahozzam az életbe Harcosként :'D
Ha nyersz(és ha feladod is, egy bizonyos kör után), fenntartja az érdeklődést azzal, hogy pontokat kapsz, amivel erősítheted a következő játékodat permanensen. Szerintem így kell ezt csinálni.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972363974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 9464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8707, 'last_played': 1685498234}
review: If you enjoyed the first Thea, you must play Thea 2.  It is just as engrossing and fun as the first, with improvements galore and plenty of added depth to sink your teeth into.  If you've never played Thea, I absolutely recommend trying this game if you are a fan of turn-based tactical games, RPGs, and/or roguelikes.  The slavic mythology works very well to present an alternative to the Tolkien-esque worlds that are so prevalent in fantasy games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067754197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3135, 'last_played': 1709987197}
review:
The game is too unjust, even more so than the first one. It is way too RNG-heavy. You basically have to lose 10 games, to learn by heart every event, so that you know in advance which one will be too difficult. A single lost combat can end your game. 

The final nail that made me stop is a bug where a single child from my group had to do a fighting challenge, for no apparent reason. He of course lost, which handicapped me for the rest of the game.

I want to like this game, but come on. Stop putting wandering enemies 3 levels above the average of the island, stop putting unescapable challenges of high levels. And just give advices to new players. I had to lose 10 games before coming to the conclusion that you should not build any village until you have at least 15 villagers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198966367207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1671332842}
review: I have some pretty strong, mixed feelings about this game. I have Thea 1, and I do like it. Despite the fact that Thea 1 is old school, I do still play it. In Thea 2, I do like the fact that the graphics and music are updated and are much better. I like that the characters have a lot more fluid movements to them. The storyline is better, and there is some carryover of the elements of the story in Thea 1, which made some nice tie-ins.  All of that being said, I am exceptionally frustrated with the fact that the game automatically saves so bloody often. I was at almost turn 750, still hadn't had a chance to build even a dwelling for my party, and then they were just all completely wiped out in one turn. I tried to reload it, but noooo. The game had auto-saved it already, and all I came back to was helplessly watching them get wiped out again. For goodness sakes, the developers really, really need to fix this. Please just put a setting on it where I can switch off the bloody auto-save! I have turned this game off and walked away from it over and over because of this one frustrating feature alone. Then I eventually come back to it and try it again only to be met with the same frustration. And it would be such an easy fix!   While we're talking about fixes,  please, please, please give players some autonomy on the camera? With the curved map, and the fact that the camera automatically centers on the tile that the party is in and then zooms in, I lose the ability to use more than about 3 tiles to move my party in each turn. I rarely get to move 4, and almost never 5. So it feels to me like it takes forever to get my party to any location. If the developers were to fix these two things that really stop me from thoroughly enjoying gameplay, I could get addicted to this game. Would I recommend this game? For the price, it has the potential for some fun play, as long as the player has a lot of patience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963754875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 16597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16543, 'last_played': 1703182496}
review:
Thea 2: The Shattering has a lot of interesting elements going for it that as a whole package is an interesting take on a rogue like - with a strategic overland Layer - with traditional RPG components. All set in a varied slavic mythos setting.

There's a lot of variety in the games events, even if you see the same event across multiple playthroughs, depending on the characters involved, that can be very varied as there's a multitude of classical high fantasy races, undeads and daemons, together with the chosen god pick, you can end up with a completely different take on the same event.
This is because the multitude of varied characters you can have in your party, all have different tags, depending on whether they are orcs, goblins, humans, magic users, daemons, beautiful, their stats and so on. Many events have multiple different ways to solve them, from different combat solutions to outright victory via non-combat with the right traits/tags.
That leads to a lot of replayability, as no two playthroughs are the same. The variability is also a mixed bag at times, because there isn't much of a constant or red thread in the gameplay. And the balancing, or lack there of, can be quite poor at times swinging both ways, in the players favor or against the player, leading to moments with RNG that simply punishes you with a bad roll on an event.

So the game should offer many hours of gameplay and it can, but the developers have moved on to another project and neglected gamebreaking save file issues in multiplayer, that leads to save files breaking and becoming unloadable, this issue has been known by the developers for going on six months or longer at the time of writing. They've also announced a new DLC in May 2021 that hasn't materialized either and there's no sign of the save file issue being addressed or the DLC being finished or even released, until sometime after they finish up work on Master of Magic. Whether it's an indie studio thing or not, this isn't acceptable business practices nor an excuse and reviews should reflect that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967315629', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 6509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3144, 'last_played': 1669892380}
review:
A deeply frustrating game.

I took a punt on Thea 2 after reading an article on ‘the best 4x games’ in which it was described as a little different to many turn based 4x games and praised for its options for crafting. I have not played Thea 1.  The crafting system is rich and complex, the graphics are good, the storylines well crafted, but the combat system is impenetrable and unforgiving. 

I’m on my third game (51 hrs played), and my focus for this game has been to research and build better armour and weapons. It’s turn 670 and I have the best of my characters collecting obsidian a long way from the village. There are 8 of them, covering each of the 3 combat types and the highest is a L17 hunter. All have the best armour and weapons I can make, so I’m feeling quite pleased with my party. 

And then, out of nowhere a 'wandering monster' steps into my camp and kills everyone, pretty much.  The main beasties have three times the hit points of my best, and do twice as much damage as my best. They are accompanied by magic users weilding the sorts of ‘spells’ I can only guess in wonder at, because none of my party have anything like them. And even their spellcasters have more health than double my best.

This sort of thing happens quite a lot in Thea 2. There is lots of pressing the end turn button while you wait for your party to collect resources, and plenty of reloading when your party gets wiped out by random events. Saving frequently is essential. Be prepared for the combat system to be a lot less intuitive than it should be. I’m not a fan of the card based combat system - I can see how it should work, and it probably could work with some changes, but for me it’s a distinct negative.

It’s also a game where you have to be prepared to learn as you go as there isn’t a large gaming community producing updated content. The guides on Steam help a certain amount, but don’t have the depth to help you long term. There are some guides on YouTube, like Aavaks stream. At 12 episodes of 50 minutes each it’s a heavy investment to learn the game.

I really wanted to like this game, as it has style. Unfortunately it gets repetitive and having your party slain out of hand no matter what you do isn’t fun.

review:
I liked Thea 1 better. They changed too much, they made it overly-complicated, changed the pace of the game and made every character disposable. You don't even start with a village, which means that you can't rely in a safe haven (and the nature of the new events, that might simply destroy and kill your characters don't help either). There is also less voice acting than before. Although, I have to say the music, artwork and the plethora of new events are much appreciated. 
They should have taken Thea 1 and made it better (more events, more choices, better music, more art, more voice actors etc.), not totally change it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199067589312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 15806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 696, 'playtime_at_review': 12360, 'last_played': 1712430668}
review:
It took me a while to warm up to Thea 2 - the mechanics are different enough from Thea 1 to require some adjustment to the way you play. However, it's well worth the time. The story line is engaging, the different gods enable different play styles and there is so much replayability. The two changes I like best are the shift to 3 challenge types and children growing up events (especially the monster children - I just had an icicle that grew up into an ice troll in my last run).

One change I would like to see for future games is the balancing of elemental and legendary weapons. Shield leech is way better than anything else and pretty much mandatory on higher difficulty runs. I'd also like to see more varied quests that take you from one zone to another. 

Overall, an amazing game that has many hours left for me. Time to start a new run!

author: {'steamid': '76561198116551445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1661535842}
review: I wanted so badly to like this game. I really want a good 4X/RPG fusion game. I really want to see more games that draw on underutilized mythological traditions. The thing looks beautiful. But after hours of play, the core mechanics are just too weird for me to enjoy this game. The combat mechanism is both non-intuitive and doesn't feel like combat, it feels like some ancient precursor to chess that was developed before civilization had a good handle on what a *game* is. To make it worse, the same combat system is used to also decide non-combat challenges, except now instead of headbutting a wolf I'm headbutting the concept of stealth (I know that sounds awesome in theory, but it isn't in this game). To make matters worse, the user interface for the characters is really unfriendly in my opinion, and make it tedious to balance or optimize your party for the various challenges. I think the 4X aspect of the game, though not as blatantly weird as the RPG aspect, is far to slow and limited in its options to be enjoyable on its own. It was a very disappointing purchase for my collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970617782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1663193667}
review:
If you have Thea 1, you'll love this.

If you have not played a Thea game, it is a hex based strategy game of a group of tribal villagers- either roaming or eventually forming a village- where you gather, fight, or talk your way out of situations and craft gear, weapons and such. There's character types such as warriors or priests or gatherers and craftsmen. However, having a wide group of skills in vital when exploring as not everything is beat by brute force. 

Combat is card game based with initiative manipulation and targeting rules, and it does take a bit before it ALL will sink in. Just play, DO NOT SWEAT IT. Just play and do what seems obvious, and over time things will click as to what is optimal and what all is going on and possible. It's simple in its depth, but nothing overwhelming. It's cool that it uses the same system with variance for talk and strategy / non-combat type challenges as well.

Plenty of replayability, as unlocks are part of the game for new runs.

Highly recommended.

review:
(French below)
I loved the first one, played many hours. But at the end it was a bit of a click fest with setteling for each night who gather what, who crafts what etc... Now it required even more clicks!
  I find the battle less interesting and again, longer to prepare than in the first game. Which woud be fine for a few battles game, but with the usual many encounters it just adds. 
  Not clear what was the design decision to take a concept that worked and "adding more option" just increase the only negative point of the previous game. 

 A last more subjective point, I find the art of the characters less interesting than in the previous one. Too detailed so less place for imagination. 

 The god system seem more interesting than in Thea 1, but I don t see when I will find the time and the patience to try it...see points above. 

------------------
  Comme le premier en plus mieux, plus de clic de souris pour faire la meme chose. Plus d option pour les combats ce qui veux dire plus de clics de souris pour les combats. Le gros probleme du premier (l unique probleme) etait la quantite d ordre a donner dans une partie. Dans Thea 2 c est pire, pour un jeu qui semble assez similaire.  (bouger les gens qui font de la collecte de ressource, crafting, combats... tous ca plus de clics).

  SI vous avez pas essayer le premier le second peut valoir le coup, mais moi je passe, l interface est devenue un peu moins ergonomique pour un jeu qui vous force a l utiliser a outrance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028462390', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1660364196}
review:
I will start this out by saying that I do like particular elements to the game. It's got nice choices and pathing with cool ways to develop gathering/crafting.

I only have a few hours (coop) so I may be speaking out of ignorance. My few gripes:
[list]
[*] Gathering new followers seems pretty RNG/rare so opportunities to increase work force seem limited/scarce
[*] Coop in this game SUCKS. Events are just interference, can't see what they're doing, slows down turns, missions are separate, loot is given to only the person who starts the event even if someone helps, etc.

I would totally love this game if they brushed up on the coop element to either share objective quests, resources? towns? etc. Co-op means working together. The only sense you have of working together in this game is the card battles where you can synergize off each other. It doesn't really change much because solo fights you are given 7 action points and in coop you have 4 each (total of 8). 

TLDR; I like the single player side of it, i absolutely detest the coop (the main reason I got this game) features. Would still recommend it for 4x enjoyers.

review:
I played both Thea 1 and 2 on release and have played sporadicly since. They are fantastic. I prefer the second to the first, and the only thing I don't really care for is the battle-mechanics. Highly recomended

author: {'steamid': '76561198064513598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1657839895}
review:
I liked Thea 1 and was looking forward to liking this one too.  I read the negative reviews and was aware of the issues, but wanted to try it anyway.  I did enjoy the "honeymoon" phase of learning a new game.  But, the honeymoon never ended for me.  I never felt like I knew what I was supposed to do.

I was most surprised by the lazy programmer choices.  No manual.  Inadequate tutorial.  No tooltips.  Lots of information on the screen during combat for example, but no way to look up what many of the information means.  In T1 I could click on a resource in the research tree to find it on the map.  In T2, go scroll around for a few minutes and if it is there, maybe you'll find it.

If you like a game where the main challenge is to just learn all the arcane undocumented features.  If you like spending hours reading discussions because there's no manual.  If you want a follow-up game that dropped all the best features of the original.  Then this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965897672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1434, 'last_played': 1693880401}
review:
Possibly one of the best strategy, replay-able, town management with character based stat card game.
the first and second iteration is a relaxing time sink, dealing with random generated encounters and making decisions based on religion, morals, logic.

you feel attached to your group and death will happen. 
as you learn the strategies and world knowledge the next time you play it will become easier.

if you are looking for a fast paced game this would not be it, 
its slow build up and pause-able turns allow you to do laundry, homework or anything else while you are planning your groups next actions.

the music score is great, filling in the background keeping you engaged in the events unfolding.

This game checks all my boxes,
A card game that doesn't drag on and replaces a (DnD) single die throw so you are able to build skills to better improve your chances.
A town management, building up resources and collecting rare materials for better crafting to build your groups stats to your liking, rpg style.
An Adventure game that builds story through random events and a main story line, as you grow your enemies follow suit, making sure you have enough food and fire wood, making sure you bring a healer are all parts of going out and exploring the world.

the only cons i find with the game is dealing with the pet rats and the scoundrels, its a erk when one of the kids randomly choose the scoundrel as a profession.

i would hope in the future there is more crafting and recipes and events added.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035346531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1646573389}
review:
I liked the first Thea and was looking forward to playing this, but it just didn't work for me. I could get past the fact that it took 5+ hours of playing before most of it made sense, but even once it started to gel for me it just felt... disappointing.

The biggest issue here is the card combat. Even on maximum speed, it feels sluggish and annoying to play through. This leads to wanting to just auto-resolve most encounters because they are annoying to play through. Of course, when I started to autoresolve almost everything, I noticed that the auto-resolve typically got me a better result than playing the combat. At first, I thought this was just because I was bad at the combat, which is admittedly very confusing at first. The more I made myself play out the battles, though, the more convinced I became that the auto-resolve would frequently get me results that were mathematically impossible to achieve while actually playing, at least in some circumstances. So, the optimal way to play the game seems to be to mostly not play the most "game"ish part of the game. Not great.

The UI here is also quite poor. Aside from the card game, the other things you do are mostly craft, gather, and explore, and all of these feel laborious. On the overhead map, it can be difficult to tell which hex a quest marker is actually on. It's easy to end up moving to the wrong spot by accident, and there is no way to take back your move afterwards. The interface for keeping track of quests is basically non-existent, and you will frequently find you have no idea what you are supposed to be doing. Assigning people to gather is also laborious, as some basic features, like swapping the place of two characters by dragging one of them onto the other, are missing. Instead, you have to drag each of the two characters to the unassigned area, then place them in the slots the other formerly occupied. Crafting involves similarly screwing around with a UI that feels needlessly opaque, and once you understand it does not feel like it has enough depth to justify its complexity.

The UI issues are all minor annoyances, but given that the game encourages you to not actually play the card game, all you really have left to do is screw around with the aspects of the game that make you constantly interact with its underwhelming UI. As a result, the minor annoyances become amplified.

All in all, if you want a 4x game, there are better ones, and if you want a card game, there are better ones. It's a shame because this feels like a game that was almost good, but the developers maybe just bit off a little more than they could chew and ended up not really being able to make a coherent and enjoyable whole out of their mishmash of ideas.
