author: {'steamid': '76561198069567854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 13746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13629, 'last_played': 1595781555}
review:
Для тех, кто не знаком с серией, укажу, что игра по геймплею представляет собой необычную смесь пошаговой гексагональной стратегии, rpg, текстовых квестов и уникальных тактических сражений, оформленных в виде карточной игры. Мир и события, за исключением главных сюжетных историй, генерируются случайно, поэтому никогда не знаешь, что тебя поджидает на следующем ходу. Отдельно стоит упомянуть интересно реализованную систему крафта экипировки. В целом, если любите неспешный микроменеджмент и не против немного почитать, то определенно стоит попробовать поиграть.

Если же сравнивать игру с первой частью, то во многих отношениях сделан шаг вперед, но в чем-то и шаг назад. Изменено очень многое, но я упомяну только то, что критично на мой взгляд.

Лучше по сравнению с первой Тэей:
1. Полностью переработана система параметров персонажей. В первой Тэе это было жуткое месиво, в котором запомнить, какой стат за что отвечает было невозможно - приходилось часто открывать таблицы, размещенные в меню помощи. Из-за этого и без того адский микроменеджмент делался еще более адским. Во второй части все привели в порядок, стало логично и понятно. К тому же добавили возможность выбирать статы для повышения при получении уровня персонажей.
2. Полностью изменена боевая система. Мне нравились бои в первой Тэе и к изменению сначала отнесся со скептицизмом. Однако новая система понравилась еще больше. Теперь всего 3 вида испытаний, вместо 9. И они напоминают бои в первых частях Disciples, только с возможностью влиять на очередность хода сражающихся юнитов. Вдобавок появилась система активных скиллов, которые можно применять в испытаниях.
3. Мир разделили на острова с разными биомами и степенью опасности. Добавили возможность строить лодки для преодоления водных пространств. За счет этого, а также возможности основать деревню в любом приглянувшемся месте, освоение мира стало интереснее.

Хуже по сравнению с первой Тэей:
1. В первой части на максимальной сложности можно было понести потери основной экспедицией на поздней стадии игры просто нарвавшись на очень мощный блуждающий отряд. Здесь же разработчики не смогли адекватно сбалансировать новую, более навороченную, боевую систему. Теперь, разобравшись с боевыми механиками и системой крафта, можно без труда составить убер-отряд, который зевая проходит любые испытания в любом из трех режимов. Даже на максимальной сложности все серьезные проблемы заканчиваются на ранней-средней стадиях игры.
2. Гораздо хуже работает система развития мира - респавн гнезд и агрессивность монстров. В первой Тэе все было отлично. Например, в первые ночи нужно было до заката сгонять всех в деревню и отбивать отряды тварей, выползающих из кромешной тьмы. Гнезда нужно было регулярно вычищать, а со временем появлялись все более и более опасные, постоянно выпускающие все новые и новые отряды монстров. Перед дальним походом было актуально строительство башни, увеличивающей обзор вокруг деревни, чтобы раньше замечать надвигающуюся на нее опасность. И рано или поздно рядом с деревней вдруг появлялось какое-нибудь логово троллей или гнездо великанов, и вы спешили вернуться домой основной экспедицией, чтобы не случилось беды. Теперь всего этого нет. Даже на максимальной сложности мир игры быстро пустеет. Новые гнезда если и появляются, то очень-очень редко, да и то, не спавнят врагов. Уплыв же на дальний остров не ждите, что там кипит жизнь - скорее всего там будет полнейшая пустота. Непонятно, почему разработчики не смогли перенести систему спавна из первой части. Может, это техническая проблема нового движка, или же просто не хотят тестировать свое детище.

Указанные два момента очень сильно портят впечатление от игры - она просто до сих пор сырая. Однако раз уж я сам наиграл 200+ часов (2 прохождения на максимальной сложности), то не могу назвать ее плохой. Так что рекомендую.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030437510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2445, 'last_played': 1662994979}
review:
Great fun, and a worthy sequel that builds on what we loved about the first game. Great tactical depth, you are given full freedom over where you want to go, how you want to get there and how many risks you want to take. Full disclosure - I am probably only still in the mid-game and haven't completed a full play through, but wanted to give this positive review before I cracked on with building a larger ship so I can explore a new continent (and hopefully find a dwarf and a goblin). 

Advice I would give to a new player would to be not too overwhelmed with all the choices you have. Play 50-100 turns on normal, have a sniff around - try new things - make mistakes. Game for me is  most fun on hard - which encourages you to think strategically about what resources you want to collect, manage the seasons (getting back to your village for winter) and has a good challenge factor (you have to build up strength before you can just go anywhere on your starting continent).

Hoping they will make Thea 3 one day, or bring out more DLC for Thea 2.

review:
Начну с главного: У ИГРЫ ЕСТЬ РУСИФИКАТОР! Он в мастерской, достаточно годный! Есть конечно не переведенные места, но их не много, есть ошибки в тексте, но они не критические. Спасибо ребятам за локализацию! Именно благодаря ним я купил данную игру, ибо даже зная английский, мне лень было переводить тонны текста, так как все события в игре текстовые!

Я почему-то испытываю проблемы, когда пытаюсь написать отзыв о данной игре. Она не казистая по графике, у неё проблемы с интерфейсом, странные баги в мультиплеере, она достаточно хардкорна и не понятна для новичков (гайды в помощь), но блин какая же эта игруля залипательная, в неё играешь как в Цивку, ещё один ход... ещё ход... для любителей таких пошаговых стратегий самое то! Карточные бои не много портят картину, мне больше нравились бои из первой части, но и к ним можно привыкнуть. 

Мне игра понравилась, мы даже поиграли в неё с друзьями по сети: у нас личный рекорд проигрыш в 3 хода! 3 хода и твоя группа в могиле! Вот это хардкор!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017933188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1710968765}
review:
Play the first one instead

Quick summery : it is a game where every thing has been balaced to oblivion, which makes every ting feel the same. And it seems like they have focused to much on end game, for a game where you spend a lot of time in early game. 

It seems like they have added a lot of new stuff, but they have also made a lot of the old stuff really boring. The new combat system could be interesting if it was not for the lack of interesting equipment, and abilities. Each of your characters have acces to different ability based on weapon and skills. Some are attack skills, which places them on the field and allows them to attack at the end of a round, other are abilities which either boosts and/or lowers the speed and/damage of  one or more played cards. You each take turns, five times each round, where you commonly have 2 mana. Using a ability cost 1 mana, plus 1 for each time that character has been played. This leads to you allways only play your best cards, and use the same skills in every combat. It is something which could have been really fun, but the except is just boring. What they should have done, was to give the different abilites different costs, and expanding the abilies which can be used. 

The new crafting system is so boring, definitely in the beginning. It does not feel like there is any major difference between different type of materials. All items of the same type, does the exact same thing, just better or worse. You have a slider which which increases the better materials you use, and that determinants how high stats the item gets. So it is no longer interesting to seek out new exotic materials, to try and find cool new combinations. It is just 10% better damage. All items can be build either has normal, elemental or legendary. Where elemental and legendary, have the more intressting effects, where their sliders are just harder to fill up. So you can either get a lower ranked item, with higher stats by picking normal or more instresting effect but lower stats. But these to are so hard to fill, to any mening full extent, what there is no point in early to mid game. Which means every thing just fills the same for the first 200+ turns. 

Villiages have become boring as well, they work the same as in the old game, but all the buildings only gives really boring affacts. You no longer gain followers via buildings, so there are no fun races you can gain which excotic materials. And early game materials give little to no effect, you are lucky if you can get your crafting+ and gathering+ building to give you more then +4 with tier 1-3 materials. 

The same goes for the misstions, i have had 6 starts now, and it is allways the same events you get. I game which is focesed around losing and replaying runs, need a way more dynamic early game.

review: Honestly, this game is a gem.  If you enjoyed any of the Eador series or lords of xulima, I think you will enjoy it.  Unique world, story rich, tons of replayability from procedurally generated worlds, resource management, 1 / 2 city kind of game where choices matter...  I was so pleasantly surprised by the depth of the mechanics: having never played thea 1, I'm not sure exactly what brought me to it.  I will say if you're randomly looking for a game that will grab you and you enjoy a fantasy trope rpg with a whole lot to offer, this is the game for you.  The only major issue I've found is a lack of information available from forums / discussions / youtube- you've really got to dig if you're a player like me who's a completionist.  Regardless, enjoy it!

review:
Замечательная игра с лором, кто играл в первую часть увидят ряд изменений, что в механике города, ведь теперь можно кочевать по всей карте или основать свою деревню, выбор за Вами.

Моды бывают действительно годные, но если орк спит с единорогом, это уже проблема, так как у них родился эльф)

Игру рекомендую к рассмотрению, но уважаемые разработчики добавьте русский язык, русификатор есть в мастерской, но хотелось бы видеть его в официальном исполнении тем более есть такие сервисы как localizor io которые могут с помощью комьюнити помочь с переводом)

review: Играю на 172% сложности, получилась неплохая стратегия выживалка. Не понравилось отсутствие связки основного сюжета с этими рассами на островах. Т.е. темп развития у меня в разы обгонял необходимость по основной ветке сюжета вообще плыть на эти острова и что то там кому то доказывать или выяснять, Команда горячих пацанов могла и так решить все вопросы силовым путем по божественному заданию и никакие эльфы с гномами мне для этого не были нужны.... это плохо потому что теряется глубина восприятия игры и мира в ней. Таким образом скажу так, базовый движок не плохой, увеличение мира прошло успешно, ветки развития интересные, а вот режессура квестов никакая...

author: {'steamid': '76561198052769845', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 9140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2898, 'last_played': 1696364495}
review:
Thea 2 combines concepts from various genres to make a unique game. Player controlled characters have RPG like skills and leveling. It has a strong crafting system with the option of town creation and management. Story line driven events with choice options that can impact far into the game. A rogue like element which upon victory or death a player gathers god points (victory points) to be able to add starting boons to tackle different story arcs or harder difficulty. Battles are handled using a card game with the stats of the cards being determined by the level and equipment of the characters. Heavy RNG reliance. 

Interesting game, with some fun mechanics. Huge learning curve. Many of the story events are non-intuitive so you just have to play through and remember the best choices. This means beginners should save scum, change the starting options to manual saves, as it is easy to die unnecessarily if one does not know the "correct answer".  RNG can, and often will on higher difficulties, out right kill the whole party without warning. In this sense, the game is horribly unbalanced; or maybe perfectly so. Depends on what you like. The difficulty settings are broadly malleable, which is one of the game's saving graces; it would not be enjoyable without this customization ability.

Be aware the time it takes to play any one game is long. Most games take 300 turns or more at an average of two minutes a turn. Some turns are very quick, while others require longer deliberation. 

Overall its a good game, offering many hours of entertainment, challenge, and/or escapism.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023141222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1980, 'last_played': 1628013953}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971389142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 6348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3847, 'last_played': 1654053331}
review:
It's very good but not as good as the first game. It definitely will hook you once you get a hang of the new game mechanics in it but it has some flaws too.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
- It's got that grand adventure feeling that the first game had
- There's a lot of weapon and armour variety in it
- Research is now more streamlined
- The crafting options are really good
- There's a lot of nice new options when you start a game, depending on unlocks you acquired
- The new autoresolve is really good, and gives you a chance to fight the battle manually if the autoresolve result wasn't good enough

[h1]The Mixed[/h1]
- I had a hard time following the story, the events seemed unrelated at times
- The world map is now 5 islands, with higher resources cordoned off from you which seems really artificial
- The voice acting isn't as good as the first game, but still decent
- There are harsh difficulty spikes

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
- The new card combat system is bad, it's supposed to be more predictable but it's just flat out worse than the first game
- Some of the game mechanics are weird, you can die from losing an argument for example which makes zero sense
- The devs don't want you to savescum, but the RNG is brutal at times forcing you to save scum by clicking through the menu, they should have added a quick save and quick load
- The quest markers and quest list keeps disappearing for some reason, trying to figure out what you're supposed to be doing and where that is requires a good bit of digging through the UI

author: {'steamid': '76561197991621121', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 12684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7313, 'last_played': 1687802923}
review:
Ein sehr hartes, aber phantastisches Spiel mit vielen tollen Geschichten welche zu unterschiedlichen Ausgängen führen können.

Recht hart, vor allem der Anfang, bis man etwas abschätzen kann, ob man eine Chance hat die Gegner anzugreifen, oder ob man lieber einen Bogen um sie machen soll. Man verliert Charakter so oder so mal, auch ist manchmal etwas RNG dabei. Dafür kann man aber auch häufig speichern und neu laden.
Das Spiel beglückt einem mit spannenden Geschichten und einer grossen Welt und Völker die es zu erforschen gibt. Leider nur in Englisch.
Ich bin kein Fan vom Kampfsystem. Die Kämpfe sind entweder Mental, Spirituell oder Physisch und jeder Charakter hat darin wiederum seine bevorzugte Stärken und Schwächen. Ausserdem sind die Charakter Skills je nach Kampf auch nicht nutzbar, was eben das System sehr Komplex macht und man idealerweise mit einer gut gemischten Gruppe umherzieht. Das System ist aber sicher besser als das recht simple vom Vorgänger.

Den Vorgänger kann ich aber auch empfehlen. Beides sehr wundervolle Spiele die mit viel Liebe erstellt wurden. Der Preis und die freien DLC's/Erweiterungen sind mehr als fair und leider schon fast eine Ausnahmen im momentanen Spielemarkt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101203163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5338, 'last_played': 1589799916}
review:
I've played about 100 hrs now. I like the game, but I have some suggestions:

1. There needs to be a "populate the research slots" selection on the circular camping menu, and it doesn't need to change the screen. Alternatively, the research slots could remain populated on land like they do on water. Either choice would eliminate a bunch of tedium.

2. The save game process should eliminate 2 clicks by going from the "game to save selection" directly back to the game without the "Warning - game has been saved" and "Resume" steps.

3. As others have said, the crafting needs an overhaul. By mid-game, most of the materials are useless, and tedious to deal with. The better materials needn't be better at everything  than others in the same class. More variation in the capabilities would be interesting.

4. I've played once with villages and once without. The villages help in some ways, but because of resource distribution and slow travel, they end up being a detriment. If there were some way to disband it and rebuild it in another location, that would help. One possibility is by building a "land ship" (sledge) that could slowly haul a great load across the map. The seed would need to be recoverable obviously. The structures need to have more useful benefits too.

The game is interesting, but I won't play it again for awhile. Hopefully some of the issues will be addressed,

review:
Been playing it for a bit but I think it is a waste of money. The game has loads of potential and looks fun. But even tough this game requires you to read a lot (which becomes very tedious after a while) it is very very bad in explaining thing.
It took me 10 hours playing to realize all of this:
1 I still have no clue what the endgame is. What is the goal of this game.
2 I still have no clue how to get a balanced team and how to make them so I can effectively fight all 3 kinds of battles.
3 I still have no clue what is the best place to build a village.
4 I still have no clue on how to get a second village.
5 I still have no clue if building a village is even beneficial. I build one, Left with a strong team to do quests only to have my village murdered by an opponent I was unable to defeat because my team was too far away. So what is the point of a village.

Then there is a lot of other stuff that wasn't clear from the beginning.
I know one thing. This feels like a waste of money and I am going to watch 10 hours of youtube videos to try and find out: What is the point!

Update. Played it after watching some video's. After one playthrough I am pretty bored with it. It's all the same and playing the scenario's again. Nah.
Also it lets you win too easy and then the last quest when you decide to continue is just too hard. I am never playing any of the battles since the auto resolve is usually a far better outcome (it spreads damage over all the characters where you only have 7 characters to choose from when you play the battle yourself). Or maybe you don't get 7 characters at random... I don't know. A lot is never explained.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182465235', 'num_games_owned': 290, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 1020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1588812068}
review:
This is a tough one to review, I'm only 15 hours in but i'd like to give some initial feedback.

[h1]DIFFICULTY:[/h1]
The difficulty is non-sensical, you will be going through extremly easy fights that are extremly reppetitive and boring so you will be auto-resulting most of them and then out of nowhere, an event or a fight that looks like a mundane one will wipe out your entire team because once you decide to chose the fight option you cannot backtrack your decision, you are forced to either, skip to results, fight manually or forfeit all your goods. The difficulty is really not well balanced. I had two full parties of level 9s + die to one singular character because it ended up being a "Faith" fight and my characters werent really that good in faith, but the thing is that on the map this character looked like a normal fight but once you click on it, you find out you only have two options, fight faith or surrender, like how was i supposed to know before hand this wouldnt be a physical fights like all the others.

[h1]TERRIBLE DESIGN[/h1]
I despise how you cannot see any information about an opposing party before deciding wether to fight them or not, you're basically going in blind, so it makes it barely impossible to prepare for a fight without knowing, the only way to know is to save your game, fight them, and reload your save to go back.

Random events will pop out of nowhere all the time, most of them being choice based and pretty easy, and then out of nowhere one of them will wipe out your entire village, or curse all your characters because you didn't chose the one good option, (example: i had a event with a chicken, the choice was to either kill the chicken or bring it back to the village, i brang it back to the village and it ended up being a demon and gave 3 curses to ALL of my characters, WTF?!)

You will be friendly with one faction than see one of their expedition out on the map, so you will try to interact with them to see your options, just to realise they will either, want to fight you or a mental challenge to prove to them that you are friendly. Why are they still hostile even though you are friendly with their factions?? whats the point of being on good terms with their faction if they still treat you like an enemy when they encounter you.

This game will make you grind for hours upon hours, than one bs fight or decision will wipe out ALL of your progress.

The tutorial repeat itself every single time you start a new game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I honestly think this game can be pretty fun even though the grind is a bit tedious but it is plagued with so many bad design choices and it is so punishing to the player that it is hard to recommend.

So far id say get this game if you have a friend to play with or are a masochist,
I'm leaving a negative review but i will keep playing until im done with this abomination of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072147900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 34182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34182, 'last_played': 1586886162}
review:
TL:DR
It's a good, fun game, with lots of content, different events and options to explore. It's a game for RPG and Strategy tinkerers (people who like trying a game with different approaches to meet the win criteria).

Fuller review
I like both this title and Thea: The Awakening. Both have a similar feel to them with some game play elements (gathering, crafting, event style, ...) which are also similar, even though the combat system has changed. There are multiple ways to play the game - different gods give you different options for powers and play styles. There have been a good chunk of DLC added to the game post release - MuHa games have been very good in this respect. Even though the game was solid on release, the new DLC content updates has made me come back to the game several times.

If I were to critise some aspects it would probably that the locking away of starting powers and gods feel a bit too steep/far off when you start out. I get that starting small and growing is a good way of guiding the player into different ways of exploring the game, but I think it would have been a much better idea to just let the gods unlock when you've beat the game with one of the other gods. Some gods work this way - certain quests will grant you some gods for future games (Triglav and Nyia), but I'd have preferred this to be the way with all of the gods. It would give you more of a "now you've mastered this game style, here, try another, see if you can beat that as well".

That said, there are no caveats to this recommendation (other than that if you do not like RPG/Strategy hybrids or games where gathering and crafting is a fairly sizeable component, but then, you have probably already stopped reading ;) ).

author: {'steamid': '76561197996664052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 4556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4492, 'last_played': 1588332101}
review:
I think I can sum this game up quite well by saying "this game does not hold your hand."  Some people might like that sense of freedom and exploration, but make sure you start by going into the custom difficulty sliders and enable manual saves.  Otherwise, you will unknowingly have your entire team wiped.  A lot.  And there's no coming back from that.  Sure, the game might leave you with a level 3 Scoundrel and a level 6 Crafter, but the game will already be advanced to where all the enemies out level you and you have no hope of coming back.  Time to restart.  And while this has the potential to be fun, the early stages of the game can be a bit tedious.  You start on the main island and have access to the unfolding main quest and a handful of random quests, and this stage is all about getting to a point where you can establish a small band of warriors and get them fed and geared up.  You will do this mostly through gathering resources (either by farming them or winning them through combat) and crafting equipment.  You can also trade at towns or with traveling merchants.  The part that really makes different playthroughs feel unique is where you seek out different factions to support and doing a sidequest to awaken your chosen deity, and that requires you to build a ship and take sail for a different island.  

The quests and events in this game can fall into two categories: one category are quests that have correct and incorrect choices that you can learn as you go and remember for subsequent playthroughs, and the other are random outcomes, albeit influenced by certain stats.  The later can be frustrating.  For example, your main character who started life as a child has grown up and gets to become a useful character for a change.  You send Luna to learn to become a wise and powerful witch so you can finally have a magic user to blast away wolf packs that keep pestering your starting settlement.  Luna fails and transforms herself into a diseased rat.  Let that sink in for a second.  Your main character is now the most useless creature in the entire game and can bite your opponents for 2 damage for the rest of the game. You cannot undo this.  If you keep leveling your Chosen hero, yes, they can get stronger and eventually do 4 damage per turn to Krakens that have 600 HP.  You MIGHT be tempted to "save scum," and reload your game to before this happened, and I would say you should do this until you learn the ropes and are ready for a true rougelike run.  Now... experienced players will say, of course, what did you expect would happen?  Witches are an advanced class, and you should have recruited a second magic user before your child grew up so they could help guide their spiritual path.  And you also should have been raising the correct stats for them.  Then you would have only had a 50% chance of becoming a rat!  

I say this to try to capture the essence of the game.  I'm giving it an overall positive recommendation, and I reached 75 hours at the time of writing this.  I didn't really understand some of the basics of combat until well after 20 hours.  For example, you'll learn early on that some weapons are completely useless in physical combat and are only useful in mental or spiritual combat challenges.  Some weapons can be crafted that are useful in all three types of challenges (e.g., wands, but you can also create enchanted swords that can be used in both physical and mental combat although they use different stats for each attack type), but even these weapons are not useful in "conceptual challenges" because you can't use weapons in these challenges.  But you can use skills that your character learned by leveling up!  Whew!  

Combat also takes some getting used to.  You take turns deploying your characters, and there's an incentive to playing characters as soon as you can (they have faster attack speed and can sometimes attack before the enemy).  But this comes at the expense of not knowing what your opponent is still going to do.  You might play a squishy archer on the backline behind your tank, but you should really know if the enemy team has a character they can deploy that can do a piercing attack that will hit both of your characters or if they have someone who can target any space on the map.  You will learn early on that having high armor ratings is really important, because without it, you're going to lose a lot of characters to permadeath.  

Once you get the hang of it, though, you can start to enjoy the setting and lore of the Theaverse with all its demons and imps and curses and basically everything being out to mess with you in some way.  Then there's the gods- new gods, old gods, ancient beings that aren't quite gods, gods without their memories, gods that split into shards and gods that are shards.  It's a lot of interesting stuff to try to piece together as you enter a world designed to be held in a shaky balance of light and dark and making plays that either return the balance or push things off the scale in either direction.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985727392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1272, 'last_played': 1587223953}
review:
So this is kind of an odd duck.

Some of the sales pitch and a lot of the (really awesome!) art suggests you'll be playing a god, titantic in scope and power. Yeah... not so much. Your selected god is actually absent for the entire game, and instead one of their tribal worshipers is their divinely appointed Chosen, tasked with overseeing earthly matters. Do they get the divine powers? It didn't really seem so either; my Chosen had a single special ability which was quickly outmoded.

So yeah, this is a game about managing the survival situation of a largely mundane primitive tribe, in case you're as impressively oblivious as I was. It's a decently fun one though!

The game starts prior to any settlement, with your people roaming the land to scrounge for precious resources. It's possible to play the whole game in that state, and I'm tempted to do so. The setting seems to strike a balance between some standard fantasy elements (dwarves, elves, etc, etc) and some less often visited European myths. The bulk of your fantastic interactions will be with 'demons' (no relation to the image that word probably calls to mind), a diverse type of creature that comes in all forms of body and disposition. They range from little house spirits that grant good luck to monsterous blighters of your entire village. Lovely people.

As the game progresses, you'll slowly develop technological advancement that can unlock things like buildings for your village that grant some handy bonuses, new cooking recipes to better stretch your supplies, and access to newer and more sophisticated crafting materials. The game, fundamentally, is kind of a craft-em-up, feeding your outputs back into the system to make ever more powerful stuff. There's a small combat system (which can be entirely handled automatically if you want), but your effectiveness seems to scale to the power and flexibility of the equipment you've cobbled together more than anything, so it does all kind of come down to that in the end.

I enjoyed all of this, despite generally being exceptionally disinterested in crafting heavy games, and completed one campaign, but I'm not sure I feel inspired to play it again, despite an ostensible full pantheon of the strikingly low-impact gods to choose from. There are a few reasons for this. One of them is that once you've finally settled down your village in a spot with access to a comprehensive selection of resources, there's actually very little incentive to do anything other than hit next turn repeatedly for a very long time. There's a handful of respawning nodes and quests out there you could explore, but any rewards for them are miniscule compared to what you can get just gathering at your village for a turn, and you'll need to gather a *lot*. The high end encounters seem to require top end equipment, which has some truly ludicrous ingredient requirements. I think I spent around 900 of my 1100 turn campaign just waiting to accumulate the parts to do this. I'll bet skilled players probably could find ways to do it much faster, or in some more interesting ways (remaining wanderers for instance), but for some other reasons outlined below I don't think I will do that.

The game is very big on story events that will crop up randomly. This is where the vast majority of the interesting worldbuilding and such comes from, and is an integral part of the experience. Unfortunately, there's not quite enough of it to span even a single campaign, and some events in particular seem prone to regular repetition (I don't have enough fingers to count how many problematic demonic teeth I pulled out). I felt like I exhausted most of what there was to see even in just that one game, and they frankly started to get rather tedious after a while.

The game seems to have a lot of expectations that you will play it repeatedly, with most of the options for what the game start looks like (including the gods you can choose from) requiring unlocks with a currency you get by playing. The prices are pretty ridiculous though; I earned about 20 points in my game, and the costs on single trait cards seem to range from 5-20... and you choose something like eight trait cards for each start. The early game is the most interesting stretch of it to me, so more diversity in it is appealing, but as a campaign winds on I think most of these choices would end up sliding into irrelevance.

There's a really neat skeleton of a game here. It seems like it falls in the class of game where there's tons of mods and customizations out there to try to flesh things out, which I'm personally just not really interested in doing (there's too many good games out there for me to want to try to cobble together my own perfect one). What's there is atmospheric (music is great) and very appealing for a little while. If the price point doesn't bother you, its a fun experience, for a few hours at least!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973804734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 21248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14912, 'last_played': 1702111745}
review:
The first time I wrote this review I started it with "Great game - slow tenor, and thoughtful."

1. Core mechanisms of exploring and resource collection are strong
2. Ramp-up of difficulty is good, and controllable to some degree (part time, but also part how far you travel)
3. Party / village design is sensible and strategic, and there are opportunities to do some quite cool stuff
4. Side quests are - often - really interesting. The lore of the game is really (really!) strong
5. The gradual "god point" metagame / unlocks are pretty interesting and I think well-paced
6. Depending on your starting setup, you can go in some very different directions.

I'm now up to 600+ hrs, which for me is a lot. It's just such a great game - with a lot of "one more turn" tension and not too much (!) save-scumming.

The developers have continued to put new updates into it, and that's really helped to keep it alive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053004482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 35533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23173, 'last_played': 1649674464}
review:
Thea: The Awakening - 565 hours. 9.5/10. 
Only real downside was the village UI but once you learnt to save groups it was lots better.

Thea 2: The Shattering - 386 hours. 6.5/10.
Have given number 2 a real shot and even bought some pizza for devs a couple of times because MuHa impress me so darn much but the three negatives are pretty weighty. The three enormous positives are great, but two of them aren't about the gameplay itself but MuHa's choices.

Positives:
- Artwork. HUGE upgrade on the original and amazing in its own right, love it.
- Transparent mod making tool with steam workshop. The definitive saving grace for Thea 2 as it lets you speed up the game to an extent and the building overhaul mods are to die for.
- Free downloadable content forever. The game has one price tag. If any of you have tried keeping up with DLC on Crusader Kings 2, Civ 6 or Warhammer: Total War series you'll know what I mean. The downside of this is of course they can only have so many people working. In the age of micro transactions keeping a gaming company buoyant on initial purchase fee alone seems amazing to me.

Negatives:
- Party and resource UI. Both are woefully inadequate and the least polished part of the game. In fact, unpolished doesn't even come close... clunky, annoying, near non-existent?
- New combat system. This one is purely personal opinion but I loved the combat system of The Awakening and hate the combat system of The Shattering. After my first couple of playthroughs I've almost exclusively auto-resolved ever since. This adds to the next problem due to having to outgear all encounters so dramatically.
- Slow falls short of the mark on this one. I'm a long haul gamer. I play Civ on marathon setting and talk to every NPC and read every option in RPG's. Thea 2 just doesn't flow for me. It's not even that Thea 2 takes a long time to finish. You can complete both your chosen storyline and lightbringer storyline in rather short order if you're focused. They have also released the pirates storyline for late game. However, between turn 200 and 500 there's... nothing. It feels like the entire middle of this novel is missing to me and its not enjoyable.

Thea 2: The Shattering is still a positive for me for the main reason of I feel the game release was a financial decision over a completed work. Muha are committed to this game and I believe it will get better with time even if the combat system stinks for me personally. They made some great steps forward with the steam workshop and artwork but now the rest of the game needs to catch up. Crucial elements needing work are town/party UI and engaging mid-gear objectives.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091773889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 14646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12362, 'last_played': 1684929815}
review:
The cons, more or less: 
Needs a fairly simple map editor, a little more story variety. Some more trait cards, like Elf Gatherer/Craftsman, or a half-breed trait (to allow a half-elf, or half-orc) to allow more diverse starts. Being able to change your starting city appearance to match a different faction maybe. The mini-map being revealed takes away some of the excitement of exploration. A little more coop functions, like establishing routine/daily trade deals, letting incantations effect neighboring groups and not just your own, maybe even a more dynamic shared-village approach though that last one might be harder to implement. New biomes maybe, randomize which are present in any given map? Just a wish list in case they read this.

Otherwise, it's a unique concept, mix of strategy, rpg, quasi-4x. The implementation of coop is a nice bonus; really evokes the imagination to concepts of dividing tasks/functions such as one player focusing on the crafting, the other gathering, the warriors and hunters vs. priests and witches. Tons of possibilities. Has modding capabilities, a few good ones out right now. The card battles take a little getting used to, but the differentiation between Physical, Mental, and Mystical challenges is very refreshing, and your characters can 'die' from a loss of either Life, Sanity, or Faith; but losing doesn't guarantee death either, you could recover. There is a lot of potential here, and I'm happy to support the devs in their future developments as I think they show great promise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134281792', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3331, 'last_played': 1694374992}
review:
Если вы надумываете покупать эту игру, то осмелюсь вас предупредить перед покупкой, попробуйте  сыграете в нее у друга или иным образом... Вхождение в игру очень сложное! 
А так славяне! Игра стоит своих денег! часто обновляется, эвенты, моды тоже нормуль ))) 
Эта игра подойдет для любителей пошаговых стратегий и рпг,
но не рекомендую знакомиться с жанром начиная с нее ! По началу игра будет душить вас своей механикой добычей и эксплуатацией всего сущего и не материального, НО особенно своей боевкой! Со временем вы поймете, что игра именно про это))) Весь кайф тут именно про абуз всего, что вы видите и даже не видите, но понимаете, что это тут есть (со временем поймете, о чем я). Особенно игра становится интереснее с друзьями! Начиная игру у вас сразу появляются планы на будущее, кто какую профессию в приоритете будет качать, кто добывает, кто крафтит, а кто бить всех по голове, что уже заставляет ваши извилины двигаться, а это ОЧЕНЬ ХОРОШО! Игра не подойдет тем, кто не любит душнилово и пришел с шутеров, ртс, моба и арен. Т.к. игра может вам показаться очень медленной и однообразной... Но это рили не так! 
Для кого плюс, для кого минус, но тут нужно читать и читать довольно много! (квесты, диалоги, выбор судьбы некоторых персонажей и дать по макушке этой стае пчелок или все же уничтожить их метеором, а может вообще добазариться с ними, чтобы они притащили вам мед!
Боевка тут оригинальная и не каждому пойдет по вкусу! Мб вы такой же как я, будете плеваться от нее, но в итоге разобравшись с ней, начнете абузить ее как последнюю Ш
Что есть тут самый сильный плюс? Это ее абузная составляющая! Игра на столько продуманна до таких мелочей, что если у вас есть активный питомец, то он может сыграть большую роль в квесте (т.е. отдельное предложение в выборе вариантов ответа), ваша раса (человек вы, 
орк, эльф или АРМИРОВАННЫЙ МАТЬ ЕГО МЕДВЕДЬ и т.п. !) даже ваши характеристики могут дать вам особый тэг, который обязательно сыграет вам на пользу! Особенно сложно тут воспитать детей... Хоть это и самый главный элемент в геймплее, но даже один мать его рандомный квест может сломать его становление волхом или лекарем, переведя его на путь вора или бродяги!
Вообщем игра очень веселая и однозначно стоит своих денег! И понми! Не поабузил, не поиграл в Тею!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990936027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 18309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8784, 'last_played': 1587509420}
review:
This game is insane. My best scientist is a giant boar who was turned into a werewolf. MANBOARWOLF. My daughter went on a spirit journey and her body dissolved, so she came back a wraith. I punched a god and got turned into a tree. 

Confused yet? SO AM I. It's okay. Thea 2 is a dynamic, story-driven blend of 4X and RPG, with combat that takes place using cards, inside of a procedurally generated world. It has dozens of races (nearly all of whom can either be acquired or recruited in some way) - numerous gods, tons of ways to handle most situations, you can craft the One Ring of Sauron or use up all your food smoking herbs in a goblin sweat-tent. 

For a small team, Thea is unbelievably deep, profoundly polished, and utterly fantastic. Buy it! Buy it twice! Turn people into frogs! Craft legendary weapons out of bones and BLACK HOLES! Did I mention the game is incredibly moddable? The game is incredibly moddable. All of the DLC has been given out FOR FREE and Thea 2 has no DRM of any sort. 

If I had to pick one thing I don't like about it, the game runs on Unity, and is poorly optimized, meaning it's an unbelievable resource-hog. However, even on lower settings, the game looks gorgeous, most of the art is hand-drawn, as are many of the character portraits, and it's a game worth letting your computer run hot, to get lost in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018869716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1543687205}
review:
Absolutely loved Thea 1. 
The things Thea 1 needed was more events/questlines, a mid-game between main quest and giants, and a minor streamlining of stats/recipes. (And a rebalancing of difficulties vs scoring.)

Instead what we got was a terrible new combat system, a worse crafting system and a poorly designed gating of content-stages.

Would happily plunk down €50 for a major update to Thea 1,
can't think of anything positive to say about Thea 2, sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063018219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4320, 'last_played': 1620412845}
review:
Сумасшедший гринд. На локации с тремя т3 ресурсами и углем приходится сидеть 300 ходов чтобы что-то скрафтить и начать выходить с острова. Игра постоянно подвисает и периодически крашится. А если пока вы мучаетесь с прохождением выйдет обнова - вам похерит сейв.
Для сравнения по скорости игры - на полное прохождение первой части со всеми ачивками примерно 200-250 часов, во второй при идеальной стартовой точке, за 72 часа только призрачный шанс на первое прохождение часиков через 30-40.
Еще к слову о гринде на одну единицу т5 ресурса нужно 165 единиц т2 ресурса и 6 угля. На элемент экипировки нужно в среднем 30 единиц ресурса. Одеть одного персонажа оружие+амулет+броня 90 единиц т5 или 14850 единиц т2 + 540 угля. Думайте сами, решайте сами...

author: {'steamid': '76561198073587956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 39601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19098, 'last_played': 1699506297}
review:
En general es un una mejora de la primera parte, y encuentro mas mecanicas y opciones ; positivas que negativas.

-Es bueno que puedas elegir donde crear tu aldea o ir como un trotamundos por todo el mapa.
-Aunque la gente sienta nostalgia del sistema de combate de cartas como si fuera un mazo, personalmente me gusta la restructuracion estilo Yu-gi-Ho.
-El hecho de que los personajes sean reclutados y tengan hijos da un sentido de aleatoriedad lo suficientemente genuino y menos molesto que crear edificios con ciertos especificos materiales

Lo malo

-la variedad de efectos es mayor (actualmente) pero es inutil usar armas de una mano y los escudos no compensan
-aunque interactuar con las aldeas es muy ventajoso, una vez que llegas a 50 puntos de amistad y desbloqueas los usos especiales terminas reclutando personajes y mejorando mascotas en la inmensidad de los casos

En general recomiendo el juego si buscas algo diferente dentro de este genero de (estrategia por turnos hexagonales) y tambien recomiendo la primera parte, pero si empiezas con este juego lo mas probable es que te frustres mas con la precuela

author: {'steamid': '76561198068841234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 24512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17943, 'last_played': 1698479756}
review:
This game takes a while to get used to. I really like this style of game, exclusively single player, but I can understand why some wouldn't like it.

Combat can be hard to comprehend, but is fairly easy to realize which attacks/abilities are the best after a few games. Normally, you want to specialize in one area (Physical, Mental, or Spiritual) and one ability. 
Grinding can be very, very dulling at times. The gist of it is, the 2 ways to improve your characters are from leveling up, which grant either stats or ability upgrades. The other way is through gathering. Now there's 5 tiers of materials, which all get progressively stronger. The problem is that only tiers 1,2, and 3 are gatherable. In addition to sinking research points into additional tiers (which get very costly at tiers 4/5), those same tiers (4 & 5) are only obtainable via crafting. That requires you to use 12 of the previous tier +1 coal to make 2 of the wanted item. Example: Elven Wood is a tier 2 wood item. In order to upgrade it into Ancient Wood (tier 3), you need 12 Elven Wood +1 coal and some amount of progress dedicated to crafting it. Now while you will get 2 Ancient Wood out of this... it really adds when if you account for the fact that it may take 2 or 3 turns to even gather 12 Elven Wood. And it'll be another day to craft the Ancient Wood. So if you're lucky, maybe 3 days to make 2 Tier 3 items, where most items that require crafting will need at least 15, and if you want a pure Ancient Wood item, you'll need maybe 50 units or so.

If you got the time, this is a great game to sink into your chair or sofa with its relaxing overworld music and slow pace of gather/craft cycle. But you may sitting down for longer than you hope if you want to accomplish great feats.

review:
I like Thea 2. If you're new to the game, you're in for a treat.  In many ways it's a turn-based RPG, I suppose, with individual characters who gain levels with experience, crafting, movement across a hex-based map, combat, social encounters, and so forth.  But it also can have a bit of a Civ-like flavor, as you research techs and (possibly) found and develop a village. It also has roguelike features: there's a meta-game of unlocking Gods and God points for new characters and other benefits.  It's also challenging: even on easier levels, winning the main quests isn't easy, and its roguelike structure means you accept bad results rather than save-scum.  Its lore is a refreshing change of pace: it is grounded in Slavic myth, not your usual Norse or Greek or Tolkienesque mythology. 

 If you enjoyed the first game, you'll probably like this one too.  The UI is improved, the quests are more developed, even the art is better.  The major change is that combat and conflict resolution is different; it now plays out on a map of cards that is two columns deep and several rows wide.  In general I prefer this new system, but unquestionably it takes a while to get used to.  Watch the tutorials closely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119307692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 240, 'playtime_at_review': 3035, 'last_played': 1712417576}
review:
Thea 2 takes some time to grow on you, even if you played the first game. My first two hours in this game were a bit uncertain, i.e. the UI felt bad, the item system overcomplicated, the attributes didn't make a lot of sense etc. In short I felt lost.

To be perfectly honest: even after completing the main quest (and Gosk's Might quest, which is comparable to Giants Return from Thea 1), I'm still not 100% sure I got everything right.  It was a fun ride, though.

Let's start by the good parts. For me the most enjoyable part was the combat. Even though it looks overwhelming at first, it's not that complicated and lets you find devious ways to flawlessly handle even enemies that autocombat is totally unable to defeat. The game system also somehow manages to constantly serve you combat that is just challenging for your party. The fights are also rewarding - after a battle you won perfectly you are happy, because you managed to find the right solution, and after incurring losses you usually blame yourself for making a needless mistake. It isn't anywhere near XCOM, but on the other hand the battles are totally fair with no randomness involved (well there is one ability that randomly targets enemies, but that's just about it - and you probably won't ever use it anyway). In short: battles are excellent, but you need to take your time to get into them.

The villager management is also fun. You often keep trying to get a child from another species, then you strive to teach it as much as you can, so that it grows into a solid class, you groom your human children towards a class you need the most right now, sometimes you're tempted to take the chance and let the kid grow into something random (and might get anything from a rat to a mighty demon). This part involves a lot of RNG, but that also keeps it interesting.

The graphics, at least in the 2D part, are amazing. Your hand-drawn characters look great and it makes you care about them.

You will be encountering a lot of events, mostly of mythological nature. While there is a lot of room for improvement - you often have no idea what your decision will bring and even if you had that event in a previous game, RNG may cause your decision to lead to a different outcome. Some of the events are a lot of fun and I'd like a way to see them all.

Now we're coming to the survival part. You need to gather resources, craft items, cook food, build new structures in your village, research new resources and recipes etc. This is fun at first, but it quickly gets rather tedious and repetitive. Resources are split into tiers, ranging from 1 all the way to 5. It is here that I dislike the balance & design. Tier 1 resources are worthless and there's not even a point to gathering them (except wood for campfires). Tier 2 resources are widely available on your starting isle and will get you through your early and middle game. If you are serious about finishing the game, though, you need tier 3 resources - these can be gathered on other islands (and sometimes on your island, too, if you are lucky). So far so good. However, the pain point comes with tier 4 resources. These are composites, i.e. they can't be just harvested - to get these you must combine a large amount of tier 3 resources. Example: to get 2 Crystal Wood you need to combine 6 Ancient Wood (tier 3 wood) and 6 Diamond (tier 3 gems). If you want to craft that cool Crystal Bow, you need to spend a loooooot of time by gathering and then combining. Also, do you remember that there are 5 tiers? The same rules apply for tier 5, i.e. you need 6 pieces from tier 4 to get 1 piece of tier 5. Extremely tedious, boring and unfulfilling.
Fortunately you also find a small amount of tier 4 and 5 materials by completing high level fights, which will let you craft a few tier 4 and 5 items just before the endgame (there is exactly one battle where you really need these).

Story is also not very exciting. Without spoiling too much - if you want an interesting story based on Slavic legends, look elsewhere. In this type of game, though, story is not that important.

UI could be better. As I often work with UI designers in my daily job, I kinda questioned the design of user interface in Thea 2. It is ugly, forces you to do a lot of clicking, sometimes it is misleading, often doesn't provide you with the information you would need.. this is probably the part that could use the most enhancement.

Despite of all my reservations I'm still recommending the game. If you liked the first Thea, you will like this one too. If you haven't played first Thea yet, maybe that would be a better place to start, as I liked that game a tiny bit more than the second one.

review:
Its a weird shift from the first game.
a lot more complex. the amount of information and traits and stats to understand is pretty hard to grasp.

The food warning really need to be more pronounced. someone in my group died from starvation, i felt no real warning (symbol in the bottom does not "spring" out at you) keeping track of all your characters and gear feels more cumbersome compared to the first game.

some events for some weird reason pull all the characters into the event despite them being far apart from each other. Even when the event does not make sense for the people to be involved in that event.

I do like the crafting and gathering system a lot more compared to the first game. 

The world seems impossibly big (at default size) to ever traverse in any timely fashion.

Some of the values are listed as 1.9 then 190% without seemingly making a big difference, cant tell.

Then the card game part. This part is way worse compared to the first game. I find myself annoyed by it and just resolved it without playing it.

I hope that the starving icon be more pronounce like maybe flash more if someone is getting more and more wounded from it.

review:
真心不錯的遊戲,買之前都沒抱多大期望,玩下來完全是精神時光屋,遊戲給我的感覺就像是文明帝國+RPG+卡牌,配合起來想不到能有這樣的結果,不過教程跟說明有點不足,剛開始時差一點就被勸退,需要給多一點點耐心去摸索,了解之後就可以正式開始殺時間了 ... 寫評論時玩了兩局,一局是傳統勇者玩法,一局是殺人王,都可以正常遊戲,殺人王還因為可能殺太大,遊戲中段還給了我一個惡魔天賦跟令人恐懼的特性,感覺這樣的設定很不錯,會呼應你角色在遊戲中的行為,代入感增加不少,遊戲非常值得入手...讚

有一點補充, 其實這遊戲故事內容有點單薄, 而且角色升級不算太難, 以至於遊戲有點快步進後期, 再加上自動戰鬥, 遊戲感覺有點像跑進度, 而且自動戰鬥非常感覺不到自己的角色在成長, 去掉自動戰鬥感覺會比較耐玩, 而且更能展現卡牌部份 ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198074695007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 3537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3537, 'last_played': 1583720262}
review:
I was leaning on recommending this game initially but towards the end I just got bored and gave up, so wouldn't recommend myself.
The game loop is ok and pretty addictive, but it gets quickly repetitive, and you reach a point where you are just constantly skipping turns to build up resources.
I gave up around turn 1000+ as I just realized I wasn't really paying attention or cared, even when I setup my second village on a new better location I just stopped caring.
If you really want to get this game, I would recommend getting it only on deal. It's basically just a repeat of previous Thea game, so if you liked that and wanted more this is it I guess.

Below are the main issues I had for this game myself...
- It's a bit too similar to the first game, to the point I'm not sure why it wasn't just an expansion for the first.

- The Card game isn't as intuitive as the first game. It improves in areas but I often had an issues where it would show like forever resolving stack but wouldn't allow me to select anything, I guess it was stuck or I just totally missed something during the tutorial (I also couldn't find a good online guide to clear up if I was missing something.) So I ended up playing most the game by auto-resolving. This is generally what I would do for the first one also (I would only manually resolve if it was 50/50), but was hoping for a better more intuitive approach for the card minigame in the second game.

- It doesn't make sense to me that only coal can improve other resources, that there is not other resources that can do the same seems an odd choice. The normal game mode even restricts you from starting out with coal on the starter island, which I don't understand at all. You start out on an simple island that you can't really improve on, and you have a max limit of two villages for a game, so you just have to be a nomad and build up for like 500+ turns or whatever it takes you. Then you have to go searching around the dangerous secondary islands for a good village location (which will be random so you might not find anything.) These secondary islands will test your highest level characters with highest level gear oftentimes. High level gear you can only reasonably create in a village. So essentially you have to waste 1 village location for most playthroughs on the crappy starter island and keep skipping till you have good resources and gear built up.

- It can be tricky to increase your population outside random events mostly. This also leans into not feeling like your doing much till you gather enough resources and skills (after skipping turns alot) to knock out a story mode event. This game feels like playing Sid Meiers, with the limitation of only have two villages and never being allowed to really expand or show visible improvement. So for me it just felt like not much was happening and the story didn't feel like it was progressing. I can understand if they want to limit your villages and population to give the end of the world vibe, but theres probably better ways to do it. For example if your village gets too large, then the challenges could just scale up to match.

To sum up, it's an ok game loop, but it feels like they put weird forced limitations in the gameplay to give a certain end of the world feel, something that could have been done in better ways maybe I think.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964638838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 37155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4065, 'last_played': 1708975444}
review:
I played quite a bit of Thea 1, and rank it up there among maybe 2-3 other "Indy" games that I consider worthwhile. It took me a bit to buy Thea 2, mostly because a LOT of reviews suggested that it was a downgrade from Thea 1. Finally I got it on sale and put a good bit of time into it.

TLDR: I think it's a big improvement on Thea 1, but it's not perfect. 

Pros:
The autocombat resolve was improved. It also added a feature to manually resolve combats if the autoresolve fails (very very necessary).
The character cards/avatars are color and quite a bit nicer
Research and crafting saw some changes that are mostly (in my opinion) slight improvements
Game was expanded quite a bit from what I can tell. Much more variety in enemies and characters.
It just feels like as a strategy game the game has been fleshed out and given a good bit more flavor and replayability.

Cons:
Story feels a bit "more of the same" to Thea 1. Which is good and bad. Good if you like it and were left wanting more, but I get the sense they felt the story was working and didn't need much and wanted to polish the other game elements. I would have liked a bit more put into the story. Particularly a bit more variety and randomness of encounters. Every playthrough you run through the same basic encounters.

Don't play the game without saves enabled. Just don't. There are still random unavoidable encounters where you will get curb-stomped with no escape. They aren't COMMON, but they WILL happen, and when they do, you'll be unhappy. 

It looks like they tried to both improve and simplify the card game aspect. I think they resulted in a bit of failure on both fronts. While the three different types of card games being each able to totally ruin your game make team-building strategy a bit interesting... the game as a whole forces you into a very Rock Paper Scissors situation, where you either rush one of the handful of characters that break the system by doing everything well (witches w/ random blast), or you just build teams focused on one thing (I like to make ships full of warriors and put the boot to pirates over and over) and run like a chicken from even low level encounters of the other types.  It also feels like the overall strategic element of the card game is slightly less interesting, and more focused on just min/maxing or finding gamey strats (first strike, high str, shield leach) to defeat some of the absolutely insane level 11+ fights (Some 11-13 fights are easy... others summon an entire field of 200+ hp mobs as a single turn action... every one of which can (and does... every turn) AOE your ENTIRE team for 50+ damage. Some feel like they are story scripted to be really hard to beat (without completely gaming them)... which if that's what the devs wanted, fine... but don't call it an 11, 12 or 13 encounter then... Make it 20+. )

The Autoresolve is still pretty bad for high level fights. With it on its highest setting, I still convert fatal failures into perfect victories constantly. Not a huge deal, but when you wind up having to replay the same kraken ass-whooping 2-3 times a turn every other turn for a few dozen turns, it gets old. 

There are some random events that are just pointlessly frustrating, especially late game when you're trying to grind mats for that last upgrade that'll let you beat that crazy tier 13 fight... then a fire destroys 50 turns work with literally no way to avoid it. 

And that brings me to my last complaint. The end game crafting grinding is just absolutely nonsensically time consuming. You will be spamming end turn well past 1000 turns with little else going on trying to craft enough end tier mats to equip your characters. Yes it does force you to not just rush end game crafting, which is good... but it's taken a bit too far in my opinion. It feels like the major problem is that equipment upgrades fall off pretty hard in the middle tiers. As you get more and more decent mats in early game, you get a lot of upgrade-power from crafting.... then that basically stops. the gap in materials required to go from mid-tier equipment to high-tier is MASSIVE, and for most items if feels like the intermediate levels (and there are plenty based on the 50ish different mats available) are just so little improvement compared to the low-mid tier stuff, it's not worth wasting the mats (that you need to be able to craft the highest tier mats to get the top tier items) The ability for high skill crafters to get exceptional quality items helps with this a fair bit, but again, not enough. 


Anyway, that's a lot of complaining, but the truth is it is quite a big improvement on Thea 1, in my opinion. All around a solid game. Very worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068404004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 27190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15822, 'last_played': 1696968628}
review:
Let's start with the fact that this isn't going to be unbiased because I spent at least 5 times more time on modding than actually playing the game.

That alone should tell you that this is by no means a perfect game. I spent hours changing parts of the game to better suit my liking. But that's because I enjoyed the core concepts enough to invest that time.

If I had to describe the game in one sentence it would be: it's very basic if you want it to be.
The reason for that is that there's usually always a way to make the game simple for yourself. You could sit in your village for 1000 turns grinding resources. You could autoresolve every fight. You could just rush the main quest and complete the game in less than 100 turns or just start with overpowered characters and destroy everything.

But the important thing about this is that you don't have to. Once you understand how the game works you can make basically anything work. You don't need to stop once you got one of the win conditions. Winning only gives you more points to try out different starts.

The whole point of the game is to tell your own story. There's no need to follow quest markers around. Losing characters doesn't mean you lost the game. You're not expected to be perfect. The game isn't. Why should you?

And if you don't like a certain aspect of the game, just change it. I didn't grind out all the trait cards I just unlocked them all. Don't like a certain weapon class? There's probably a mod out there to change it. Game is too easy? Crank it up and get some mod to make it harder.

Try the free demo and see if you like the core systems. You might not grasp everything immediately but that's fine. The devs have been really nice, offering free DLC  responding to problems, helping with modding.

Normally moddability shouldn't factor into the review of a game, but simply due to the nature of this game there are simply things not everyone is going to like. But we got the tools to solve that issue. As I said early it's about how YOU want to play. So do exactly that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073371258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1583073926}
review:
This is one of those games that intrigues me with the premise but fails to grab my attention during gameplay. What I look for in such a game is to present me with interesting and challenging problems and then layer by layer introduce interesting tools to solve these problems. This is achieved when I start "theory-crafting" strategies even when I'm not playing, or otherwise thinking about the game and figuring out interesting design elements. What happened with this game is that upon playing for few hours, I got a sense of a basic gameplay loop that felt tedius and grindy, moving material in inventories, equipping parties with wood and food, making sure food is diverse, enough for a predetermined length of turns so they harvest stuff to repeat the same loop with more advanced (or just more) stuff. I would like to believe that there might be interesting challenges somewhere in there but the game just dis not present these to me, and it didn't even hint at them. As such, for a player with little time in his hand, continuing to play didn't sound like a good investment of time.

It is unfortunate because I really believe the asymmetric 4x is the future of single-player 4x games and this looks like it could be a prime example of that. The survival elements could also be used to make the gameplay more goal driven (not talking about hand-holding here) compared to the sandbox-y feel of many 4X games. It is a shame that for the time I played, I constantly felt like I was performing easy to execute tasks which nevertheless took a lot of time...

author: {'steamid': '76561198007338609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 15163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4949, 'last_played': 1683868007}
review:
Awesome game. Great crafting, great role-play and replay-ability. The people down voting this game need to give it a chance. 

Combat
I can understand people saying the combat is overly complicated and I thought the same thing initially, but after playing for a few more hours you start to understand and appreciate how much depth and tactics can be involved in combat. I feel like the real problem for people is that the auto-resolve is better than them fighting manually. So they use auto-resolve instead of playing manually. After 60 hours I am much better than the auto resolve and challenges where auto resolve said I would be wounded I can complete without a scratch.

Crafting
There is sooo many different combinations of materials and weapons that makes crafting exciting and fun to mix and match to try and get the right combination. Gathering the materials to create legendary items can be a bit tedious unless your village placement is great.

Overall I love this game and it can really be amazing with a few more events and a little balancing. Great work to the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001972668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 14483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12607, 'last_played': 1684368680}
review:
Better is worst enemy of good. Combat is deeper now, more complicated, but I wish it remained the same as in first Thea. Games are really long now, which is not bad per se.

My main issue with this game is that it promotes at every step this message that Darkness is better than Light. Magic is OP in this game, and you can only have either magic or light as your starting options. So, there is underlying message, and it is a bit creepy. Apart from that, it is an interesting strategy game.

It does have SOME replayability value, but not great. Nowhere near games like Oxygen not included or Don't Starve. It could be interesting to try different starting options, few different strategies, but main quests are the same, game length is still going to be roughly the same. So yeah. Not bad. But not that great either.

review:
Gra przy premierze była trochę niedorobiona - gorsza od części pierwszej i się od niej od razu odbiłem.
Obecnie po patchach i wyjściu dodatku mogę każdemu fanowi części pierszej ją polecić. Gra została rozbudowana w każdym aspekcie i przyjemnie się w nią gra. Dodano kilka ciekawych mechanik związanych z podróżowaniem po wodzie, neutralnymi frakcjami, czy dodano dodatkowe elemty prograsji świata i rozwoju postaci.
System walki nadal nie zachwyca, jest nawet trochę gorszy niż w części pierszej, ale można grać na auto i to nie przeszkadza. Trochę trudniejsza niż część pierwsza, ale czuć możliwość lepszej kontroli nad rozwojem sytuacji w grze.
Jak ktoś jest fanem mieszanki strategii turowej z rpg w klimatach fantasy (tu oczywiście zmieszne z mitologią quasi-słowiańską) to polecam spróbować.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053978680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2560, 'last_played': 1639415291}
review:
Great!  8 out of 10.
First part: Review for new players.
Second part: Review for Thea 1 players.

1:
A turn based Slavic mythology themed gathering/crafting/survival game, with heavy aspects of oldskool RPG and lots of artwork. The player controls a group of humans surviving a global cataclysm. The goal is to survive, rebuild some form of society and help your patron deity gain control and order over the mortal realm again.
The nice thing about it, is that there are multiple ways to victory: One can win by completing god quests, by building a prosperous society, and even by "backstabbing" your god and pursuing personal motives.
While the game can sometimes get a little bit grindy, the massive amount of lore, artwork and random events prevent it from getting boring. The game consists of turns on a world map, followed by encounters in card-based mini games.
Those mini games are beautifully drawn representations of your characters, their skills, equipment, etc.
Some card games represent common combat, while others represent the chance of sneaking by opponents unnoticed, resisting evil spirits, tracking wild animals, or engaging in dialogue with thugs. All those games are governed by the stats and abilities of your party members. The RPG-element doesn't end there:
While the attributes and classes of your characters influence their stats in mini games, they also open up completely new dialogue options and courses of action preceding encounters, resulting in huge replay value.
That's the point where the real beauty of Thea 2 (and 1!) lies:
Almost all encounters are actually short, atmospheric text based stories, accompanied by nice drawn artwork, and offering multiple dialogue options. Some of those options are basic, and are just pulling a number on your own judgement of the situation: Whether or not to trust a stranger, whether or not to scout some ruins, etc. Generally, they feel pretty intuitive to me. When the text subtly states some eerie details about a situation: follow your instincts! The refreshing thing is that some specialised characters offer additional options during those stories: Your party members possess "hidden knowledge". Often choices made will have an impact on following events a few turns later.
While this game is solid on it's own, I slightly recommend playing Thea 1 first, for the sake of introduction to the mechanics and immersion in the story.

2:
Beautiful game. If you like Thea 1, you can't go wrong with this one.
Personally, I like Thea 1 just a bit better, but not by much.
Mainly because Thea 1 feels a bit more gloomy and has got some really dark music. That's just personal preference.
There's still enough to discover, enchant, befriend and kill in Thea 2, though!
I guess one of the biggest differences is the card game: They've made it less linear, and put a 2nd dimension to the battlefield. The battlefield not only represents time during combat now, but also space during combat. Confusing at first, but once you'll get the hang of it, it feels like a slightly more complicated version of Thea 1's combat system. More confusion at first, but more possibilities later. That's just a learning curve.

Furthermore there's the option to live a nomadic lifestyle in Thea 2.
Not settling gives freedom to roam wherever you like, without having to divide your people between scouting parties and a town garrison.
Settling, however provides gathering/crafting/defensive bonuses, but limits the player to a certain spot.
There is still the option to send out parties from your city, though!

Other new features include the ability of characters to perform rituals during camping
(Those are spells they perform, providing benefits for your party for a limited amount of turns),
and the ability to build boats and cross oceans to new continents with other resources.
While Thea 2 feels pretty much like Thea 1, it's refreshing enough to feel like new.

Thea 2 offers a nice sequel to Thea 1. I can heavily recommend it.
Final verdict:
Thea 1: 9/10
Thea 2 8/10
