author: {'steamid': '76561197997047653', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2858, 'last_played': 1582563082}
review:
I really wanted to like this game, but unfortunately what should have been its strongest point, the combat, is actually the weakest. 

The game has some interesting ideas that I really like conceptually: Making the best of the random resources you've found (e.g. focusing on armor/weapon types only), trying to find a village location that can support all your late-game needs, roguelite elements (permadeath on char, random world etc) and of course, card-game combat.

Unfortunately, in practice the dynamics of the game force you into a specific strategy most of the time, run around the map and gather basic resources until you spot a good location for a village (preferably on a different island to get the all-necessary coal) and then sit in your village for 100-200 turns clicking end-turn to mine 3rd level resources to get some useful stuff to craft strong enough equipment to be able to send people out in the world for quests. 

Playing nomads is not particularly viable given the massive benefits a village provides in gathering/crafting bonuses and range and the fact that  eventually you cannot carry enough around. It's also useless to gather for trading since nobody ever has anything worth trading for! So only one strategy left, find spot for village, sit tight building, explore to to the game quests and win.

Which also brings us to the combat. Although set up to look like a card game, in truth it's more of a small abstract war game, only with more frustration. You only have a few cards to play, in very limited ways and most of the time you want them on the board. Sure, you could use their off-board abilities, but the fact that you're loosing the extra health on the board and those abilities are pretty "meh" overall, makes it more limited. I only use off-board abilities usually because those characters are absolute trash at that sort of combat and I'm out of command points. I find combat so lacking in interesting choices that I prefer to just use auto-resolve most of the time unless my option is utter annihilation (and in that case it's still better to forfeit and hope you don't lose a character)

And given that most of the rest of the game is either clicking end turn, or just clicking various text options and get some resources out, there's just not much left in the game.

If they were to make the combat somehow more interesting, I might give it another try, but as it is, I think I've seen all the game has to offer.

PS: The higher difficulties act like it's a roguelite, where you only have one save and if you do bad, you cannot save-scum, but it's a fake. Not only can you alt-f4 to get a free redo, but even if you straight up lose the game and go back to the main menu, you can just press continue and you'll go back to the last good autosave of that game, 3 turns ago!

author: {'steamid': '76561198357233674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6271, 'last_played': 1589378991}
review:
I enjoyed this game so much that I spent 100 plus hours game time during only 12 days. But I found a huge problem for this game which is that you can get a full strength battle equipment easily with 3 tier resources only, and you'll find no impetus in collecting more equipment for other characters because you don't need to, you can crush the enemies with that. All you need is 4 battle characters with highest 1 level equipment and 3 magic weapons for assistance. I can't see why I need to build a village to collect resources. I tried to build a team with only witches and inventors, it really hard to do so because the witches' and inventors' equipment are so hard to collect, they need legendary armors. If I can achieve this with 1 level strength team, why I need to choose a worse way.

The other terrible thing is the battle rhythm, it's a torturing experience to place your card over and over again during the last part of game due to the high armor or high health. I think it's better to do some replacement instead of placing your all cards again.

Other aspects are good, 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985583756', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1420, 'last_played': 1684038120}
review:
Unfortunately, it's a no for me :( 
I really wish I could recommend this game. It has a lot of good stuff about it but the negatives are just too big. 

What are the positives?
-Runs smoothly even on linux systems
-The lore is great, the writing is great, the art direction is beautiful.
-The setting of the game is a mix of slavic with sort of tokienesque mythology for good measure. Beautiful
-The in depth mix of strategy and development you need to balance is good
-Lots of variety in the way you can play the game

What are the negatives? 
TL;DR: The game doesn't respect the players' time.
-The combat system is a bit difficult to wrap your head around and you need to really know your party in depth. I mean, it loses its charm when I have to name-tag my characters like G-M-Something (Gatherer-Mental-Grigor) to remember who they are, how I need to level them up for the gear I want to give them and what roles they need to serve in the group. 
Maybe I'm missing something but the way combat is done with the stats forces you to make your characters very specialized if you want to master manual combat.

-A fucking grindfest. I mean this game is basically like a mobile game without microtransactions. You need to grind SOOO much to get resources. 
This game is highly dependent on getting resources in order to craft better weapons to make your party stronger. There are 4 tiers of resources but in reality, there are like 5. 

Tier 0 is garbage and should be used for fodder basically. Wood for heating and some other tier 1 resources (including food) to pass witch bribes to cure your illnesses/curses. 
Tier 1 is somewhat good and should be used to make your early game crafts. Gathering bags and crafting tools to help you gather faster and work faster. 
Tier 2 is a must have basically after the first winter. Especially ancient wood to make the sailboat be able to carry more capacity. 
Tier 3 is the good stuff and you can craft elemental and legendary equipment with it. This is where you want to be before winter 3. 
Tier 4 is basically the "mix" of tier 3 like elements that really help you get to the best weapons/tools/armors in the game to help you win the late game. 

The problem is that you can only really find up to tier 2 resources reliably on the islands. And even they are scattered and you may luck out and find a patch with 2 or 3 clumped together... but it's luck based. I personally never found tier 3 resource to gather on the map even after scouting all the islands. 
So what's the problem? You need 12 tier 2 resources + coal to make 1-2 tier 3 resource. This is A MASSIVE grind. holy shit is it a waste of time. And considering that you need to keep going to various islands to GET all tier 2 resources that you need (there is a tier 2 wood island, tier 2 metal island, tier 2 fur island, tier 2 rocks island, tier 2 gem island) and you have a weight limit on the ships that transport you to and from island (20k) which you reach REALLY FAST, man it slows down the game tremendously. Holy hell. Forget about settling somewhere because that will just kill your progress even more. unless you find a spot with food, loads of tier 1-2 resources and loads of coal, you are never going to be able to get the best items to finish a game. You're looking at HOURS of gameplay just to craft a legendary item. 

My suggestion, cut down on the grind.

-The grind for gods and bonuses. I mean when you start a game, you pick a god and your starting bonuses. Problem is you unlock gods and bonuses with "god points" which you earn while grinding the game. I played this game for 25h, the most I got out of 1 game was like 12 god points. You need 25 to get 1 of the best cards. 
Nope, I'm done with this massive time sink. 

This game does not respect the players' time.

review:
I've thoroughly enjoyed this sequel and think it's a good continuation of the first. It's RNG heavy and can be very punishing, so if you're not a fan of that you might want to avoid, but it's got a good combination of strategy, resource management, RPG and story (which takes the story of the previous game into account).
I notice quite a few complaints about the combat system, most saying that it's too complicated. I think maybe they should try playing it a few more times instead of just auto-resolving everything, maybe they'd get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018221953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1583777017}
review:
A lot of potential to have fun but some huge issues. Performance being one, as regardless of what you're doing fan speed is going to be at maximum or near. Given games takes ten of hours this is a problem.

It can be easy to get stuck though once you figure things out the difficult fall by a lot. It's still a problem, with notable UI issues like when trying to manage expeditions and villages.

Not very satisfying to play for thirty minutes or an hour. You won't feel like you're making progress, and/or you'll have to go through entire walls of texts. Not all can be easily navigated through the keyboard so prepare to click a lot.

The DLCs added contents but it needs some serious refinements. Not a good sign for a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997678601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 4468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1595947867}
review:
Kann diese Spiel wirklich sehr Empfehlen, das Kampsystem ist nicht ganz so kompliziert wie es auf den ersten Blick wirkt und lässt sich auch recht gut beeinflussen ohne viel RNG.
 Muss auch dazu sagen ich hab das Spiel lang gemieden da mich, Kampfsysteme mit Karten eher abschrecken. also eigentlich alle Karten spiele, hier macht mir das Kampfsystem aber trotzdem sehr viel Spaß.
 Bin jetzt auch nicht speziell Fan der Slavischen Mythologie, in einigen Reviews hatte ich gelesen es sei Wikinger Mythologie. Ist aber auf Slawische bezogen mit vielen eigenen Ansätzen auch. Sehr schön dafür das ich sonst davon wenig kenne, macht es sehr viel spaß mehr von der Welt und ihren Geheimnissen zu erfahren. Bin aber allgemein an Mythologie interessiert. 
Was mich auch noch etwas gehindert hat war, dass ich die Demo getestet hatte, die ich aber nicht lang gespielt hatte, ich kam nicht sehr gut rein weder in das Kampfsystem noch hatte ich einen Bezug zu den Attributen. Habe mir vor dem kaufen durch zufall ein Lets Play angeschaut wo in der ersten Folge eine recht Oberflächliche Erklärung abgegeben wurde, die mir aber dennoch gereicht hatte, die Kämpfe der ersten 6 Stunden zu überstehen, meist sogar richtig gut. 
Dann hat das Hauptspiel ein Tutorial... oder eher ein paar Guide Seiten zu dem Events wo die Arten Erklärt sind und wo auch ein wenig auf die Attribute und klassen eingegangen wird und auf das  eigentliche Ziel des Spiels, und was eben so wichtig ist und so. Das hat mir dann auch gereicht und wie gesagt jetzt im 2. Spiel bis zu 6Stunden weit zu kommen, und ich denke das ich mich recht gut schlage, hab natürlich überhaupt kein plan, ob mein standort der Stadt was taugt oder ob ich die richtigen Skills im Skillthree wähle und und und aber wenn ich fehler gemacht habe dann ist es zumindest nicht sehr wichtig wenn man mal was falsch macht und ich bin so bei Runde 70, meine Leute haben sogar schon Kinder bekommen usw. hab aber auch das Spiel auf relativ leichtem Schwierigkeitsgrad laufen.
Dennoch hab ich ein Mords Spaß das Spiel kennen zu lernen und eine Geschichte zu erleben, mal gucken wie ich dann neue start Karten und Götter freispiele wenn mein SPiel zuenede ist und wie viel Punkte man so bekommt. desweiteren muss ich mich mal damit befassen was die DLC im Einzelnen so neu bringen(musste die übrigens seperat installieren) 
Mir ist übrigens noch nie jemand wichtiges gestorben... als ich mal verloren hatte, ist ein Haustier gestorben ... aber sonst hat man eigentlich immer die möglichkeit seine leute durch zu bringen, und der Tod gehört auch einfach als teil der story dazu und löst weitere ereignisse aus.. klar an anfang ist das schon sehr schlimm wenn man wen verliert aber bisher hatte ich nicht das Problem.(hab jaaber auch erst einmal, mit demo 2 mal, gestartet) ich werde aber auf jeden fall bei Zeiten mein Review updaten oder ein komplett neues ausetzen. 

Hab schon viel erwartet als ich dann doch entschieden hatte mir das Spiel zu kaufen, wurde aber bisher keineswegs enttäuscht, mal gucken wie später die Story Variieren kann.


Ein kleines Update nach knapp 50std jetzt.
Ich bin super zufrieden das Open Story Prinzip wirkt hier voll und ganz und macht unheimlich spaß. Hab schon versucht ähnliche Spiele zufinden aber es ist allgemein sehr scher.Hab jetzt zumindest auch die Hauptstory soweit durch das ich eine neue Göttin Freigespielt hatte. Sehr cool, spiel aber aktuell meisten noch auf leicht, was natürlich die Gottpunkte verringert und ich somit schon Zeit brauche die Karten Freizuschalten. 
Hab auch kurz mit den Gedanken gespielt mir ein Profile von Nexus zu laden und alles Freizuschalten. Aber hab  mich dann doch dagegen entschieden, zum Glück. Wenn man oft Abende hat wo man nicht so recht weißt was man zocken soll oder so geht das doch eigentlich recht fix selbst auf leicht. Gut hab natürlich selbst nach 50std noch einiges zutun. Aber diese Rouge like mechanik sagt mir doch sehr zu.
Wenn man aber wirklich nicht viel Zeit hat und einfach so spielen möchte wie man will, kann man mein savegame laden. Würde aber sagen, damit macht man es sich selbst ein wenig kaputt, denn das motiviert auch irgendwie weiter zu spielen und nicht nur einmal jedes ereignes zu spielen und die meisten storys. Denn viele verlaufen auch durch Zufall anders, hab in einer Quest am Ende oft ein Goblin Kind angeboten bekommen bestimmt bei 6 durchläufen bekam ich ein pet oder kleinere Goodies. Aber jetzt das letzt mal wo ich auch den selben weg genommen hatte hab ich dann einfach das goblin kind bekommen. und sowas macht das Spiel einfach super interessant.

Gerade wenn einen schon die Witcher Fantasy Welt interessiert, mit all den Monstern, Wesen und Naturgeistern. Der wird hier echt regelrecht geflutet von Slavischer Mythologie gemischt mit ein wenig Standart Fantasy, wie zb die Goblins und Orks. die aber als Rasse eine willkommene abwechslung sind, gerade wenn man einfach mal ein komplett anderes spiel erleben will. Denn oft bedeuten bestimmte rassen die in der gruppe sind die gerade eine quest bestreiten, verschiedenste lösungswege. 

Ach ich fang schon wieder an so doll zu schwärmen. :D

Muss echt sagen, als ich die Demo gespielt hatte, hab ich mir gar keine Zeit genommen mich in das Spiel einzufinden und es gefiel mir gar nicht. Hab nach etilchen Stunden Battle Brothers und der Ankündigung des Wüsten DlC dort, ein Open Story Game gesucht. Fast schon etwas Verzweifelt, Stoneshard ist noch etwas früh in der Entwicklung. Und Thea gefiel mir gar nicht.
Ich habs dann einfach gekauft. Mit dem wissen der erste Teil, hatte einem Kumpel echt gut gefallen und den durchaus sehr guten Reviews auf der Shop Seite zum 2. Teil. hab ich bevor ich über haupt angefangen hatte, ein kleines Tutorial auf Youtube angeschaut, wo auch der Kampf gut erklärt wurde. Da nach hatte ich direkt los gelegt.und es auch relativ gut hinbekommen, gerade durch die einstellungen die man selbst vornehmen kann. Da würde ich auf jeden fall sagen die ersten male auch selbst ein wenig darin rumzuschauen, man kann sich auch 2 Bonus (ein sammler und ein Crafter) Leute für die Gruppe aktivieren.

Alles in Allem, nur zu Empfehlen das Spiel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001145666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1392, 'last_played': 1583245369}
review:
I bought this game with high hopes - especially that many of the problems with the original would be addressed in the sequel. But no, it is still a slog. Long periods of nothing happening and then  cloudbursts of overwhelming forces that knock you out of the game.  Problems (IMHO) include;
   -  autosave should be every turn. Overwhelming forces come out of nowhere and kill your army without warning, especially just after you designed new equipment and shifted your staffing around! No quick save.
   - Map is hard to read and exploring takes too long.
   - Game has concentrated on depth of play rather than playability, e.g. you can design just about anything but is it fun? Not for me.

   I'll be watching for updates.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057445783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 18841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9283, 'last_played': 1686678670}
review:
Игра однозначно стоит того, чтобы играть! 
Плюсы:
1) Непривычные механики, помесь стратегии и книги-игры. Отменный генератор приключений и фана!
2) С любовью прописанный мир
3) Открытость для модов сообщества
4) Разработчики поддерживают проект

Минусы:
1) Анимация ходов надоедает
2) Нет штатного русификатора (но есть нештатный)
3) Нет хорошей вики по игре (прошёл игру на несколько раз, но так и не знаю многих тонкостей с другой стороны подогревает интерес к игре)
4) Однообразие основных квестов (на 5 прохождении и далее уже знаешь что и когда будет)

Про сравнение первой и второй части: Вторая, на мой взгляд, богаче возможностями, но первая более цельная. Играть интересно в обе.

Русификатор есть в vk, но с intermediate английским вполне можно и без него играть.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007372413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 16605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15342, 'last_played': 1687098453}
review: Grüsse liebe Leser, im Grunde würde ich das Spiel empfehlen in der Hoffnung, dass auf dieser Basis sich noch ein ausgewogenes Spiel entwickelt. Der stark schwankende Schwierigkeitsgrad von ganz einfach zu super Schwer, wo dann plötzlich die ganze Truppe tot ist, oder schwer verletzt, und der Autosave vor gut 10 Runden das letzte mal gespeichert hat, ist ja nicht das schlimmste. Die Eintönige sich ständig wiederholende Musik lässt sich nur komplett abschalten, da es keine Möglichkeit gibt ein Lied zu überspringen. Das Kampfsystem ist weit vom klassischen Stein, Schere, Papier System entfernt, da hat man keine große Möglichkeit als Bogenschütze gegen einen Tank (Nahkämpfer) zu bestehen, da er sofort im Nahkampf ist, egal wie Gross und langsam er ist, man kann ihm nicht weglaufen oder sich verstecken, denn Deckung scheint es nicht zu geben. Das überflüssigste im Spiel ist aber die Nahrungsverarbeitung und Verwertung. Mir scheint das die Entwickler mehr an guten Essen und deren Zubereitung interessiert waren als an der Herstellung von Ausrüstung und Waffen, denn man verbringt mehr zeit damit Nahrungsmittel zu kombinieren oder aus einer umständlichen Rezeptliste zu fischen als sonst etwas im Spiel. Liebe Entwickler, die Nahrungsproduktion hätte man sicherlich "viel" einfacher machen können. Und zum Schluss noch eine Kleinigkeit, hab noch kein Spiel gesehen, wo man ein Schiff mit nur 6 Leuten quer übers land mit sich rumträgt, warum kann man das Schiff nicht am Ufer parken und später wieder mitnehmen, wie es sich gehört, oder vom Schiff runter etwas aus dem Meer fischen? Das wars für Heute liebe Leser, bis zum nächten mal. Euer Lord Garfield Zergroph

review: If you like 4X or Heroes of Might and Magic type games you are going to like this. However... Some of the negative aspects include extremely random RNG. For example you will be enjoying things like 2-3 destructive events in a row that effectively can wipe you out without save scumming. author: {'steamid': '76561198065329433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 3899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3475, 'last_played': 1608181124}
review:
I've gotten around to doing a proppa review of this instead of joking how it's infuriating how a random dialogue conversation can lead to your run ending at a moments notice. Instead I'll talk about what's really frustrating:
     - a complete lack of Quality of Life in a game that isn't Dwarf Fortress
     - a complete lack of polish in a game released from early access.
Let's go through the menus

Village Information
The supplies is fine, it's barebones but it doesn't need to be complex, the tasks on the other hand is utter crap.
Imagine showing me tasks that I had no one assigned to and then telling me I had 6 more which are nowhere on screen and cannot be accessed. Even then the information it gives is only the amount of turns until you get your next harvest, not good stuff like how much progress you're making a turn, highlight it and all you get is information on the item. 
The Buildings and Ships is just bad, it gives you the information on the buildings but the only time that's useful is if you're looking to replace them and it doesn't even show you an icon of what quality the building is.

|| So I'm going to have to go through some mechanics. There's three qualities in the game trash, normal, and masterwork all of which have unique icons to show you they're different. Trash gets a trashcan, normal gets nothing, and masterwork gets a hammer+star.  These qualities will apply to anything you make in the crafting menu and they effect the stats of anything crafted. However, these only show up in your inventory, if an item with a quality is equipped to a character the icon will disappear and since buildings don't appear in the inventory you never see their quality. ||

Again this is the only place you can even inspect your buildings which means if you want to try for a better quality building or one of different materials you'll have to go back and forth between the crafting menu and the village information menu.

Group Info
So this game is a lot of scrolling through menus, re-scrolling through menus, lots of micro if you actually start a village, lots of it needless. There's a button to stop your people from eating raw food and there's a button to make it so new food sources aren't used automatically. Basically, there's no button to prevent new RAW food items from being used which means you have to do that shit manually. 

Similar thing with fuel but not really a problem there but you know there's something funny going on there too.
Coal, you can of course burn it but it's got a real nice outdated description "Quite useless for crafting" meanwhile it's used in 100% of this game's material crafting which is how you get the high end-end game materials but I'm getting ahead of myself here.

There is no way to check where moral is coming from, you'd think it'd be the morale gain button but apparently not. I send out a small squad to collect some mythical leather and they had 90-99 morale and 4 food types. Meanwhile my guys at home have 5 and are stuck at a permanent 50-59, and same goes for the squad once it comes back. I would like to also point out what a shit morale system this is, one where it's entirely based on the food types. Food variety should effect morale but the idea that I'm happy/sad based on whether or not I ate one too many sandwiches is ridiculous. 

Inventory
For the love of god why are there two filters? You have tabs with icons at the side of your inventory which sort by; All, "People", Equipment, Resources, and Cooked Food. Few things here the icons are very misleading. You have raw food put in with stones, metals, etc and the icon is a log instead of the fork and knife representing food, WHY? Second there's a filter drop down on the bottom which opens up into a bunch of phrases such as raw food and COOKED FOOD WHY IS THERE TWO WAYS TO SORT FOR COOKED FOOD? Hmm maybe it's because this one can't even sort for animals. There's actually none that sorts for animals, you want animals you have to look into the equipment tab, but wait you can sort for armor and weapons but neither of those sort for animals! No way to sort for people either but let's just talk about that real quick, yes PEOPLE are in your inventory. The inventory is also the only way you can split up your characters into different units but you can't check what your guys have equipped from this menu, you have to go to

Equipment
I want to say this menu is close to functional. Actually equipping your guys is fine, when you highlight items the game will show you the stats of both items next to each other. You'll probably get a bunch of guys later on so the game generously gives you a sort button. This is where it starts going downhill. So the screen is not persistent, if you leave to another screen it will go back to default settings. Why's that bad? Well the game by default sorts from A-Z which means if you've got a bunch of guys and want to easily find specifically "X" class characters to equip them you have to change the sort every time. There's no way to change the default and you might think this isn't so bad until you realize you'll probably be transitioning back and forth between menus quite a bit.

Gathering
It's basic and it's serviceable, drag'n drop your guys in the place you want the sorted and the game tells you how good they are at gathering. Each resource needs a total number of points to be reached in order to harvest them. So say I collect leather I need 180 points. Each gather produces some points which will eventually reach that score. So a gatherer which produces 60 a turn will take 3 turns. A gatherer which produces 60 and produces 90 will take two turns. There is overflow, this means (using the leather example) if a gather or multiple gatherers produce 360 turn they collect the leather twice.

Crafting (Cooking and Composites too)
is the same as Gathering mostly which is fucking terrible because you don't care if you have a surplus if 'x" resource but you do care if you have a surplus of "x" equipment because can be very costly. In the base menu you only have 1 option, how much do you want to craft? You can't say "Do until we have 'x'" or "Do until we have 'x' of 'x' quality" nothing like that. You can't have the game just autoscrap weapons of a quality you don't like. Speaking of things I don't like, I don't like how there's three qualities. Instead of having something like a percentile increase/decrease depending on the best smith's level you just get a chance of getting shat on or getting something good. The chance depends on the difficulty of the material used and the smith's crafting level. So the better a craftsman the faster and better the thing made is. Gee it sounds like having multiple cr- yeah it's fucking pointless having more than one. You will always be crafting faster than you're gathering materials unless you have a bunch of amazing gathers+"x" resource spot on the map to gather from. 

Which is redundant when you realize the best materials can't be gathered they have to be crafted. Doesn't that mean crafting good? No crafting still very, very bad, the conversion rate is ridiculous. Example a tier 2 material's (a material you don't have to craft) best conversion rate is 12 of a random tier 1 material of the same type+1 coal for 2 of the material. For context that's like 1 full harvest of the material plus some coal which can't be found on the main island (I think, it used too but it seems like they patched that out). Review too big, check comments.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967035726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1581471680}
review:
I've played the first game to completion a few times, and mostly enjoyed it. This one however, has done two things horribly bad. 

First: Combat is overcomplicated, making you just go for auto-resolve instead of fighting. This kills all feeling of what stats do and how to build your characters because you have no idea how things work. While Thea 1 had some weaknesses in the combat system, it was overall quite fun and intuitive. This is not. 

Second: Having your village depend on the resources you build it with for stats is a horrible design choice.  This would only work if you could pack up your village and move on as you've gathered the resources you want from it. The game essentially becomes a rush to get a good enough resource to get +2 gathering radius from the village, and find a spot with a good mix of resources to harvest and just camp it. 

Also, visibility restrictions just added an extra fu to the experience. Play the first game, it's way better.

Edit: I just revisited the first game. I feel I should point out some positives in case dev reads this:
UI is far smoother on several fronts. Other than the crafting tab being a bit unintuitive, there's a lot of good UI improvements. 
Improved graphics is nice. The icons for resources are far better. The research tree feels somewhat better too. This game is far from fubar.

So, how to fix? 1: combat needs complete revamp. I get the idea, but it's WAY TOO TIME CONSUMING. The first game had a system that, while flawed, had the correct amount of time per battle, and choices. I tried a few times and just gave up on fighting. I couldn't make head or tails of it, and abilities were a pain in the arse to use and keep track of. If the game was purely about combat, maybe, but this game is as much about resource scavenging, building a tribe, and risk management. I fought each battle in Thea 1 manually, but Thea 2 made me give up that after 2 battles.

2: Makeshift villages: Make a village you can demolish (with full refund with regards to the magic stone you need to build it, maybe 35% refund for each building), but has lower bonuses (let's say 75% of regular village). However, this village will provide the bonuses for mental health and summon the demon to protect it. This should be a bit cheaper than regular village. Also, maybe make regular villages more expensive and powerful to give the feeling of finality of settling in, move the "rebuild your totem" research further away, and also make both the research and ritual more expensive as well. 

2.5: having to set up camp to get resources when moving around is a pain in the neck. IT'S EVEN FREE (in terms of movement cost) in this game! Why would one ever want to not set up camp? Remove setting up camp, nerf wild harvesting slightly to compensate for the makeshift villages making it possible to hunker down on a resource patch that's good. With a makeshift village, you can create a mechanic of being fearful of exploring too far from the village (because you increase the risk to your villagers exploring when they can't rest properly in the protection of the village), while not wanting to build and demolish the village all the time. It'll be a good balancing act between safety and progress. 

This review really annoys me, because I think there's stuff here that can make it a 8/10 game, maybe even 9/10, but atm it's a 4/10. (Thea 1 was a 8/10 for me)

review:
As someone who has seen many small studios trying to make it into the gaming world, i must say that Mu-Ha Games takes the cake. Developers simply never stop working on their product, listening to feedback and delivering content. Their commitment to the product is outstanding, and deserves every praise.
That been said, the game itself is an improvement of the 1st installment, developing the storyline along the mythology, adding mechanics and concepts that makes the 2nd an actual sequel. In terms that it agregates and expands on their 1st game, presenting a new game for newcomers as well as for veterans.
So buy it without fear or doubt, you WILL get your money's worth.
Now for the tiny list of cons:
Needs a more fluid menu, for load/save.
Some events apear very often (this is more a personal note than an actual con).
And that's it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025345354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 32827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3886, 'last_played': 1690718752}
review:
Игра очень понравилась, большая свобода выбора вариантов прохождения и стратегий, не подходит для тех, кто не любит трудности (как и первая часть), присутствуют элементы выживания. Не хватает обучения и подсказок по взрослению и воспитанию детей, хотя сам процесс выведения из них взрослых интересен). Сравнение с первой частью: добавились путешествия по морским просторам и возможность самому выбрать место постройки деревни, упрощена система испытаний, сильно поумнел ИИ (в ручном режиме схватки), однако сильно затянулись бои в ручном режиме относительно первой части, в кооперативном режиме можно выбирать разных богов, отсутствует официальная локализация . 
     Игра по прежнему развивается, часто выходят патчи и уже 2 крупных БЕСПЛАТНЫХ DLC. Все добра и приятного времяпрепровождения.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030712401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 27935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17746, 'last_played': 1686993001}
review:
Достойное развитие первой части. Случайные игровые события интересные; задания неплохи, но их мало, и они повторяются в каждой новой игре. Отличная идея дать богам разные слоты — нельзя найти идеальный состав бонусов и всё время выбирать их.
Очень интересно изучать игру, находить различные стратегии победы. Для новичков выжить сложно будет даже на среднем уровне сложности, но по мере прохождения становится ясно, что и как делать. После нескольких успешных попыток уже и тяжёлый уровень становится по плечу, но даже с самыми сильными бонусами он не становится простым в прохождении и поддерживает интерес к игре.
Для первого прохождения рекомендую самый простой уровень сложности, так как многие механики (например крафт) неочевидны, и потребуется время, чтобы разобраться в игре.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009093962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 284, 'playtime_forever': 1782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1675914795}
review:
[b] Overview [/b]
Thea 2: The Shattering pulls no punches and explains little. It takes a bit of an investment to get to a point where things make sense and you can freely pursue your goals without worrying that there is some other task that needs doing. Once you overcome that hurdle, there’s a challenging, deep, sandbox, party-based survival game that stands out as a unique and rewarding experience.

[b] The Odds Are Stacked Against You [/b]
Your introduction to the world of Thea begins with a selection of which god you serve. Only two of these are unlocked at first with several others eventually becoming available. Each of these offers their own unique boons and impacts your starting conditions. For example, Zorya, a goddess of turmoil and magic, grants you a free warrior and scavenger while also increasing the initiative of your party in combat. You’ll then have a number of points to customize the other aspects of your starting party ranging from resources to equipment to additional characters. Many of these options are locked as well, though each game will grant you some points that can be used to unlock them in further adventures.

Once your party has made it into the world, you’ll receive a variety of quests but the most important task that you have is to survive. The denizens of Thea are particularly hostile, but the cold and hunger can be just as threatening under the right circumstances. In order to keep your characters healthy and happy, you’ll need fuel (wood, coal) and food (the more variety the better). The passage of time with its seasons, weather, and day and night cycle will also challenge you with modifiers such as reduced food harvesting speed, hindered movement, and shortened vision.

When the basics of survival are in place, it’s time to turn your ambitions outward. A wide variety of resources are out there to be harvested, offering varying levels of efficiency for crafted items and structures built in your settlement. You may be able to make a suit of armor with iron but making it out of the far more challenging to acquire moonstone will offer a vastly superior piece of equipment. Resources fall into one of the primary categories (wood, stone, metal, hide, bone, gems, and food) and most crafting requires only a resource type, not a specific resource itself.

Research is invaluable as it unlocks the capability to harvest more advanced resources, craft new equipment, cook new recipes, and improve your efficiency overall. On the other hand, cooking allows you to combine food resources to create new types of food, not only boosting morale by expanding your party’s selection but allowing you to stretch how far your food resources can go.

Building a settlement is also useful in many ways, though interestingly enough, entirely optional; the nomad lifestyle is one that also has its own strengths and weaknesses. Settlements boost the harvesting talents of characters within them and allow the construction of structures that provide very useful buffs and abilities. You may still be trekking to distant lands but a cared for and protected homestead offers many advantages.


[b] Pen the Tale of the Chosen [/b]
The lore of Thea is quite unique and always as some interesting new event around the corner that isn’t an expected norm in contemporary fantasy. Slavic myths take center stage and you’ll be navigating through them as a chosen of the gods in a fantasy rendition of a post-apocalyptic world. You’re able to choose which of your starting characters is the chosen but be warned that if they die, your story has ended. I’ll avoid spoiling too much on the main storyline but you’ll be experiencing most narrative events via a visual novel-like style of narration that offers several choices for almost every one of them.


[b] The Bold and the Brave [/b]
If all goes well, your roster will increase in size throughout your story. New children are born and new allies are discovered, including several races and plenty of classes to keep you entertained. Some may be talented warriors, others may have a skill for crafting or gathering, others still may be blessed with a knack for oratory; regardless, all are important and incredibly useful parts of your group. The individual talents and many uses for these characters will surprise you if your expectations are based on others in the genre.

In my most recent adventure, I began with a warrior (fantastic at physical combat and challenges), a scavenger (half-mad woman in-tune with the mystical side of the world), and a gatherer (vastly superior to others at resource collection), who chaperoned a pair of children through the world until they grew into valuable characters in their own right. One of these became a zerca (cleric with incredible wisdom) and the other a witch (powerful spiritual combat class), though we were also joined by a craftsman who vastly improved our capability for putting together new equipment.

These characters improve by gaining experience and levelling up; levels alternate between boosting one of an option of three stats and choosing between two abilities (these may upgrade old abilities or teach a new one altogether). I enjoyed this style of progression quite a bit, my only complaint being that at times the stats offered for improvement were too random and nearly useless to the individual in question. I wasn’t particularly pleased when my hunter ended up surpassing my warrior’s strength by a noticeable amount.


[b] Your Three Lives: Health, Sanity, and Faith [/b]
Hostile encounters play out differently in Thea 2 than in anything else that I’ve played. Characters are represented by cards that are placed on a grid that includes a front and back row, one for you, one for your enemy. Positioning matters as each character’s abilities are chosen at the time that their card is placed and equipment and abilities have varied ranges and areas of effect. To paint the picture more clearly, a greatsword will deal damage to a foe in melee range as well as to those adjacent to them on the front row. Alternatively, axes deal the most impressive damage but only to a single target, while bows can strike any foe without restrictions. There is quite a variety of weapons that you’ll be able to get your hands on and they are plenty of fun to customize your party with.

What stands out with this title is its distribution of hostile encounters into physical, mental, and spiritual combat and challenges. Your warrior is likely to excel in physical combat and challenges, though they are just as likely to be absolutely terrible when it comes to those of the mental and spiritual varieties. Your physical tanks and damage dealers may pale in comparison to the overwhelming mental power of your zerca that had only offered some minor talent for supporting the party when physical challenges arose. It was interesting to see each character’s ‘life’ take the form of health (physical), sanity (mental), and faith (spiritual) and see a rather unimposing physical character become a tank as soon as an encounter broke out that couldn’t be resolved with a savage beating. These differing types of encounters also allow you to make many choices throughout your story, such as slaying the bandits who are attacking you or simply talking them down and I appreciated it.

Final verdict in the comments.

review:
I would recommend this game to others.  It is very in depth and has quite a learning curve.  Depending on what play style you are looking for, this could be slower paced.  If you try to rush through it without maximizing each turn the mobs will get too strong and kill you!   
In my opinion this game has elements of D&D, Final Fantasy Tactics, Shining Force, Civilization, etc...  There is a easy 100+ hours of playtime in order to unlock all characters and explore content.  Support the developers and enjoy the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198188214023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 2331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1692209282}
review:
Il gioco è davvero molto bello e, a mio modo di vedere, è costruito in modo anche più intuitivo rispetto al primo episodio, senza perdere assolutamente di sfida: mi riferisco, in particolare, all'interfaccia di battaglia, che ora permette di capire molto meglio il senso di giocare una certa carta e di giocarla in quel certo momento... A proposito delle battaglie, ho letto critiche a proposito del fatto che, giocando più volte una certa carta, un eventuale danno da essa ricevuto si propaga su tutte le altre copie: ebbene, bisogna, in realtà, comprendere che, [b][u]giocando più volte la stessa carta, non si invocano un eroe ed alcuni suoi avatar, né più esemplari in copia dello stesso eroe, ma si invoca quell'unico eroe perché intervenga in combattimento in più occasioni[/u][/b], cosicché è naturale che, se costui ha perso, ad es. 3 PF, al primo impatto, nelle fasi d'intervento successive egli non potrà che affrontare il combattimento senza disporre di quei 3 PF (a meno che, beninteso, un altro eroe (o lui stesso, se ne ha la facoltà) non abbia nel frattempo applicato a suo favore una azione di guarigione. 

Splendida anche la musica, estremamente sognante ed evocativa dell'immagine di una mitica antichità slava.

La sola avvertenza riguarda, come per mille e mille altri giochi, la lingua: l'italiano, tanto per cambiare, non c'è e l'inglese adottato, pur presentandosi estremamente vivace ed espressivo, non è certo quello dei corsi-corsetti-corsettini pratici di pronta beva che vanno oggi per la maggiore: è un inglese non dico curiale, ma sicuramente assai ricco lessicalmente, di bel livello letterario, che rimanda agli oggetti classici della letteratura romantica (o neo-romantica) e dunque, per capire il senso dei testi (e della ricenca condotta dai personaggi), può essere opportuno, all'inizio, aver la pazienza di dare un'occhiata a dizionari di inglese di buon livello (on line, ad es., il WordReference).

author: {'steamid': '76561198030701407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3420, 'last_played': 1619102193}
review:
Mixed bag - as I understand it devs are still working on it.  Right now I'd give it a hesitant recommendation.  The new combat system is heavily automated while also complex - I autofight almost all battles, combat feels tedious for the most part.  I'm not sure what the logic is for allowing a character to appear multiple times on the battlefield.  The initial quests (first ~50 turns) are boring, even annoying, after the first few plays.  Interface oddities - lots of times you only have 1 option but require a keypress/click to progress.  Why?  Sometimes escape works to exit a screen, other times not.  You can click/drag the tech screen, but not the map.  When you have resources turned on, it can get hard to select a stack.  Crafting/building feels pointless - build a few gathering items, everything else will come as drops.  A good weapon and a mediocre weapon feel almost the same - everything is a spectrum.   Too many events - I can hit "end turn" and have 5-7 attacks, random events, etc. happen while sitting still.  Can't do anything about physical or sanity damage, only faith has a repair action.   

That's a big mass of criticisms, sorry!  The slavic mythology theme is fun, though I haven't found much difference playing different gods.  Exploring and events are kind of interesting.  Graphics are good to excellent.  Pacing is fair-to-good, resource gathering is somewhat satisfying but can drag when trying to refine advanced materials.  I'm hoping for continued refinement - a lot of games release with rough edges then turn out great, and Thea:Awakening was excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030824996', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 12519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6718, 'last_played': 1610660526}
review:
So. People will say "You recommend the game, and then write a negative review!" Yes, that is right. Here is why.

This game has a lot of potential, but I have come to believe that the developers don't really want their players to have fun. I will explain below.

1. Almost all of the game is behind play-walls, which means you unlock it by playing. This is normally fine, a good thing even. The problem is that the things are not explained. The "Orc Child" unlock does not mean thay you get an Orc figher, no you get an Orc gatherer or craftsman, which you already have other people taking care of, The point is supposed to be that you should get the child to grow up, then get another Orc, and hope they will get a new orc child and wait for that child to grow up and THEN you get your Orc figher. Only, by that point you should have won the game, unless you deliberately delay winning to get this fighter...

2. Random maps. Again, great idea, and for most games this is a plus. However, in this game you get to build ONE settlement. So, you walk around searching for the perfect spot, that have a level 3 resource, coal, a lot of other resources, and at least one source of food. Now, finding this spot can take a really long time. Yes, you can be micromanaging parties that go out of the settlement and get some resources you cannot get in the settlement, but it is so much more of a pain than just finding that perfect spot. IF you could have automatic trade routes between gatherers and the home settlements, then fine. But there is nothing like that.

3. Random level ups. You do not get to build the characters you want.

4. You get random rewards of mostly crap. So, you get a lot of crap together and find a trader, but the trader mostly have even worse crap than you have. So, traders are mosly useless, unless you lack for food, and then you could just restart the game.

5. Point 4 above about the random crap resources would be fine, if you could do something with them. But research is super slow, and a lot of the building research options are so bad they may as well not exist as far as I am concerned. Also, how much of a difference can there be mining gold than mining silver? Just let us unlock all three level 2 resources of the same kind for 1 research point! And I do not like the several tiers of items. Like, OF COURSE I want the +20% bonus to crafting the item. So each item might as well cost 3 research points. Which again would be fine, but research is just too slow. 

6. Each island have ONE settlement with each of the two races associated with it. On a large map, it is a chore to find that one settlement.

I am not talking about making the game easier. I am talking about design decisions. Why not let the players level up characters the way they want? Why not let the players upgrade resource NODES instead of upgrading endless individual resources. Why not show what the unlockables really mean. Why not have traders in the game with unique items you really want? Why not allow more settlements?  

So yeah. I just wish the game was more interesting. The art is great, the ideas are interesting, I love rogue-likes, but this game is just hard for me to like. 

I guess I should look into mods.

review: Thea 2 is an excellent game, like its predecessor, though this one provides even more variety in playstyles given that you don't need to settle down in a village, and has a much more enjoyable conflict resolution card game. It hits the right spot between randomized text based adventure, 4X strategy game, and skill/crafting development RPG all coupled within a roguelike progression system between playthroughs. It's very well done all around. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059466962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4171, 'last_played': 1578554258}
review:
Thea 2 is a neat game: Civ-like strategy with a heavy dose of survival and a tad of role play and storytelling. There is also quite a bit of replayability as your starting settings will change the story, the world map and you can greatly modify the difficulty to suit your liking.

For those who played Thea: the Awakening, here follows a list of differences between the games:
[u]Stats and skills[/u]
Where characters in Thea 1 had a good amount of ability even at level 1, characters in Thea 2 will start will next to nothing and will improve greatly as they level up. The ability of characters in Thea 2 revolves around 6 base stats divided into three groups (physical, mental and spiritual) which powers the skills in combat, challenges and expedition tasks.

[u]Items[/u]
In Thea 1 a level one character could become a super hero the first turn if equipped with top tier items. In Thea 2 items now scale off of item-specific stats. So a top tier battle axe now scales with strength which means a lvl 1 gatherer will do little to no damage with the axe while a high level warrior with tons of strength will hit like a truck.

[u]Resources and gathering[/u]
In Thea 2, not all resources can be gathered. In fact, the top tier resources will have to be crafted. 

[u]Challenges and combat[/u]
Challenges and combat are still resolved through playing of cards. The big difference is that only your 8 strongest characters in the challenge specific stat group get to participate. A level 20 warrior speced in strength won't get picked over a level 5 witch speced in spirit in a spiritual challenge, for instance. One character can be played multiple times but the cost of playing the card goes up as you do so.

There are more differences of course but these are the major ones. 
All in all, the good changes are the items and stats whereas the new way resources and challenges work are changes for the worse to me. Just as magnificent as Thea 1 though. Keep up the good work!

review:
Plus complexe et exigeant que son prédécesseur, Thea 2 est un bon jeu de gestion fort d'une ambiance marquante car adaptant un mythologie relativement peu connue en occident. Les possibilités de personnalisation offrent une rejouabilité somme toute correcte, bien que les événements tendent à se répéter assez rapidement. 
En somme, un jeu à recommander aux amateurs du genre pour son gameplay comme son univers.

review: I would love to give this a good review, but the randomness and outright unfairness of the encounters, regardless of difficulty settings, makes the game nearly unplayable for me.  Would probably be fun for those who enjoy games where there is a random chance of death on every turn who then get to start over again from scratch.  What makes it even worse is that there appears to be a good story in here somewhere, but I doubt I'll ever get to see it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100310913', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 2366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1582719559}
review:
如果汉化也跟上速度就好了，当然也期望官方能支持中文，那真的对游戏的推广有很大的帮助。我从西娅（Thea 1）开始游玩的，很棒的作品，刚发售的时候因为没有官方中文就没有买，知道不久前有人告诉我有汉化mod，我才趁着促销的时候购入，玩了一会，还是一代作品的味道，也优化了很多一代的问题。但作品还需要打磨和剧情的扩展，而不是仅停留出个续作就完事了。

目前我游玩的时候出现故事线重复和固定化选择，导致背板和SL能减轻战斗难度，我希望制作组还能继续更新作品，在随机剧情里出现相互关联，比如你救了一个恶魔，在下一个背板剧情（即你之前玩过这个故事也知道如何选项）时候，出现恶魔帮助或捣乱的选项，让整个剧情更戏剧化，非常感谢制作组能做出很不错的作品，期待你的更多的内容更新和DLC的制作。

author: {'steamid': '76561197997374224', 'num_games_owned': 678, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1576642684}
review:
Thea 2 is an interesting take on the 4X genre, taking the first few turns where you have a single city (or even just a settler) and spreading it out into a full game, while adding a rich world along with survival and RPG elements. It also has a rogue-like feature, with won or lost games giving you currency to unlock new items to choose between for your next group of survivors.

While I loved the premise - the first few turns of Civ where individual cities matter and you’re still discovering the map are my favourite part of that game - the clunky UI and obtuse stat system made me rebound off Thea 2. Simple tasks like moving your group, assigning gathering and crafting orders, and checking the status of your characters quickly became a chore, and when those are the things you’re doing most it quickly sapped my will to keep going.

The combat system has a lot of depth - physical, mental and spiritual combats draw on completely different stats and skills to determine damage, health and available attacks, and each type of combat has a variant which uses equipment and one which doesn’t - but in practice it made it hard to judge how well my party matched up against any given encounter. This was a problem when the consequences of failing are so high; party members have a risk of dying each turn when any of their 3 health totals are below 30% and losing any of the starting characters might as well be a soft failure state since it slows down your rate of progress so much. Losing your designated “main character” loses you the game outright.

These problems may have been fine if I had acquired the points to unlock new items with any kind of speed to add some variety, but I only unlocked a couple items in my time playing the game.

I wouldn’t recommend the game without a UI patch, but I very much look forward to a sequel where these problems may have been addressed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073987259', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1606362429}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003516766', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 6072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4866, 'last_played': 1588530003}
review:
Totally will redo a new game / Et ce sera avec certitude qu'il y aura une nouvelle partie !!!

[ENGLISH] Excellent creator of stories - current game :
All began with 3 children (a chosen elf girl & human boy & girl).
The boy died, the girl, when coming at age was killed and transformed into a spirit. The chosen one became an elf gatherer.
The wraith decided to have affairs with the elf, and was born an undead body (the boy ?).
This weird trio was later saving children (goblins & humans) and a broken skeleton.
One of the boy saved became a creepy Zerca - sort of leader -, who had actually more than 6 children with the 5 girls in the group (but weirdly not the chosen one, who became a druid elf - she may be more into undead ? Other guys just have no way).
2 goblin children became a swamp monster and a fairy forest.
Recently, the group have saved a bunch of scavengers (2 guys, 1 boy).
Yeah, there was some dead in the journey, but hey, that's what make the survival of this group really unique.

[FRANÇAIS] Excellent créateur d'histoire - partie en cours :
Tout commença avec 3 enfants, une elfe "élue", un garçon et une fille.
Le garçon mourut. La fille joua trop avec les arts mystiques, et revint en esprit vengeur auprès de l'élue, devenue cueilleuse.
L'elfe et l'esprit eurent une affaire, et naquit un mort-vivant (le garçon ?)
Cet étrange trio sauva plus tard des enfants (gobelins et humains), ainsi qu'un squelette cassé.
Un des enfants devint un Zerca "creepy" (terrifiant), sorte de guide/chef, avec la particularité qu'il a eu 6 enfants avec 5 des femmes du groupe (pas l'elfe, devenue druide, qui doit avoir un truc avec les morts-vivants). Les autres hommes du groupe n'ont pas leur mot à dire.
2 enfants gobelins sont devenus monstre des marais et fée de la forêt respectivement.
Le groupe a récemment sauvé des "scavengers", des pilleurs (2 hommes et 1 garçon).
Oui, il y a eu des morts pendant ce voyage, mais c'est ce qui rend la survie de ce groupe vraiment unique.

author: {'steamid': '76561198241585396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 10769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10737, 'last_played': 1707927929}
review:
I am absolutely in love with this game. The beautiful illustrations, the mythical lore and the bespoke events are really addictive and I spend hours on end playing... just... one... more... turn!

The random nature of some events together with how you drive your journey across the world is very interesting and promised different gaming experiences each time. I have tried a couple of the gods and each seem unique and authentic.

So pleased I have been supporting the devs since Thea 1 and I am amazed how they still pump out free content. That coffee I sent their way really did the trick ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198347827316', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2463, 'last_played': 1587397802}
review:
优点缺点很明显，中后期大量垃圾时间，游戏成长曲线有问题，难度也有问题。
因为是自由高，所以只要赞人找地方建村庄，收集材料做装备。然后剧情平推。
只要数值高了，装备好了，一路A过去。

建议加入一个阶梯的剧情，通过剧情来解锁特定的材料，与等级上限。
随机剧情与固定剧情掺杂在一起，比如有随机的剧情可以解锁随机类型的材料，特定的村庄解锁特定的材料。

通过主线来解锁等级上限，在有限的范围内解决问题，这样挑战战斗就会更加有趣味，需要思考搭配。而不是数值碾压。

人口需要精简，或者有方法能够让玩家主动限制人口。目前主动控制人口的方法，我只发现了卖掉或者丢到野外饿死。

给差评是因为定价问题，游戏质量与价格不符合。不打折不建议购买。

author: {'steamid': '76561198027897938', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 15747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4320, 'last_played': 1705774675}
review:
I have played and loved Thea: The Awakening and was very excited when they announced its sequel.
For all who expect to have the same game, just with a new story: quite a bit has changed. Some changes are good and some not so much. While your first steps in Thea: The Awakening were rather gentle The Shattering can easily crush you on your first 15-30 minutes into the game. So for all who do not want to be utterly frustrated or hate constant reloading, I would advice to tone down the difficulty. 
It took me a while to figure out how to reliably survive everthing the game threw at me, but all in all I would rate Thea 2: The Shattering a great successor to The Awakening.
For all who like a beautiful story, with nice graphics, an innovative gamepaly and are not bothered to be challenged by a game Thea 2: The Shattering should definitely be worth a try.

review:
Нельзя плохо относиться к игре, где можно начать крысой, избранницей Велеса, и замутить с призраком, каким-то образом наплодив детей зомбарей.

review:
A poor follow-up to a great game - Thea 1 is just way better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007835793', 'num_games_owned': 517, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 11521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6992, 'last_played': 1684032475}
review:
Хорошее продолжение(мне правда первая часть больше понравилась, она как то уютнее что ли была), некоторые нововведения спорные, но в целом хорошо.
На старте 2часть никакая была, но разработчики не бросили и довели ее до ума и сейчас в ней контента раза в 2 больше чем в первой.
Из однозначных плюсов, это замечательная музыка и арт дирекшен, расширили так же лор и сюжет по сравнению с 1 частью.
Боевка спорная, но в целом терпимо, так же некоторая перегруженность в плане вещей и материалов(но это имхо, многим может и понравиться).
Всем кому понравилась первая часть рекомендую и просто тем кому нравятся медитативные игры.

review:
Игра это очень достойное продолжение первой части. Все было улучшено. Крафт-Квесты-Дети-Рассы.
1. По началу может отпугнуть,усложненная система крафта. Но мир развивается и улучшение материалов -очень верное решение .
2.Для этой игры есть хороший русификатор . Да , пока не все ветки квестов переведены. Но учитывая качественный перевод - это простительно.
3. Понять суть нового мироустройства можно , только пройдя путь нескольких богов . Теперь есть ваш аватар -полноценный член отряда (как и дети).
Так что очень рекомендую к приобретению

review:
Not many games delve into slavic mythology and this one does it good from narative standpoint.

Game is an interesting take on 4x strategies with a healhy dose of RPG elements.

Some people don´t like combat system. You can skip it with autoresolve, which offers you broad outcome how challenge / fight will end and you can still try to do it manualy afterwards if you don´t like it.

Just like the first game (also very good), it is product of love from small studio. First game was supported with additional free content, so you can expect it also here in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012248636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 29411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11188, 'last_played': 1702923532}
review: I enjoyed the first Thea, but the changes made in Thea 2 make me never want to go back.  The child bonus level system, the upgrading of lesser resources, the revamped combat system.  So many great things that took a fun indie 4x and produced a sequel that is better in almost every way.

review:
Thea 2 is good like the first game, true sandbox experience, endless replayability thanks to the random generated world and events. Every god has it's own unique style and story. It has also multiplayer Coop and has been well disigned for it (can crash very rarely).
The game is not balanced so well but to be honest this is not the game which really needs hyperbalance thanks to the sandbox nature. But i can't really thing any negative side of this game really.
Well looking forward to Thea 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003213131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 592, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1575062127}
review:
Bon, recommençons cette putain d'évaluation de merde puisque la nouvelle interface de steam à décidée de l'effacer quand j'ai cliqué sur "Non" ...

Vous l'aurez comprit après ce petit spoil, je ne vais pas vous recommander ce jeu.

Donc ayant joué au 1, je m'attendais à de la maturité, à un jeu dont les promesses vertueuses seraient enfin tenues, à de la difficulté, à de véritables ennemis ....

Ralalala, qu'est-ce que je peux être naïf moi ...

Donc commençons par le début, c'est un jeu qui est à la croisée des chemins entre civilization et fallen enchantress, si vous ne connaissez ni l'un ni l'autre, allez jouer à l'un des deux plutôt que d'envisager d'acheter ce jeu-ci.

Qu'est-ce que je reprochais au 1 à l'époque ? Des fins de parties impromptues ? Des ennemis inexistants ? Des objectifs de quêtes obscur ? ...
*petit rire de dépit* 
Allez, on prend les même et on recommence !

Donc première partie, difficulté au max, choix de divinité et de différent bonus plus ou moins sympathique, c'est un bon point. 
Commencer le jeu et risquer plusieurs fois de crever, c'est un bon point.
Du craft en veux-tu en voila, c'est un bon point.
Des musiques sympa, des graphismes sympa, une prise en main facile, c'est trois bon points.
Début de partie tu choisit une carte énorme de style pangée, le jeu te sort une carte énorme avec des îles, c'est un mauvais point.
Tu restart ta partie et tu vois que toutes tes options sont sauvegardées, c'est un bon point.
Tu arrives sur la carte et c'est encore des putains d'îles, c'est un mauvais point.
Tu recommences, encore, encoreee, ENCORE, ENCOOOORE, cinq fois d'affilées afin que le générateur de carte comprenne que quand tu demande une pangée, ben, bizarrement, tu veux une pangée et pas des îles, c'est un mauvais point.

Donc, je me balade, je rase des cités états, sans le vouloir, le jeu ne m'ayant pas prévenu que le truc qui veux m'attaquer peut-être simplement calmé en faisant des quêtes de merde qui augmente la réput, et donc que ces cités rasées sont autant de futurs quêtes, loot, exp de moins. Chiant. Je finis par le comprendre comme un grand, je les caresse dans le sens du poils, fais des quêtes en veux-tu en voilà, et finalement toutes les cités états sont mes amies. Je m'attend donc maintenant à croiser les autres joueurs joué par l'ia ...
*trèèèèèès long soupir devant mon clavier*
Comment dire ça simplement ... les devs ont oubliés, peut-être, d'introduire les vrais ennemis dans le jeu, là on ne tape que du trash mob en permanence. Imaginez civilization où vos seuls ennemis sont les barbares, palpitant hein ?
Je préfère me dire que les devs ont oubliés hein, parce que ça peut arriver à tout le monde de faire des bourdes, plutôt que de me dire qu'ils ont fait EXPRES de pas mettre de putains de vrais ennemis dans ce jeu.
Nan parce que sinon ça voudrait dire que non seulement dans le premier jeu, mais aussi dans le second, quelqu'un ce fou de ma gueule ouvertement pendant que moi je lui donne de l'argent.

Donc, je finis l'une des quêtes que j'avais en cours ett ça termine ma partie, pourquoi après tout, la quête "semblait" importante (notez l'utilisation judicieuse des guillemets), donc oui, pourquoi pas. 

Je me motive donc ARDEMMENT, car je viens de débloquer une des deux races bloquées à cause de quêtes, et je me dis qu'il faut donc la tester sur une nouvelle partie et que cette fois-ci je ne ferai pas la même quête, mais en tenterai une autre pour voir ce que ça donne.

J'avais juste oublié le générateur de carte de merde entre temps ...

-_-"

Donc, après quelques moments de rage intense, je commence une nouvelle partie, sur une pangée,  le jeu se déroule mieux que la première fois, je sais ce qu'il faut faire comme recherche, ce qu'il faut débuter en priorité dans la ville et comment orienter mon perso principal, donc c'est simple, je prend même tout mon temps pour avancer dans le jeu et ne commence à faire mes premières quêtes que vers le 70ème jour. J'explore la carte jusqu'à en découvrir un bon quart, j'entame les trash quest des cités états afin de me faire aimer, quand soudain ... SOUDAIN !!! VENANT DE NULLE PART !
"Fin de partie, vous avez gagné."

Hein ?
Nan ... je veux dire, vraiment hein, HEIN ?!
Comment ça j'ai gagné ?
Attend là je viens de finir une trash quest qui me donne un enfant gobelin ... en quoi j'ai gagné la partie ? J'ai même pas fait autant de tour que dans ma partie précédente ! J'ai finit aucune des quêtes principales ! J'ai pas rencontré toutes les cités états de la carte ! J'en ai même pas exploré 20-25% !
MAIS PUTAIN DE BORDEL DE DIEU DE MERDE !

Vous l'aurez comprit, je ne vais pas vous recommander ce jeu, vous vous douterez surement du pourquoi.
A bon entendeur ...

review: Though it took a little while to get used to the card system (as I was still in the mindset of the original), I still found the game play enjoyable. Remaining a group of wanderers for so long was odd as well, but manageable. Crafting, my go-to in games like this, is the one thing I'm back and forth on currently. I like a lot of the recipes, but it feels a little constraining to make even the simplest weapons and armor at times. Especially if you're trying to design something that protects you from morale and spirit attacks...which are VERY plentiful in the various beasties of the world. More than one game has come to a crashing halt, due to getting my soul kicked in before Round 60 or so  :)  Still, it's quite fun, and I'm looking forward to seeing what else shows up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023630517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 19510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15456, 'last_played': 1685534736}
review:
To keep it short, it is an amazing game, but if you were in love with Awakening (the first Thea), there is a chance you'll hate it and I have no way to tell you how it will go. My first guess comes as a warning to the newcomers to the series, you might have just forgotten how janky and frustrating the Thea is, because you already learnt how to game the system and so many things changed that you'll need to learn it again.

I really enjoy the emergent narratives, so I'm giving some leeway for janky mechanics as long as they spew out interesting stories at me. Unlike in Awakening, in which you had to force the roleplay, Shattering gives many more opportunities to do it naturally. You still have events in the overworld in which your characters participate, but it doesn't end there. The more elaborate challenge system means you may witness many situations you can narrate easily. There's also much more customization for characters skillsets and attributes and, though it's not as big or in-depth as in traditional RPG, you will end up with a whole bunch of characters, each with own quirks, strengths and weaknesses. You'll also interact with settlements of different races around the world, you'll no longer be alone against the world - unless you decide to make it so.

There's whole bunch of stuff to list as a precaution, as it might have not stood in my way to enjoy the game, but it may stand in yours.
The game, especially on harder levels is very much about chasing/staying ahead of difficulty curve, there is possibility to turtle down if you lagged behind too much, but in that aspect Shattering is tedious and downright boring. Don't get me wrong, there's a lot to do, just very little of it is captivating in a long run, so it serves much better as a background noise for boldly going into the world with your strongest party, while back in the village your people take care of gathering, crafting and research.
The sailing aspect is unpolished and makes for little more than wasting turns, though I like the idea and I'm glad that the devs are addressing its major issues and introduction of new map type helped as well.
The randomness plays a big part and you may face challenge simply beyond your current abilities. Rarely you may even start in simply hopeless spot and everything just goes wrong, with no way to affect it beyond postponing the inevitable. Tying to this is the fact that you need to learn a lot, some of the 'bad' choices may end your playthrough abruptly and you won't know whether you're ready for them until you've went through it and got your skull caved in. Sometimes multiple times.
The writing sometimes may be hard to catch up with, the player is present in the game world in a form of Chosen, which creates disjointed narration, as they may not be present for all the events, so the narration alternates between you and your people or just telling a story. It can get confusing at times. It's worth noting that the story itself is solid, the main quest will get you traveling across the world to see how different races want to remedy the Shattering and - the best of all - if you're not feeling like it, you can just bruteforce and finish the game without leaving the starting area, though it won't be easy. And this is just the main storyline, there are branching sidequests and even the random events give interesting choices and reward you with captivating stories (like a vampire that got awestruck by the beauty of my craftsman and kept stalking us).

review:
Thea 2 continues the wonderful tradition started in its predecessor, marrying 4X to a small scale of a single group, a village, a few people doing their best to save the world and an RPG. Gather, hunt, craft, solve events, grow your community, gain access to new and better ressources, combine them to outfit your party, research, explore... all in a very much untapped world of slavic myth.

This is definitely one of my personal favourites of 2019, and an easy way to eat up hours with "just one more turn/crafted item/milestone" syndrome. Give it a try, it is a very solid game, with a great team behind it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108222175', 'num_games_owned': 774, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 16121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4715, 'last_played': 1678982432}
review:
Я долго думал какую оценку поставить (что уже говорит о многом), в итоге остановился на том, что она не заслуживает "пальца вверх" как одиночная игра.

В кооперативе с приятным собеседником (как повезло мне) она заметно лучше, но кардинально ничего не меняется. 

Можно долго разбирать плюсы и минусы, но я остановлюсь на двух ключевых, по моему мнению, моментах:
1. Эта игра не та какой её хотят представить разработчики.
Например написано что это 4X стратегия (как Civilization), и это не правда. Здесь толком нет ни исследования (eXplore), ни расширения (eXpand), ни соперников которых можно уничтожать (eXterminate), здесь есть только добыча и переработка ресурсов (eXploit).
Написано, что это рогалик, но от рогалика здесь только случайная генерация карты. Её даже роглайтом сложно назвать. Она подразумевает множественные прохождения (боги открываются постепенно), при этом в ней каждый, КАЖДЫЙ раз происходят одни и те же события и квесты, которых не так и много. Начальная цепочка вообще ВСЕГДА одна и та же.
И так далее. Всё чем эта игра хотела стать реализовано в зачаточном виде.
2. Эта игра кривая и неудобная.
Распределение заданий, окошки снаряжения, перемещение отрядов, карточная игра — такое ощущение, что играешь ногой, а не рукой. Настолько всё неудобно сделано.

В общем и целом она выглядит интересно только по причине отсутствия конкурентов.

review:
Its an engine improvement to thea 1 thou lost interesting combat mechanics in the process.
Many things that felt lacking in the first one were added but some of the new features are not as nice.
Like the fact you can build all materials as upgrades from previous tier materials makes it a bit afk farming game. 
Combat feels a bit too complicated and boring so you will auto resolve all events.
They made many fixes to this later including no more islands world generation.
 
Its a good game but first game with this engine would be the most ideal option.
Would give it a rating 7,5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059718128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 14657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1240, 'last_played': 1648598737}
review:
Since I've played this game over 100 hours, I though I should update my review and make it more comprehensive.

It's still not as good at the original!

2 Biggest Pros:
- Food transfer bar between groups.  This was my biggest complaint of Thea 1 and they solved it spectacularly.    
- Character setup and child growing up choices are great, a lot of different types to acquire and play.

2 Biggest Cons: 
- Most resources are literally useless.  You only want like 1-3 advanced resources so you can make better shit.  Research doesn't hinge on crafting anymore, so unless you can make an upgrade, your blood bone or elf/druid trees or 4 kinds of inferior leather are just trash.  
- Lack of good voice acting.  There's a new decent female acting voice, but her narrative voice is like a cold shower.  The story/quests overall are harder to keep track of and the in-game quest tracker is anti-helpful. 

I want to give this a thumbs up, but it's gonna have to be better than Thea 1.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005599943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 10930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5397, 'last_played': 1691086796}
review:
Ne wczesnym dostępie byłem trochę wkurzony. Ta gra wyszła za wcześnie i była mocno niedopracowana. W tej chwili uważam, że jest w stanie bardzo dobrym i mogę śmiało polecić ją każdemu miłośnikowi turówek. Dla tych co nie grali w jedynkę, mamy ekipę, która ma za zadanie przede wszystkim przetrwać, a poza tym odkryć, dlaczego Bogowie utracili swoją moc. Poszukujemy surowców, jedzenia i opału, bronimy się przed wrogimi stadami i konkurencyjnymi plemionami, wytwarzamy przedmioty, które umożliwią zwycięstwo w 3 rodzajach potyczek - siłowych, mentalnych i magicznych oraz rozwijamy technologię i postacie, których to postaci mamy mało i strata każdego to poważne utrudnienie. 
W stosunku do jedynki jest lepiej jeżeli chodzi o walkę, mamy większy wpływ na rozwój postaci, bardziej rozbudowany crafting, pływanie na statkach, można prowadzić badania, w jedynce trzeba było wytwarzać strasznie duże ilości przedmiotów. Na minus mniejsza liczba postaci, większa stagnacja na początku, zanim będziemy w stanie wysłać ekipę na eksplorację minie trochę czasu.
