author: {'steamid': '76561197975437519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1575525290}
review:
I really enjoy the first game.  I was very excited when I saw the second game.  I was greatly let down by what I got.  
I was impressed with the artwork and color of the new game. The lack of voice narration for all events was disappointing but understandable.
The card mechanic has changed in such a way that it is unrecognizable to the first game.  
Characters have so many abilities and other nonsense that the simplicity of the card game may as well be replaced with more traditional video game mechanics. 
They added health for to correspond to the other combat challenges  which adds consequence to failure. In the first game they normally solved this problem by having you enter the original combat at a disadvantage if you failed the alternate challenge.  In the sequel, you can lose party members for failing a speech check. Which seems appropriate under some circumstances, but silly under others.
They added more resources which is nice  but limit the way to obtain the villagers you need to harvest them.  You get to place your village, which is a huge improvement. Your village can also be upgraded to have access to even more resources on the map, but without characters to harvest them it does little good.
Lastly, the game feels unfinished.  Certain obvious options are missing from dialog (like only being allowed to threaten and rob a group of NPCs that say they don't wan't any trouble), a starting quest isn't possible with the characters you are given, or an impossibly difficult monster single-handedly wipes out your whole party on the starting island.
Overall, I say give this game a pass and play the original if you have not already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062976227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 16402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9316, 'last_played': 1668429417}
review:
Rundenstrategie mit Rollenspielelelementen das über die wählbaren Götter mit der Zeit leicht abgewandelte Spielweisen ermöglicht und so zum rumprobieren einläd. 

Die Mischung zwischen Erkundung, Aufbau und Aufrüstung seiner Leute macht Laune. Allerdings fühlt man sich in diesem Teil ne ganze Weile ziemlich ans Dorf gefesselt, sollte man sich dafür entscheiden eines aufzubauen.

Kampf- und Craftingsystem sind schwerer zu durchblicken als im ersten Teil also braucht man auch ein wenig bis man da wirklich durchsteigt. Die haben da nen ganz guten Job gemacht. Allerdings scheint das Spiel im mom an manchen stellen noch nicht 100%tig geschliffen. Fällt aber auch erst wirklich auf wenn man sich ne ganze weile damit beschäftigt hat. 

Alles in Allem schönes Spiel in das man ne menge Zeit reinstecken kann und auch mit Kollegen.

review:
玩過一代之後滿期待二代的內容，看到簡中mod出來後便果斷購入

遊戲本身的玩法基於數值判定，然後執行小遊戲畫面去判定結果與輸贏

搭配上主線與支線故事的選擇，前期應該會得到遊戲的樂趣

特別講一下比前代改進的部分大概是地圖改為隨機產生，所以就算是重複遊玩至少地圖還有變化

同時遊戲也結合經營村莊等玩法，不過初玩感覺村莊系統跟前代一樣沒甚麼特別的變化，希望未來能多點彈性

 總體而言是個少見的遊戲類型，期待遊戲能更加完善。

review: Thea 2's a fun and detailed strategic RPG with tabletop/card game mechanics. Has a bit of a learning curb with occasionally where the RNG can occasionally be harsh along with the perma-death, but ultimately a satisfy experience for me. Random map generator makes for a lot of replayability, however the map scrips can produce some more tedious than fun maps more often than I'd like, but can be forgiven that it's map generator does get updated along with other content and balance updates. Def kudos the developers for their post launch updates and support for their game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067177225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 108518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18619, 'last_played': 1707005947}
review:
I think everyone should play the demo and see the game before buying it. It won't please everyone. You should also be willing to put time into it as each game takes time to progress and it is hard to learn without experiencing it. If you don't know what you're doing you can take excessive risk (and lose) or do too little (gets dull). Once you can see the full picture it's a good game, not a great game.

Thea 2 is more polished than Thea 1 but it could really do with some of the wildness back in to make it less predictable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970926048', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1190, 'last_played': 1581913315}
review:
Where the challenges in the first game were fun because they were difficult, the challenges in the second game are annoying because they are chaotic.  I really like the visual updates and the performance of the game is spot on. I adore that I can decide where my village settles down, but I detest the spawn mechanics of this iteration.  Existing mechanics I once thought of as quirky, I now see as halting because I expected a sequel to improve on them, like it did with the quality of visual design.  Ultimately, it is missing the feeling of exploring a bleak vastness that really made me appreciate surviving in the wilds in the first game.  

Mostly I am just disappointed.  Happy to have bought the game though, as I did have fun; but get the first one instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031021712', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20582, 'last_played': 1665286075}
review:
The Thea series represents an evolution of the 4X genre that focuses on exploration above all else, and devotes the mechanics of the game to serving that desire to uncover the world's hidden secrets and discover interesting ways to surmount challenges and use resources.

Styled like a tradition turn-based strategy game, Thea 2 has a hex grid, and units that have movement modified by the terrain. The terrain itself includes resources, hills, oceans, enemy settlements, neutral towns, and a variety of other things to find on journey. The biggest difference is that you don't claim the land. You can build a village, though the number of villages you can have is very tightly controlled, and the world outside your town walls can never truly become yours. You don't own the world; you live in it.
The units themselves are not limited to soldiers, either. There are farmers, religious leaders, animals, and even children. They band together with their own individual names, stats, and equipment, because they represent the people, the entirety of your tiny population. It elevates the stakes of a deadly world and fosters an emotional connection with each randomly generated character.
The resources are used in one of my personal favorite crafting systems I've ever seen. rather than calling for specific resources, recipes call for types of resources, and the specific resources used change the resulting item. I only need to discover the recipe for swords to make swords out of Iron or Ancient Wood, but one sword might deal more damage, or deal bonus damage to injured targets.
Conflict, including combat, is played out on a separate, 4-row board where the characters are placed, using their relevant stats and abilities to go up against monsters, fallen rocks, or the concept of rationality, depending on the nature of the conflict. This lets all those individual characters and the bonus granted by their equipment shine in their individual realms of expertise. Couple this with the fact that most conflicts can be avoided or altered by the right combination of stats, abilities, and choices, and the possibilities seem fairly limitless.
Altering conflicts happens in events, which play out a bit like miniature choose-your-own-adventure stories staring the people of your village where the available options change depending on things like whether or not you have a hunter in your group or how many members of your group have good Perception. These scenes range from getting ambushed by wild boars, to talking a dragon out of treasure, to finding a child in a cabbage patch, and an overwhelming plethora of other things. This makes each game a unique story tailored to the randomly generated characters.
If you want an experience that can be fully completed, Thea's near limitlessness may become a frustration, though there is a main story line that can be finished, so the game can be beaten, and with a very comprehensive difficulty customizer, you can easily get the exact level and type of challenge you're looking for.
On the other hand, if you want to discover, this game has endless depths to be plumbed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198178140450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 152018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 467, 'playtime_at_review': 54460, 'last_played': 1711877034}
review:
Для тех кто не хочет читать кучу буков внизу, а хочет просто узнать чужой совет о данной игре.

ДАННАЯ ИГРА МЕНЯ РАЗОЧАРОВАЛА И ЕСЛИ ВЫ ВПЕРВЫЕ РЕШИЛИ СЫГРАТЬ В "Thea", МОЙ ВАМ СОВЕТ, КУПИТЕ ПЕРВУЮ ЧАСТЬ. ВЫ ПОЛУЧИТЕ КУДА КАК БОЛЬШЕ УДОВОЛЬСТВИЯ.

Как не прискорбно это осознавать, но мое терпение кончилось и я больше не могу давать никаких авансов данной игре. Но все по порядку.
Во-первых, скажу что я фанат первой части и была в восторге когда анонсировали вторую часть. Следила за разработкой. Купила игру в первые же дни релиза. А теперь даже жалею об этом...
По моему скромному мнению разработчики тупо погнались за деньгами совершенно утратив суть первой части. Начнем с самого начала с черт бога: как по мне развитие богов в первой части куда более захватывающее, хоть идея покупки черт достаточна интересна, их количество мало, а  разнообразие удручает. Далее идет выбор избранного. Ну здесь дело идет ни шатко, ни валко, просто с моей точки зрения было бы куда интереснее выбирать основную расу, а не отдельного юнита. Это бы хорошо показало концепцию различных островов (да это бы потребовало куда большего объема разработки. Ну уж простите, я заплатила цену равную цене куда более проработанной игры, так что могу жаловаться). Далее идут острова с ними в общем-то все неплохо, но эта вечная проблема с ресурсами. Которая по мне решается вполне просто и даже двумя путями. Хотите уникальные острова, да, пожалуйста, создайте и проработайте кучу рецептов с уникальными для каждого острова и его набора ресурсов. Это требует слишком много усилий? Ладно, тогда сделайте чтоб на каждом острове были все ресурсы просто каких-то много, а каких-то мало(в плоть до всего лишь единственного экземпляра).
Далее идут квесты, именно то за что и любят мир Thea. Да очень приятно увидеть последствия принятых решений, но на этом и все. Основной квест или условие победы это вообще ужас. Может я делаю что-то не так, но я умудряюсь пройти главный квест по статистике увидев только 1% от имеющихся историй. При этом, пройдя, кучу повторов, да и выбрав все возможные в них ответы. Так что уважаемые разработчики если уж вы не смогли написать длинную вдумчивую историю, так растяните квест искусственно, что бы дальнейшие шаги появлялись через больший промежуток времени и между ними могло появиться больше рандомных событий.
Так теперь очередь сражений. Ну к ним и в первой части были претензии в сложности. Как не странно боевая система второй части куда легче, но при этом и сложнее чем в первой. Просчитать исход того или иного действия стало легче, но вот у меня выпали все стрелки или только бойцы ближнего боя(что чаще) и как их использовать в шести клетка т.е. в трех для ближнего боя и победить, ума не приложу. Также, не знаю, у меня одной изменение ползунка скорости боя ни на что не влияют? (причем самое интересное, что в ранних версиях бой ускорялся)
Ну и под конец игровой процесс в общем. И тут для меня все совсем печально. Ведь, задумайтесь, с даты релиза прошло полгода(не EA, а именно релиза законченной вроде как игры), но у меня лично баги вылетают каждый третий запуск игры.
Некоторые враги просто застывают на одном месте и больше не двигаются, ресурсы то неожиданно появляются из ниоткуда(на что я в общем-то не жалуюсь), то исчезают(а вот это грустно). То герои с кучей здоровья внезапно дохнут, а слабак с 1 выживает. Ну ладно тут я могу перечислять кучу всего. Обобщим тем что багов куча и маленькая тележка. Ирония данной ситуации в том, что даже после окончания поддержки первой игры в ней остались баги(ну ладно, не баги, а неприятные шероховатости, но все же).
В итоге скажу, что пока главным достоинством для меня в игре является карта, но этого как-то маловато для восторга. И вернись я назад в прошлое не купила бы игру даже в память о первой части. И меня терзают смутные сомнения что игра так и останется в этом каком-то промежуточном виде. Если честно у меня складывается впечатление, что если над первой частью работала группа увлеченных энтузиастов и благодаря этой энергии они решили выпустить вторую часть. То сейчас они в стадии творческого кризиса и застоя. Надеюсь я не права и запустив игру через пол годика открою для себя новый шедевр.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079294145', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 9836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7439, 'last_played': 1684947470}
review:
aillant farmé théa premier du nom, je m'était préparé de longue date a accueillir le second opus. et je n'ai pas était déçu. reprenant de nombreuses méchanique du premier jeu en les rendant plus adictives encore, le jeu s'ouvres en plus aux modeurs de tout poils qui se font un plaisir de rendre l'expérience encore plus fun qu'elle ne l'était déjà en changeant les règle et ajoutant du contenu.
le crafting est prenant surtout sachant que chaque type d'object a son propre design et nom suivant le matériel de craft utiliser. ce qui peut entrainé des cas ou tu a presque plus envie de crafté un truc moins fort, mais qui pue le style. ou se forcé a avoir un matériel de craft T5 spécifique pour se faire une armure sublime digne des dieu. et c'est là le seul petit point noir, le jeu si tu t'y implique et commence a farmé pour avoir du vrai matos cool, peut être très long, et une fois le village de départ placer sur une zone abondante en ressource avec un point de charbon nécéssaire pour fusioné du matériel de craft en matériel du Tiers supérieur, alors il peut se passé presque 200 tour a ne faire que crafté et miné des ressources. mais ça c'est si vous rushez pas le jeu en finissant a la vavite la quète divine et la quète des illuminé qui peuvent au final être assez facile a faire dés lors qu'on a un matériel a peine du tiers trois ou quatre un peu bon, et des personnages aillant assez tuer.
le jeu est chronophage, mais fun, et j'espère un jour voir popé un DLC pour ajouté encore de nombreuses quètes post endgame comme avec théâ premier du nom avec le retour des géants. par exemple de nouvelles iles plus hard avec enfin des ressources de T3 voir T4 que l'on puisse minné, ou des créatures plus puissante encore que les dragon et les géants... même si il y a peu de chance.
bref c'est un excellent jeu pour passé le temps et se sentir maitre d'une troupe de héro lier par un dieu tout puissant pour sa renaissance et le sauvetage du monde! et aussi un jeu fun si votre kiff c'est le craft a outrance jusqu'à avoir une team dont chaque membre vaut un dieu en combat singulier façon skyrim ultra modé avec armure cheaté, parce qu'un guerrier en armure lourde tout en "coeur du monde", ça pue quand même le style!

author: {'steamid': '76561198071650701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 20753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8998, 'last_played': 1688150844}
review:
Great game. Major case of Civ style one more turn syndrome. There is a bit of a steep learning curve which can make the game seem unfair but believe me when I say it feels a lot better once you learn what is good and what is not. Just as a tip, healing at villages is really helpful to get past some tougher fights. Also elves, specifically elven mages are quite powerful, almost over powered. An elven mage with ground shake witch scales off destiny will constantly get permanent  destiny increases if you spend any time on the elven island due to the amazing forest fires and depressed bandits. This can scale to ludicrous, one shot everything levels in the late game. 
Also as an added bonus the event system allows you to simply change things that you really don't like, for example there is one town event in which your town is raided scavengers who steal your stuff and make you chase them down to get it back. It is not a hard event but it repeats what feels like every 5 turns. So I set it to only happen once per campaign, and hey presto problem solved by ticking a single box. Not everything is as easy as this but any event can be changed if you have enough time on your hands. Just remember to make back ups. Don't just start changing things and ruin your game. 

TL;DR good game, elves op, please no nerf though, I like playing harmony gods.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009337703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1941, 'last_played': 1691606106}
review:
Really interesting X4 story-rich RPG game specially for those who like East-European folklore. 

However it is rather rough on the edges specially in the late game (250+ rounds). To me it feels like this game is still in the late stage of early access. 

There are a number of mods I can only recommend to use that add more content and a number of quality of life improvements to keep you going beyond 300 rounds: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1808226295

But the developers are still working on addressing that issue so it may get resolved in the feature after another 1 or 2 (hopefully free) DLCs.

All in all I recommend to try the Demo first and then buy the game on sale if you like the game play and story overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088352478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8787, 'last_played': 1587578453}
review:
Man. Thea 2. After looking at some other reviews I've decided to keep this short and sweet. This game feels incomplete and lacking in many areas, while they are one of the only games I've played with unique aspects and mechanics(crafting system, event editor), it feels like an early access game that has a lot of potential. I suggest waiting until more updates come out, to me it feels like a 7/10. 


To those interested still:

I play this game a lot offline but probably only 300-500 hours total. I've also played Thea 1 and other 4x games. If your looking for a challenge with lots of mechanics to learn then you'd honestly like this game, but personally I like to chill and grind for months. If your like me I highly recommend mods. Sadly I tried to get into the event editor but not enough tutorials out there for it and it also feels like there's parts to it hidden thus not being interactive. It's honestly a great game that could provide a lot of content. If you have any questions feel free to ask

author: {'steamid': '76561198083935924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 32421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26506, 'last_played': 1594862261}
review:
This game is on the verge of being really good, but there are key issues that make it unplayable after the start.

First, the good things. I like how the combat is card based(like Magic the gathering). There has also been a lot of work developing gods, races, abilities, weapons, armor, and resources. There are a few good early quests and the storyline is okay.


here's my key issues:

1. No real endgame, and it takes too long to achieve. For example, you build a town. it may have a few good resources, but not all of the ones needed to craft weapons/armor you need to progress to the endgame. So you inevitably end up clicking for an hour through turns trying to get characters and town built up so you can safely send out a team to get needed resources.

This is very tedious. The demon who guards the town should be extremely strong, but limit his fighting range to town only. Allow for the building of towers that fire boulders and such so the town with a demon can be safe while the main group is off exploring.

2. The difficulty in getting "monster" kids is hard enough, but what's more frustrating is getting stuck with an orc craftsman when you want a slugger. Should not be difficult to get your 1st orc slugger(etc). make it harder to get the 2nd, but not being able to play the classes you want isnt fun. way too much failure in getting good classes early in the game.

3. many of us like starting with a warrior as a main character, but dont want to be human. make an orc slugger or dwarven warrior options. Give them penalties that disappear over time if they are too overpowered at start, but they need to be options.

4. many of the god traits are underwhelming. Some are good, some are just ridiculously bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972950234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 36631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20792, 'last_played': 1675213355}
review:
Overall, I like and enjoyed the game.

I wish it had done more to surpass Thea 1, however. The game feels a lot like an expanded Thea 1, as it shares most of the systems, but I feel this left me with a lot of deja-vu, and not too many new things to learn or problems to solve. 

But I can't at all suggest that this game isn't as good or better than Thea 1, and is more polished, so I would recommend it to anyone who either didn't play Thea 1 or who would like to play Thea 1 again, but with a different story and new mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038718638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5635, 'last_played': 1570651851}
review:
I really loved the first Thea: The Awakening and also the DLC. In best hope for a good successor I bought the second part and have to say that it´s not really bad, but much worse than the first part. A lot of really great ideas, but not well implemented and right now really bad balanced.

Pro:
-Nice story
-Sometimes you can choose between several options in a dialogue that really have consequences.
-Mod support!
-good individualization of your characters (attributes, traits, class)
-Position of your village is up to you

Contra:
-until you know the story line you will often run into decissions of a pattern like 1. fight a battle that you will lose, resulting in the loss of many members of your group or your complete group. 2. loose your whole group or several members instantly.

-Items useless: you can craft a ton of different weapons and armours, depending on the skill and ingredients, but you will end up using only two or three different recipes. i.e., early in the game you can craft books out of scaled or mythical leather, which are the best items for spellcasters in the game. I simply didn´t find any recipe/item for my spellcasters that´s more effective. Everything else you will find or craft is then trashed due to lack of use.

-Item weight unbalanced: the weights of the items doesn´t make any sense to me. A book has roughly the same weight as a sword or two-handed axe.

-Items unbalanced: I was unable to train a fighter that hits harder than my spellcasters with their books. I mostly stuck to spellcasters with books and hunters with bows. Everything else was so much weaker that I didn´t use them in any challenge, making roughly 80+% of the item tech tree useless. The same is for the ressources tree - you only need two of the six ressource groups two craft armour, books and bows.

-Why so many character classes?: you have three different challenges: fighting, talking, magic. Only hunters and the spellcasters are able to deal with all three effectively, and with better performance than every other class. i.e. hunters do much more damage in fighting challenges than fighters, and with higher flexibility. Fighters are pretty much useless in two of the three challenge typs, while hunters and spellcasters are not. I also would like to have more difference between the characters: i.e., there is no real difference between healers, witches and wise people. They are all spellcasters and differ only in details of their stats. Outside of some really few challenges also the race of the character is pretty much unimportant, be it an orc, dwarf, human, ghost or demon.

-Grinding: High tier ressources give the best items. If you really want to have a heavy armour made out of the highest tier materials, you will need dozens of turns to gather materials from a lower tier und convert them up to high tier material. In a normal gameplay you don´t need these items. Because you can only get them in the late game, you will have high level characters. Their performance in challenges is mostly depending on their stats, not on their equipment (and their class, as I described before). The only task of your village is to give boosts to crafting and gathering, enhancing the production of high tier materials. Don´t get me wrong - it still needs dozens of turns to craft the equipment of ONE villager out of high tier materials, hundreds for a complete group. 

-nothing to do: while your grinding for ressoucres in your village, there is nearly nothing to do. You can run around and kill groups of enemies, which is always the same and therefore extremely repetitive, giving few XP and more or less useless ressources. The quests of the different factions are only search and destroy or deliver some ressources, the story line is pretty short and no challenge for trained characters (equiped with books and bows from early game). This means, all you can do is grinding for XP and wait. Boring as hell.

-Fighting: Nice, unique fighting system, BUT: as I said before, you only need two classes. Everything you do in combat is spam out your hunters and spellcasters. Hunters usually only need one hit to kill most enemies and are the first so strike. Your spellcasters only need two spells, icelance (hitting one enemy with extreme damage) oder random blast (hitting two enemies with very high damage). Because of lacking balancing there is no need to do anything else without making every challenge harder for you. 

My suggestions for improving the game:
-get rid of the grinding aspect, before everything else. Make sure that you can get high tier ressources from enemy groups, quests, merchants, direct gathering and so on.

-rebalance the weapons and characters, making every character usefull in its own way. Right now, there is no point in training or recruiting anyone else than spellcasters or hunters.

-make the different races unique. In the first Thea, I was always happy to have an orc or elf, because they were high performer in their own, special way. Now I don´t really notice anything of them.

-Give me a reason to build the village if I don´t want to grind. Honestly, there is no need to settle down if you´re interested in anything else than clicking the end turn button again and again.

There is so much potential, you have such a lot of really great ideas, now make sure that they form together a game that is really fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065513913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 17965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1405, 'last_played': 1635674261}
review:
Кому понравилась предыдущая часть, тот купит эту не читая обзоры и будет прав.
Кто не играл, настоятельно советую пройти сначала первую часть. Конечно, сюжет The Awakening нам кратко перескажут в диалогах (но самому быть свидетелем тех событий всё-таки интереснее). А вот освоиться с игровыми возможностями посложнее будет. Здесь возможностей раза в три больше, и игра их сразу вываливает на на тебя. И очень поможет, если уже знаешь базовую механику. В общем, The Shattering напрямую продолжает The Awakening как по сюжету, так и по игровому процессу. Грубо говоря, в Thea: The Awakening мы начали в заботливо поставленной нашим богом в идеальных условиях деревне, исследовали мир, знакомились с его обитателями и законами. А в Thea 2: The Shattering нас с ходу бросают в мир, нет времени понимать кто есть кто и что происходит; деревни нет, её надо основать самому, а для этого самому придётся выбрать место, и хорошо, если ты помнишь, что в этом месте должна быть древесина и два разных вида еды, и какие профессии жизненно важны, и что строить в первую очередь.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043757982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3625, 'last_played': 1701013068}
review:
Bon, soyons clair, cette suite n'est pas comparable à Thea the awakening.

Je ne sais pas qu'elle note mettre a ce jeu.. elle oscille entre 2/20 et 18/20. Pourquoi ? L'exemple est a la fin du post.

Points positifs:
Graphisme beau ++
Ambiance sonore très sympas ++
Richesse d'events +++
Richesse d'équipement +++
Gameplay original +++
Histoire intéressante ++
Difficulté modulable (DIEU MERCI) +++
Workshop ++

Le jeu me plait pour ces points, il est beau cool digne d'être la suite de Thea 1. Mais il y a 3 points vraiment très noir qui pénalisent atrocement le jeu et qui au final lui font perdre toute sa superbe  et un dernier point qui est facultatif mais qui est le rêve de tous:

Points négatifs ils sont 3 majeurs dont 1 le premier qui détruit le jeu, tout simplement.

1) Le premier, le pire et celui qui détruit le jeu à mon goût: l'équilibrage économique. Désolé mais il n'est pas bon. 
Il faut des quantités astronomique de ressource de tier 2 pour fabriquer des équipements de bon niveau (T5  ou T6 mais T6 j'ai même pas testé vu la quantité de ressource demandé pour le T5.. T4 étant a peine meilleur que l'équipement qu'on peut récupérer dans les loots ) ou du moins qui rendent la partie jouable (sans créer de village je parle, uniquement en étant nomade).

2) Farming de ressource: Dépendant du premier point, le jeu se résume actuellement à récolter récolter récolter récolter récolter. C'est un minecraft au tour par tour. Donc a part faire passer les tours y'a rien d'autre. Et c'est très rapidement chiant du fait du niveau de die and retry du jeu.

Et dans la continuité la transformation de ressource: Une fois avoir amassé les ressources de tiers 1-2 ou a la rigueur 3 il faut les améliorer pour avoir de l'équipement de qualité moyenne. Et beaucoup pour avoir un équipement de bonne qualité. Et massivement pour avoir un équipement de qualité ultime. ET LA TRANSFORMATION ne dépend UNIQUEMENT que d'une ressource de combustion le charbon. Autre point négatif..

3) Les combats de type "Sanity": sauvegarder à chaque tour, c'est l'unique conseil que je peux vous donner pour contrer ça. J'ai déjà perdu plus de 60% des membres de mon groupe parce que après un échec avec grave blessure (pas défaite totale) les chances pour que les compagnons se barrent sont terriblement haute. Et si cela se passe, soit vous aviez sauvegardé soit vous pouvez recommencer. Ridicule au final, un compromis excellent aurait été le retrait de ces personnages dans tout type de combat pendant quelque tours (10 par exemple), ils ont le moral a 0 donc ils participent à rien. Plus logique que le départ en solo de ces péons dans un monde apocalyptique. C'est un non sens pour ma part..

4) Créer son village. 
En ayant compris que tout est basé sur la récolte ET le charbon, il faut trouver un spot où planter son village avec AU MINIMUM:
1 bois T1, 2 sources de nourriture différente (végétal/animal), 1 charbon, 2 ressources T1 ou T2 différente dans un rayon maximal de 3 hexagones.
Ca c'est pour les ressources. Maintenant le personnel:

2 récolteurs, 2 guerriers, 1 docteur, 1 magicien de classe violet et un autre jaune, 2 crafters. Donc 9 personnes au minimum pour garantir une défense précaire mais acceptable. 
J'en suis a 1033 tours et je n'ai que 22 personnages et 1 animal. Créer un village a ce niveau du jeu est pratiquement impossible vu le niveau des groupes de monstre et les conditions requises. Ou est l'équilibrage ? Et j'ai entendu dire qu'on peut créer 2 villages ? Mais les gens doivent jouer combien de tours dans ce jeu 2000 ? 3000 ?


Voila c'est à peu près tout. Les points négatifs sont bien moins nombreux que les positifs et un seul suffit à masquer tous les points positifs.

Je recommande le jeu car il est bien, vraiment bien mais un équilibrage de la récolte s'impose car il détruit le jeu. On passe son temps à passer les tours pour récolter et transformer. C'est chiant et linéaire. 

Voici un exemple simple du niveau de ridicule en ce qui concerne la récolte: 
Spiky gathering tool (meilleur item de récolte): 30 spike leather
2 Spike leather (3 points de recherche): 5 mythical leather (2 points de recherche) + 5 dragon bone (2 points de recherche)
2 mythical leather: 12 leathers de rang 2 (1pts de recherche par type de cuir)
2 dragon bone: 12 bones de rang 2 (idem pts de recherche).

7 points de recherche minimum, 11 pour être plus efficace, 13 pour être optimal.

Donc le calcul c'est pour UN SEUL item de récolte de qualité "parfaite" il faut:
75 mythical leather et 75 dragon bone qui proviennent chacun de:
456 cuir de rang 2 ET 456 os de rang 2.
Pour craft tout cela il faut également 165 charbon. Un total de 1077 ressource pour UN SEUL item de récolte. Sachant que le jeu entier est dépendant de la récolte. Dans Thea the awakening il en fallait de mémoire 5 nimblewood, 5 branchettes et 2 charbon et moins de 10 points de recherche pour le meilleur item de récolte...

J'ai dans ma partie actuelle besoin de 8 outils comme celui la, cela représente donc 8616 ressources à récolter pourquoi faire ? Pour pouvoir récolter plus vite.. et j'ai calculé grossièrement le nombre de tours que cela représente à mon niveau actuel de récolte: plus de 200, 200 tours a simplement taper entrée.. Non j'en suis triste et déçu. Et je précise que j'ai même pas d'équipement de niveau T5 ou T6 a plus de 1000 tours.

Le jeu a un potentiel immense, plus grande que Thea 1 mais le fail total de l'économie le rends boiteux. Une mise a jour ou un mod rectifiant cela est nécessaire pour pouvoir prendre son pied a ce jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117247340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2867, 'last_played': 1580892976}
review:
I loved Thea: The Awakening. I love MuHa Games. I love the rogue-like elements, but if you're looking for a true successor to the original game, this is not it. Honestly, this feels like it could be DLC for the original.

My issues with the game are as follows:
1. Pacing
2. Exploration vs. plot
3. Combat
4. City building

1. Early leveling vs. late game leveling can be pretty rough because the challenge difficulty seems to ramp up like crazy from the early to mid game. I got absolutely destroyed the first couple times i got past level 10 because generally the challenges seemed to get way harder all of a sudden. Also the main story line feels really short this time. The same could be said about the god  quest line too. It was like suddenly it was over and the final fights for each didn't feel particularly special or memorable.

2. A lot of the the issues with exploring being fun are alleviated with the pangea map. But for me at least the biggest fun-sucker-outer is the mini-map. the version that's currently in the game (1/3/2020) automatically shows the entire continental layout, including biomes. It lets you beeline to places without ever having been there before. and makes it super easy to finish quests. I really feel like they could take a page out of Civilizations book with the fog of war/growing map. it would add a lot to the game.

3. In the original Thea we had two health bars. in Thea 2 we have three. Honestly, it's too much balancing to be worth it for the devs and the players IMO. Now you've gotta keep characters for magic, social and melee, because if you lose in any of the three categories you're dead. The card system is already super deep, I really don't think it was necessary or added anything but confusion for new players. it also adds more research into an already bloated equipment tree.

4.Is there any reason too? to be honest, it doesn't really make sense to split your group up. also the buildings that used to strengthen your people and protect them against enemies are all gone. no more wall that gives your settlement extra defense, no more idol that gives characters magical protection against the forces that assail you. Just a weaka** watchtower that increases health and sanity. A few buildings that dribble in resources, and a little extra research from a school. Honestly, it feels so weak to build a city, and it also makes the game super grindy if you do. Instead of being able to explore the world or build cool buildings, I found myself desperately grinding T2 and T3 resources so that I could make T4 resources to make gear or buildings. The problem is that it literally take hundreds of turns to get enough resources to make a single piece of gear that's worthwhile. 

Do I like this game? yes, but I'd recommend the first one to friends over this.

I want to take a quick moment now that I've gotten all the achievements to talk about non-pangea maps. when I first heard about this game and saw the trailer that showed different continents I was super pumped because I thought it was gonna add a lot to exploration and give some diversity to the map. It did, but at the cost of making travel super tedious. There are no monsters in the oceans. there's only three events that I found in 1k+ tiles of sailing around. That's literally over an hour+ of gameplay where the most interesting thing happening is running into so sirens. There's also no reward for going to the edge of the map. Just endless ocean. I wish the world was either flat (had an edge) or spherical (wrapped, so if you went left far enough you'd come out on the right). TBH I think it would have been sick if the world was flat, there could be pieces slowly coming of and the longer it take the less world there is left to save. But I really think there needed to be ocean monsters, or something needed to be done to make ocean travel/ exploration fun, because honestly, it wasn't fun :( I just found myself hoping to get back to shore as soon as possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039812292', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1238, 'last_played': 1575493622}
review:
Where Thea Awakening ends this game pick up and continue after some time passed in game.

If you like survival turnbased strategies you will like this one too.

You can divide game in several parts - one is story which is nicely created and uses a lot from slavic mythology....

Another one is survial and building of your town and your characters - you need to discover materials, gather them then train your builders and then create epic iems for your party - but ofcourse takes time.

Last part of grame is combat and chalenges - there if you like you can play each combat/chalenge by yourself in foor this game specific card fight (your characters have some attack some HP/mystic/stamina which are used in rows against oponent)  - there is possible to skip a lot of combat/chalenges by using autoresolve if you find them boring.

As a lot of simillar strategies it could become boring during time but you have several Gods which allow you different replay and story. When I would compare it to some game it is same as playing HeroesofMightandMagic strategy or Civilization.

So game is ideal for slow peaced approach when you have time and want to relax.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013079289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 12565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12553, 'last_played': 1581751025}
review:
This is a good game despite some negative reviews I've seen. The story builds on the first Thea game so you get a nice feeling of continuity if you play them in order. The combat system in the first was more fun (in my opinion) but it was also much easier to "game" so you rarely lost. So...

Pros:
- Great story that builds on the first game
- Graphics and interface are much better than the first game
- Crafting...omg, lots of crafting
- Extensive "science" tree to unlock through research...it's big... 1000 turns was insufficient to unlock everything
- Huge maps, the world feels expansive
- A more challenging combat system than the first game. You will be forced to compose your party carefully or suffer for it. There are three different damage types with three separate Life bars. You party has to be able to deal with all of them.
- Very reasonable price, especially if you buy it in a bundle like i did. This is a big one. Alot of value at the price point
- Character art is amazing. The details are hilarious, 
*Bonus* At least one Monty Python reference

Cons:
- The game slowed down a bit on my midrange gaming computer after i got past turn 1000. Never crashed though
- The original combat system was unique and a bit more fun. Most of the negative reviews i've seen are complaining about this. Not a deal breaker
- Could use more content or a longer main quest line. I was able to beat the game before getting top level gear. 
- The "You were robbed" event needs to be a one off event... easy to resolve...but boring after it pops up the 20th time
- Needs a wider range of random events
- A tutorial on crafting materials needs to be added the the existing tutorial
- Game progression should not be based on the turn count. I found that if you spent too much time crafting and harvesting, the monster progression got out of control fast.

This is a good game. Buy The bundle and play em both.

author: {'steamid': '76561198217344511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 23831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14829, 'last_played': 1656990173}
review:
Thea 2 doesn't feel like a successor of Thea: Awakening.

You know, I really want to like Thea 2: The Shattering. I've poured over 250 hours into the game through Beta till this writing but it's not the kinks it's just the feel of the game I have an issue with. The RNG doesn't bother me, gaining an Orc Matriarch is sweet, but overall I can't help but keep comparing this game to Thea: Awakening which I love. 

So maybe that's my downfall and reason for my down vote. 

Anyways, Thea 2: The Shattering feels like any other table top 4X TBS game. The story isn't compelling the encounters are lackluster, and though I do enjoy Conan and Goblin Slayer, not-so-subtle, references the events are kinda boring. It's like the money broke the game. Sure it's cleaner, more user friendly and has a variable learning curve depending on your difficulty setting but it's not the Thea I fell in love with in the original game.  

But to remove the nostalgia, there isn't much to the game that would distinguish it from it's peers in the TBS 4X space. The learning curve isn't steep at all.

Play in the dark Fantasy world of Thea:Awakening for some engaging late night fun. Or kill some time with the Vanilla Thea 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964992623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1585, 'last_played': 1695668847}
review:
Not as good as Thea: The Awakening.

It truly is a difficult follow-up on a very succesfull game, where the creators had to make som changes to the game but still keep the soul of it. 

The biggest issue is the new combat-system. They should have kept the original system. The new system is just to... Difficult to put your finger on it, but it sucks. 

Sailing is an interesting addition, but as in all other games of this type sailing gets old pretty fast fx. Heroes of might and magic. But this gets solved with a patch. 

Resources are weirdly advanced. Getting to top tier is not a goal. 

GUI has fixed a lot of issues from The Awakening. Overview screens and so on, but the neatness from the Awakening is gone. The GUI design (Color, placement and size) isn't that great. 

All in all - some good new features and a few bad ones. Unfortunately the bad ones seem to out weight the good ones. Understandable decisions by the creators, but they just didn't work that well in reality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014863727', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 3248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1802, 'last_played': 1568862120}
review:
As much as I expected to like this game, and even though in many ways it's richter than the original, after some time trying I've realized that it is overall less fun: It's frustrating in all the wrong ways.

Most importantly, it's clear that the developers *never* got feedback from real outsiders. Game and UI choices that kill the game would have been noticed within an hour's play by somebody not already steeped in the game.

The main map icons for ruins, quest locations, and incidental goals have no legend - ok, that's just unnecessary learning curve - but there is absolutely no provision, while looking at the map, for finding out *which* location is which. You have to go there and enter it, and hope that the encounter options give you the chance to back out. Most especially, the difference between "there's a vermin nest, could you clear it out" and "your next main-plot goal is a cavern full of high-level bandits who will TPW you without an option to back out", when they might well spawn in adjacent hexes, is more than a little necessary.

Perhaps worse, since there are workarounds (like manual saves, which just waste a few minutes of your time each attempt) for that, there are critical design-level balance flaws. It is entirely possible to have a decent early game and then discover that the further parts of the map have RNG-driven crippling issues, or to have a too-strong wandering group spawn where it blocks progress. So you can have 80 hours of work wasted at random, and all you have to show for it is a handful of "god points" (long-term progression).

I should also mention the badly tuned God Point system, which was already a problem in the original game and is now worse, but which you can work around with by modding or by using the built-in editing tools in a trivial way (there's a video showing how). There are many many things to unlock, with the trivial costing 2-5 points and the significant costing 25, and even a wildly successful playthrough (which took at least 40 hours, mind you) will net around 10-15 points. 400 hours of play, even with no failed runs, will not unlock everything. So, instead of a long-term progression mechanic (like in, say, Slay the Spire), this becomes a blocking gateway in front of what's basically a perk-selection mechanic (like in Pillars: Deadfire) - but unlocking the perks takes far too much time and effort given how few you can apply to a given game.

One final note: While the new combat system is a great deal richer than the original, it's also much more tedious than the original. I find myself just hitting the "autoresolve" button every time because I don't want to deal with it - and since without that the game is 80% resource grind, 15% hitting autoresolve, and 5% reading story, that's a big problem too. In this case I am pretty sure that the desire/need to use only language-independent icons on the combat screen is most at fault; a better designed UI featuring clear (localized) text might have rescued it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961372576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1555990748}
review:
Even without getting to the complaints of the negative reviews from players who got further into the game than I, I'd have to recommend against Thea 2 just because the new combat system sucks all of the joy out of it.

I loved Thea 1, and while the card combat mechanic did get tiring because of how simple it was relative to how often you had to do it, it was really crisp with plays that felt really meaningful.  In Thea 2, the combat is sluggish and unenjoyable.  It feels slow.  Effects that aren't simply damage feel really weak and underutilized, and even then the game will periodically throw you into special battles where most of those effects further get stripped out.

The worst part of the resolution mechanic, however, is that it's really hard to read and anticipate how it'll resolve.  In Thea 1 the visible lining up of the cards made how things were going to play out really clear.  In Thea 2 you're playing actions with an action speed that gets modified by how soon in the combat you play it.  These speeds get added to a timeline to determine in what order they get resolved, and then may be further modified by effects once in play.  It's a lot harder to quickly sort out what is going to happen and make plays, and the consequences of getting it wrong can be severe.

I really hate to downvote this game because Thea 1 was a unique gem.  It had a really eclectic build of fighting, exploration, crafting, and fantastic storytelling that came together to be extremely compelling.  In Thea 2, however, the conflict resolution mechanic that is so unenjoyable that I can't bring myself to keep playing to see more of the delightful world they've built.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074671653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 15123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1703, 'last_played': 1707348882}
review:
Very mixed, as I loved Thea 1 and like Thea 2. It has improved since its initial release. And...thumbs down.

This has all of the right components to be a great game. 
- Lots of resources, upgrades, crafting trees, city improvements, etc.
- A unique and reasonably high learning curve to figure out the combat system, both challenging and rewarding
- Slavic mythology (although Thea 1 was definitely more engaging with the storyline)

That said, there are TWO fatal flaws that cause me to rule thumbs down.
- SLOW GRIND with the God Points. The ONLY reason I re-installed this again was the mod that enabled all god point options. It would take hundreds of hours of gameplay just to unlock the top tier Gods, let alone the top tier perks. (such as Goblin Shaman)
- No real community. Tried looking for a Thea 2 Crafting Guide? What are the best spells/abilities? Compare Thea 2's wiki/community to Thea 1's. There is no real community around this game. 

Things that have improved since my original review are the interface (although I still really dislike having to cycle through resolution settings every time I start the game), turn speed, and a slightly better sense of balance than a year ago.

As I said originally, I do wish I could recommend this game. But the Devs have said "We're done," and unfortunately they did not listen to the multitude of community feedback that was offered. 

Had there been a decent wiki and crafting guide, that would have tipped my vote to a Yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148733921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2774, 'last_played': 1605478142}
review:
As a person, who spent eons of time on Thea the Awakening after playing Shattering for almost 50 hrs in I can tell that there are a couple of features that I am missing desperately. 

Things I lack from the previous game:
1. The resources actually mattered in the previous game from the start and defined your gameplay in a major way, so the material you used in crafting bore more significance (i.e. Elf Wood gave bonus to dex, myth to tactics, dragonbone gave you ll etc)
2. Limitation for resource spawning per island, in Awakening your settlement could spawn near top-tier recourse and you needed to manage your workforce and find the best ballance between gatherers and crafters and warriors to survive till the time you can benefit from the resource (i.e. If you were located near the Elf Wood you were sure to go for elfs, if by a huuuge luck you would have steel or mythril spawned near your settlement that would be insane luck). Each playthrough was very unique because of that. In Shattering the setup is just different and I feel like it takes away from replayability. 
3. Pantheon progression: It was an amazing feature to unlock the gods as you play and level them up. I really enjoyed it, I loved it tbh and I reset my profile dozens of time to play with not leveled gods, to see them progress. I think that approach implemented currently in the game is more "casual". I prefer an old one.

Though I desperately lack these features and the level of replayability they gave the game I would like to point out an exceptional quality of MuHa games products, professionalism of their team and the way guys work with community. If to weight this game separately I do think it is a decent product easily worth it's cost, so I give a game thumbs up, because I feel like a lot of negative reviews are there because of expectations after Thea Awakening were skyhigh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009526949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 7212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6309, 'last_played': 1570621788}
review:
Edit: the Pangea update changes the layout of the map, but there is still no fog of war and resource locations are still very predictable. I will not update the rest of the review, but keep that in mind.

First off, this is NOT A 4X GAME. I don't know why it keeps getting labelled as such, but players expecting real 4X gameplay are going to be disappointed. If you're looking for a unique RPG / survival / strategy experience (that's also pretty damn difficult with a steep learning curve), though, you'll probably like this.

I've enjoyed this far more than the first Thea (which felt too easy and got repetitive too quickly), and there are many changes and additions I really like. It still feels slightly unfinished but is very playable and the Workshop support is a fantastic improvement over Thea 1. If there's something you want, or don't like, there's a decent chance someone made a mod for that very thing.

Some players consider Thea 2 too grindy, and I disagree. Because while you CAN click end turn 50 times and just sit there crafting or researching for the full 50 turns, world progression will punish you and I don't think you're supposed to play that way. The game is much more enjoyable if you embrace the challenge and only craft the handful of things you really NEED, right now, and that will give your best characters far more power to keep the group alive. Don't even try to research or build everything or give everyone the best equipment. You don't have time for that. World progression will kick you in the butt if you don't stay ahead of it.

Changes / additions from the first game that I really like:

-Children are now playable (though somewhat weak) characters and will gain bonus stats and skills as they level, until they turn into adults, which also gives you more influence over the class they'll grow into.

-You don't need to build a town right away, and in fact I recommend you don't do it until mid or late game. You'll need characters to  keep your town safe, and depending on RNG more characters can be hard to come by, even though baby events are more frequent.

-Speaking of babies, cross-breeding between species is a thing and might lead to interesting results

-Stats / skills have been streamlined but are still very diverse, and card combat is now more interesting (but also more complicated, which you might enjoy, or not). Crafting is also more complex, which I enjoy but not everyone does.

-The different races now have their own towns and factions, and you can trade with them, which I really appreciate. Trading removes a lot of the early game grind and reduces the need to craft or gather basic equipment. Some races like the Shadowkin are better for trading than others.

-God bonuses are now (mostly) integrated into a trait card system of selectable starting bonuses. Some of these need to be unlocked, some are free. Instead of unlocking things for a specific god you do so for one of 6 (I think?) domains, and can use the same bonuses for another god who shares that domain. So if you're like me and try new starting conditions often you'll still benefit from unlocks later on.

-The game is now definitely more challenging, which makes even the early game far more exciting. It's still very possible to complete the main quest, but unless you've been playing for a good long while, you'll probably have to make use of manual saves to reach that point.

-Many quests and events are now tied to a particular faction / island, which means that if you visit one you haven't been to before, you're guaranteed to see brand new events.

Things I don't like / still feel unfinished:

-The complete world map is revealed from turn one, which makes exploration somewhat meh. In the early game exploration is still fun because you'll need all the ruins, faction towns and resource nodes you can discover, but later on travelling is tedious and more of a simple timesink than fun.

-To add to the above, without mods the towns and resource nodes that spawn on a given island are VERY predictable with only a tiny bit of mostly insignificant variation. Each island has exactly one type of tier 3 resource node and it's always the same one. More randomization would have improved replayability.

-The size and number of islands always stays the same and their shape only varies slightly. Also, you always start on the same island, which is always the easiest and always at the center, and starts to feel repetitive after a few games. The difficulty of other islands is always the same too, and only influenced by overall world progression (turns passed). I don't know why there is a need for a generic starting island at all, would have been far more fun to let the player start anywhere, and just make their starting island the easiest and the others random.

-NPCs don't fight each other, which can lead to silly situations like two enemy factions occupying the same hex without anything happening. They walk around their island but don't do anything until you interact with them.

-While there is a decent amount of enemy variety, the higher level enemies that you'll fight ALL the time in the late game are always the same lightbringer and demon types of difficulty 6-9. Over and over and over.

-Tier 4 and 5 resources can't be harvested from the world period. They have zero chance of appearing. You can get decent amounts of them by killing the same difficulty 6-9 enemy stacks over and over, which gets old fast, or by converting lower tier resources into higher ones, which is time-consuming and tedious and also gets old fast.

-Without mods there isn't a lot of variation in god trait cards, especially not free ones that you don't need to unlock. Also gods (mostly) don't change the overall gameplay experience in any significant way, to get a truly unique starting experience you'll need to grind points first. Would have been nice if there were god-specific buildings and researchable crafting recipes, such as unique spells for magic domain followers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003977551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2918, 'last_played': 1704535102}
review:
Очень, очень спорно. Релизом назвать сложно. Баланс и тормоза главные минусы. Разнообразие ресурсов обманчиво (решает эссенция, а ее видов не так много). Основной сюжет довольно слаб.
Отдельное спасибо за неадекватный разброс сложности основных квестов. У предыдущего квеста боевки были на 2-3 сложности, следующий на 8 (без варианта отступить, хотя судя по текстовке никто не мешает), а после него 5-6? Почему бы и нет.
Три полоски жизни. Хп, психика и вера. Смертельный исход от ран и магии логичен, но от неудачных переговоров? Не уломал соседей поторговать, все, вскрываемся? Я устал, я ухожу?
Переделанная карточная боевка скорее плюс, просто нужно привыкнуть.
Баланс довольно сырой. Как на глобальной карте (встретить кучу паков 5-6 лвла сложности на первых ходах как нефиг делать) так и в боевке (призыв демонов\нежити\животных довольно часто не выгоден, да и статы их никак не увидеть, только методом тыка). Довольно жесткий старт, но выжив первые два года становишься имбой (ни разу не нужны были шмотки из самых последних ресов). Торговля нужна только первый год, т.к. шмот годен только для старта, а чем-то покруче никто не торгует.
Хоть основной сюжет и слаб, побочных квестов стало больше, что плюс (хоть и задалбывает вытаскивать сраного старпера из дыры 2-3 раза за год).
Баги после релиза все еще имеются и не мало.
При всем при этом не хочется рекомендовать, но мастерская заставляет все же поставить палец вверх, хоть и авансом.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020816542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 20123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5688, 'last_played': 1581701661}
review:
Overall a great game--I recommend it.

Pros:
*Unique gameplay -- feels like nothing else (other than Thea 1).
*Has that "just one more turn" feeling the best games give me.
*Developer has a great DLC policy -- it's free, but if you like it, you can give a tip via "pizza for coders" item.
*Deep gameplay--feels like I could play dozens of times and still not learn all the tricks and secrets.
*The Slavic lore is fascinating.
*Fabulous artwork.

Cons:
*Still a lot of bugs, none game breaking, many annoying. Should be in early access.
*Steep early learning curve and not much in the way of useful tutorials. I'm not sure how you would learn this game without a ton of save-scumming and experimentation. There are some lets play videos and walkthroughs out there, but many of them aren't great either.
*The UI is not good. Often takes 3 clicks to accomplish what should take one. (Saving a game is a great example. And you will probably need to save a lot as you're learning.) Lots of annoying, counter-intuitive elements throughout the UI.

author: {'steamid': '76561198346738958', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 2584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2584, 'last_played': 1589091236}
review:
Fairly hybrid, deep, unique. One of my all time favorite.

+ city-building (tough building a city is not essential, you may just wander nomadically, with one or more than one group) + cards + CRPG + management + exploration + crafting + some survival.
+ rich progression of 40+ villagers from childhood to adulthood, individually. 
+ faith, sanity, (many) skills, races, classes etc.

- events sometimes repeat themselves too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986022825', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1565548654}
review:
Okay, I've been beating my head against this game over and over... and not feeling all that great about it.

Both Thea 1 and 2 do some really neat exploration with Slavic mythology, something not really ever brought up in video games, and pairs that exploration with decent writing. The voice acting and art further enhance that particular flavor the devs are going for. If nothing else, Thea is a unique series.

I really want to like this game - I really really do. I bought it because one of my favorite streamers/youtubers played both the original and this one, and he knows enough about the game to make it look like something I can easily learn and adapt to over time.

In reality, Thea 2's early game is a RNG mess. An amazing streak of luck starting on turn 1 will turn sour because the game decided to drop a bunch of powerful enemies just out of sight, who proceed to grind down your entire party until you lose enough people to ensure a restart.

Thea 2 wants you to play it over and over again. The way it accomplishes that, however, is to punish you for hours on end until you're allowed to see new content. There's an unlock system tied to your progress, with points attributed based on a number of factors (which all pretty much amount to playtime). If you want to start in a solid enough position to avoid getting ruined by commonly bad RNG, you have to pay a time tax to give yourself enough of a fighting chance with more powerful starting characters, equipment, and resources.

Doing the first set of opening story quests over and over has become a frustrating experience over twelve hours of gameplay. I've seen the early game SO MANY TIMES without even touching the mid. It reminds of me of XCOM 2 before they fixed the horrible mess of its early game with War of the Chosen. There's so many other difficult games out there that I can play and at least get the sense of progression that Thea 2 denies me, even on the easiest preset difficulty setting. 

I wish I spent more time reading reviews and player complaints before hitting that buy button; this is a purchase I regret.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039641368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1683, 'last_played': 1659714977}
review:
I’m really enjoying Thea 2 as I enjoyed its predecessor. Especially the improvements to the UI and the additional complexity coming with the new card game I like very much. The stories are engaging and fun to read, the ship/island mechanic and founding a settlement being completely optional allows for more freedom to play the game the way u want.

But there are still some bugs and it could really do with some additional QoL Features like allowing to select also Items and not just characters for comparison in the equipment tab or using the shift key for switching compared items or transfer stacks in trading screen. Further, some descriptions for the quest symbols on the Map would be great since I often don’t know what I stumbles into when entering a Quest on the Map. 
Also, I haven’t made it super far yet in the game, but it feels like some abilities and items are a kind of redundant or unbalanced

review: The game is good, but grindy for some play styles. Some things do need to be re balanced like the material essences, and in my opinion the 10-2 resource refinement. But it is still a good game overall. In Thea: The Awakening, the play style was more about the 'One city challenge'. In Thea 2, it's more (favored) to play in the 'Nomadic' style. Yes you can still set up a city (or two?), but to play that way, and to try and get the best gear, before doing much, will take you a good 1100+ turns. It's okay to do that if you want, as there is the 'Domination Victory' type. But as I stated, it takes a long time. And it does 'feel' a bit lacking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053280003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 4413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3442, 'last_played': 1647631579}
review:
It's odd to find a fair comparison to this game. It is the turn-strategy equivalent of a sandbox, more or less. You start in a wide world with a few supplies and some companions and your only objective is to make your mark. You basically make your story and objectives as you go along and decide how you want to play it this time.

Combat is odd, but you get used to it. Challenges are genius; it's not all about brawn and killing people; you need competent strategists that can come up with plan or negotiate terms with foes to powerful to fight; and also there are magic users that can protect your fighters who would be helpless against a mental assault on their dreams or an otherwise deadly curse from a witch.

The game is not without its flaws, but I am not even going to list them; they disappear all the time! The best part of this game is its developers. They keep improving on an already good game for free, polishing it further without rest every few weeks. If you don't think this game is worth your time or money, check back next month because it will come back better!

review:
I absolutely loved the original and bought this sequel as soon as it was available on Early Access.  Unfortunately, every new thing they added to the second game actually seems to make the game less fun, less interesting and many things make very little sense, even in the strange world of Thea (My best negotiator is unavailable for a hunting challenge because we talked to some fishermen yesterday with the negotiation still hurting her sanity score?  WTF?)

Having played a few times during EA, I hoped it was all just a balance issue, and that the full release would be much better, but I am so disappointed in this - a sequel that just makes me want to load up the original instead is a sequel that's just not working.

review:
Guiding settlers from a odd bunch of hunter-gatherers to dragon slaying munchkins and iron-to-gold transmuting alchemists!  Recent patches have got the game to a very balanced and rich state. 

That said that are times where you just need to press the end turn button 50 turns in a row (the aforementioned gathering and crafting taking place) and I have a pet peeve about events where you're asked to lose a fixed percentage of your food, which is unrealistic and gets your system to choke when you have food stacks in the 5 digits by the end game. (I would like to see the 3 dwarves carrying away 25.000 cooked meals).

But anyway overall strongly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961800098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1607694213}
review:
I loved Thea 1 so much.  The mythology, the characters, the fiddly little inventory management/crafting system.  I found it by accident and fell in love.  I played it several times through (which for me is an accomplishment).  Thea 2 is just a shell of  that former game.  Fixing some things, while losing a lot of the charm that kept me playing.  There are only 2 things that truly remained in tact : the choose-your-own-adventure style events still have a lot of charm to them, and the fun of building a weird interesting party of adventurers (one of the areas they truly went all out on in part 2).  My party are frfequently a very interesting mix of humans and monsters (too bad those differences rarely mean much).  Every other aspect of the game (though mechanically similar) just feels like a hollow shell of its previous self.  Crafting is grindy and uninspired.  Materials are island locked, and have little to do with the properties of the items made with them (other than the tier of the material).  Characters have more to do, but are usually used for the same rotation of abilities (and can equip less inventory).

The biggest disappointment is the combat.  Thea 1 combat had its issues (rush to hammers), but the novel approach and crunchy rules were satisfying and different.  In Thea 2, though they did introduce totally new mechanics, it ends up feeling like a slow, repetitive, uninspired slog with little variation based on your enemy.  A true strategy game has move/counter move at its heart, anticipation, misdirection, etc.  This system doesnt allow for much if any (You dont even know what cards the enemy has in their hand most of the time).  So you find yourself playing the same patterns :  Warrior first, then summons, then archer/caster.  And the balance of gear/items/abilities continues to be a problem for this designer, winning is simply finding the most unbalanced tactic and spamming it.  All until you encounter the party wipe by the big baddy you have never seen before.  MAJOR step backwards.  I have actually seen people praising the auto-resolve combat.  Which is both sad and hilarious that someone would praise a button to skip what should be one of the major tiers of the game play.  


I will give it more time, and hopefully find more redeeming qualities, but Im not holding my breath.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999015580', 'num_games_owned': 687, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 19486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9546, 'last_played': 1708292409}
review:
When I first learned of Thea: The Awakening, I bought it immediately, and it exceeded my expectations in every way! I stayed up till 5AM multiple weekends, I replayed it more times than I could count. So, obviously, when the developers announced a kickstarter campaign for Thea 2 I was there on day 1 throwing money at the monitor. That is to say, I am a bit biased.

But I gotta be honest, once I got my hands on the kickstarter demo, I was weary of the new combat system - it felt a lot more convoluted and a lot less predictable than the card game of Thea 1. I haven't had the highest of expectations for the sequel - I've seen way too many indie studios spinning tires when it comes to sequels of their first hit.

And then the Early Access came along. And I could not stop playing it - everything that made Thea 1 awesome was still here and most things got much, much better. What impressed me even more, are the changes that occurred from the first September backer builds to early access, to release version. The developers work tirelessly adding mechanics in, reworking things that felt underwhelming (not many of those to begin with) and balancing the game to the point when every campaign I end up developing a completely different strategy, combining the strengths of my deity, party members and the biomes I end up visiting.

But if you've not played Thea 1 and are here for an explanation of what the game actually is, I gotta say, even after 280 hours in Thea 1 and 2 combined I don't have a concise answer. Let's say it's a kind of 4x game in a dark Slavic fantasy world (think Witcher, but less "westernized", though it features elves, dwarves, goblins and orcs). It is an interactive fairy-tale, where you follow the lives of a small group of people trying to survive in a harsh world. And this harshness is an integral part of the experience - like in XCOM you will care for every person in your group and get super sad when you lose them. Growing up children could turn into all sorts of weird creatures and over time your party starts looking like a wandering circus.

In my view Thea 2 is the perfect example of that elusive narrative gamedesign that we were promised for decades, while game companies kept shoveling clones of the latest hype genres...

author: {'steamid': '76561198039051387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1221, 'last_played': 1564541931}
review:
While Thea 2: The Shattering was not a bad experience, it was lacking or frustrating in too many areas for me to recommend it.

For context, I enjoyed the original Thea enough to play it end to end 3 times, including chasing down all the achievements. So this is the standard against which I compare its sequel.

Positives (+), negatives (-) and neutrals (~) by different components of the game-play:

Exploration
+ Being able to choose the site of your village
+ Thematic differences between the different islands
+ The variety of world events, especially those that hint at events from the original
~ Travelling by water is some what dull
~ Scattering higher tier resources across the map can make gathering them tedious
~ Weather and seasons add detail & texture, but can be a bother to endure rather than a mechanic to exploit

Combat
+ Type of challenge and its consequences much clearer
+ Which stats matter for different challenges clearer
~ Auto-resolve often more effective at resolving challenges than player
- Additional dimension (2D) + player ordering + variety of potential abilities makes combat chaotic and unclear
- Defence is additive but offence is multiplicative so effectiveness scales strangely
- Only seeing thumbnails of your characters/enemy much of the time

Crafting
+ Addition of research as a crafting type
+ Separation of cooking from crafting
+ Being able to favourite specific recipes
+ Party overview option to manage gear of multiple party members at once
- Material type is mostly cosmetic, only the number and essence matter
- 4th & 5th tier resources require significant refining from lower tier materials leading to 100's of turns to create enough material for one piece of equipment
- Character skills and equipment skills are competitive not complementary

Menus
- Hot keys work in some situations but not in others
- Can't press escape to close menus

review: It pains me to give this game a negative review since I truely love Thea the awaking and was excited for a sequel, however until more patches are put out to improve balancing I can't play or enjoy it and would suggest others who might be interested in the game wait on purchasing it.  My first play through I did alright but made a bad choice in an event and chose to start over. Like the previous Thea game you get Exp type points to unlock new starting bonuses. I started the new game and was attacked by a level 2 army of bees within the first two turns losing 2 characters and then attacked by a second army of bees soon after.  I've chosen to restart multiple times and each time two or three armies of 2 level bees spawn extremely close to my starting  point and attack me with the same results. I've adjusted the settings and tried playing with different deities with no different results. I will reinstall this game after several months to play it again and hopefully be able to change my review.

review:
Completely brilliant.  Steep learning curve.  Needs better documentation, perhaps?  Maybe learning how all the stuff works is part of the enjoyment process; for me I guess that's true, but for others it could be a turn-off.

I played the first Thea a lot and really got to know its ins and outs, even playing on 250% difficulty, but I decided to start out on the default 100% difficulty for this new game since I had heard that some of the systems had changed.

My first game I died to a swarm of bees on turn 2.  My second game I starved to death when I ran out of wood on turn 10.  My third game I built a sailboat and found some magical bones on a distant island.  Used them to craft amazing hammers that my warriors use to smash everyone who gets in their way.  I have a bunch of friendly giant rats living in my village that I founded; they help out with resource gathering, construction, and scientific research.  I built a spellbook out of diamonds.

Two of my villagers found a baby in a cabbage patch.  I'm not sure what they were doing in the cabbage patch at night.  When she grew up, she had the markings of a witch, so I sent her into the Grey Realm as a rite of passage to unlock her powers.  Instead, her soul was ripped from her body and she returned as a terrifying wraith who reaps her revenge on the living by draining the sanity from my foes in battle.

She's also pretty good at cooking pirogi.
