author: {'steamid': '76561198028641304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 8040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1026, 'last_played': 1693704832}
review:
This game is not quite ready.

The original Thea had a problem where you'd be going about your business and a random encounter with monsters would destroy you. This could happen at any time. They've improved the system a little bit by allowing you to see what will happen if you let the battle mini-game play out without you, but the results can still wipe out your entire group. And there's nothing you can do.

I'm sorry to see that they've also reduced the number of character traits from the original game which had I don't know, 30? Now we're down to 6. And while you can now choose which trait your characters develop when they level up, you get double points if you choose the first trait, which appears to be randomly generated, so your choice doesn't mean anything.

They also have some very annoying dialogue boxes which cannot be navigated with a keyboard. You have to click on buttons that are appearing in different places on the screen and again, the choices you make don't actually matter. There's one early on in the game where you need to choose between "Tell him you'll help" and "Agree to help".

This impacts the battle dialogues as well. There are constant attacks from roaming monsters that are not a threat, but you don't really get anything for beating them.

One of the things I really liked about the original Thea was the crafting system because there were so many combinations and variations on the art and the effects on the crafted items. The crafting system in this game is clearer, but also very shallow. Very limited variation in both the art and the effects, and whereas in the past you could gain tech points by crafting, that's no longer the case.

Anyway, I think this game has a lot of potential, it just needs some work. Kind of disappointing that it was released before being balanced but I guess that's the way the industry works now. Instead of them releasing a fully balanced and playable game for $50, I pay $20 and I get to participate in the process. Meh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100787668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1563848482}
review: I don't do a lot of reviews, but I had to because of how much this game breaks my heart. Thea is one of the best coop strategy games ever created. Thea 2 is a piss poor rogue lite disguising itself as a strategy game.  I'm sure rogue lite people will love it, but us folk that like to sit down and tackle a strategy game with depth are highly disappointed. Last night I played 7 straight games in 3 hours, Dying each time on below easy from random enemies floating around.  Trying to get enough to start your town is rediculous.  Highly disappointed in this game and glad I got it on sale and not the kickstarter.  I guess you can't create lightening in a bottle twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143585209', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2148, 'last_played': 1584290376}
review:
J'avais été séduit par le premier opus, qui figure parmi mes favoris - j'espérais donc que Thea 2 offrirait aux joueurs une version enrichie de son prédécesseur, avec peut-être même un micro-management un peu allégé. 
C'est tout le contraire qui se produit ici : les options sont plus nombreuses certes, mais le micro-management des groupes s'est également alourdi. Le système de combat a évolué : à niveau égal (compérativement à Thea 1) ils sont souvent plus faciles si vous les gérez à la main au lieu d'utiliser la résolution automatique. 

Malheureusement, les mécanismes - et l'interface, sont devenus assez abscons. Sur Thea 1, je savais à quoi correspondaient les divers signes & icônes disponibles. Sur Thea 2, de nombreuses indications m'échappent. 

Ceci explique peut-être cela, mais sur Thea 2, j'ai aussi un mal de chien à progresser : mes équipes se font constamment décimer par des adversaires nettement plus puissants qui non seulement les attaquent, mais encore les pourchassent et les rattrapent quand je tente de les fuir. 

J'avoue que je finis par me lasser de patouiller ainsi un peu à l'aveuglette avec cette impression que je peux me faire laminer à tout moment sans trop savoir d'où ça vient. 
Si je n'avais pas autant aimé Thea 1, j'aurais assez rapidement désinstallé le jeu mais aujourd'hui, après plus de 30h d'efforts et de micro-management bien vain puisqu'il finit en bouillie sous la botte de monstres errants et autres Lightbringers, je me dis que je dois avoir mieux à faire ailleurs. Désinstaller Thea 2 pour ré-installer Thea 1 peut-être...

------------------------------

author: {'steamid': '76561197985772988', 'num_games_owned': 1162, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4535, 'last_played': 1582185524}
review:
Minor complaints, but I like it quite a bit. 

It does a great job with story and pulling an unusual fantasy world from Slavic myths and the balance of civilization style game and RPG feels great. The events that come up are interesting and the narrators eo a good job with voice acting. I love the detail that my characters look like their portraits on the world map. It has a lot of the elements I liked from Thea 1 kept in it. 

I like the change from gods purely getting stronger to god points that unlock startup options changing it from a game that gets much easier to a game that gets very different every play through.

I like the main story has many branching directions it can go into. These directions sometimes have difficulty spikes you can't walk away from, but going to the different islands will do different things and often further branches of multiple things. The main story feels a bit short but it's designed for multiple plays of variation. 

Sometimes the game could explain how it works better. For instance, I was 50 hours before I realized I wasn't finding tier 4+ resources, because those are crafted from the same menu as food. I wish the game told me this. It changed a lot. 

The balance seems a bit off. You are generally still better off being townless wanderers until you leave the first island. This makes it a bit of a non-choice until you leave that island, but these things are hard to balance. If your island size isn't huge it makes the start boring to explore.

It has a lot of dead grind time when you can't really handle the next main story so you need to craft equipment but you'll need to craft better equipment for them. There isn't much to do during that time except explore locally and see the same events again and again. This would be fixed with more stuff and events similar to how thea 1 got the giants free DLC. I'd pay for content DLC. This would also help extend how long the main stories feel. 

I know, despite how much I enjoy it this game, that it wasn't a huge commercial success for them. It probably led to overall losses like the first one. I hope they put out another "coffee for coders" style DLC so I can pay them for portrait variety the art team does while the coding team works on adding more content.

play through 5. died turn 3 died by stingers

author: {'steamid': '76561197962520519', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 24553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2559, 'last_played': 1684243908}
review:
I was a big fan of the prequel and had high hopes for this one. Is it as worth playing? I'd say definitely. If you haven't played the prequel though I'd pick that up first, it's cheaper and is a great game.

If you buy this game and want to master it, you're up for a rough ride. First of all, there's no documentation, hardly any tutorials and presently no extensive wiki page. When it comes to crafting you have to pretty much figure it out for yourself, which took me a really long time.

The game is quite complex in all aspects and if your game style is to optimize, you're up for a lot of micro. Also, the game's pretty hard. I've finished the prequel on the hardest difficulty (350%) many times, so I was surprised to rack up a couple of losses on normal (easiest, 100%), before I got the hang on things.


I was at times in doubt if I would recommend the game, but now I'm not. I'm starting to love the thing. However, it's still feels slightly empty at times, with events repeating. I suspect the prequel has more events and content as it is right now, but that's after several extensions and patches. I hope the devs will release more content for this one, but it's already a really good game. Thanks devs =)

What would make Thea 2 an all time PC classic?
- More content, more stories, more events.
- Half of the buildings are useless at this point, while some are great. They simply need to buff a lot of buildings.
- More tooltips and info, maybe an ingame database with all the stuff in it, like the civ games does (especially crafting materials). This is just so it's easier for people to actually learn the game.

I think the game's on the right path to doing these things and they did it on the prequel. Until then I'll play the game some more like it is, already a really good game!


To sum it up, if you like micromanagement in your 4X games and/or storytelling you should pick up this game. Not recommended for beginners of the genre, unless you don't mind dying a lot.

Edit: After a few hundred more hours, I still have to praise the game as one of the greats. It likely has the best crafting system in any computer game – it's simply amazing how you can craft and gather, but also reforge items you find. And how you can upgrade your gear more and more. While a great system, it's also complex and will take you some time to learn.

I'll rate the story of the game 5/6 at an average, although some moments are amazing and some not that interesting. This is way above what I would rate most games.

After beating the game on the highest difficulty and hundreds of hours, you are left hungry for more game. More missions, more bosses to beat, etc. Another big DLC would be fantastic. However, the game already provides hundreds of hours of first class gameplay for seasoned strategy players.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985242191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2962, 'last_played': 1563321224}
review:
Thea 1 i Thea 2, to trochę jak śliczne, zgrabne i kuszące bliźniaczki, które ubrane w piękną, choć może trochę skąpą szatę graficzną, obiecują wspaniałą przygodę dla tych, którzy zapłacą niewygórowaną cenę za ich kupno. 

Po tym co w przeszłości zaprezentowała pierwsza siostra, jest się przekonanym, że młodszy model, będzie jeszcze bardziej wyzwolony w swych preferencjach i zapędach. 

Na pewno warto zaliczyć je obie - nawet jednocześnie...i choć wszystko z pozoru - mniej lub bardziej - mają takie samo, to jednak Thea 1 wydaje się tą bardziej.... wygimnastykowaną, i to do niej będę wracać - choć polecam obie.

To co doskwiera mi po wspaniałej przygodzie z Thea 2, to nawet nie system walki, o którym wielu pisze. Zgodzić się jednak muszę, że starsza siostra, znacznie ciekawiej dopieszczała gracza w tym zakresie. W mojej ocenie natomiast, główną bolączką Thea 2, jest ubranie jej w wiele wyspy na których dzieje się akcja....pływanie raz w jedną raz w 2-gą stronę po zasoby, jest dość męczące i zniechęcające. Przypomina to długą i mało ciekawą grę wstępną zmierzająca być może do epickiego finału ale na drodze do ekstazy, stoi nie tylko stanik nie do rozpięcia, ale i pas cnoty.

Słowem końca, Thea 2 to wspaniała partnerka do zabawy, choć w porównaniu z siostrą, brak jest jej błysku w oku czy też tego uśmiechu co zwala z nóg - nie wolno jednak zapomnieć, że Thea 2 ciągle rośnie i być może dojrzewanie zrobi swoje, a jak nie to modderski salon piękności ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197976834325', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 2989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2989, 'last_played': 1562293035}
review:
I played Thea 1 for hundreds of hours and loved it. I got bored with Thea 2 after about fifty, and despite the time I put into it, I don't think I enjoyed much of that time at all. Mostly I felt like I was slogging through it, waiting for the fun part.

I think a number of design decisions made Thea 2 a much weaker, less interesting game, particularly in the early part of the game. That's important, because one aspect of both Thea 1 and 2 is that the game expects you to lose a lot. A pretty typical experience for either game is that you progress until you reach a challenge you haven't seen before, and then lose decisively. You learn to avoid certain things by losing, since it's usually difficult to assess how dangerous an action is until you've already committed.

Crafting is a big part of both games, but the early crafting for Thea 2 is much simpler and less interesting. In Thea 2, early weapons have no special attributes based on material, and all materials are very much flattened and simplified. A sword made of stone is pretty much like a sword made of steel, or of wood. All that really matters is the tier of materials you use, and how many, and you get the same stats. Eventually that changes if you progress to tier 4 materials, but I never made it that far. I kept going through the progress-fumble-lose cycle before that point, and the early game became such a grind that I stopped caring about seeing the mid to late game.

Combat now has a tactical grid for playing cards, instead of just alternating with the enemy. This should be an improvement, but in practice it means the results are much less predictable, and losing characters much more likely if there's any challenge.

Making it worse, surprisingly, is the improved auto-resolve. Auto-resolve now lets you know the outcome before selecting auto-resolve, which is good, but it's also far, far less likely to kill off a character than manual combat. There's now a strong incentive to choose auto-resolve for all challenges. This takes all the flavor differences and special effects out of the game, since you no longer see things like area effects, speed, and tanking abilities play out. You just pump your numbers and hope auto-resolve gives you better results, or you run if the result looks bad enough.

In manual combat there are now some all-or-nothing situations where you either win overwhelmingly or everyone dies. Some monsters now have a slow attack that does a ton of damage to all your characters at once, and the enemy can play those monsters multiple times in a turn. If you have enough damage to bash through that monster's HP before it can act - which requires a LOT of damage, since they're also very tanky - you wipe the enemy. If you don't, that monster wipes your party. Auto-resolve tends to give you "everyone takes moderate damage" for that situation instead, which is another reason to avoid actually playing out combat.

Some weapon setups now have little or no value. Sword-and-shield used to be important in Thea 1, but now the defensive benefits of shields are small, and one handed swords do little more damage than bare hands. Part of the problem is that swords now multiply defense rather  than give a flat bonus, so a 2 handed sword and decent armor is actually better defensively than a 1 handed sword, shield, and armor, because the 2 handed sword has a larger multiplier.

The overall result is that many of the early important decisions are gone, both in crafting and in combat, so the early game is now a huge grind, once you've grasped the mechanics. There's a lot of wait, wait, wait while you mine minerals or craft items, hitting end turn over and over, and the random encounters do little to break up the monotony because you just hit auto-resolve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103229660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 3741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2685, 'last_played': 1706498678}
review:
Several improvents from Thea 1 do not make up for a lot of blunders.
The combat system is improved, graphics are nice, there is the exploration/faction system... but it's all weak and bleak, in the end, if compared to Thea 1.
UI is not user friendly and looks half-baked (yet, the "make expedition balanced food package" option is very handy).

I finally quit when I wanted to replace the idol, and the message was simply: "Check the idol receipt, to see the improvents". Really? Couldn't you lazy programmer just make a better UI for the player, so that one could immediately see how could be the new idol perform compared to the old one? Should I go back and forth several menus for that!?!?!?

Also: unforgiving. You have no way to avoid a too difficult challenge, there is no hint. You just go there and die unwittingly, losing your beloved PCs in an instant. Feels unfair and unbalanced. I saved a lot to avoid grief and punishment.

Finally, the faction system is very lousy: factions give you few, repetitive missions and once you get friendly you do not win much.

Thea 1 was simpler, but more coherent, more solid, more fun - even if it lacked some advanced features Thea 2 has.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108237427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1831, 'last_played': 1583349468}
review:
Thea 1 war und ist mein absolutes Lieblingsspiel, daher habe ich mir Thea 2 bereits im Early Access geholt. 

Leider ist dieses Spiel unglaublich langweilig. Mir hätte es schon gereicht, Thea 1 einfach nur ein neues Gewand, neue Quests und Gegenstände zu geben - leider ist Thea 2 ein völlig neues Spiel, das wenig mit dem alten Thea gemein hat. 

[list]
[*]Die Karten sind sehr weit gestreckt, viele Runden gehen drauf um an Orte zu gelangen
[*]Die Rohstoffe sind.. überflüssig? Es macht keinen so großen Unterschied, ob jetzt Mid- oder Hightier, nur, das man für das Sammeln und veredeln mal eben 50 mal auf Runde überspringen drücken kann
[*]Die Quests sind einfach.. meh? Bei Thea 1 war ja immer dieser subtile Humor dabei, das fehlt.
[*]Die Fähigkeiten sind einfach nicht spaßig weiterentwickelt worden. In Thea 1 wurden sie ja zufällig zugewiesen, was jeden Charakter einzigartig machte. Hier ist es mit selektiertem Levelsystem, wobei viele Fähigkeiten kaum oder wenig Einfluss auf das Spiel habe
[*]Dörfer... Die Gebäude sind extrem enttäuschend, denn ihr Nutzen ist überschaubar. Auch ist es nicht mehr möglich, mit den verschiedenen Materialien verschiedene Kulturen, wie Orks oder Goblins anzulocken. 
[*]Kampfsystem ist nett? Aber es fehlt diese simple, tödliche Einfachheit des ersten Teiles, wo jede Karte ganz überlegt abgelegt wurde. Stattdessen erschlägt mich das UI mit Informationen und Fähigkeiten, die kein Mensch braucht.
[/list]


Es ist kein schlechtes Spiel. Nur ödet es mich unglaublich an.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042750885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 42754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14776, 'last_played': 1683891443}
review:
Graphics ------------ Not mindblowing, but not ugly/bland enough to be an eyesore. Quest Art's pretty good at portraying the world through imagery.

Music --------------- Calming.

Length -------------- A match can go from at least 400 turns (if you know what you're doing) to well within the thousands of turns. Try the demo to see how long it takes you to get through a turn. There is also an ingame currency called Godpoints that you use to unlock More Gods to follow and more abilities to choose that will effect your starting party and status within the game. Around 30 Godpoints can be earn per normally completing the main story on hard more.

Difficulty ------------ The early game, being the first hundred turns, can be unforgiving on Normal and Hard. You can change the difficulty through the match settings. The game becomes much more manageable and routine after your party is equipped with decent armor and weaponry.

User Interface ------- There are a lot of pages of text and images you will be going through to craft items, unlock items to craft, manage gathering and other party things, complete quests, and more. 

Combat -------------- You attack and defend yourself from enemies in a Turn based field where cards representing your characters are used to battle. The combat is easy to pick up and difficult to master, but the auto resolve option is accurate enough to allow a well equipped player to skip to the results of repetitive, low risk, battles when needed. 

Overall color palette - Feels grey.

In the end ----------- There are quite a few questionable choices with the User Interfaces and lack of quality of life options to ease the burden on the player with managing items and such that it can detract from enjoying what the game presents you. Getting past the UI issues, Thea 2: The Shattering gives the player a decent adventure through a harsh Slavik fantasy world where your party must gather resources to create better equipment in order to survive. 

Ademdum ----------- 4X stands for Explore, Expand, Exploit, and Exterminate. It is a term used mainly for games that deal with the player building continent spanning Empires while creating alliances with or eliminating any other player in order to win a match. While, technically, Thea 2: The Shattering does have all 4Xs, the player(s) are battling the Environment(meaning computer controlled enemies and story events) rather than each other, and at best can set up two single tile towns/villages for gathering materials to create advance weapons and armor for the parties to continue on with questing and such. 

If you're into what has been written, then try the demo first to see if the game is indeed for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000155206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 8506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4916, 'last_played': 1699211942}
review:
Thea 2 is a great continuation of great game.

It builds on top of the first thea idea, polishes it, and introduce new game mechanics that fits nicely on top of old ones. Combat is extremly polished compared to first thea, so was crafting and city building. But at the same time game has much higher difficulty curve and is much more brutal.
Especially on higher diffs.

The balance is a bit lacking in my opinion - they are characters (elves, dwarves) and items (tomes with wicked AoE attacks, easly craftable the other ring) that tend to break the balance, making the game way too easy.

A multiple endings and different island biomes to explore provide a nice way to counter the repetition, though some endings are harder to achive then others.
Events tend to repeat itself, but just like in Thea 1 there is a modding support (via workshop) and event editor so there will be a lot of new events comming up to spice up the game.

The modders has already started to create mods, and some of the mods are great way to diverse the game.

I will not focus on visuals here, because in my opinion they are the least important thing - 2d art (which is what you will be looking at majority of time) is in range of rock solid to gorgeous, the 3d art is okay and the world is belivable. 

Overall - do I recommend this game?
Yes I do! It's a nice cRPG/X4 hybrid, with multiplayer option, which requires more time investment to master - but is really more about exploring and strategic planning then exploiting AI weaknesses...

author: {'steamid': '76561198008479711', 'num_games_owned': 600, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 23820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1830, 'last_played': 1628029504}
review:
My really short review of this game, as a HUGE fan of the original Thea: The Awakening.  

My initial impression of the game after a few hours of play was "oh...a dumbed down (i.e. simplified) version of the original."  Initiallly, I really wasn't a huge fan of the simplification.   Then I played more.

If you liked the original Thea The Awakening, you're likely to like Thea 2 just as much.  Some UI elements are worse, some are better.  The combat is different (perhaps better), the character development is dumbed down as far as stats go but also expanded upon with a nice variety of skills and abilities (which wasn't the case in the Original).  The combat is still a card game, but again expanded upon due to the variety of skills and abilities.  

Beyond those two things the game plays pretty similar to the original;  Exploration and party management, some town development (or not), gathering & crafting, all driven by events generated as you play.  And this, to me, was the bread and butter of the original.  What kept me clicking that "just one more turn" button until the wee hours of the night.   

I find myself staying up way too late, again, as I have not done often since growing tired of Thea the Awakening.  This, to me, makes the game as a success.

For someone who didn't play the original, this is perhaps a much better game to start with due to the simplification of challenge types and stats involved it will be far less of a challenge to get the hang of.    
The game still has a brutal streak like the original though and is quite difficult early in the game with the possibility that the power curve will get ahead of the player and crush them, so my advice would be to do yourself a favor if you are new to the Thea series...and play on easy for a few games before trying to prove how cool you are with a higher difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131221653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 9357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5978, 'last_played': 1576542167}
review:
I wasn't sure about this game at first, but I have come to absolutely love it. The recent patches have vastly improved gameplay to the point where Thea 2 is more enjoyable than the original. Muha Games has created another classic, and I am looking forward to playing it more and more in the coming months.

If you are a fan of MMORPG crafting systems, then this is the perfect strategy game for you. Crafting is the best part. There are hundreds of possible recipes, and you can choose to adventure for components or make them yourself using coal. Thea 2 supports both turtling and aggressive strategies, which is really nice to see. 

The game does need more tooltips and optimization, but I imagine that those issues will have already been addressed by the time you read this review. The card based combat is hard to understand, but the autoresolve is so well done, you don't really have to learn the minutia of the cardcame to really enjoy it.

I can't recommend Thea 2 enough. It's a highly enjoyable, challenging, and engaging strategy game. It's a high recommend for me :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198073632886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1592860789}
review:
Do you get your money's worth here? Absolutely. Solid strategy game with plenty of unique RNG to keep things exciting and you can easily fall into a loop and lose hours and hours into this game.  That being said I would recommend Thea 1 to my friends before the sequel. Not just for story reasons, but Thea 1 is a tighter game and easier to get right into. 

That is really my biggest compliant about thea 2. I almost wrote a review against this game after 3.5 hours of playing it as I didn't make it past 20 turns and had gotten murdered by trash mobs and had access to no resources and since it my first playthru that is on easy. Even now playing it more I still have Very little clue about many mechanics this game has as things are not explained very well or even at all. There is a lot of depth here, but you are more likely to fall into that depth than slowly explore it.   

After failing a great deal and getting destroyed by Bee's I figured out a strat did a few quick restarts to make sure I could build a village that didn't suck and am able to start exploring and get a feel for things which is when it finally hit me and I was getting that fantastic Thea feel once more and can recommend this to anyone who may be interested enough to read these reviews. 

Thea 1 is still over all a better game, but Thea 2 is no slouch. The few things I feel I must point out if you are coming from Thea are... ... 
1. Combat is new. Not necessarily worse, but different and going into it with the mindset from the first won't work so well. 
2. Gods are also different. I personally feel they are worse and even after looking them up didn't feel any of them jumped out to me as "Yes this is how I want to play!" as I felt the first one did. To be blunt the ability to slot your choices makes your gods feel more like story fluff and less anything else. 
3.  Slower.  There is a lot going on earlier with a spread of options and added rituals and the ability to choose stats/skills on level up changes up how things go. In thea 1 I immediately felt like I was diving into it and excited to do so. Thea 2  the start is bland as I just see this huge text wall of check boxes I'm going to go thru before I can get really going. That pacing is definitely going to make more playthru's less likely as starting is the worst part of the game. 

End story still a fantastic experience and if you like strategy games you can't go wrong here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005795879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 13952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6614, 'last_played': 1691600134}
review:
I played thea: the awakening, completed it. loved it. one of my all time favorites.

however, it took me quite some time to get used to the change of combat mechanics and stat weights on weapons etc. 

upon taking the time to do so i've come to the conclusion that thea 2 is almost just as good as thea 1 if not a slight improvement.
( that's based on playing in the beta and a few weeks after it's full release) 

I love the way you can chose to set up a village where ever you decide depending on the amount of resources on an island, eventually being able to travel via sea to adjacent islands.
( which change on every playthrough)

The music, storytelling, voiceovers and art are all as amazing as ever. 

i've still yet to complete/finish the main story for thea 2. yet i'm still enjoying the slow pace of exploring every area of the map and reading/listening to every piece of dialogue.

i love games that make me feel like i'm not in a game, but in a story that i'm a part of and being able to resonate with characters or being able to imagine the personalities of each individual adventurer that joins my group based on their attributes + character art and forming a close bond with said characters. 

For instance, two characters will occasionally have a child. i'll make a note of who belongs to who and as the game progresses you may come up to a hard challenge/encounter when suddenly the "father" may give his life to protect the sibling, 

( were i basically go into a challenge that's too hard for my current level of adventurers)

Which in turn may make me chose which direction the child goes in once it reaches adulthood, does the child try to avenge their father or were they too young to remember their fathers noble sacrifice, so instead they learn as much as they can from their mother or perhaps they try to forge their own destiny ? 

Being able to come home from work and loading into Thea 2 to find out what new adventures await my band of followers is just so rewarding.
thank you to all those that have dedicated so much time and effort into this lovely game =')

author: {'steamid': '76561198133708514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2789, 'last_played': 1561183808}
review:
I'm fairly disappointed with this title.

 I felt a sense of freedom and exploration in the original title where exciting resources could be located anywhere. Now you always start on a new-player island and the resources are boring. Want to move to a new island? Good luck. First you must build a vessel by farming copious amount of wood. Did I mention the enemies will probably kill you easily? And sailing, it's tedious. One turn to load onto the ship, then the next turn you move. So imagine having to sail to several different islands, gather resources, potentially lug them back to a town somewhere just to craft the good gear in order to combat the overpowered baddies. 

The progression of the game does not feel smooth, at least to me. It goes from easy to too hard to easy, to impossible challenge out of nowhere. Save scumming is something I didn't have to do in the first game. It seems to be a necessity if you value your time in Thea 2, however. 

The voice acting is passable but seemingly sparse compared to the first's whimsical tales. The female voice actor is not as good as the male, and she doesn't quite capture the desperate, dark, mystical nature of Thea. 

The music is good, maybe not quite as exceptional as the Thea the Awakening, but there are some great tracks here. 

Building doesn't feel as interesting, despite being able to build everything available. This may have to do with the slow resource gathering and sailing to all the various islands. 

The stories here are pretty good, but the main story arc needs some work. You don't always know where to go and what to look for. The quest reminder tab should be more full, or include a journal of important events to keep you on task. 

The card fighting is alright when you feel you have a fair shake at victory. One godlike enemy during endgame had a nasty lifeleech that made him unbeatable for my high-level party. Oh well, no problems thanks to loading my old save up. Now I know not to do something like that, or maybe auto-battle might figure it out. Ugh. 

I was so excited for this title. Now I can't even muster the energy to play. I hope the developers keep working to make it a more smooth experience for the player, because right now the magic of Thea is at a fizzle. Please fertilize the life-seed so Thea continues to grow.

Thank you,
A Thea Fan

author: {'steamid': '76561198211256301', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8604, 'last_played': 1640522907}
review:
Calling this game bad is ignorant and saying that it's not bringing anything new to the table since Thea 1 is also ignorant. I put a fair amount of hours into this game and would say that it's a good game but i don't think it's finished. 

Combat/playstyle  
Thea 1 has without a thought better easier and more enjoyable combat than Thea 2, but the new games shines in it's diversity. You can fight in 3 ways in Thea 2, Faith, Mental and physical, while physical is easiest and will be a choice in almost all encounters with, humans, elfs, monster etc. A mental run is completely possible and quiet fun and will offer a new way to play the game then if you just run around and smash everything. Faith is basically magic and will give you the choice to release curses and gain loot, characters or new quests or quest paths. Don't get me wrong, doing a mental run or magic run will give you the option to smash everything to your pleasing by using weapons, scrolls and artifacts. Which, depending on your materials of choice, will turn your mental stats into meat crushing power. In general, it's a bit rough for a beginner since weapons primarily only boosts the stats of your characters and doesn't give you damage. STATS AND LEVELS ARE FUCKING KEY to a successful run, equipment works like a multiplier. Since this is the case, i strongly recommend only leveling a character for a specific thing. Like, a smiths should only have his points put into wisdom, knowledge etc. 

Story
It's faking good and i am totally biast, story isn't important to play the game but a nice bonus. Going in blind where more enjoyable so i ain't gonna say shit

Crafting
It's good and bad, you have many options different thing but i really thing that the overlay is bad and a bit confusing sometimes. Knowing the effect of metal and jewellery for example is a bit scuffed and most of the times you will only switch back and forth to find what's got the biggest number for smashing. They should really take a look at the crafting again since it can be so much better but i thought that will happen. Crafting is also grindy and you will spend multiple turns gathering and then crafting. Turns will fly by so be careful and don't try to craft the best shit in the beginning. 

Gods 
Wtf did you do? like the whole game is about gods and the different personalitys and belives of said gods. But all the gods kinda feel the same, like if i play a peaceful gods that is more of a nature and beast type god. Then i expect that there will be some sort of bonus or penalty for mistreating nature of just slaying deers left and right. Buts it's just like any other god, it's quiet disappointing actually and i feel is the weakest part of the game. I am just hoping the modding community will create more gods or a revamp of there skills and properties. So that a gods actually has a special playstyle and not just the same play style with some small bonuses. To clarify, you do not play as a god but it's chosen one.

conclusion
Bicc bicc learning curve but it has it's moments and you should give it a try, even if it is a rng slave simulator., you do actually have power. Either to influence the rng or just becoming good at knowing the good and bad events or just doing good decision making. The game is in your hands but you just need to play a bit to know what to do and when, but pls psl pls pls pls pls, if you are a modder do a god mod to this game, it's truly its weakest point and biggest mistake. This game could be so good if only the gods were more unique and more influential of the playthrough. And yes Thea 1 is much better in many ways but this game in my opinion has more content and that should be accounted for and is a big reason this gets a positive review. But this game has stuff that is annoying that i haven't mention or forgot but just read otehr comments if you want a wider perspective of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986902042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 8145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3690, 'last_played': 1699990649}
review:
[b][u]The Short of It[/u][/b]

Thea : The Shattering is more of the same with a fresh coat of paint, but that's certainly not a bad thing, in most regards, as the predecessor was already a very good game, though some new mechanics are a bit questionable.

[b][u]The Long of It[/u][/b]

As the world shattered, six great islands were formed, the world was made anew, and even the pantheon of gods was reshuffled, some of them destroyed or missing to make room for new ones. As the Chosen of your god, it is up to you if you will di his or her bidding and restore his/her portfolio, or if you will reject the gods and strike out on your own. You begin with a small and inexperienced group of travellers, some even children, and must explore the world, gather resources, fight all sorts of enemies in all sorts of ways, in order to hopefully create a lasting legacy.

All challenges are resolved through a card game, with different characters being good at different challenges. Your warrior, for instance, may be good at hacking down enemies, but she will struggle when faced with magical beings who try to enchant her, whereas your zerca will be good at tackling magical threats, but will be chopped into cordwood by the first random orc he sees. This necessitates a diverse group of characters, even more than in the first game, since now combat can't solve everything, plus social and mental challenges can now actually damage and even eliminate your characters.

You also have the option to build a town (and you really should), which can erect buildings, generate resources, provide a place for your expeditions to rest, lets you craft better items and food, and so forth. This, too, is pretty much the same as it was in the original game and it's still enjoyable.

[b][u]The Right of It[/u][/b]

Thea 2 plays mostly like the first game did, and there are only a few real differences of note. Thea 2 has all the strengths its predecessor had and is still very enjoyable to play overall. 

The card system has also been overhauled. No longer is it randomly determined who goes first (and thus who has the advantage), but now characters actually have an initiative score, and the battlefield looks different, as well as the rules. Still, the card game remains challenging and interesting for those who liked it in the first game. 

[b][u]The Wrong of It[/u][/b]

One thing that's been changed is the world map and allocation of resources. The world is now divided into six islands, and every island has its own biome, meaning that the more rare resources are restricted to one island, per type. This will make it necessary for your band of adventurers to travel to and fro to collect goods and materials. It's not exactly clear to me why this was done, since it feels like this adds a bit of unnecessary tedium. Travelling takes a long time, and gathering is rather slow, meaning you'll spend lots of turns either getting from one place to another, or camped out and waiting for your people to gather the next bit of mithril. A lot of playtime in Thea 2 is static, and you need to be able to enjoy this particular type of game.

Thea 2 is also ill in the same bed as its predecessor was: a lot of the mechanics are obscure and in need of explanation. Crafting, especially, with its essences and challenge types, can be dizzying to understand. It also has the very clunky and unintuitive UI its predecessor had. There is an unnecessary amount of clicking involved in every action, and this can be irritating.

But the biggest fault to find with Thea 2 is the Lightbringer faction. Hoo boy. These luminous pests turn up on every island, and they are far too strong for a beginning group, which means you'll spend a lot of time hoping that they'll pass by you without engaging you and wiping your whole party. Trying to get rid of the spawn points is even worse since these are usually level 7 or 8 challenges, impossible for a smaller or less experienced party. They are a massive annoyance and in dire need of a nerf, especially in the early game.

[b][u]The Last of It[/u][/b]

If you enjoyed Thea: The Awakening and think you'll enjoy more of it with a new sheen, you should be fine buying Thea 2. If slower-paced turn-based games aren't your thing, give it a pass because it's not a game for the player who wants quick results.

review:
I've been following this game from it's early access and I played the first Thea game. I can say the game has been improving steadily and it offers unique gameplay and game mechanics. The slavic mythology part of it is well researched and enriched with tolkienesque elements. There are lots of nice small stories along the way and the game is fairly replayable.

A few aspects of it seem somewhat unfinished and not well thought through:
- Rituals are seem secondary to Gathering and Crafting, but in reality they are only used to remove curses and recover the magic health bar. They should add a possibility to spend resources on rituals to bells (or buff) the party. The better the materials, the better the buff.
- Different Deities offer different way to go through the game, yet one must always make sure they can tackle all 3 challenge types in order to survive, which limits your options for party specialisation.
- On harder difficulty one only gets 4 points for characters, but some of the characters cost 4 points. It's impossible to push through the initial challenges with only one  character.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072044082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 57353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2556, 'last_played': 1602448681}
review:
Mit Thea 1 habe ich bisher über 600 Stunden verbracht und dachte nie, dass mich ein PC-Spiel so fesseln kann - umso mehr habe ich mich auf Thea 2 gefreut. - Grafisch natürlich besser als Thea 1 und auch die Kämpfe sind anspruchsvoller / komplexer - das wirklich "fesselnde" an den Thea-Spielen ist aus meiner Sicht aber die Story, die sich immer mehr entwickelt, auch abhängig vom Vorgehen und daher ist der Wiederspielwert enorm. - - Hier ist mir aufgefallen, dass Thea 2 mit vielen Aktionen an Thea 1 anschließt und wer bspw. alle 4 Hauptstories und 5 Götter von Thea 1 mal durch hat, wird mit Thea 2 seine wahre Freude haben - man trifft doch wieder auf alte Bekannte aus Thea 1 und Ihre "alten" Probleme wie bspw. den Zwergenschmied "Bohdan" mit seinem "Liebesproblem" ..... auch wenn es für viele Leute evtl. so nicht reizvoll ist, ältere Spiele zu spielen, so empfehle ich doch, Thea 1 komplett VOR Thea 2 durchzuspielen - nur so kommt man bei Thea 2 in den maximalen Genuss des einzigartigen englischen Humors, den die Thea-Serie auszeichnet.

Übrigens...als Verheirateter und Berufstätiger Gamer sind für mich die Thea-Titel auch grandiose Spiele, die man mal zum entspannen "zwischendurch" spielen und unterbrechen kann, ohne dass man gleich Gefahr läuft, dass alles vorbei ist - das englisch ist auch hervorragend gesprochen......bitte mehr davon :-)

Anmerkung: Temporäres In Game Event "Halloween" 2019 war wirklich gelungen !

review: What is most fun about Thea is progressing your characters and exploring the world. The progression part stays fun for about one playthrough so the exploration part is the main reason for playing it multiple times. The combat mini-game can sometimes be fun but most of the time you are else really overpowered (and you usually use the auto-combat option) or you have almost no chance at all. Later in the game you can build some combos and then it is hard to find any challenge at all. Still i think the game is fun to play for at least one playthrough and that can be 100+ hours. So its easily worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970671096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1651751114}
review:
Drawing on less commonly used mythology Thea presents a really interesting world to explore with some very unusual twists on the usual story tropes in fantasy games. Added to the fact that each time you play the outcomes of various actions you can take are changed by your group skills, your god and a little randomness and there's a great deal of replayability here too. 

The combat system is very different which makes a nice change and having different challange types forces you to choose between diversifying or mastering a path and hoping you can survive the other perils you might find. A really good risk reward structure.

If you're looking for a really interesting game world to spend some time in that offers some really different gameplay, pick this up!

review:
First Thea was a masterpiece so I bought this when it was in EA. 

This Thea is similar but still unique with a lot of new things added into the game and that's why I love it. 
Some things still need balancing (made me ragequit a few times) but with great devs who are regularly updating/patching everything it is on a great way to become worthy successor and earn the title of masterpiece once more.

review: Big problem is unfinished UI. No drag-and-drop for panning world map. No shift + click for quick assignment (It's really painful in 2560*1080 resolution to drag and drop). No consistent closing shortcut key (ESC in Thea 1, ESC or Enter or none(!) in Thea 2). And after I just moved my unit, why should I click them again to set up a camp? Ridiculous. I really loved Thea 1, but 2 is a disaster.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013825603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 26729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2219, 'playtime_at_review': 2571, 'last_played': 1712430974}
review:
Thea: the Awakening is one of my favorite surprise releases of the past few years. It was brutal. it was heartbreaking. It was amazing. When Thea 2: the Shattering was announced, I gladly backed it on kickstarter. I participated in the Early Access phase with lots of feedback, and watched the game grow and improve with each iteration. 

So, how is Thea 2? Well, in a few words... It's AWESOME. 

Is it a perfect game? No, it is not. There is always fine tuning to be done, but once you get a hang of the game, you see it's brilliance. 

Yes, it is harder than Thea 1 was. It is also a lot more complicated, but I'm a 4X and Strategy fan and if I can't get a hang of it, should I even play it... So, I "got gud" as the kids say these days. I really like a lot of what MuHa games did to improve the game and I'm waiting to see what else they have in store for us.

Having said all of that, the game is REALLY hard at first and it does take time to figure our. It is a susrvival rogue-like 4X after all and the gods of Thea are capricious.

This is an eXemplary game in my book!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009646871', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 23179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5506, 'last_played': 1689014966}
review: Thea 2 is highly enjoyable. There are so many more things going on and things to do than in Thea The awakening. Although survival  isnt quite as hard at the start because you don't have a village to defend. The graphics are very good, combat is well balanced, and the Slavic fantasy mythology setting is unique. You grow attached to your characters as they level and explore the world, it is never easy if one of them dies.   I was a Kickstarter for this game because I enjoyed the first one so much and I was able to see how much hard work this small team put into the game. I do hope they put out an new event pack for this, because I know I will make multiple play throughs with the different gods.  Get this game if you enjoy RPG type strategy games, Its worth the price for the replayability.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995455792', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1284, 'last_played': 1699324544}
review: The long and short of it is if you liked Thea 1, you'll like Thea 2. The question is if you have 1, is it worth buying 2? Both games are very similar, and 2 is more an iteration on 1 than a revolution. 2 does make one serious improvement over 1 though, and that is in the ability to chose where you wish to settle, or to even live as a nomad if you choose. Overall, 2 is more of a good thing and if you have any desire to support the developer and signal your demand for and enjoyment of games like these I recommend the game.

review:
The game has a lot more content and a lot more things to do than the first. I really loved the first one. So if you're a fan, you'll probably like it. The card game doesn't seem to interest me as much as the first one, I find myself mostly just doing auto-resolve, so.... that's a thing. You spend a whole lot more time gathering things, since they're all so far away and on distant islands, which is a different thing. The story is good and the developers will continue to work on the game till it's 10/10 I'm sure.

I love how Thea2 has grown from the first game. All the changes to the crafting mini-game are changes I’ve been waiting for. I can’t even begin to tell you how much time I spend on cookouts with my group: a feature that I was hoping would make an appearance. I can’t help but think about the emergent gameplay that we are presented with. I want more and more. (and one more turn)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995975604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13325, 'last_played': 1686078401}
review:
Art 10/10 The style, the lore, and the overall thematic aesthetic is just amazing.
Gameplay 9/10 Sometimes, you are unable to get any kids. Other times, you have too many and run out of food. Or they turn into rats. Even though there are ways to mitigate rng luck, it can absolutely ruin a run in unfun ways.
Audio 8/10 The voicelines bring a lot of life to this game, but sometimes it's jarring to be in the middle of an otherwise beautiful and compelling soundtrack and then suddenly a voice narrates an event.
Overall, I absolutely love the the way you can customize the difficulty, the various gods and their quirks/traits, and how different one gameplay session can be from the next.

review:
Отличное продолжение первой части. Те, кто играл в первую обнаружат много пасхалок, кто не играл - в курс дела введут, что почем объяснят.
Всем интересующимся славянской культурой - must have.
Авторам также удалось неплохо адаптировать специфичные славянские темы и юмор для западной аудитории.
Игра требует доработки напильником для комфорта, и разработчики постепенно расширяют номенклатуру напильников.
Осторожно! Есть риск залипнуть надолго!
Upd. Как и ожидалось модификации отлично освежают игру, а при зачатках логики и прямых руках модифицировать можно и самому.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985444774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2227, 'last_played': 1664862745}
review: Although different from Thea: The Awakening, specially in its research and combat mechanics, it remains a solid game with a lot of details that keep every run unique, with a nice story, well-writen events and a great diversity of enemies (that, like Thea 1, can become followers in certain conditions and encounters). It does, however, require quite a bit of patient because of a lack of control customazation, a lot of dragging/clicking to execute actions and grinding for materials, but familiar for those who played the first game. In general, the world and exploring is much more interesting and better implemented. If you enjoyed Thea 1 definitely give it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071309484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 20789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15856, 'last_played': 1562369727}
review:
You hunt resources out, the gods want you to save their worthless hides. Last time it was from too much darkness, this time it was from too much light.

Whilst they steadfastly refuse to fit a cosmic dimmer switch, you most jump through hoops, harvest materials to build a ship or a village and gear and weapons... all the while trying to build up some kind of tribe that can survive the demon infested islands you inhabit.

I love it. I die so quickly and jump right back in. it has a touch of the old roguelikes to it as you game score earns god points allowing you to unlock new Gods and new starting gear and characters.

It has replayability and charm but if you dont like the turn based nature of the game or the card game based challenge mechanics... it will start to annoy you.

Do your due dilligence, watch a couple of playthroughs. Get a feel. I love it. Hope you do too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055838774', 'num_games_owned': 1303, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1561811574}
review:
Interessanter Ansatz eines 4x Strategiespiels in der slavischen Mythologie; solide, doch teilweise mit verschenkten Potential

[i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/8049466/]Der Spielekey wurde der GGC-Curations kostenlos zur Verfügung gestellt[/url][/i]


[h1]Spielerlebnis[/h1]


[u]📰[b]Story[/b][/u]

Die Geschichte besteht aus einer Hauptstory und vielen verschiedenen Nebenquests. Dabei ist der Ablauf der Hauptgeschichte ziemlich ähnlich und unterscheidet sich nur marginal in den ersten Runden. 
Die Variation wird durch die Nebengeschichten und Ereignisse hineingebracht. Dabei besitzt jede Insel eigene Ereignisse. Nach einem Spieldurchlauf wirst du mit Sicherheit nicht den Großteil der möglichen Auskommen der Ereignisse erlebt haben, was wiederum du Spieldauer erhöht.

[i]70[/i][b]/100[/b]



[u]🎮[b]Gameplay[/b][/u]

Du startest mit einer kleiner Gruppe an Personen, die du dir zuvor selbst zusammenstellen kannst, unter dem Zeichen eines der acht Götter. Am Anfang sind nur zwei der acht Götter freigeschaltet, um weitere freizuschalten, musst du entweder ein Spiel mit deiner Gruppe erfolgreich absolvieren oder mit Gott-Punkten freischalten. Die Punkte werden dir nach einem Spiel, auf Basis deiner Perfomance, gutgeschrieben, hierbei erhältst du diese auch nach einer Niederlage. Als Gewinnoptionen stehen dir der Abschluss der Hauptquestline oder durch Domination. Für den Dominationssieg musst du jeweils eine der zwei Anforderung aller drei Kategorien erfüllen.
Im groben wanderst du über die Insel und sammelst Rohstoffe und Essen und errichtest möglicherweise ein Dorf. Es ist aber nicht notwendig, du kannst auch das Spiel “abschließen” ohne ein Dorf zu errichten, was aber die Schwierigkeit dezent erhöht. Da du im Dorf die Möglichkeit bekommst Gebäude zu errichten, welche dir Boni im Kampf geben oder einfach einen großen Lagerplatz für Gegenstände. Die Gebäude können mit verschiedensten Rohstoffen gebaut werden. Diese findest du verteilt auf den Inseln, je weiter diese Rohstoffe im Forschungsbaum sind, desto wahrscheinlicher ist es, dass diese sich auf einer anderen Insel befinden, was dich dazu animieren soll die anderen Inseln zu erforschen.
Ein großer Aspekt des Spiels sind die Herausforderungen, welche oftmals mit den Ereignissen mit einhergeht. Diese können jeweils in eine von drei Kategorien fallen, physische, mentale oder spirituelle. Jede Kategorie besitzt 2 Attribute, welche wiederum unterschiedliche Effekte auf weitere Fähigkeiten des Charakter hat, sowie die Effektivität bestimmter Waffen. Zur Absolvierung einer Herausforderung musst du die Gegner in einem “Kartenspiel” besiegen. Dabei erhältst du am Anfang deines Zuges Aktionspunkte, die du in Aktionen deiner Charaktere umwandeln kannst. In den meisten Fällen wirst du die Auto-Resolv-Option wählen, da du keine Lust hast, immer wieder dieselben einfachen Herausforderungen abzuschließen. Die mögliche Herausforderungen hängen aber auch von den Personen in der Gruppe ab, so kannst du andere Lösungen der Probleme erhalten, sofern du z.B. ein Jäger oder Dämon in deiner Gruppe hast, um nur paar zu nennen. Ein Problem, welches ich zum Teil mit den Herausforderungen hatten, dass sie ziemlich rng sind und dir ohne, dass du wirklich etwas dafür kannst, den ganzen Spielverlauf versauen kann.
Die Generation der Inseln ist zufällig und bietet somit immer eine neue Erfahrung. Durch den zusätzlich Multiplayermodus kann auch mit mehreren Personen gespielt werden, ein wichtiger Aspekt im Hinblick auf die längere Spielbarkeit.


[i]75[/i][b]/100[/b]


[h1]Technische Aspekte[/h1]


[u]🎥[b]Grafik[/b][/u]

Allgemein ist die Grafik moderat, dafür beeindrucken die Bilder welche für Geschichte und Begegnungen verwendet worden sind. Die Wettereffekte und die Darstellung der Jahreszeit ist atmosphärisch umgesetzt worden. Viel lässt sich aber nicht mehr dazu sagen.


[i]68[/i][b]/100[/b]


[u]🎶[b]Musik[/b][/u]

Die Hintergrundmusik ist harmonisch und gibt dem Spiel einen ruhigen Charakter. Die Hintergrundgeräusche und Aktionsounds sind auch angenehm. Im ganzen eine schöne musikalische Kulisse. Ausschließlich die Hauptquest wurde per Voice-Acting eingesprochen, ansonsten sind alle Textbausteine selber zu lesen oder zu überfliegen. Die eingesprochenen Texte sind jedoch qualitativ hochwertig und somit die Abschnitte eine willkommene Abwechslung. Eine deutsche Übersetzung der Texte oder Voice-Acting ist nicht vorhanden.


[i]70[/i][b]/100[/b]


[u]💢[b]Unannehmlichkeiten[/b][/u]

Es ist öfters vorgekommen, dass das Spiel auf einen Bug gestoßen ist, in den meisten Fällen war es welche, die den Spielfluss nicht beeinflusst haben, aber ein zwei Mal musste das Spiel dennoch neugestartet werden.

[i]-1[/i]

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


[u]⚖[b]Meine Meinung[/b][/u]

Thea 2 ist eine interessantes 4x-Spiel, eine Kombination aus RPG, Survival und Strategie-Spiel. Die größte Schwäche die ich bei dem Spiel sehe, ist die dürftige Balance des Schwierigkeitsgrades. Am Anfang ist es eher Glück ob du überlebst oder kläglich scheiterst und am Ende sind deine Charaktere so stark und du hast so viele, dass kaum eine Herausforderung dich zum Schwitzen bringt. Im ganzen ist es ein solides Spiel und das Setting in der slavischen Mythologie.  


[i]71[/i][b]/100[/b]

[i]Bei Fragen oder Anregungen stehe ich in den Kommentaren zur Verfügung[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198032678645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5936, 'last_played': 1637922578}
review:
It's not as compelling or entertaining as the first one. It gets boring quick, the mechanics are repetitive. The replay value is low because even though you have many unlocks and gods to choose from the mechanics and storyline are ultimately the same. Once you beat it a couple of times you realize that you're pretty much doing the same thing each time in terms of what types of resources and weapons you'll be gathering and making. Once you reach a certain point in gathering and crafting the game becomes easy. So you just rinse and repeat, this was also the case to an extent in part one, however it was far more compelling to keep exploring and crafting, in this one it's simply not the case. 

It's worth a shot if it's on sale, I had high hopes for this game because of how great part one was, however something doesn't feel right here, be it the islands, the card play, or the mechanics, it's not very cohesive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079025889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 17507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1695, 'last_played': 1705154857}
review:
Отличное продолжение Thea:The Awakening
Мир игры стал значительно больше и разнообразнее.Появилось много фракций,отношения с которыми могут быть совершенно разными(от яростной вражды до крепкой дружбы).Количество ресурсов просто огромно.Сильно поменялась система крафта (для неё по прежнему нужны ресурсы,само собой,но вот результат создания предмета может быть разный).Для создания особо крутых предметов потребуется создавать самому и материалы.
Что все таки вызывает сомнения,так это боевка. Система боя стала более сложной и разнообразной,но это может не всем понравится.Механика боя стала по моему слишком мудреной(при том что карт мы можем разыгрывать значительно меньше,чем имеем по факту).Я все таки привык к боям как в первой Тее и они меня вполне устраивали.Но это моё личное мнение.
В любом случае,игра получилась интересной,затягивает с первых минут.Тем,кто с удовольствием играл в первую Тею,вторая должна понравится.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074424737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11799, 'last_played': 1561475502}
review:
I loved the first game, and I was not disappointed by this one. I bought early access based on the first game, and I think the developer deserved my support. The game mechanics are still similar but they have improved the crafting system  a lot.  The stories are still based on slavic mythology which I find very interesting as I have limited knowledge of their myths and stories.  The portrait art work is really nice, it would be nice if you could choose your villagers portraits.  
The only improvements I can suggest right now are
1. the child birth rate is rather slow, and the male /female ratio seems a bit off
2. some of the changes to the fighting card system as compared to the old Thea are a bit confusing, they could use a brief tutorial.
Overall a great game if this is your type of game.  I would definitely recommend it even if it is not your type of game especially as they have a demo version out.

review: A worthy successor to the first Thea game. It has the same vibes and atmosphere with all new combat system, which is in my opinion a little harder to get used to than the one in the first Thea but not bad in any way. New (optional) seasonal effects system is also a big plus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042410508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1607, 'playtime_at_review': 5176, 'last_played': 1712223379}
review:
It's a great game, there have been some pretty big changes from the first and they can seem a bit jarring to begin with but ultimately they're for the best if you can stick with them. 
The combat takes a little getting used to but is more flexible than the original. Character statistics are vastly more streamlined and actions are replaced with skills either learnt from leveling up or granted from equipment, their power is based primarily on the stats they use. Crafting has been simplified as well with ingredients now grouped in tiers which grant a certain amount of power to the recipe they're used to craft and empowering the skills the equipment grants. There's also a huge variety in characters you can have ranging from the original warriors and craftsmen to goblin beastmasters or orc matriarchs to snakes, unliving rats or vampiric striga.
It may have benefited from a little more time in Early Access but the devs are still 100% committed to still working on the project and upcoming DLCs (which will probably be free). They're a great team and deserve your support.
If nothing else they have a free demo to get a taste for the game, it never hurts to give it a try!

review:
A great game - far more complex than the 1st although it loses some of Thea 1's charm because of this.

Game would get a solid 90+% in my book if not for 1 thing

The UI is THE worst I've ever encountered. I have been playing game for 31 hours and I STILL press the wrong thing at least 3 times a turn. My characters move when I dont want them to or dont move when I want them to. Its got to the point where I wont stop on a resource otherwise I spend 5 minutes trying to reclick my team.

There are keyboard shortcuts but as usual left handed people are seen as beings from Mars & are not catered for.

This UI is truly horrendous - if you can get past that there is a decent game underneath but also quite a tricky one.

Thea 1 was basically build up numbers and steamroll everything whereas Thea 2 is far more dependent on equipment & skills - quality over quantity.

Mainly because of the new craftingsystem. at the first view you might think its way more complex then in thea 1 but it isnt. generally there are only 5 resources each from tier 1 to 5 (wood, stone, metal, leather and gems) you will allways build similar items using one of this five resources. this is way less then in thea 1. the buildings are bad too. its just so repetitive to grind grind and grind just to get tier 1 or 2 ressources to build the same item with a slightly qualetybuff. author: {'steamid': '76561197991657927', 'num_games_owned': 1410, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 2582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1561571743}
review:
I really don't understand the complaints about the change in how combat works. The way it is in Thea 2 actually refines the combat and makes the different kinds of attack more clear than they were in Thea. In Thea the best course of action was just to avoid anything but physical confrontations until you became strong enough to attempt other kinds of challenge. But in The Shattering spiritual and mental combat types are more clear to anyone with enough sense to understand the workings of the game and that you have to have diverse party composition rather than just a handful of thugs whilst your gatherers and crafters sit at home washing the dishes and such.

Events in Thea 2 are far more diverse and weirdly storied, I don't see it as a major drawback that you don't always know what is around the next corner because you don't know which kind of attack type the enemy will be most proficient at. It's a learning curve and you get to know the best approach to take against each enemy type. Those who have posted negative reviews likely neglected researching them so that they could be more effective.

There are far more options to trade for the weird and wonderful in 2 so your stockpiles of low level resources never become useless as they can in the first game. Supporting other factions by questing for them will also increase the value of trade. All in all it's a lot less desolate of a game. The crafting mechanics have also been refined and expanded and the random breeding and interbreeding of your followers can produce weird and wonderful results. I was astounded to suddenly get a popup telling me that a wraith (which was the result of a human failing the coming of age trial to become a witch) had got it on with a human and produced an undead monster and again when said undead monster bred with a human and produced a goblin.

As was its predecessor Thea 2 represents superlative value for money in terms of potential entertainment time.

Get this game. Ignore the foolish. And always remember the children are the future. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198107412985', 'num_games_owned': 1979, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1527, 'last_played': 1561254426}
review:
[h1]《西娅2：破碎》(Thea 2: The Shattering)评测：紫之夺朱乎？另辟蹊径乎？[/h1]
[i] * 感谢SteamCN提供游戏评测机会
 * 本评测在SteamCN社区的图文链接：https://steamcn.com/t499732-1-1 [/i]

[h1]总评[/h1]
一款糅合了桌游跑团、生存、经营等要素的回合制策略游戏，选题独到，策略深度足够，有开多周目体验不同玩法思路和刷成就的必要。秉承前代奇幻世界观，改良了前代许多不友好的设定，声光效果进步尤其明显。
但开发者对国区一贯采取了偏向高价区的定价策略，加之本系列无中文，英文阅读量不少，上手偏难，单局耗时颇长，轻量级玩家请谨慎入坑。仅向策略经营类死忠粉丝严肃推荐本系列两部作品。



[h1]完整自洽的世界观：东渐于海，西被于流沙[/h1]
主标题中的“Thea”、音译“西娅”，不要听起来就自行脑补成某某女神之类。按本系列的世界观，“西娅”仅仅是游戏所在世界里，主大陆的名称而已。话说这块大陆，硕大无比，东渐于海，西被于流沙，承平已久，都赖一棵世界巨树恩庇。奈何某年月人类自己作死，非要破坏世界树，于是日月无光，群魔乱舞，生灵涂炭——但无论如何，人类幸存者总还是要苟下去不是？解决了温饱，世界那么大，冒险者们总是想出门去看看的吧？看看如何教日月换新天的吧？自此，本系列一代的世界观就呼之欲出了。

到了二代即本作，西娅大陆更是破碎成了若干块漂移的岛大陆。永恒的黑夜虽已褪去，但魔物仍在各岛大陆上游荡，伺机反扑。种下世界树的种子，建立小小的定居点，坚持活下去，找到更多世界树之种，就有更多在其它岛大陆上扎根的希望，进而揭晓西娅世界的秘密。

本系列的世界观，就故事性而言，当然比不了权游、冰火这种扛鼎作品的体量，但起码清晰勾勒出了虚拟“西娅”大陆的历史沿革和风土人情，大体与老牌系列如《伊多》(Eador)或是《奇迹时代》 (Age of Wonders)一样，尚能自成体系，需要玩家通过实际游戏过程中的系列互动事件，主动作出选择，推动近千种事件走向，享受接近跑团的醍醐味。但由此带来的庞大英文阅读量，可能会劝退大批非硬核玩家。

就游戏性而言，季节、天候、昼夜、地形、种族、神祇、产业链、科技树、生存要素等等一应俱全，更可贵的是做到了系统数值平衡，没有手工耿大师式的无用废品（并非植入广告：欢迎微博检索“手工耿”），也没有明显的龙傲天型硬伤，工业水准远在我们一般认知的独立工作室级品质之上，值得认可。



[h1]相比前代的改进：不迁怒、不二过[/h1]
即便是萌新玩家，也能直观看出本作画面相比前作的大幅提升。笔者尤其赞赏本作的人物立绘，本作的彩色绘稿相比前作的单色线条绘稿，姿势水平真的不知道高到哪里去了，更何况本作立绘大多在方寸间营造出的强烈夸张感和对比感。

评价策略游戏，光谈画面，无异于肤浅的耍流氓；总归还是要拿游戏性和策略深度来说事的。笔者曾对本系列的初代作品，给出过比较苛刻的评价 (https://steamcommunity.com/id/CHN_Ryan/recommended/378720)，着力抨击了前作盘古大陆体验单一、随机性太强破坏玩家算路和刻意鼓励多周目刷刷刷的设定。一朝被蛇咬，当笔者戴着有色眼镜开始尝试本作时，却惊喜地发现，制作组对本作进行了相当认真的打磨，前代那些蛋疼之处，真的一个都不见了。制作组这种“不迁怒、不二过”的朴实作风，着实值得点赞。

本作大地图还是单一的盘古大陆吗？请看游戏副标题的“破碎”二字，并不是白写的！按本作世界观设定，“西娅”世界破碎成了N块大陆，当然玩家初始登场的“新手村”型大陆，各方面条件还比较温和。等到游戏中盘，玩家有实力造出探险船只，就有机会探索其它大陆了！不必看着材料树尽头、仿佛诺亚方舟再世的究极大船流口水，谁说小舢板不能横渡大洋？所谓富贵险中求，密布火山熔岩的大陆上，有着充沛的黑曜石储量，适合锻造各种附魔型神兵利器；北境的冰雪密林中，苔原狼的毛皮又轻又暖，拿来做皮衣或是蒙皮盾都是极好的——此条并不适合广大非酋玩家！尤其是开了禁止自动存盘选项的非酋，开浪前请务必三思！

本作野怪还会胡乱刷新吗？当然不会了。再者，本作中登场的所有NPC生物，都有明确的阵营归属，是敌还是友，均依赖于对玩家的好感程度而定。完成相应阵营提供的支线任务，还是连续击杀相应阵营的生物，均会明显影响玩家的外交关系。世上没有无缘无故的爱或恨，本作甚至提供了类似《文明》系列“外交胜利”的条件判定，当然达成条件会比较苛刻。

本作值得多周目反复刷刷刷吗？即便是不考虑常见的成就解锁要素，回答也一定是“当然值得啊”！玩家的白板开局，默认只有2位已解锁神祇，以及数量相当有限的开局资源/人员/装备/天赋/职业可选项。随着玩家反复进行游戏获取解锁点数，并按需逐步解锁各元素，有机会在后续新开局时，尝试多种经略思路。解锁种田型神祇，搭配工匠和采摘者的开局，方向自然迥异于有战神加持，战士和猎手等强力战斗型角色的开局，玩家就不会有刷刷刷的无聊倦怠感了。甚至大可在初始队伍中多配幼童幼女，苟过游戏最初的若干回合，耐心抚养孩子们成人，为他们钦定职业方向，鼓励他们自我奋斗，偶尔也要看随机的历史进程。通常玩家亲手调教养成的角色，往往能力更为专精，更能让怪蜀黍型玩家有莫名的满足感（？？）。



[h1]杂糅的游戏乐趣：紫之夺朱乎？另辟蹊径乎？[/h1]
坦白讲，策略、经营、桌游跑团，单看哪一条都是小众游戏类型，同类老牌名作带来的无形参照系压力，加上独立工作室宣发能力有限，很难从这片红海中扑腾起太大浪花。

此时，开发者另辟蹊径的巧劲就体现出来了，创新性地把上述几种游戏类型杂糅到一款游戏中，用合理的世界观作为解释，先勾搭上述任一游戏类型的爱好者入坑，再令其眼前一亮：啊，原来这款游戏除了我喜欢的某某元素，还有这么多新鲜的内容！那就下一回合到天亮吧！

笔者以为，就本作的实际体验而言，[b]“近乎无限地深度经营”和“传统跑团风格的战斗冒险”[/b]，是其中最为亮眼的那一抹紫色。

什么叫“近乎无限地深度经营”？翻成大白话就是，“我就是喜欢种田啊”！只要不是挑战全部最高难度设定档的铁人型玩家，或并非研究急速通关的速通党，都会相当享受全程“种田”的乐趣的。

比如，只要对本作稍稍上手，就会发现“生存”概念只限于最初的头几十回合，贯穿游戏始终的正是“舌尖上的西娅”。鱼/肉/蛋/菜/海苔/米粮……十几种食材，在定居点厨房里排列组合，化作近百种美食，各有现实中的出处，效力各不相同。冒险者的胯下马、掌中枪的威力，必须建立在充裕的后勤补给之上。

再如，稍有种田经验的玩家都知道，除非击倒boss级老妖爆出的传奇装备，否则冒险者的各式装备，靠自己打造总归是要好过路边野怪爆出的随机物品的。
自己怎么打造装备呢？
先攀对应科技树，解锁相应配方，包括装备需要的原料配方和制造装备的场所物料清单，别忘了装备配方和建筑物料还有等级区分，像是木制指环就没法跟龙骨钻石指环相比；
接着要收集配方涉及的原料，有些要靠采集特定矿源获取，有些要靠击败特定敌人获取；
然后要在定居点，建设铁匠铺之类制造装备的合适场所；
最后还要有矮人之类手艺过硬的工匠，花时间亲手打造成品；
一件成品出炉了，这只不过是探险队其中一员身上某一处的装备而已，距离探险队全副武装的装备还差很多很多……哇，好麻烦的样子，可我们种田党还会怕麻烦吗？ 

什么叫“传统跑团风格的战斗冒险”？按笔者的理解，就是以文字选项驱动的冒险事件，鼓励玩家通过大段文字描述，沉浸在虚拟的冒险场景中，当机立断，做出（自以为）最适合当下的选择，面对由此带来的战斗和奖惩。本系列游戏在此基础上，更分别设计了桌游式的战斗规则，鼓励玩家不单纯靠肉弹型角色+铁罐头型装备，遇事不决就平A过去，而要审时度势，善用己长，套路就是早年间冯巩老师的[quote]“我就想跟潘长江比个大，跟陈佩斯比美发，跟帕瓦罗蒂比劈叉，跟美国总统布什比说中国话，哎呀，说死他！”[/quote]——队伍中的医者巫师等人纷纷表示，下次遇到兽人战士，一定要强调以德服人、以理服人的传统美德。

如此游戏过程，到底算是紫之夺朱，还是另辟蹊径，笔者个人愿意给出中立偏正面的评价，更鼓励每一位玩家个体去实际体验感受。



[h1]定价策略：不忘初心乎？[/h1]
早在去年年底，笔者就曾两度主动联系本作开发方，提出本系列两代作品的国区定价（https://steamdb.info/app/606230/  https://steamdb.info/app/378720/）似与国区的相对低价区定位不符，恳请他们酌情考虑，看能否推出对国区玩家更友好的定价策略。

开发者团队的设计师 Mila ‘Yuuki’ Irek是这样答复的，原文引用如下：
[quote]We always try to stay fair with our pricing policy and we stick to guidelines set out by Steam. 
（中译：我们一贯公平审视我们的定价策略，并坚持来自Steam的定价指导方针。）[/quote]

在商言商，毕竟不是哪家开发者都有波兰良心蠢驴的觉悟。像是《巫师3：狂猎》The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt  https://steamdb.info/app/292030/ 这种3A大作当白菜价铺街的姿势，并不适合拿来道德绑架其它开发者。

笔者随机选取了一些品质相对出色、且因支持中文而小有名气的独立游戏作品，作为参照系：
这是我的战争 This War of Mine  https://steamdb.info/app/282070/
漫漫长夜 The Long Dark  https://steamdb.info/app/305620/
陷阵之志 Into the Breach  https://steamdb.info/app/590380/
木筏求生 Raft  https://steamdb.info/app/648800/
守墓人 Graveyard Keeper  https://steamdb.info/app/599140/

可以看出，这些非喜+1的优质独立游戏作品，大致符合以下特征：
国区定价区间在34-68元之间；
有质量在可读水平以上的中文版，会是不错的加分项；
以国区定价为基准线，同一游戏的低价区（俄罗斯、阿根廷、土耳其等）定价，大致是国区的六、七成左右；而高价区（美国、欧盟、澳洲等）定价，大致是国区的2倍甚至2.5倍左右。
当然，笔者这种小样本统计分析可能没那么有说服力，欢迎读者大佬尝试用爬虫程序配合SPSS等数理统计分析工具，进行更广更深评估。

本游戏及其前作的国区定价，分别是100元和99元。本游戏及其前作，均不支持中文。
……本评测，到此为止，谢谢阅读。

author: {'steamid': '76561197997584767', 'num_games_owned': 1017, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1585485980}
review:
For some reason the second Thea is less endearing than the first one, which was flawed but also loved by me. And yes, most gameplay systems are better thought out and the actual card-combat game in principle allows for actually using a strategy and be less being in the hands of the RNG. If only that same RNG wouldn't still be highly unpredictable in almost every other aspect of the game.

For example which characters are put into your "hand" during combat or what kind of random encounters are given to a group. These encounters cannot be spotted on the map like the roaming monsters, so basically you cannot plan for them. And yes, this was how it worked in the first game as well, but in Thea 1 we just had overall health to worry about as a stat... now we have two more (sanity and faith), basically again health bars but with a different colour. Mental or faith/ritual challenges thus do not add a different twist to the card combat game: they are basically just the same only with different skills and a different health bar at stake. And if the health bar drains you again have a good chance to lose the character, only they "wandered off" instead of "bled out", but the results are the same. 

The only way to counter these problems is to grind and grind some more: grind resources, grind research and XP and then slowly wait for your master craftsmen to finish new, slightly better items (prepare to click "next turn" a lot while doing nothing else). 

The game systems perhaps work on paper, but to actually playing this game is not a lot of fun. I'm sticking to Thea 1 and so should others until they make some changes to this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067514441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 5880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4954, 'last_played': 1677226449}
review:
A captivating game you can thoroughly enjoy with a right approach and expectations. It keeps you pleasantly engaged in a flow of ensuring your small group of ragged humans survive throughout cold winters, lack of food, and hungry wolves; make new alliances in this hostile and harsh world, become stronger and fulfill their deity's quest.

You can play nomadic to visit more places and get more experience or establish a village to boost your crafting, gathering, and research.
The most valuable resource is your people. They could die from grave wounds for good. This is a game of chances. However, you can influence the chances. Raise a healer in your party, run for a friendly village to rest and recover, flee from the hopeless battle, be wise.

Once, I lost six strong characters, some died, some had mental breakdown and left the party. I continue no matter what and won, and that was so satisfying. The game is designed to assist you in winning despite heavy losses.   

You don't have to grind for higher tier resources in order to win. Eventually, you will figure out that perception is best for gatherers and hunters, wisdom - for crafters. You give a sword to a warrior, a bow to a hunter. To better understand the mechanics, you need to read a few beginner's guides because the game doesn't explain everything explicitly. As a result of integrating different game concepts in a holistic fashion,  the interface is bulky and requires quite a lot of clicking, which hopefully will be fixed with quality-of-life patches.

All in all, the game is immersive and deep, has a lot of potential for future content and adjustments, and the committed and responsive developers are working hard on enhancing and polishing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045551437', 'num_games_owned': 580, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 25061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13820, 'last_played': 1698520816}
review:
I have bene enjoying the game so far.  The workshop was just implemented which will bring some new quests and eventually classes, which will mean more varied game play.  The game did suffer during it's early days, but the devs are constantly improving thte game and taking our suggestions. 

 This is a complete game, the UI is rough some times and hotkeys will be a welcome addition, but it's not a big deal to me.  If you need hot keys and a more streamlined UI in order to try a game, I'd recommend waiting another month or so.  If that doesn't bother you and you want a strategy game that is part RNG and part really knowing the system and learning from your failures, than this is the game for you.
