author: {'steamid': '76561197990265656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3858, 'last_played': 1568138910}
review:
I like the story, setting and arts: core ideas are pretty decent, and Thea 2 actually feels like diving into an original adventure.
Yet the gameplay feels more like tech-demo, rather than complete game:
Right from the start you see that game is meant for replayability: most of the options are locked with god points you get during lasting session. Ok, after two restarts I've beaten the game on easy difficulty - and that allowed me to unlock one more god alignment and couple of strating party options (one of the cheapest).
You start the game again and see that there is no replayability at all: boring combat with very few and imbalanced abilities (auto-resolve is a savior), same events to evade hurricanes, thunderstorms, floods and forest-fires. below fifteen story-rich events. below ten chapters in the root story. Dull crafting system: only jewelry and scrolls/artifacts will give you a variety on the outcome depending on the used material/essence - all the rest will just increase numbers... (why in the world the craft designer allows to loop through materials rather then select desired properties like spells, damage type, weight etc?!)

I'm not familiar with Thea 1, and bought Thea 2 in the moment of release after early access period, but apparently it's still in early access - come back in a year or two, after purchasing a bundle with missing content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029991501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 26338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10259, 'last_played': 1685398386}
review:
This is a very fun game that you should try. It's different in feel from the first one, yes. But everything that made the first one Thea is here in the second one. I could launch into detailed reasons why, but let's be honest, those things matter, good and bad, to me alone.

What it comes down to is this game is worth buying and putting hours into. It's a neat RPG storytelling experience with light settlement management, and interesting resource management and crafting. The game has been, for me, thoroughly enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021689855', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 7519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2444, 'last_played': 1593152842}
review:
Thea 2 Improved a lot since it's release and as a lover of the first game (Thea: The Awakening) I was extremely excited for this one. 
 They added minimap, balanced resources and fixed small bugs and issues. It is obvious that there are some more rooms for improvements but current state was enough for me and my other 2 friends to have fun for hours.
 
 What I like:
-Fun story
-Still has wide range of crafting mechanics in it 
-New god mechanic

What I dislike:
-All islands generate so similar in minimap
-You have to sacrifice your cosmic seed to build a town. And town mechanics are a bit worse than the previous game
-Feels like main quest needs a bit improvement, we all felt a bit aimless while playing

review:
This game is truly amazing and is among the most innovative games of recent times. The way it blends RPG, Strategy and Survival mechanics with Rogue-like elements is pure genius. The game also has very good replayability.

Also at the time of writing this review there are still quite a few things that could be improved but the devs are constantly working on it so I am confident that it will get even better over time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054054385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1573735721}
review:
W porównaniu do części pierwszej w której się zakochałem ta gra to gniot.
System walki został niepotrzebnie skomplikowany, jest nieczytelny i totalnie bezsensowny. W przypadku większej drużyny zupełnie utracona zostaje przewaga liczebna, gra zdaje się losować 7 kart do wystawienia.
Możliwość zagrania jedną kartą więcej niż raz to jakiś poroniony pomysł, zwłaszcza, że w żaden sposób gra nie sygnalizuje czy dana karta została już zagrana czy nie - pozostaje wgapiać się na siłę w przypadku, kiedy portrety się duplikują.
Statystyki przedmiotów są nieczytelne i pogmatwane a gra zdaje się ich nie wyjaśniać w należyty sposób, co sprawia, że chaos staje się męczarnią zamiast rozrywką.
Duży minus za brak języka polskiego, co w przypadku gry stworzonej przez rodzime studio jest w mojej ocenie strzałem w pysk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198853681171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1560701577}
review:
[h1] [i] [b]Thea 2[/b] - отличная стратегия, в которой нет ничего невозможного. [/i] [/h1]

Не так быстро увлекает, как [b]Heroes of Might and Magic[/b], но вполне самобытная и по-своему интересная игра, черпающая вдохновение из Славянской мифологии.

[quote] [url=store.steampowered.com/curator/11769719-Dreams-of-Genesis/] А тут вас ждёт ещё больше интересного!  [/url] [/quote]

В первую очередь стоит отметить, что разработчики поступили правильно, добавив демо-версию: ведь всегда проще попробовать самому и понять, нравится или нет. Иногда даже банальная вкусовщина заставляет склониться к покупке или выбрать что-нибудь более подходящее.

Уже начиная с главного меню на вас сваливается куча всего приятного: и красивая картинка, и качественный саундтрек, который хочется слушать даже просто так, вне игры. Но, как всегда, есть одно "но": всё на английском. Сейчас эту проблему активно решают неравнодушные люди: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/606230/discussions/4/3658515990050316702/] скачать русификатор можно здесь[/url]. 
Я же пошла по хардкору и узнала много новых слов :D

Игра представляет собой RPG со множеством элементов: здесь вы найдёте и крафтинг, и сражения, и исследование карты, и строительство городов, и, конечно, куда без изучения таинственных руин и разговоров с путниками. Рассмотрим поподробнее некоторые из пунктов.
> [i]сбор и крафтинг[/i] - прежде, чем что-то создать, нужно собрать ресурсы. Это можно сделать, изучая карту, исследуя здания и пещеры или сражаясь с монстрами и выполняя квесты. Каждый из способов хорош по-своему;
> [i]исследование карты[/i] - местами не очень понятно, куда идти, чтобы выполнить квест, иногда очень мешает туман, из-за которого всё видно в лучшем случае на 4 ячейки вокруг;
> [i]сражения[/i] - самая неоднозначная из всех частей. В раннем доступе не было авто-режима, а в системе битвы трудно разобраться с первого раза, сейчас же он появился и, чтобы не заморачиваться, пользуюсь им.
В битве есть несколько нюансов, значительно осложняющих жизнь: вы не знаете, какова сила противника, пока не вступите с ним в бой, можно только попытаться предположить. Вас запросто могут сгрызть самые обычный крысы, а пара хищно выглядящих волков трусливо подожмут хвост и сбегут. 

[b]Что мне понравилось:[/b]
+ чарующая атмосфера и проработанный мир;
+ хорошая оптимизация;
+ необходимость пораскинуть мозгами;
+ огромное количество возможностей и большой выбор дальнейшего развития событий.

[b]Что не понравилось:[/b]
- местами трудновато осознать, что от тебя требуется;
- непредсказуемый ИИ.

Минусы незначительны и не мешают наслаждаться игрой, высокая реиграбельность делает её ещё более привлекательной, но.. казуальной её не назовёшь, здесь придётся вникать и, возможно, долго. За счёт разнообразных возможностей приходится долго их изучать, либо действовать методом проб и ошибок - и то, и другое одинаково действенно, но требует анализа и затраты времени.

Кому понравится эта игра? Однозначно рекомендую любителям старых добрых RPG, особенно настолок. Остальным советую выбрать для начала что-нибудь попроще, всё-таки, для первого раза слишком много нюансов.

[b]Итог[/b]: лучшим решением будет попробовать демо-версию, прежде чем покупать полную, чтобы составить своё собственное мнение об игре, потому что она довольно специфична. Лично мне она понравилась, есть желание время от времени изучать этот таинственный мир.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035865028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 13897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9454, 'last_played': 1667363109}
review:
Definitely is an improvement from the first Thea most of the negative views are due to people who played the first having irrational nostalgia for the first much like if somebody in Russia today said 'things were better when Stalin was around'.  Thea 2 quantitatively has more quests, more monsters, more characters, more items, more skills, more victory conditions, more locations, more choices than the first.

Compared to other strategy games it will probably take longer to get to a fully optimizable playthrough due to needing to put time into the game to unlock better Gods/traits and trial and error of what items/skills/choices are the best.  Length of playthroughs can take up to 40 hours, impressively the game never takes long to process AI movements or each turn.

Compared to other role-playing games this one requires you to abandon emotional attachment towards each individual character at certain points so its probably the most squad-centric RPG there is, you might even end up with multiple squads roaming around the map.  You don't always have the option of choosing which character takes the fall or participates in some events, but if you really wanted to you can build your entire game around one superhero like character.

review:
I love this game! 
It seems to me to be the game they wanted to do with Thea 1, but now they had the funding for polishing and perfecting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020051016', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 29214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1187, 'last_played': 1696493603}
review:
Thea 2 has an events editor that allows you to curtail the game exactly how you like it at any point in or during the game. This very powerful events editor mode enables you to not only edit but add in more content to your hearts desire. A powerful developer content creator tool, given for your personal use.

Thea 2: The Shattering: It takes some things we've all seen before and smashes them together to be unique in it's own right. I'm actually enjoying the time I spent thus far and with this game it focuses around replayability. So I know I will be logging in many more hours to come. That should mean you could easily spend a good 50 hours easy per play through and then with the way the game has procedural generation and the other god/starts unlocks as you play... this game could offer some good fun for a good length of time for you. 

The map has hexagons like the game called Civilization, you move your units likewise within your turn and end it as so.
The battles play out like the game called Witcher and it's card game called Gwent. 
The skill tree and stats associated with your characters as you progress through the world is mostly standard to any RPG.
There is a build system where you can plant down one to two places where you are able to command a city. 
There is no limit to splitting up your characters into parties to roam, gather, and fight as you see fit.
There is a demo, download it and play through 50 turns, I only took two turns and seen enough for me to buy. 

I recommend this to any strategy RPG enthusiast. It does have multiplayer but I can not comment on such as I am still playing single player. Just giving you some feedback to help you fellow gamers decide on your next adventure in gaming. Good Luck!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026114952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1560359152}
review: I was a great fan of Thea 1 and was very much so looking forward to playing this one. While there are a few systems that I think they improved upon: you being able to choose where you set up your town, building rapport with different factions, and the new starting system where you are able to choose abilities and companions; I think that there are too many areas in which this game falls flat. Certain types of combat are too punishing, mental being the main one, the difficulty ramp is far too severe: you go from fighting lvl 1 and 2 mobs to facing off against near impossible odds with the Light Bringers and that bandit camp, and while these are indeed potentially avoidable you are given no forward warning as to their difficulty. Also quest markers on the map do not let you know what quest they are associated with. I do still love the artwork and the story, and the random encounters are, for the most part, fun I just can't bring myself to recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084839528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3020, 'last_played': 1559491013}
review:
I really wanted to love this game. Thea 1 was a very pleasant surprise and I enjoyed it - sure it had its flaws and I was looking forward to a sequel that fixes the flaws and polishes the strengths.

Sadly, that didn't happen.

The gameplay in Thea 2 is quite similar to Thea 1, the biggest difference in gameplay mechanics is the new combat system (also a little cardgame). The new combat system is "fine", but even if it's all new, it didn't improve the game (it's not "better" than the old system, just "new").
Exploration/random events are pretty much the same as for Thea 1 (I guess the number of possible events is higher, but they play in the exact same way). Sure RNG can mess things up here and there, but that's okay in my mind. The game is meant to be played a bit like a rogue-lite: By playing you unlock differents starting gods/abilities which you can use in your next playthrough.
Normally I'm a fan of this concept, but Thea 2 is not really suited to be played again and again and again from the beginning - each playthrough feels way to similar to motivate you after a while. And each playthrough can take many hours. 

But the biggest issue for me is the fact that some enemy encounter just wreck you, without warning. And by "wreck" I mean killig your entire party, leaving you basically no option than to start all over again. Sure, if you leave your town unguarded and get attacked, you cannot defend it - that's okay, watching over your town is part of the game. But what really bothers me are the quests that tell you "go there" and as soon as you arrive, all available event options spell desaster for your party. The story does not take equipment/level into account, so you have to memorize for your next playthrough which battle of the main story you can take on with what certain group/level of people. You simply don't know how strong you enemy are beforehand, which is not a bad thing if a dead party would not force you to play maybe 5 hours of the exact same game again, until you reach that story point again and remembered at which point your party can handle it.

Thea 2 has so many good aspects and features. But the game designer failed to create an enjoyable game out of this pieces.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110464481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 18507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3168, 'last_played': 1704461921}
review:
I have completed this game twice on 100% Difficulty (Easy mode).

I would give this game the ratings as below:
Replayability: 9 / 10
Game content: 9 / 10
Interface: 6 / 10 - controls can be improved and splitting of team in order to refresh town or interact with buildings 
Difficulty scaling: 2 / 10 - Going from 100% to 150%, it becomes no maual save mode, you only save if you quit the game. I crashed around 150 turn or so, I haven't yet checked if it saves if you crashes. If it doesnt, then this issue should be fixed. at 150% difficulty its probably like 3 times harder as the resources become very scarce and scales such that your children have a very high chance of dying if they lose more than 50% hp from auto resolve.
Developers are updating the game to fix the bugs and issues, hopefully we can see future updates with more classes available and more balanced stats making. Difficulty should be adjusted for harder ratings in order to conserve population. Even my warrior with 30% hp is susceptible to dying within 1 turn after successfully clearing a challenge

author: {'steamid': '76561197970541909', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1658352131}
review:
The most unpolished game I have ever played. 
Worst sound design / implementation I've ever experienced in a game. Ugly, clunky and annoying UI.

Half of the buttons\animations are completely SILENT. 
Killed an opponent in combat? - no sound whatsoever. 

Tutorial barely teaches ANYTHING, combat tutorial is a joke and doesnt explain 80% of the things on screen.
Overall the game feels very cheap and embarrassing UX-wise.

If you enjoy polished games avoid this at all cost. Game feels like its in ALPHA, which surely indicates there are many more issues I havent even encountered yet.

The gameplay becomes repetitive and tedious very quickly, in large parts because the UI/UX is so terrible forcing you to do repetitive mundane tasks every turn for no apparent reason other than lazy/stupid UI design. Could have been a good game if a lot more effort was put into the user experience.

These developers seem to have very little pride in their product.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026728939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 18747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9793, 'last_played': 1561359015}
review:
Interesting sequel to Thea 1's game mechanics: islands, choosing where to build your village (if you choose to build one at all), new classes, new races, new gods, abilities and combat mechanics.
RNG allows for plenty of replayability, it's pretty much a rogue-like strategy game.

Story wise the game isn't as long as Thea 1 currently. Thea 1 did add a bunch of quests later in the game and since the devs have the same attitude towards Thea 2 as they did the prequel, I believe more content will be added.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005010020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4564, 'last_played': 1654535206}
review:
Thea 2 is a great game. Not as great as it could have been but still an absolutely great game. 

If you played the first game it's basically more of the same but with a more interesting combat system where all classes can with the help of the right equipment help out. I highly recommend giving it a go if you liked the first. If you haven't played the first game, I'd say go buy that first and then come back to this.

Why would I recommend the first game? Quite simply this game doesn't feel quite finished. I'll list my (minor) issues with the game below.

The cons ones: 
Too few events. The game feels like it's lacking ALOT of events, I expect more than the first game, not less.
The village is basically pointless, especially since the few events related to them are mostly negative.
The cap on rare races/classes. It's an rng game. Let us mess it up!
God's having the little impact. Played through the game 4-5 times. Haven't really noticed much of a difference between them.
Too little enemy variation. On higher difficulties you quite quickly just end up facing Leshy's repeatedly and thus only gaining Leshy loot = Leshy equipment. More variation would make the playthroughs more different.
(This was a problem in the first game too) Too few pictures. It can't be that hard to add a couple of more stock images to each class to give variation, same for opponents and what not.

With that said. It's a pretty awesome game to throw away a couple of 100 hours on. Looking forward to the expansions and DLCs that will complete the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032826872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 9048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4182, 'last_played': 1706110944}
review:
it plays like a 4X and RPG, but it's combat is like a Card game,,,,,the story is dark but interesting, and it is a hard game to beat. but that just keeps me coming back for more...you can start out wit 6-6 people in your expedition of several classes, depending on what God you pick, you will have a different party leader that is supported by the God you chose and you will see children grow up into classes of two of the three domains that your God have access to like if its the nature domain, you will children grow up to be hunters and warriors, magic domain they grow up to be scavengers and scoundrels or zercas 
as you play you will earn points and when you have earned 100 point for things you do in game like adventures and quests, you gain a God Point that you can use to either help out the start of your party with equipment food fuel or starting characters,,,,or you can when you get enough God Points, unlock another God as the first one that you unlock cost 3 GP and the second is 6 GP,,,,,Did I say you will be constantly attack by monsters for a while ?
OHH,,,,You can craft stuff like weapons and armor after you put advancement points into the thing you want to craft, the other part is you have to gather resources to make those items, I suggest that you find a place where you can gather food and fuel at the same time and get about 65-70 of each then go gather the improved resources and make armor as you dont start with any of very bad armor, then make weapons and do quests and adventures. Oh, you have to put advancement points into resources too it has several settings of difficulty

author: {'steamid': '76561198030720157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4718, 'last_played': 1685242181}
review:
The stories within the game are definitely the high point, with some fantastic shorts and voice acting. It's unfortunate that more of the content is not voice acted, but still, a great highlight. The score as well is quite enjoyable.

The game does a decent job at a choose your own adventure type, following the path/ideals of a chosen god when you start. Unfortunately, since choosing a god path does not prevent you from going against their domain, nor are there any penalties in doing so, the player has to restrain themselves and stick too their ideals even though every other option might be VASTLY easier/more rewarding/better story etc. 

The autoresolve system is very overpowered. Even on "low" settings, you can win encounters with no losses that you would instead be completely obliterated by. Encounters are, all in all, still unbalanced. You will either run over them with ease or get completely slaughtered by what seemed to be an even match based on the previous fight. For a truly gruesome experience, you definitely want to avoid using auto resolve and try to figure out solutions to the various encounters. That being said, re-obtaining certain characters and leveling them to take on content once again is a complete slog/grind snooze fest indeed. 

The game's pacing is very slow after the initial exploration of the starting biome. The Red Hill encounter is a "hard wall" the results in a lot of grinding forcing you to explore the surrounding regions along with an absurdly long grind to build a boat if you did not settle a village for the craftmanship boost.

Since enemy spawn nodes are linked to your position in some fashion, if you stay in an area for a while, you can move on and explore the rest of Thea completely bereft of encounters and spawn points.

Settling a village is very different then Thea 1. Since you can refine materials upwards with coal in this version, you have greater liberty in settling location, focusing on the # different resource and a food types. This allows you to "create" any tier materials without leaving your starting island/village. It's not fast, but then that depends on your gather/crafting limits in game setup.

Village life is also a trap, as the village very easily gets overrun if Lightspawn start to occur on the island you settled plus any other nearby hostile factions. Setting down a village basically means your group needs to stay within the boundaries of encounters or it will likely get run over until your population grows to a decent size with a good balance of skill sets, buildings or equipment. You can't really abandon villages since cosmic shards are very finite (you get 2? per play through total). Besides, if you make Chosen rings with tier 4/5 materials, whoever wears it with a shielding or life leech weapon is basically invincible. 

The game is clunky, in its current state. There are too many systems and skills in the card system that causes severe balancing issues as much for players as for opponents.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117550327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 769, 'last_played': 1623193451}
review:
The game has the basic pieces of a good story and good scenario in place but fails to deliver. This is because the quests start out interesting but lack depth and fall flat very quickly. Choices hardly matter. Furthermore, there are only like 5 to 10 quest chains (and yes that includes side quests) in total. They brought over an interesting mechanic with God Points but really all Harmony based Gods are the same and while the Gods have interesting backstories, their backstories play hardly any part in the game itself,  thus killing the replayability that this game could have had if the execution was proper. 

Furthermore, growing ones population and expansion are not really mechanics in this game. At some point you will get another seed (people from previous Thea games will know this) which will allow you to expand but that's about it. Even though there are children there is no way to increase birth rate or manage your population. What you start out with is pretty much what you'll end up with in terms of number of people with the addition of a maximum of 1 or 2 people to your town. This takes away another set of mechanics that could have made towns interesting, but once again the game fails to see this through as well.

The few good things are that the game has a wide variety of resources, that translate into an interesting crafting system. The town survival and constant monster  attacks are interesting with a few different factions. 

Overall, this game needs more story content, deeper character development for the Gods, better population growth and management, as well as a better implementation of town expansion and growth mechanics. If they do that in a future DLC then I would recommend this game,  until then, sorry devs your game is just too bland.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023304900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1559790556}
review: The "Tutorial" is a basic account of click this here and click that there for card battles.  That's about it.  I have spent some time trying to figure out the rest of the mechanics.  You click, your party moves.  You make a camp and gather resources? only I'm not sure if they're gathering anything.  This is very confusing with little to no explanation on how things work.  If my camp is within one hex of a resources, so the game tells me, I can gather that resource.  Only that's not the case.  For most resources, there isn't a harvest option.  Any enemies met early in the game will decimate you.  The card battle system is not very inventive and strategy seems random and impossible.  I really want to like this game, but it needs work.  If you hover your mouse over something, a description needs to pop up.  If you hover your mouse over an action, there needs to be an explanation pop up.  Or even more simple, text on the screen that explains what different buttons and options do.  There needs to be a comprehensive instruction manual.  I've clicked a few of the "walkthroughs" and they are vague.  The game in it's current state is unplayable.  Hard pass unless more work is done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038290352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1562539206}
review:
This is a really fun game with a lot of character.  At 25 dollars, it's definitely a buy. There are definitely some rough edges, but you'll have fun with it.  I play it with my wife and while we're still on our first run through, I can already tell it was a good purchase.

There's definitely some room for improvement: 

1) there's not a whole lot of documentation and the tutorial doesn't really do a good job of preparing you for anything except the basics.

2) God Point (basically unlocking new content) is super slow. I mean, tediously, grindy slow.  I almost want to give the game a thumbs down based on it.  I'm 250 turns in to my first game and I'm sitting at 2 God Points unlocked.  I don't intend to play this game 50 times to see everything, and if that's going to bother you, you might want to hold off on playing.

3) the events get a little repetitive: I feel like I've done more than my share of demon dentistry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995159815', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1561030433}
review:
Unfortunately, I cannot recommend the game at the moment. The developers are constantly updating though, so my review will hopefully change in the near future.

I loved Thea, and had high hopes for its sucessor. Indeed, a lot of the changes and new mechanics make a lot of sense, and add depth and character to the game. The writing and art is still, if not even more, beautiful than in the first part.

But, there are huge problems with controls and the UI, so every single thing you do takes twice as long as it should take. As an example, crafting and cooking are constant parts of the gameplay, but you can't just double click a ressource to drop it into the recipe, no you have to drag it over. If you want to move your group, you have to click it, which opens a menu, then you can scroll to were you wanna go, right click , wait until the path shows, and then finally move. This take 6-7 seconds, and is just garbage compared to Civ VI were it would be 2.

This is exacerbated by the fact that the game isn't running well. I easily beat the system requirements, but fps is still quite low. The game seems to waste an insane amount of ressources, and there are a lot of reports of gpus etc. overheating.

Tl;dR: There could be a lot to love, but this game shouldn't have left early access. It is an unfinished product, and so I cannot recommend it at this point.

Edit 1: The performance issues seem to be fixed if I play on "fantastic" and then set everything to the lowest settings. I've send my stats to them and they are working on a fix. 
The controls are still a bit wonky, and I feel the game is a bit too grindy compared to Thea 1, but it is damn good game, and I can definetely recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119297620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 7825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2095, 'last_played': 1682323702}
review:
EDIT: The most annoying problems have been solved since the review below, and that's why I'm changing it to positive. There's still a LOT of work to do in the UI department, though.




Unfortunately I can't recommend this game. It has a lot of character and interesting, meaninful mechanics, but the terrible UI and some weird design decisions ruin this potential. The game is just a click fest: there's so much unnecessary clicking for it to show you information that should be readily available it's disheartening. But the real problem with the game is that, even though its creators designed a very good card-based combat system, you can never know what an enemy stack is composed of, and, once combat is initiated, which skills the opponents have. Add to this the fact that you can't run from some encounters and you have a great combat system thrown down the drain, becoming nothing more than a disguised lottery. Since you don't know what you're up against, you can't really strategize as much as you normally could, nor pick your fights, equip yourself accordingly etc.

Hopefully this will be fixed in next patches, because there's a lot of potential here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072044943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 12556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4837, 'last_played': 1584723774}
review:
This is one of those cases where I'd really like a "neutral" option. I'm going to lean into "Recommend" because there are a lot of good things in this game: the art, the lore and atmosphere (except for the random joke-y references like the "orcish inquisition" event), the gameplay itself is great fun and the "one more turn" syndrome is more real with this game than any other I've played. (helps that turns pass so quickly) It's also a relatively cheap game while being well-polished and mostly bug-free.

However there are two major caveats:
1) The developers have decided that absolutely everything must be dictated by RNG with a very high variance in the possible results. From your stat and skill choices, to starting gear, to even quest triggers - almost everything is subject to a die roll. This can obviously be very frustrating if one of your key character never gets to learn one of his main skills, or also make a playthrough a lot easier if you stumble into a lategame-worthy piece of gear on turn 20, which has happened to me. Unlike a game like Blood Bowl, you also don't really get to influence most of those rolls at all - if the game never gives you good skills to choose from, that's too bad start again. In some aspects, it feels more like playing a slot machine than making meaningful strategic decisions.
2) Every playthrough starts to feel same-y after a while, unlike a game like Endless Legend that can still feel fresh after the tenth game. This is because not only is the beginning always the same (and with the amount of restarting you'll likely do, you'll end up sick of those early quests really soon), but there are a lot of strategies and choices that exist but are simply not viable. For instance, out of six islands you can really only settle on two because the four others have lategame doomstacks waiting for you right off the bat. So your choices are to either settle on one of these islands or play full-nomad (which is considered quite a bit stronger right now) but that's it. There are a lot of possible events and characters to meet but eventually the game does start to become quite repetitive and it hurts its replayability.

The devs are committed to pushing a new version every two weeks as of writing this review, but we don't have much visibility on what changes those will bring apart from the addition of things like achievements and cloud saves down the line.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997601276', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1559517734}
review:
I might try to revisit this later, but at this current time I cannot recommend playing this sequel to one of my favorite 4x games I've played.  Now, I know I have almost no time into the game at all, but not since playing the last Assassin's Creed game I played (Unity, I think?) have I just instantly known I wasn't going to keep playing the game after only having played about an hour.  

For AC, it was a totally different reason, I just realized after playing I had played so damn much of the series that I was burnt out and didn't even enjoy the basic gameplay anymore, the core mechanics.  An hour or so into Thea 2 and I realize that I just wasn't enjoying the core gameplay mechanics, the combat namely.  Combat in the first game had a learning curve but was overall simple yet brilliant.  Once you figured it out, you knew what was going on.  The combat in Thea 2, I don't know, it's like the devs we respected tried to get too ambitious or something.  The simpleness and good flow of the original is replaced by something that's overly complicated enough and requires enough clicking and acting to just completely break the flow and make you not excited to play combats, which are basically what's going to be eating up all of the time you spend in the game, since even simple combats with 1 enemy can be a chore with so much clicking and micromanaging.  So yeah, just at a base level, the combat became unenjoyable and I just don't want to play it anymore.  I might revisit this game at some point, but right now I'm more likely to go back to Thea 1 then I am to start this back up again.

Sadly, I'll be refunding, because it's simply not fun or interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103463979', 'num_games_owned': 2354, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1559258700}
review:
Thea 2: The Shattering sıra tabanlı bir survival, strateji ve rpg oyunu. Oyun birkaç farklı oyun türünün özelliklerini barındırdığından içeriğinin oldukça dolu olduğunu söylemek mümkün.

Oyunun strateji mekaniklerinin en basit yönü olduğunu söyleyebilirim. Haritanın bir noktasında başlayan yönettiğimiz küçük grubu hayatta tutmak, geliştirmek ve kaynak bakımından zengin bir yere yerleştirmek önemli. Keşif amaçlı gezdiğimiz haritada düşman gruplarla karşılaşıyoruz. Burada rakibimize uygun taktikle birimlerimizi yerleştirip savaştırıyoruz. Kart oyunlarını andıran bir savaş ekranı olduğunu söyleyebilirim.

Oyunda birimlerimizi, karakterlerimizi vs geliştirebiliyoruz. Çocuk yaşta edindiğimiz karakterlerin gelişimini tamamen biz belirliyoruz.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025889917', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 180252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81955, 'last_played': 1689625364}
review: Absolutely the best turn based strategy game I have played. Perhaps appears quite complex at first, a little slow for some and still has some development to complete at the time of this review. However, if you like a deep immersive turn based game, where no two games are the same and with plenty of scope for character growth then this is definitely worth a go. I have played beta game from the day of release and this is on the back of being a major fan of Thea 1 The shattering. The development team have worked hard to make frequent changes (and there have been many) and I have been impressed that they have listened to feedback and tried many suggestions. The changes to the Alpha version will be less frequent, I guess, but the main game is there and it has been honed to get the balance right. So the challenges are: rare materials and items are tough to make: the best character classes are difficult to obtain; it is not always easy to predict outcome of events and it requires careful resource management to decide when and where to build your first village. The rewards are: a highly immersive strategy game with plenty of character races, portraits, classes and skills; a massive choice of equipment types and abilities; a range of deities to be the chosen for; hundreds of research developments related to materials, equipment, buildings and recipes; a vast array of factions to befriend or destroy and lastly testing, humorous, quirky and downright cheeky events to overcome. Yes there is period of learning the ropes, but it is not hard and the rewards are a really immersive entertaining game which I have had thousands of enjoyable hours to master and still learning new stuff all the time. Definitely worth the money

author: {'steamid': '76561198013132245', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 316, 'playtime_forever': 3549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1669688506}
review:
I have logged many hours on Thea: The Awakening.  I always played on fairly high difficulty, so I never finished that game.

From what I can tell so far with almost 5 hours logged in Thea 2: The Shattering, this is quite similar to the first game, with a lot of additional features added, but still roughly the same feeling when playing.  If you've never played either, I'd say this is well worth the few dollars more over Thea: The Awakening.  

!!!They have also added a Demo version that will let you play 50 turn games for free!  Super!!!

The game is fundamentally a group RPG hack+intel+sneak+heal+overpower+several.other.fight.modes - and - slash (you see what I did there right - I replaced the word "hack" with a bunch of other things, because you're not just hacking - the battles come in many flavors and don't always involve killing).  While Thea: The Awakening had 1 dimensional battles with cards all lined up on a string and events taking place between 2 fighters next to each other, Thea 2: The Shattering has 2 dimensional battles that are a little bit more mysterious exactly how they work.

The most difficult part of the both games is not knowing exactly how difficult an enemy group is, until you show up on the battlefield.  In Thea 2: The Shattering, it's even more difficult, as the enemy hand is hidden as you lay out your cards, and it's hard to know what tricks they'll have up their sleeve.

Additionally you can build your whole city anywhere you like because you start out with a band of nomads that are literally running for their lives in this horror-filled wasteland.  Do you risk getting wiped out just to try to make your city out of better materials for a long-term boost, or just build one as soon as you can?  I don't know!  I haven't gotten that far yet!

So yeah - this review is written while I'm still a little green - but I have played enough to say this is by far one of my favorite all-time games and I am just a tiny bit sorry I waited as long as did before buying it.  If you only have time for 2 games this year, this should be one of them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122721506', 'num_games_owned': 1639, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 5842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5789, 'last_played': 1621780604}
review:
《Thea 2: The Shattering》是一款趣味性极高的策略游戏，讲述的是玩家作为神明的选民带领信徒拯救西娅世界的故事。游戏的玩法综合了以跑团玩法为核心的探索冒险和以资源采集玩法为核心的异界求生，使得玩家能体验到丰富多彩的内容。

游戏的一开始，玩家可以在选择信奉的神明、初始的人物以及额外的奖励物资。选择完毕后，玩家将带领着信徒小队开始在陌生的世界中探索，在探索过程中能遇到遗迹、村庄、游荡的怪物和种种事件。除了地图上明显的可触发事件之外，每回合结束的时候还会随机触发各种事件。在每个世界之中，玩家能根据自己意愿选择某些分歧处的行为（当然，部分行为要求对应职业或者对应物资、对应神明领域才可实施），根据玩家的选择，也会导致不同的结果，从这点上有些类似于跑团。

除了冒险以外，游戏里还有资源收集的元素，地图上有各种各样的资源点，玩家可以通过驻扎营地或者建设村庄来开启采集物资界面。在收集了物资之后，玩家可以利用这些物资建设建筑，制作工具和装备，最终建立起繁荣的小村庄。除了资源精炼、装备制作、建筑建设外，游戏里还有人口繁衍的设定，结为夫妻的一对角色（游戏里允许是同性）在一段时间后可能会触发获得孩子的事件，孩子在一段时间后能长大成人，养成元素十分丰富。

游戏里的人物升级能从二到三个升级选项中选择奖励，当孩子长大成人时更可以根据孩子的属性来选择不同的职业试炼。除了升级系统外，游戏里的装备系统也十分丰富。游戏里的装备是可以自定义涉及的，玩家可以从四种类型的主材中选择一种，再从四种类型的辅材中选择一种，然后放置对应类型的材料即可开始制作装备。每种类型的材料又分为数种等级，同一等级的材料可能还有不同的特点，这使得制作装备的配方极其多变。不同材料不仅会影响到装备的属性，更有可能影响到装备的性质（比如带有特殊的属性或技能），这种材料和装备的变化也是游戏的一大玩点。

但是，游戏存在着一个问题，相比于养成内容的丰富，游戏的战斗环节十分枯燥。这里不详细赘述游戏采用的卡牌战斗模式，只说一下我个人的体验，那就是可操作的余地不多，而且还非常繁琐。事实上，游戏里没有太多需要思考的内容，战斗部分基本靠数值碾压来决定胜负，经营部分也没有太多运营的技巧。取而代之的是，这款游戏更注重经验的积累，不同事件里选项导致的结果，不同材料制造装备的区分，不同建筑和装备的作拥，玩家需要一次次探索来积累经验（值得注意的是，在默认设置下，游戏不允许s/l，所以试错的结果往往是要重头再来），最终才能拯救世界。

"Thea 2: The Shattering" is a highly fun strategy game that tells the story of the player as a godmind leader leading the believer to save the world of Thea.

At the beginning of the game, players can choose to believe in the gods, the initial characters and additional rewards. After the selection, the player will lead the believer team to explore in a strange world, encountering relics, villages, wandering monsters and various events during the exploration process. In addition to the obvious triggerable events on the map, various events are randomly triggered at the end of each turn. In each world, players can choose certain divergent behaviors according to their own wishes (of course, some behaviors require corresponding occupations or corresponding materials, corresponding to the Shenming field can be implemented), depending on the player's choice, will also lead to different results. From this point, it is somewhat similar to running a group.

In addition to the adventure, there are elements of resource collection in the game. There are various resource points on the map. Players can open the collection material interface by camping in the camp or building a village. After collecting the materials, players can use these materials to build buildings, make tools and equipment, and eventually build a prosperous small village. In addition to resource refinement, equipment production, and construction, there are demographic settings in the game, and a couple of roles (allowing same-sex in the game) may trigger an event for the child after a period of time. After the time, I can grow up and develop a very rich element.

The character upgrade in the game can choose rewards from two to three upgrade options. When the child grows up, he can choose different professional trials according to the child's attributes. In addition to upgrading system, the equipment system in the game is also very rich. The equipment in the game can be customized. Players can choose one of the four types of main materials, then choose one of the four types of auxiliary materials, and then place the corresponding type of materials to start making equipment. Each type of material is subdivided into several grades, and the same grade of material may have different characteristics, which makes the formulation of the production equipment extremely variable. Different materials not only affect the attributes of the equipment, but also affect the nature of the equipment (such as with special attributes or skills). This material and equipment changes are also a major part of the game.

However, there is a problem with the game. Compared to the richness of the content, the battle of the game is very boring. I won't go into details about the card battle mode used in the game. Just talk about my personal experience, that is, there is not much room for maneuvering, and it is very cumbersome. In fact, there is not much to think about in the game. The combat part is basically determined by numerical crushing, and the operating part does not have much operational skills. Instead, the game is more focused on the accumulation of experience, the results of the options in different events, the differentiation of different materials manufacturing equipment, the construction of different buildings and equipment, players need to explore again and again to accumulate experience (note: In the default setting, the game does not allow s / l, so the result of trial and error is often to come back again, and ultimately save the world.

review: A great combination that's not done well very often - 4x style strategy and RPG. Definitely worth your time if a mix of those sounds interesting to you. The writing and quests are pretty interesting and character stats are used in very cool ways. A more polished and enjoyable experience than the first game, and while there are still some rough edges it can be very engaging. The card game used for skill check resolution is both a little more complex and tricky to understand than the first game's, but overall I think it's an improvement, especially given the completely non-random auto-resolve option, which lets you opt out of the card game when you're willing to take the auto-resolve results.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284438487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1980, 'last_played': 1652407729}
review:
Great Game, NERF LIGHTBRINGERS! The game is actually almost up to par on my expectations from playing Thea 1. In all honesty, it's fun and kills countless hours every time I play it which leaves me feeling satisfied, NERF LIGHTBRINGERS! The only real issue I'd say I have with the game is possibly the balance between Nomad style game-play and City Builder game-play. Having a city makes it feel like a sin to send anyone out to do anything until 150-200 turns in when you have your city pretty much built, while Nomad ramps up pretty quickly once you make 'The Other Ring' and feels amazing for adventure play-style, NERF LIGHTBRINGERS. Better hope that a dedicated wiki gets created and info pours in, because even with the tool tip some things are still very unclear and can only be inferred upon what exactly they do, NERF LIGHTBRINGERS! Oh did I mention the biggest and most seen enemies, the disgusting LIGHTBRINGERS, are stupidly hard and deceptive as all hell? See, the game has this lovely mechanic that tells you the difficulty rating of the fight you are about to get into, which is all nice and all since it works for everything except LIGHTBRINGERS (Seriously, nerf them for the love of all gods!). A level 1 Lightbringer village having a difficulty rating of seven on the starter island? Seems very.... I don't know impossible?  What happens when I want to take on lvl 7, 8 , 9, or 10 lightbringer villages on the outter isles? Just give up and bang my head into a brick wall? Then there's the instance when you run into a Lightbringer spawn that has a difficulty rating of 2, TWO NOT TWENTY, and they spawn in a mob that has 91 hp and 21 damage, oh yeahhhh sure that's TOTALLY a difficulty rating of 2. It just doesn't make any sense. One other thing I might mention is be ready to rename a lot of your villagers, because seeing just about everyone in your village with a variation of Slava or Slawa at the end of their names gets old after the 4th or 5th game, at least it did for me. Anyways, I would absolutely recommend getting this game and taking your time in learning all the ins and outs of it. The game is complex, beautifully made. Yes, it may have some balance issues, NERF LIGHTBRINGERS, but it hardly detracts from what is essentially a amazing adventure, story, and game. (Oh and the sound track is pretty good too.)

On a side note: Multiplayer is pretty fun as well if you have a few dedicated friends to enjoy the game with, however they really need to fix how god points (currency used to unlock new gods and their trait cards) is distributed at the end of a multiplayer game since at the moment it seems only the one who ends the game through the summary screen actually gets the points, which is counter productive to enticing players to actually want to play multiplayer.

Overall Rating: 8.7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198003552176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 12588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5335, 'last_played': 1694811564}
review:
A mighty fine sequel to perhaps the best game in its genre (whatever that genre may be). Thea 2 improves on and fleshes out nearly every aspect of the first one, and also adds a few new bits in besides. The story and setting are still solid, and now Lada, goddess of love and hope and good times in general is head of the Pantheon, so hurray!

For those that didn't play the first game...

The Good: That stuff I just said, and also interesting and deceptively deep combat, robust crafting, satisfying exploration, an in-depth difficulty editor, kick-ass art, and hot, naked, redhead bird ladies. Also, I'm one of the starting characters (I kickstarted it)! So, hot, armored, axe-wielding warriors, I guess?
The Bad: Can be quite a grind, especially when it comes to making end-tier resources. The challenges/fights are all very similar, regardless of which skillset they use. The highly random nature of events can be frustrating for some. 

Highly recommended if you want some turn-based exploration and story-heavy strategy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990902063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1640537792}
review:
Overall, a very strong and fun game, so let's keep that in mind while I write this.

I'm going to start with the potential cons because they are very few. Almost everything is a positive.

1 - The learning curve is super steep. About 89 degree straight up. Now, personally, this doesn't bother me. I like exploring the different systems in the game and learning about them, but it is worth knowing.
2 - Sometimes you lose in a way which feels unfair. And yes, I understand that there are Rogue-lite elements in this game. But some clue about the difficulty of challenges would be welcome since a single failed challenge can simply wipe you out.
3 - The game has an irregular decision tempo. There's quite a few period in the game where you'll simply be clicking next turn.

Ok so with that out of the way.

The game has great style. A lot of amusing and interesting story elements from a culture that is not often explored (Slavic myth). I love the challenge system. I like that there are often more than one way to succeed at a challenge (physical, mental or spiritual). And while the decision tempo is perhaps a bit slow, overall the decisions are very meaningful. Overall, this game is a different beast than a lot of games out there. There's a bit of 4X strategy, some RPG elements, some Rogue-lite elements, and a "card" based tactical battle/challenge.

It you're willing to accept some quirks, and put in a bit of time to get passed the steep initial learning curve there's a lot of content as well. There are different gods you can follow (that subtly change the interactions with the story). Each start for each god can be configured in a number of ways. You can unlock additional perks, which make for different combinations.

I'd give this a 9 out of 10. A very solid game from a company that clearly builds with passion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001861572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1582664332}
review:
Although I have none of the technical issues some people here describe, I still can't recommend this game.

Being a huge fan of Thea: The Awakening, my hopes were high for this sequel. Unfortunately, the game manages to take several steps back compared to it's predecessor.

My main issue is that the sense of adventure and survival seems completely gone. The heavy amount of repetition, micromanagement and grind were always somewhat present in Thea. Not only has it gotten worse in part 2, but it seems to have become the whole point of the game, like some type of crappy F2P mobile mmo. The world building is still present, but it all feels empty now because of terrible flow. Very disappointing, I hope the developers are aware of the fact that something is off and that they have a road map of some sorts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144212976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 1286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555, 'last_played': 1582755749}
review:
I'm new in the world of Thea, and i'm very satisfied with this game. I waited for something else, but this type of game is better than what i expected. This narrative, turn-based-strategy, with survival and character-developing elements, plus operating as a card-game in battles make this game a very interesting one for me.
Other interesting aspect in the game is the artwork, the characters' appearances sometimes amusing, or intriguing, often unusal, and because of this, the game has a different atmosphere than the mainstream games with beautiful heroines and heroes repeated until boredom. Also the narrative, the missions, and the story have an alternative feeling, which makes the game outstanding from the ordinary fantasy games.
An other very important component is the music, it's music could kill a game, but also can animate it. Thea2's music, in my opinion, is the best component of the game, it creates a very immersive atmosphere, and i could listen to it forever!
Weak points of the game is the poor sound effects in battle, and the poor visuals which are representing the strikes and other actions in the battles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970733474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3130, 'last_played': 1585175358}
review:
Le jeu aurait dû rester en Early Access.

Beaucoup de trucs ont été améliorés côté "Qualité de Vie" (réduction des clicks et tout) comparé à Thea 1 mais beaucoup de points qui mettaient le jeu comme unique en son genre ont été bousillés.

1. Les ressources.
Dans Thea 1, les ressources avaient un but et étaient distinctes. La soie était légère, le bois noir appliquait du poison et ainsi de suite. Dans Thea 2, elles sont toutes pareilles: Tous les bois sont pareils, tous les gemmes sont pareilles. La seule différence est la quantité d'une autre ressource identique "essence" qui varie de l'un à l'autre. Un type de bois a plus d'essence de bois qu'une autre, c'est tout. À la longue, tout ce ressemble. On ne pense plus "j'ai ce type de ressource et je vais adapter mes tactiques en conséquence" mais plus "prendre n'importe quoi et faire n'importe quoi".

2. Les ressources avancées.
Dans Thea 2, les ressources avancées doivent être assemblés au lieu d'être récoltés. On parle de centaines de tour pour faire une seule ressource. C'est ridicule.

3. Les statistiques.
Les statistiques sont mises pêle-mêles sur l'écran et on ne sait pas trop qui fait quoi. Par contre, dès qu'on lit les détails, on se rend compte que seulement une faible quantité d'éléments sont importants et le reste prend le bord assez vite.

4. Les combats.
Les combats sont maintenant divisés en 3: Physique, Mental et Spirituel. C'est bien comparé au n'importe quoi/comment de Thea 1 mais on sait pas plus qu'est-ce qui se passe. La table des cartes est peu intéressante. De plus, certains combats inévitables peuvent arrêter une partie car il n'y a aucun mécanisme pour récupérer lorsque les pertes s'accumulent. C'est une spirale vers le fond.

5. L'interface.
Certains éléments de l'interface ne répondent pas du tout, notamment au niveau du panneau des quêtes et de la mini-carte.

6.Le Monde.
Dans Thea 1, le monde était généré aléatoirement. Maintenant, c'est 6 îles, toujours les mêmes 6 îles. Toujours la même île de départ et toujours la même progression.

7.Les Dieux.
Le concept de cartes est bon mais c'est l'équivalent actuellement d'avoir un choix de 50 cartes avec seulement 2-3 de bonnes et le reste ne vaut rien.

8.Les quêtes.
Toujours la même chose au même moment ou presque. Les mini-événements ne sont pas balisés donc on peut avoir le même truc 3 fois d'affilés. Aussi, les options ne sont pas cohérentes car certaines ne mènent qu'à des échecs assurés.

Bref, attendez un peu avant car actuellement, ce qui rendait Thea 1 intéressant n'y est plus.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982971433', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 5114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1654053970}
review:
Apesar de me doer dar uma crítica negativa a Thea 2, ele simplesmente não vive à altura do seu antecessor. 
Primeiramente, está muito claro que o jogo foi lançado antes da hora.  Uma coisa é dar suporte contínuo ao jogo, outra bem diferente é lançar uma versão supostamente "gold" para só depois ir corrigindo imperfeições que deveriam ter sido sanada no beta ou no early access. 
Se isso não bastasse, comparado ao primeiro Thea a dificuldade desse jogo disparou mesmo no nível mais fácil. O primeiro Thea não era um jogo fácil, mas você conseguia aprender relativamente rápido, enquanto neste a curva de aprendizado está bem mais complicada, fruto tanto de um tutorial mal feito quanto de um manual inexistente, como de uma quantidade de estatisticas para cada personagem e diferentes abordagens para cada encontro que são na maior parte das vezes incompreensíveis, ou, quando são compreendidas, exigem um grau de atenção gigantesco para resolver os encontros. OU apelas simplesmente para a "autoresolução", um truque barato utilizado pelo jogo para você superar encontros quando você for muito mais forte que seu oponente. 
O problema é que o jogo vira um enorme grinding, no qual você perde muito tempo matando montros de baixa dificuldade, sem saber ao certo, na verdade, qual será a dificuldade do encontro, até ser surpreendido por encontros aleatórios que pune seu grupo sem nada que se possa fazer ou colocam contra inimigos cujo grau de dificuldade é muito superior ao do restante do grupo, o que pode fazer você perder todo o seu jogo se não tiver salvo varias vezes em diferentes slots para fugir do encontro punitivo. 
Não seria terrível se ao menos você pudesse repor eventuais personagens perdidos com alguma razoabilidade, como ocorre em Darkest Dungeon, mas aqui perder um personagem qualquer significa passar horas novamente fazendo um grindindo com um novo personagem até recuperar a equipe que se tinha quando perdeu, isso se a essa altura do campeonato não tiver surgido outra ameaça muito maior do que os seus personagens estão preparados para enfrentar. 
Lamentavelmente, conseguir vencer o jogo atualmente está muito mais para uma questão de sorte do que propriamente de habilitade ou estratégia. Enquanto não corrigirem o desequilibrio no jogo e não pararem de trazer alterações a ele a cada dois ou tres dias fica dificil recomendar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005164860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1783, 'last_played': 1631837963}
review:
As of May 2019, I think the game needs to cook more.  I am going to wait to see if it gets any better, but I am not enjoying it yet.

In the first Thea, you could have fun if your dudes rolled junky stats by exploring, crafting, and equipping.  You could focus your buildings to make more dudes so that you could have the mix you need to survive.  Exploration was viable and fun.

This Thea, your dudes' stats are critical to a lot of mechanics. Exploring, crafting, equipping, and questing can only do so much.  Even if you can craft or find a decent equipment, it might as well be foam toys for these guys.

I don't have enough dudes that I am willing to lose my highest level ones to the random monsters or any plot quest at this point in the game.  I am playing it on the lowest difficulty, why am I frustrated?

author: {'steamid': '76561198039048284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 23441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4323, 'last_played': 1689369075}
review:
Feels like there should be two reviews: one for those who are new to Thea and one for those who played the first.

Thea 2 has you managing a small group of devout survivors in an early medieval somewhat post-apocalyptic world. The game is at its best with aesthetics, drawing inspiration from slavic mythology, which is a welcome change of pace. The only thing that compares, off the top of my head, would be The Witcher.

Yet it is just as original in terms of gameplay, with an incredibly complex but not obscure and mostly fair card system. During combat, each of your character is a card, with strengths and weaknesses depending on their class and equipment.

You'll spend most of your time exploring, working on a choice-based branching main quest to save the world, getting sidetracked with numerous quests and events, looking for rare ressources and crafting tailor-made equipment for your cherished characters with them.

Now one thing you need to know before purchasing the game is that it's punishing. Much more than the first, and even at the lowest level of difficulty. Think X-com. When you fuck up, your people WILL die, you WILL struggle to replace them. Fucking up includes trying content that's too hard for your party too soon, having an unbalanced party and meeting your counter (lacking magic-users and being faced with a magic challenge, having a backline character with low-health and no shields against AoE, having a shield-reliant team vs true damage...) or simply not being efficient enough.

All in all, an excellent game worth much more than its price with high replayability, but only for masochists and perfectionists, if you're looking for theme-park gaming with fast, easy, forgiving fun you're in the wrong place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042846139', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1683857987}
review:
I picked up this game when it first was released since I enjoyed Thea: The Awakening so much. I got in a bit of a rut not enjoying map games for a while. That has since past, and I tried out the game some more.

It is very different from Thea 1! The original seemed very easy to me after a bit of playing it. I just played 3 games and hopped directly into a trap that instantly kills my whole party with reckless abandon. I haven't had this experience of learning what paths to avoid instant death since when I first started Thea 1, and I am thoroughly enjoying.

After my first death, I found out that character actually have 3 health bars, which means you can die by going in over your head in other challenges. In the first, you only had to worry during a physical fight.

After my second death, I found out that the difficulty of challenges is marked by a number in a circle next to the card that indicates the type of challenge. This is different than the skulls.

After my third death, I learned how to maneuver the dudes on the red mound without dying. (Don't try to flirt them when you have a party of all guys?) :P

I'm very excited to relearn a basically entirely new game with the same premise of a favorite one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044110464', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1583960237}
review:
The single most frustrating thing about the game is how they handled encounters.

I was a fan of Thea 1. Thea 1 had a clever way of resolving encounter and events with a mini-card game. While it was't particularly difficult or complex, it carried with it enough depth to make things interesting and keep the gameplay rolling. Your equpiment and rest of the logistic outside of these card games had a impact on them too so it was a great way of linking combat with crafting, city building, etc. Generally, people loved it.

It's like they saw the success of this model and decide to turn it up to 11 for Thea 2. A new card game is created as a minigame meant for resolving enocunter in Thea 2. In short, it was too much. Way too much.

The unnessessary components:
- Encounters now take into consideration of a board/coordinate
- Card play now invovles using points (like mana) instead of the old "you play one I play one"
- After play phase, the execution phase where actual moves take place invovles a lot of "cast time" statstics. Thsi really complicates things.
- Each character of different move sets and you are essentially playing a different card depending on which mode you choose

Okay now, this can sound awesome or horrible depending on what you want. But trust, as someone who is a avid card game player who has tried just about every card game on the market, this is garbage. The irony here is that the mini-card game of Thea 2 is actually really cool and would be fun... IF IT WAS A SEPERATE GAME OF ITS OWN. Here are my reasoning of why it failed as a component:

- You are spending litearlly 70% of a supposedly 4x game figuring out how to beat an overrly complicated card game. It really is a turn off when you want to manage your town but have to play a game of greater gwent everytime you want to do something. often I want to explore a ruins or somethign but would decide not to simply because "I don't really want to play a card game right now".
- It's exhuasting: despite being a "mini-game", failing it can result in death of your people. Which is really bad. If you mess up the consequence is brutal. On the other hand, succeeding gives you kind of meh reward most of the time. So it feels like you are grinding your mind to "not lose" rather than "to win". It's not satisfactory at all and feels more work than game
- Everything ultimately leads to winning the mini-game. Whatever your objective is, it basically will eventually come down to playing a game of cards that is really not rewarding. When playing Thea 2, you are not playing a 4x. you are playing a card game's campagin mode that uses 4x element for progression, and it's honestly not really fun.

"But Calavontis, what if I like card games?" Well so do I, but the issue is the focus of the game wasn't on the card game. it honestly has enough mechanic behind it to be a standalone game, but the way it's implemented to be part of a greater game simply does not work. It's just not fun.

Honestly, my suggestion to the devs would to make a seperate card game completely. Make "class/characters" like mages to be the collectables and let players customize their characters to have different moves. 

it's unfortuant that this game fails simply because it was too ambitious in making something worked before even better. A real shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047246483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1669662402}
review:
Très très très grosse déception.
après avoir adoré le premier Thea j'étais optimiste pour ce deuxième opus et je ne comprend pas comment on a put arriver à un résultat aussi triste. 
La narration est brouillon (les quêtes secondaires sans enjeux pops sans connexion avec une trame scénaristique que je cherche encore après 10h de jeu).  Vous aimiez l'univers? bah on s'en fout, allé donc faire votre vie avec des farfadets.
L'interface est incroyablement mal foutue. vous vous souvenez des déplacements pas comodes du premier (ouvrir la roue, sélectionner déplacement puis cliquer sur la case ou faire un appuis prolongé)? c'est bon ils l'ont gardé! vous vous souvenez de l'interface d'équipement facile d'utilisation pour préparer vos personnage à tenir tête à des situations variées? c'est bon ils l'ont abandonné pour une interface minime mal foutue ou la nécessité d'aller dans un sous menu. et tout est comme ça, vous devez aller dans des sous menus en cliquand sur des cases minuscules pour ajouter des tâches alors que dans le premier opus cela était très lisible. On a régressé de 10 ans... ah et même sur la carte de campagne, tous les points d'intérêt se ressemble, donc bon courage pour savoir à quelle sous quête renvoie un groupe sur lequel vous foncez. c'est vrai que c'était trop dur de mettre le titre de la quête liée qui apparait quand on met le curseur de la souris dessus, ou un scintillement de titre de quête lié, non faut qu'on y voit rien c'est bien mieux.
Tiens on a parlé des combats? bah parlons en! parce que Thea c'est une mécanique d'interaction interessante avec une possibilité de spécialiser ses personnages en différentes approches pour réussir à triompher de situation variées. on pouvait donc préférer la discretion, les interactions sociales, la magie ou le bourrin pour affronter le chaos environnant. allé Thea 2 c'est partit pour.. merde! MERDE MERDE MERDE! putain votre nouvelle interface de combat empêche de réellement faire des tactiques construites pour jouer sur les armes, de déployer les talents complémentaires de nos gars, et, cerise sur la gateau, de même déployer tout nos gars! non mais sérieusement? on ne peut pas faire combattre le groupe entier mais on peut faire agir 3 fois le même gars sur un combat? donc t'as ton péon qui se fait broyer comme un steak pendant que le reste de ses camarades regardent le massacre? ELLE EST MORTE LA LOGIQUE! et puis parlons de la variété de gameplay! l'ennemi principale ici, on s'en rend vite compte, est une espèce de lumière corruptrice qui prend possession des gens. Sauf que l'idée était (la seule bonne idée en fait) au début ton groupe est errant tu peux te ballader et choisir où place ton village. A la putain de seconde où tu le fondes, t'as les villages corrompu qui vont lâcher des monstres bien énormes pour venir te défoncer ton village (que tu tente de bâtir avec plus d'une cahute) et qui combattent uniquement par magie. et que tu ne peux pas attaquer avant en faisant une embuscade, seule la magie est prise en compte. et ils sont bien sûr ultra op. Là où thea 1 avait une courbe de difficulté ok, le deux est ridiculement facile tant que tu te balades et deviens GAME OVER dès que tu fondes ton village. on est donc obligé de rester des gitans pendant 10 ans avant d'être sûr stuffé et d'avoir monté les persos uniquement en magie pour s'en sortir? c'est beau la richesse d'un gameplay!

Bon on va pas y passer l'année, cette daube est une déception, on va gentillement retourner sur le 1 qui doit être mille fois mieux en le modant qu'un 2 plus raté que je ne l'aurais cru possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030754881', 'num_games_owned': 458, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 2236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1621316825}
review:
For a KS that was late one would hope that Thea 2 was just waiting to polish something that was really good.  Just the opposite.  Thea 2 is less a game than a proof of concept.  The plot at the start is indecipherable.

Conflict resolution plays like a card game, much like Thea 1 save the combat is a hot mess.  How to take actions and what that action does is woeful and poorly explained.  It might be good, but I honestly can't tell you how exactly it works. 

An annoying bit is the uneveness of dialog.  There is far too much modern parlance in it for my liking.

Graphically Thea 2 is pretty.  Character art is good, though it is goofy as heck that a child can go from that art to old woman in one turn. 

The gods you can play are behind a play wall.  That is irritating... especially as I am not really wanting to play more.

Maybe after patches Thea 2 will be a good game.  However as of right now it is not and you will have more fun playing Thea 1.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113245987', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1582403430}
review:
A laggy, barely playable mess that should have spent another year in early access. 
The game is unoptimized, having incredibly poor performance even though its art style is significantly degraded when compared to the first game. 
Its combat is lackluster and overcomplicated compared to the beautiful simplicity of the original. Many new concepts have been added, almost all of which I have found uninteresting, they only exist to make the game more complicated and unappealing to new players. The only good concept I've found in my short playtime is the new factions system, which I may very well come to dislike considering the disappointment of everything else. 
The tutorial hardly tells us anything and is incredibly obtrusive, and the new UI is terribly ugly and unoriginal.

Frankly, it isn't worth it. The original was amazing, but this one feels awful. I highly recommend you either get it on sale or splurge for the first.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992943573', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 7385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1625945940}
review:
TLDR; Better than Thea 1.

Type of game: A strange mix of civilization+rpgs+survival. 

While the game could use some UI improvements and is a bit grindy crafting-wise, it isn't enough to prevent the game from being fun. Just be prepared to lose a few games, or few key units, as the game gradually continues to get harder as time goes on (and a few surprise main quests that are a big jump in difficulty).
As a consolation, each game won or lost gives points that can help with the next game - new gods and starting abilities/units can be unlocked.

I feel that the price is right for the enjoyment of the game, and is a unique experience.
