author: {'steamid': '76561198039677203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 61779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26998, 'last_played': 1684428183}
review:
In summary, as a player of Thea 1 and Thea 2, I found the user interface, game play and game mechanics of Thea 2 to be a big improvement over Thea 1. However, in my opinion, it lacks the replay ability of Thea 1. 

Thea 2 also contains mystery mechanics and other mechanics that don't make sense. Example 1: Luck trait has 2 variants, why? Luck is so poorly explained as a beneficial trait. Example 2: Equipment weight is an issue and its an added dimension to the game play that I liked. However, some items weigh the sum of their parts while some items have a weight unrelated those parts. If you are planning to gather some lighter and higher tier materials to make that better and lighter armor for your strength deficient witch, forget that idea. There is a good probability that your crafted results will be undesirable because its heavy weight does not align with the expected results from using lighter materials. 

In Thea 1, you earned points towards making a god more powerful. Therefore, I played it a lot because I was curious to see how each god evolved. This is missing in Thea 2 and I miss that. In its place, you earn god points to unlock new starting options (cards) for a god. This may be to simulate having a more powerful or varied start, but after a few unlocks, nothing seemed appealing to me. In fact, many of the unlocks just make the game harder. For example, why would I want to select a single character that costs me 4 of my 4 start up points over selecting four characters. It seems like the reward for earning god points is to make the game give the player a harder starting setup which translates to a greater grind. This is the opposite of Thea 1.

In Thea 1, each god had bonus that made game play and character load out planing interesting. In Thea 2, only 1 god seems at all appealing to me. The power of having 37% master craft chance 400 turns into the game with mostly T2 + T3 materials meant that I never had to go to other islands or get higher tier materials to win the game. Thus, other god choices are only harder not different. This limits game reply value. Also, the main quest system is entirely limited to the starter island, as far as I can tell.

Thea 2 has an excellent crafting system, but, it is complex. It is also lacking in UI details. For example, you cannot preview trash and master crafted variants. 

Moreover, the game forces you to pull out a calculator, in order to decide which gathering tool to craft. For example, if I plan to send out a team of 4 to do some gathering and I want them to have gathering tools, will it be better to make the +3.0 gather tool or the 121% gather tool? Who should get which type? It would be useful, although a lot of developer work, to be able to preview the net effect of an item (all 3 qualities) on a specified character both inside and outside of benefits from an idol before crafting it.

Early game frustration in Thea 2 cancels out much of the enjoyment that could be experienced with the outstanding event system. The events are varied, plentiful and mostly helpful. They employ a decision tree mechanic and reward / penalize a player based on choices taken. There is no way to predict the outcome of a set of choices and even those outcomes are selected from a set of possibilities for the exact same set of player responses. This is an excellent game mechanic and makes even repeating events interesting and a gamble. However, frustration sets in when you want to experiment with the possibilities because the game lacks a quick save and quick load.

I like the large variety of weapons and buildings in the game. However, some buildings seems to be of no value. For example, getting 1 T1 lumber per turn was just too low to be worth building even if you built a base without access to wood. Even the highest T5 variant of this building is lacking given the construction cost. Also, the building that generates pets never gave me a pet after 100's of turns. The trader building only had an initial trade on opening and never another. Perhaps these are incomplete, but the game has released.

Characters seem to have either a defensive(tank)/support role or damage/summoner role. The best weapon selection would be one that maximizes that role. As a result, there are many crafted weapons that I would never use because there existed another weapon that was always better for use in that role. For me, weapons like spears, axes, polearms, scrolls, bows and others never served a role.

As good as the crafting system is in Thea 2, it is missing a critical element that, in my opinion adds tons of replay and weapon load out variety in Thea 1. This missing element is the random stat or two that a crafted item would get in Thea 1. For example, crafting a sword that randomly got +2 Gather and +2 Str. I would try a sword combat gatherer instead of a +Wis Artifact gatherer.

One of the aspects that does add to replay value is the large set of difficulty settings.

The combat system has lots of options and the game can auto resolve them. I found it interesting that, if I replayed battles that were previously auto resolved, my outcomes would sometimes be vastly different. There were cases when auto resolve netted me a few scratches but manual resolve lead to a few character deaths. Then there were cases when auto resolve netted me a complete team death but manual resolve provided me with a perfect victory. Although some characters almost died on round one, by the later rounds, life leech and shield leech restored them to full health and shields.

Game stability was impressive. I had just one crash to desktop in many hours of play.

Bugs are few and mostly addressed. The only post release bug I encountered which corrupted the game file and this happened twice, is when I started with 5 characters and split them into two groups one hex apart and made two camps which both gathered. On a later next turn, when one team broke camp and merged with the other, that camp would get a harvest radius of two. On the next turn the game file would be corrupted, a pop up message informed me and the camp had a gather radius of zero.

Sound and graphics are exceptional. The UI seems to have a mobile device compatible design but functions with a mouse well enough.

The underlying story is reasonably compelling. The quest help, however, seems barely functional, perhaps even incomplete. For example, a couple of NPC villages sent me on quests, but the map does not auto scroll me to the location (hint hint devs) when I accepted the quests. Clicking on the quest link shows me the story related to the quest so far, but not where to go. Annoyingly, in mid game after having visited many NPC villages, revisiting an NPC village tells me that either I am already on a quest (where to go, I don't know) or there are none available. It would be better to clearly state one way or the other and auto scroll the map to where the player needs to go if the quest remains incomplete.

Finally, I expect there to be changes that will improve the game, like loading from the pause menu. There is also one god that I was not able to unlock even though I have 27 unspent god points. I still would recommend this game, but there is much room for improvement. I'd score it at 8/10 and, with further improvements, it could score better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052155135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1558695643}
review:
j'attendais avec impatience la suite du remarquable "Thea the awakening", hélas me voilà bien contrit : peu d'améliorations  si ce n'est cosmétiques (mais le premier était déjà très bien) Par contre pas mal de mauvaises surprises et tout d'abord un système de combat sans aucun intérêt dans lequel vous ne contrôlez rien à part le placement de départ selon des règles assez obscures. Car là est le principal défaut de ce deuxième opus : une interface de jeu plutôt lourde et qui n'est absolument pas documentée: par exemple il m'a fallu fouiller dans le forum pour comprendre comment on pouvait créer un village, ce qui est tout de même l'une des clefs du jeu. Bien sûr il y a un tutorial mais celui-ci est bien trop basique pour vous permettre d'avancer. Cela n'aurait tout de même pas coûté trop d'efforts que de publier un manuel détaillé sur le jeu.
Bref je ne trouve pas mon plaisir dans cette suite et en l'état je ne saurais vous la recommander.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037694920', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 163661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 112, 'playtime_at_review': 72825, 'last_played': 1712421334}
review:
Thea 2: The Shattering is a fantastic game to play. I could never of guessed I'd of loved it as much as I have.

At times you will find yourself chewed up, spat out and kicked into the ground but it's meant to be a hard game about surviving in a dangerous world. It's the difficulty that has me coming back all the time to try new and unique strategies to see if I can win with them. After all how exciting would the game be if I played the same way every time? It would get old very quickly.

There are a good number of events, enemies and things to do in the game and with the game being randomly generated you can easily find yourself having to do something different and new just to avoid getting killed. One turn you can be roaming the landscape destroying small weak enemy groups and the next you're forced to jump on a boat to avoid a powerful enemy group you can't beat that wandered out of the fog of war. There's never a dull or quiet moment unless you make it happen.

The game does have its fair share of problems still, but the Devs are fantastic people and take player feedback quite seriously. There have been many changes in the game due to player feedback so it shows that the Devs care a great deal about trying to make the game enjoyable to as many people as they can. It would be good if more of the games problems could be resolved sooner but the Devs are a team of 6 people and only one of them is the programmer so he has a lot on his plate. With a little time and some patience this game will be a well polished gem.

As a bonus the modding scene for Thea 2 is in full swing with many great mods already available and with many more great custom content to come so there are many great ways to enhance your Thea 2 experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007300752', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1572108497}
review:
Check out my regular Thea review and you'll see I love this series. And I fully admit that just a couple of hours of playing time isn't enough to judge a game like this. 

But...

140 hours in Thea means I have some idea how to play this series. I was also a KS backer so I want this series to succeed. The first game was a hidden gem and I go back to it from time to time. Fun, difficult but with a true sense of progression. I'm not feeling it so far in this sequel.

When this sequel  released I tried multiple times to get a game started when some random even within 30-40 turns caused an entire wipe. I'm not talking about some major stack of mobs that I can see coming and decided to take on with an inexperienced squad. I'm talking about sheer random encounters with no chance to avoid them. Choosing the wrong option resulted in a stack wipe, end of game. That exact same type of thing happened 3 times in those couple of hours of play time, all within the first 50 turns.  That's not skill. That's not fun. That's just simply screwing the player over until they learn the "right" answers to something they can't choose to avoid in the first place. That NEVER happened in Thea. So I put it away for some months.

And I stayed away while this got patched out. And it seemed to because my latest games didn't meet the same grisly end. Instead now I'm...bored. Nodding off at the keyboard bored. And I think I know why. 

The first game had a tension in it. To progress you had to research. To research you had to get research points by either fighting, exploring or (the main way) crafting. This required the player to go out into the world and tensely uncover resources, mine them while monsters are around and get back to base...all while guarding your base as well. There was a balance to it. There was a sense of exploration too.

They took out that tension and balance. Now, you just...research. Big deal. Yes, you still have to go claim resources but until you want to build something there's no drive to HAVE to do so. There's no starting city anymore so you have to find a spot for one or stay close to a decent food spot while wandering - of which there are very few. I can't tell you how big of a problem this is because you can get "food deadlocked", which actually is pretty easy to do. If you're next to just one food resource and you're running low, you won't be able to gather enough to build up a surplus. You'll just break even...which means you can't gather enough food to move from the spot that you're on. So early in the game the exploration ENTIRELY boils down to finding a spot where you can gather from at least 2 food resources so you can slowly build up enough to continue to explore. It's an absolutely stupid design decision especially considering you always only start out with about 10-12 days of food!  I'm incredulous that this glaring exploration issue still remains.

The map is zoomed in and I don't think that's a good thing,. I prefer the sense of scale from the older, zoomed out map. My squad definitely moves fewer hexes per turn which does nothing but to slow an already slower-paced game down. I haven't experienced much of the story but so far it's not as good at the first one at least at the outset. No cosmic seed or Gods struggling to survive. In fact, I'm not even sure what it's about. Maybe that, in part, is why I'm falling asleep when trying to play this game.

The interface, which was clunky in the first game and was a turn-off for many, isn't any better. It's still clunky. In fact it may be worse. I went to go build a building and had 3 choices - like a normal one, a "magical" one and something else. Except I couldn't click on the other two choices but there was nothing to tell me why. 

Some people say the combat is better than in the first game but I never, ever played Thea for the card game. I despise card games and even great ones like Slay the Spire fail to capture my attention. I played Thea for the other elements and I don't think those elements are as good this time around. Thea 2 was one of my most anticipated games this year and it's turned out to be a dud. Maybe I'll revisit it and get hooked but I think that's unlikely. I just think this is the plodding, duller version of the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999169735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 8991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2263, 'last_played': 1585294151}
review:
Orcs beating gay elves and half-demons struggling with their identity. When did it all become so tiresome? When did everything become so... bland? Apparently in 2019 the height of one's writing abilities is coming up with political diatribe that reflects the contemporary world and the writer's own political views. Maybe I'm too old, but back in the days people actually told stories and not everything was a political commentary. Of course things were political even back then, everything is and has been, but the difference is the art of subtlety, which apparently has completely disappeared. Hammering down people with your opinions and practically screaming at your readers might work if you're writing a book or a column which is a political commentary about the current world, not a good idea when it comes to writing something that isn't supposed to be one. Preaching usually isn't a good way to change anyone's mind, especially in politics.


The game itself I do like, tentatively. It does suffer from couple of things though, but I'm optimistic they'll be fixed eventually. The combat is too slow so you end up using auto combat most of the time. I do like the combat and find it better over the first one's super simplistic one, but the problem is that this one takes too long. It would be helpful if you saw all of the skills your units have without having to click them, every damn time. The game is also somewhat clunky to play meaning that there seems to be a delay of sorts for things to happen. You'll be constantly setting up camp and breaking it, all the time. The crafting system itself is nice and I love how the resources work, but the crafting menus themself are a pain to navigate, which sucks since that's what you're doing all the time.

The itemization has been streamlined quite a bit compared to the previous Thea. The new crafting system is nice and actually quite cool, but the fact that your people use less items makes me wonder. Though crafting really high tier gear will take ages and if you're planning to equip your entire party with highest tier items that's going to take hundreds and hundreds of turns. The pet slot is also a thing I don't really understand. What's the point of any other pet besides a horse? What's the point of classes which can't have a pet? Your entire party loses 3 movement due to them not being able to have a horse. Sure, it might sound hilarious for a snake or for a rat to have a horse as a pet, but from gameplay perspective it's poop. Doesn't help that the horse also helps with carry weight issues immensely. Naturally, in the near future they will nerf the horse into oblivion, because we can't have nice things.

The exploration aspect has been improved. and the world is divided into islands. I like the idea, but it could use improving. At the moment they are basically just pieces of land with a bit different colouring and events. Every island has its own resource, so there's that, I guess. Maybe in the future you could make the islands have modifiers affecting exploring or combat. Maybe not, who knows. Sea travel could also use something to make it better. The layout of each island is basically the same too.

The narrating was superior in the previous title. I liked the fact that one fellow did most(?) if not all(?) of the work. It gave the game a real story telling vibe and some real charm. Him changing his voice an old witch or a snake was somewhat hilarious, but at the same time it was unique and gave a cozy feeling. The fact that he did it well helped.

Graphics are fine, besides the camera, which is extremely problematic. The lack of zoom (apparently going to be implemented, yay!) and the camera angle make things not cool. The angle is horrendous causing things to overlap and sometimes making it difficult to see in which hexes things are located in.

I'll still recommend this game for those who are interested and fans of the previous game.

review:
This game is fantastic, but I just can't put my finger exactly why I like it so much. As a first experience, it's an amazing journey. The atmosphere, the world, the storytelling, it's very immersive. The excellent soundtrack makes it even more so.

I love this game. I highly recommend it for anyone who likes rpgs, or 4x games, or survival games.
This game has very high replayability value, but even if you just play it a couple of times, it's still worth it.
Another factor is how moddable it is. After steam workshop is implemented I imagine there'll be a lot of mods to spice up the games.

I also have to mention how awesome the developers and the community are. I've been participating in their discord channel for a long time and the Developers are very talkative and great at receiving feedback. You notice how much love and effort they put into the game.

Thea 2 may be on full release now, but it will still grow and grow for a long time to come. For its price, it's a must-have game, its uniqueness alone warrants a purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052399320', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 3667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1582957440}
review:
So i've sat down now for a few hours and gave the "out of early access" version a shake before writing a review. I played the first Thea like most here and the differences between 1 and 2 are hot and cold. Honestly the changes made seem to be very forward but neutral and in ways where people will evenly either like or dislike the new direction. Things like Combat, Progression, etc. that are core concepts in gameplay, were all touched by adjustments.
Personally, I think most of the changes were either good or a fine enough replacement for the original feature, so I have had fun so far. I will say that I haven't gotten off the first island yet and it seems many people's problems are with the end game, so I cannot comment on that yet. but if everything else is great and then there's some balancing needing done in end game, I think that should deserve a recommend overall.
Pros: Basically similar gameplay to 1, making it familiar fun with new elements thrown in for new experiences.
         Continues themes of great emergent storytelling with slavic/european mythology (mostly untouched by media)
         Many reasons to keep playing, be it a new god, new random world, or just to see quests you haven't seen yet.
Cons: Must go through Summary>End the Game>Main Menu to load a game for some reason. (EDIT: idk when but they must have fixed this a while back. apparently they patch things every couple of weeks and even had a big free dlc recently! MuHA is great!)
          End game needs more tweaks for balancing/pacing. Likely related to inflation/deflation of difficulty settings.
          Not everyone likes islands apparently? (i'm that weird guy who loves playing islands/archipelago maps in 4x games so not a con for me)

This is a very brief review but I wanted to get the thumbs up out here because this game definitely deserves it. Can't wait to see what expansion-sized updates the devs add to this Thea! (and hopefully port this one to Switch like 1)

author: {'steamid': '76561197987438257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5665, 'last_played': 1684923902}
review:
Thea 2: The Shattering is a 4x strategy game, of sorts, with turn-based combat presented as a card game. The game has lots of flavor text, events, and writing (the walls of text generally have "TLDR ME" options). Thematically, it is a fantasy/apocalyptic story with lots of mythology (generally slavic), but it isn't afraid to throw in pop culture references and easter eggs throughout the myriads of events.

Do you need knowledge of mythology, slavic medieval life, or Thea 1 to enjoy this game?
-NO

How hard is the game?
-There are lots of difficulty settings, save scumming is allowed, as is event editing. However, the game is merciless until you learn the different systems. My tip? Treat it like a 4x strategy rogue-like and enjoy your adventures. 

Is this game better than Thea 1?
-Depends who you ask. In my opinion, yes. Thea 2 has so much potential (though it may not have tapped in to all of it yet)
-Early Access had a lot to offer, and the team behind it care about their game and community. You can expect more content and updates, if their track record is anything to go by.

Recommended?
-Yes, for those that like strategy games, 4x, leveling up characters RPG-style, mythology.
-No, for those that generally dislike rogue-likes. The game is more unforgiving than say Civ6 or Stellaris, in some ways. And you have to PLAY to unlock more and more starting perks. (Though, in my opinion, the start of this game is way more interesting and fun than a new Civ5/6 , Stellaris, Eu4, etc, game)

author: {'steamid': '76561198031481634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 32858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17202, 'last_played': 1693834018}
review:
Love it. (Love the first one too, a true gem). I picked this up the very first day purchase was available. I have been really pleased to see how well their team has managed the early access, the regular dev blogs and updates. And to see how they have solidly progressed the development of the game along the way and truly have made use of the opportunity that EA provides for with real users playing during development, and even integrated bug submission, easy ability to switch between beta branches to keep your save game going between updates. Its been very enjoyable to follow, and even from day one of early access with a very incomplete game, the core that was there was a good Thea play experience, while providing ongoing anticipation of what features will arrive next.

I find the core mechanics of Thea, growing and evolving your party, to be very enjoyable, especially the rich Slavic lore, and the range of possible characters and choices and their downstream influence. Its very much a 'just one more turn' experience I think. The crafting and resource gathering systems are also pretty good and augment well with the party and quest systems. The art and music are great too. I think all the new systems added in Thea 2 are very pleasing additions to the Thea gamespace.

But I also really enjoy that this is for me, a very casual game. I don't have to get too bogged down. I don't have to be 'deep in the game' unlike other types of titles, or VR at the opposite spectrum of total engagement, which I enjoy all of those kinds of experiences, but sometimes light is good. So I can get up and walk away, come back, etc. But its still attractive, engaging and rewarding where I am not inclined to disengage and start reading the news or shopping. 

So yeah, all in all I think this is a great title. So is the first one. And this is a developer I will continue to follow their work. Great stuff, if you liked the first one, of course this was a no brainer and you already should have this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967050510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 22578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17814, 'last_played': 1585110112}
review:
I was a huge fan of Thea 1, and Thea 2 definitely delivers.  The combat system in Thea 2 is very different - I highly enjoy both systems, but the new system in Thea 2 I have to say has more flexibility and potential.  The quests and random events are extremely enjoyable, and now you have over a dozen neutral factions to interact with.  The God Card system is a drastic improvement over Thea 1's God level-up system.  The art and music are amazing.

Some balance and quality-of-life improvements could definitely be welcome, but I'm not worried because I know the devs are definitely listening to the player base.  The game has come a LONG way since it first entered Early Access, and we know there is still more content coming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041681580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1557779889}
review:
I don't usually write reviews without plying some hours to get a fair evaluation.  I generally can't stand people that review a game after 0.6 hrs played, however please forgive me for becoming one of them.  I played 87 hours the first Thea game and enjoyed it.  After 96 minutes of the sequel, I can only state that for me it wasn't fun.  The combat has been changed for the worse,  and the mental combat invariably leads to your character and the party edging closer to Jimi Hendrix dreams and insanity.  I survived the 60's, don't need to relive it in my games.  

A monk on a mountain top told me long ago "Get lots of fiber and don't play games that aren't fun."

author: {'steamid': '76561198073545504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 13284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7843, 'last_played': 1588605633}
review:
Достойное продолжение первой части.
За время раннего доступа игра постоянно шлифовалась, превращаясь из бесформенного камня в огранённый алмаз. Был проведён весь цикл работ от пробы пера и фич, до баланса всего и вся, и итог мне однозначно нравится.
Как и в первой части, геймплей спокойный и ненавязчивый, объединяющий в себе не слишком мудрёные 4Х стратегию, РПГ и ККИ. Вторая часть продолжает выбранный курс, когда к игровым механикам применимо слово "просто" исключительно в своих лучших смыслах, но не стоит думать, что она не может быть сложной - настройки сложности имеются на любой вкус. Вдобавок, теперь тут есть возможность игры по сети! Ах да, относительно первой части, бои тут теперь намного менее рандомны и в большей степени зависят от игрока, а не от того, как легли карты.
В общем это та игра, за которой можно приятно провести время. Кстати, несмотря на отсутствие перевода, для комфортной игры, не углубляясь в сюжет, достаточно самых элементарных знаний английского, даже не дотягивающих до базовых, как у меня :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198215272943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 69073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8839, 'last_played': 1690477415}
review:
(147.3 ч. в момент написания)
Разработчики молодцы, надеюсь не опустят руки со временем и получат достойное вознаграждение за свой упорный труд. Игра - шедевр, в нише пошаговых стратегий. В сравнении с первой частью на голову выше, сбалансированнее, интереснее... и это уже на этапе бета-теста. Всем кто качает пиратки... советую купить эту игру (по скидке) и не мучиться уже)) и разрабам приятно ;) 9/10 один минус за оптимизацию и русский язык, которого нет... но надеюсь всё починят.

(сейчас)
800 часов. Куча стримов и гайдов. Подвожу черту. Разработчики убили реиграбельность понижением сложности. Каждую последующую партию нам играть легче, одни и те же квесты, новые возможности для последователей за божественные очки. Зачем с первого прохождения вбухивать ВЕСЬ лор игры в голову не подготовленного игрока. Это сложно переварить. Славянская философия очень своеобразна, как и история. Самые простые решения, которые можно применить уже сейчас:
1. Порционно выдавать новые пачки квестов, при каждом новом прохождении, может быть даже исключая старые пачки. Далее, ещё жёстче привязать квесты к богу или типу избранного персонажа или к сложности партии. Не так как сейчас 90% общих квестов и 10% уникальных, а наоборот. Порционность позволила бы дополнительно подсадить фанатов на ДЛС.
2. Усложнение каждого последующего прохождения. Либо квесты должны быть сложнее, либо настройки усложнения мира открываться постепенно. Прошли на лёгком, попробуйте на среднем. Прошли на среднем - попробуйте на сложном и т.д. То же самое с новыми фракциями. Играем за Девану - на карте есть фракция лесных демонов. Играем за Мокошь - Водных демонов и т.п.

Полировать игру и убирать огрехи можно вечно - о них вообще умолчу. На мой взгляд именно стратегического подхода не хватает, чтобы взлететь на орбиту. Ну и пиара известными блогерами.

review:
Thea 2 is mixture of 4X, RPG, card game and rogue-like - it's one of its kind no game is quite like it. If you like some or even all of those you should definitely check it out.
Thea 2 has amazing replayability - if I could only play one game for the rest of my life this would be it. It greatly improves and expands on the concepts of Thea 1.

For me it's one of the best games I ever played - hence a happy [b]9/10[/b]

[h1]Quick gameplay summary[/h1]
In Thea you start us with a small group of characters (determined by your choice of gods and which traits you choose) - you need to survive, battle monsters, face random events, gather resources to craft new things, research new materials and recipes or just not starve. You want to find out why the world has been shattered and restore the power of your god. To do this you roam the lands, eventually found a village and recruit more characters/make babies.

Encounters are done via a card game where your characters and their skills are your playing cards - however, there's also an auto resolve. Challenges can either be fight, social or magic which different characters are suited differently for.
You can adopt lots of difficulty related settings yourself, the game is hard in general (there is perma death) so it is challenging. Random encounters can leave you cursed or lose some of those precious resources.

[h1]pro[/h1]
[list]
[*] interesting character growth and equipment mechanics - leveling up and outfitting your characters can make all the difference
[*] encounters/quests - the encounters/quests are absolutely gorgeous. Decisions matter, the skills, traits and race of your characters matter (options you otherwise wouldn't have). It's not black/white - it's grey-ish and is a very mature world. A lot of them have interesting decisions even with impact on future encounters and a lot of them are out of the ordinary. There are also A LOT of them
[*] there are often multiple ways to resolve encounters, just through choices or through multiple different challenge types depending on your group - combat focussed groups, groups focussed on talking their way out of situations and magic user groups can all be successful which makes the game more RPGy/individual to me than classics like Baldurs Gate (heresy, I know)
[*] replayability - every game is very different, world is randomly generated etc. you also unlock new traits to play with
[*] world building - the world of Thea is interesting and unique, you'll come across all sorts of interesting creatures most of which can end up in your party (not only elves, goblins and orcs but also ghosts, demons etc.) and they're meaningfully different and have vastly varying power levels
[*] I enjoy the card game a lot, it gives you interesting options of different skills to use and multiple group setups can be successful - it's also difficult enough that it's not clear what the best move is
[*] devs are great and listen to feedback, for Thea 1 they even published a big free DLC - so there being more post launch support isn't even a question, it'll be there
[/list]

[h1]con[/h1]
[list]
[*] micro management - it can tend to get micro managy, like throwing away/recycling items when you're over the carry limit or optimally equipping every character (especially if you're up to > 15 characters), crafting/cooking good items so if that sounds like a drag for you the game might not be for you
[*] the game can feel unfair at times - some events let lots of your good resources go to waste, curse characters or lead you to a hard challenge. There's some chance involved in children growing up as to which class they can become. Not having the class you need can suck but you can influence it with what attributes you train children in. To me that's part of the challenge/fun (some events also have ridiculously good outcomes), but again not for everyone.
[/list]

[h1]Comparison to Thea 1[/h1]
Some people in the reviews claim that you'd be better off playing Thea 1 and that nothing much has changed so I want to highlight some things:

[list]
[*] most controversially the card game is different (2D instead of 1D and you can play characters multiple times albeit at the cost that you can play less total cards) - I was very skeptical at first but love the new system so much that the Thea 1 system feels simplistic
[*] attributes and challenges have been vastly streamlined - Thea 1 had what felt like 100s of attributes and 9(?) different challenge types which was simply overwhelming. Thea 2 is down to 3 challenge types (fight, social, magic) which have 2 main attributes linked to each one. Then there are challenges against enemies (can use weapon skills) and against concepts (can't use weapon skills). It's still very fun and challenging to build a group but you don't need to consult the manual all the time. Well done!
[*] You can actually have 2 settlements (hopefully more in the future) and you start without a settlement so you can choose where to settle or just roam the lands
[*] Through the introduction of essence (a craft material has x of essence y) crafting is much more clear what will get good results and predictable
[*] obviously there are islands and sea travel with some fun events now
[*] islands all have their own different biome and encounters, I like this design but it also means that events might not feel as varied because they are bound to certain islands you have to be on to experience them
[*] portraits are colorized which imo gives the game a much more polished look
[*] some quality of life features made it in (give a group 10 varieties of food that last for 70 days)
[*] auto resolve now roughly previews the result and you can still decide to do it manually which is super great - wish every game did this
[*] Gods only give you "slots" you can use, you can slot traits you unlocked in those slots yourself which is fun
[*] You can now actually do research to up your research points and gain some bonuses
[*] seasons and weather effects have been introduced which give an interesting twist every now and then/way you should adapt
[*] quests/encounters are great and varied as ever, there are even some nice references back to Thea 1 (ever wanted to know what happened to the dwarf and his rusalka wife?)
[*] characters can now have pets
[*] you can summon creatures onto the battle field
[*] one of the downsides is that not everything is voiced anymore, loved the voice actor
[/list]

Again it's a great game as is. The last couple of patches also addressed some balancing problems some of the negative reviews complain about. I can really recommend the game and am also still looking forward to where it will go/DLCs/Addons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003496314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 9138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4043, 'last_played': 1675704687}
review:
Кратко - игра хорошая, интереснее первой части, но со своими проблемами.
Подробнее:
  + Множество вариантов старта, благодаря настройкам божества и псевдо-случайной генерации мира (т.е. при каждой новой игре вы будете делать упор на наиболее доступном виде ресурсов на стартовом острове и отталкиваясь от него качать снаряжение и прочее).
  + Полезны все три основных параметра, но игру можно пройти в чистую при помощи любого из них.
  + Интересная система исследований.
  + Хорошая боевая система, у вас есть шансы одолеть вручную события, которые не может одолеть автобой (кстати, автобоем вы будете пользоваться в соотношении  ~30 к 1).
  ~ Отличная идея с островами, но морские путешествия это жгучая жопоболь от случайных событий с сумасшедшими требованиями.
  ~ На позднем этапе игры очень много гринда, поэтому приходится вручную распределять собирателей и ремесленников таким образом, чтобы производилось и собиралось нужное кол-во ресурсов во всей производственной цепочке: уголь, Т3 > Т4 > Т5. 
  - Некоторые случайные события слишком сложны для вашего текущего уровня развития.
  - Слишком много боевых событий за ход, иногда случается до 5 штук за один пропуск хода.
  - Ресурсы не сбалансированы, некоторые просто не нужны. То же самое с предметами и постройками.
  - Интерфейсу следовало бы уделить больше внимания.

review:
Steam needs to give us another option other than yes or no for a game review. Maybe? If desperate? Rainy day? Barely?

I have a lot of frustrations with this game based on backing it in kickstarter and what I wanted was ignored by the developer. I wanted thea 2.0. This isn't it. 
I uninstalled and ignored the game for more than 18 months.
Now if have tried to suppress my frustrations and retry the game. 

After giving it a run for a few weeks, I have to say that the developers have improved the game significantly since I last played it. It is a challenging and enjoyable game. The lightbringer faction is too strong  still, and the non human children progressing to adulthood is very limited, but otherwise it is worth a go. The stories and quests from thea are a nice bit of dressing, Just don't call it thea 2, cause it ain't that.

review:
Замечательное развитие идей  первой части. Плюсы:

author: {'steamid': '76561198106842450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1994, 'last_played': 1685735523}
review:
Thea 2 es una interesante mezcla de géneros que van desde la gestión, casi como si fuese un 4x clásico, hasta un juego rpg con un combate táctico basado en un sistema de cartas con los componentes rpg de turno.

Comparado con su predecesor, es un salto adelante en todos los sentidos, ya sea en el sentido de jugabilidad, gráficos, sonido y considerablemente mas intuitivo, pero también tiene cosas que no sabe hacer tan bien.

Una las principales, es el hecho de que tengas que jugar un orden de islas adecuado para conseguir progresar en el juego o los enemigos te van a destruir de mala manera (esto fue solucionado al poder elegir un mapa que esté separado en biomas pero en el mismo continente) 

Las misiones principales me parecen considerablemente menos interesantes en el punto de vista de la historia, pero son bastante potables. Un detalle que le quita nota, es que carezca  de una traducción al español.

Volviendo a los puntos "no tan buenos" el juego es mas lento que el anterior, y muchas veces, sobre todo en las primeras partidas vas ir al remolque de los enemigos y si "tardas" mucho te puede ser algo cuesta arriba acabar un juego o que sea eterno y necesites 1000 turnos para acabar una partida "corta o media"

El progreso en la actualidad es bastante mejor, en particular en términos de dificultad.

No me voy a explayar en los puntos buenos correspondientes al predecesor, ya que hay muy buenas añadidos en todas las facetas, uno dellos sería en como funciona el sistema población. Los niños ya no son un objeto y crecen siempre, independientemente del limite de población, por poner un ejemplo. O poder hacer materiales mas avanzados con carbón y un recurso anterior, las mecánicas de la aldea, y que no tienes que limitación a la hora de elegir si quieres un edificio o otro. En la actualidad, depende de la esencia de los materiales que hagas para determinar lo bueno que es un edificio.

Luego hay puntos que podrían ser mejores. Para la gente que le encanta el componente de inmersión, estaría genial el hecho de que ya que ahora los personajes tienen hijos entre si, lo de que pudieras rastrear su linaje y este influenciara sus estadísticas del futuro hijo, ya que las estadísticas son vitales para nuestros vástagos, ya que tienes que cumplir algunas para que puedan acceder a ciertas clases. 

Habría que añadir algún tipo de evento en plan "matrimonio" y evitar posibles incestos o poligamia descontrolada, ya que ahora mismo, tus personajes pueden tener un hijo y ese hijo tener un hijo con su madre o su abuela, algo ridículo.

Espero que en una futura expansión esto sea algún componente "importante" o en Thea 3.

Le doy un 8/10 en este momento, puede que tenga una nota más alta según el juego salga de EA y saquen los DLC gratuitos, ya que el predecesor mejoraba bastante con la expansión de los gigantes.

Recomiendo absolutamente el juego para los que les gustó el Thea 1, para los que no han probado anterior, me es más complicado, ya que esta mezcla de géneros es complicado encontrar juegos similares. Es un gran juego pero al mismo tiempo no es demasiado profundo en muchas zonas. 

Digamos que para los que no han jugado al predecesor, les invito a jugar al anterior y luego pueden dar el salto a este, ya que esta traducido y lo considero mas "simple"

PD: El juego de momento no esta al Español, cosa que también quita un punto para llegar al 8,5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032996700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2454, 'last_played': 1557014739}
review:
Too long and too much unnecessary random. 

First: if you want to create lategame equipment, you will have to farm a lot. Much more, than worth it. And both resources and research points are very slow to gain, compared to the amounts they are needed in. 

Second: when growing up a child (one of the most important ivents of the game - gaining a producer/warrior/etc) your options are randomly based on stats of a kid, and then you are again randomly tested if a child passed a test. So, if you wish to have some special interesting characters you would have to save/load a lot of times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006038479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1690015283}
review:
Big fan of Thea The Awakening and overall I am pretty excited for Thea 2:The Shattering. These are my initial impressions which I will update later. The new card game is a big improvement and the changes to children development and more developed characters is a big plus. Graphic improvements are a bonus.

Can't comment on story or events yet.

Not a big fan of the choices surrounding changes to the map system, having islands and sea movement was something I liked but the fact that each island increases in difficulty and some materials are pre-set to be on certain islands as opposed to random placements is not something I agree with. Would much prefer a move random experience where I could end up with two large land masses or seven small masses or one big and five little. This is particularly important for replayability.

review:

review: Hah, I'm terribly addicted.  I loved the first one and this sequel is worth every cent.  I bought it on April 26th and it consumed my weekend, 4 days later and I'm 41.9 hrs in.  Plenty of Gods, plenty of character options, plenty of quests ... plenty of everything! I hate to take play time away to write a review, but I was compelled to after this quest dialogue, "A couple of big bastards set up camp in a ruin we want to explore and they bloody ate our patrol! author: {'steamid': '76561198120990805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 10584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4397, 'last_played': 1684218003}
review:
Amazing Strategy/RPG, where you do not take care of your character/4-man group, but instead of a whole little village, consisting of various different characters with various strengths and weaknesses. Explore the island, succeed challenges and gather materials - you will need them all to grow stronger and build a working community. (In other words...survive)
Thea 2 is a real step past Thea 1. While Thea 1 was a funny, little whimsical mix of Strategy and RPG in a Slavic-lore inspired world, Thea 2 is better in every single way.
Pros:
- tactical combat/challenges resolution is better than Thea 1
- pretty art (now in colour!)
- instead of 1 island, now you have 6 of them - each with their own biome and special enemies
- lot more different races and demons, varied resources, complex and exciting crafting system
- better skill/bonus buying system for your god

Cons:
- it's one of those "one more turn" games :D
- the game has a lot of depth, complexity and a learning curve. While I like that a lot, new players should read a few guides to learn the mechanisms

author: {'steamid': '76561198089989828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 12056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4616, 'last_played': 1575564157}
review:
I'm happy
Thea 2, as the first one, took me and don't want to let me free.  I had to start again my 900+ turn party after the last maj, this fact would have turned me mad in another game, but here, i'm still enjoying this magic game. Btw, thank you dev for your kind answer when i asked about the Ea feature (i wondered if game developpers could avoid it) Your little team of 5-6 is making another pretty game, i love all in this game.
developer_response:
Hi, in response to your question, we are a team of 5, now up to 6, so we are in fact not able to fully test the game ourselves. But, this is not the only reason, the other one is the fact that player feedback creates a better game as far as our experience can tell. So many features and design decisions were made from T1 feedback, and so many more changes, added features etc were added during EA thanks to our wonderful fans playing and sharing their thoughts and suggestions. 

We try to communicate things as clearly as we can, but I am very sorry if you feel you were cheated in any way by buying a game in development. 

In short, it is of course possible to create a game without ea, but for small studios it is much more difficult and you are robbing yourself of the wonderful impact that you get from a real player base, as opposed to paid testers, who are simply not the same.

Hope this answers your question, all the best!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035886796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 11022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6082, 'last_played': 1581860057}
review:
More work than fun. 
I´ll list a few important differences between Thea 1 and Thea 2:

Islands:
Thea 1 has one big landmass where you could go whereever you want whenever you want. Thea 2 has islands and you should clear them in a specific order, gated by monster strength and your research. Because you can only harvest what you have researched. And without those ressources you have no chance to survive on other islands. In Thea 1 you could choose how fast you want to play the game, in Thea 2 the game decides how fast you are. That leads to a very similar game each single time. Starter island, then goblin island, orc and ice, dwarf and elf islands.And i know exactly before i start the game on which island is which ressource because it is always the same. 
With one big landmass and random ressource distribution like in Thea 1 every single game is different.

Crafting:
Level 1 ressources on starter islands, level 2 ressources on second isle and so on.. But the higher tier ressources are composite materials where you need lower farmable ressources and combine it into something better. Sounds good but is completely out of control now. Little example? I want a building and need 42 Earth cores for that. Earth cores are composite materials and i would need: 6888 Rubies + 2268 Darkwood + 9072 coal ! And everytime you harvest you get 20-40 ressources average. Not fun.

Events:
Yesterday i sailed back from a highlvl island to my crafting town. Full ship with great resources that i farmed there, it was dangerous and lasted dozens of turns. Long story short: 3 times the same sea-event, i won all 3, but i got 2 times the message: You were too slow(there is no timer) and now you loose 30% of your cargo. Unavoidable ressourcesteal even if you won that event. Same with at least another townevent where you loose 50% of your food! Not fun.

Story:
Confusing. The mixture of old speech and slang is really hard to understand if you are not born in an english speaking country.

These are just a few of the problems i see and i won´t talk about balance, itemisation and the weird factions because it is 1 month left in early access and i hope the devs can fix a few of those things. To date i couldn´t force me to play longer as a few hours per game and then see me restarting; it is just too predictable and tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320024131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 1038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1555251815}
review:
《Thea 2: The Shattering 西娅 2: 粉碎》是《Thea:The Awarning 西娅: 觉醒》 的续作，它以回合制为基础，包含 4X 策略、生存、RPG 和卡牌游戏为元素，是集各种策略类玩法的大成者。总结评价见最后。

游戏故事背景基于斯拉夫神话和其民间传说。玩家将扮演一位神，带领平民同时也是信徒在危险的世界中生存下来。最先要收集资源，最初只有基本资源，随着后续研究解锁得到更高层级的资源，建造建筑并逐渐扩张探索，提高信徒们的力量并通过招募壮大团队，实现游戏的最终目标。游戏地图程序化生成，有着丰富的地形环境和资源点。游戏非常注重细节：如人民吃的食物种类越多士气越高，士气越高有移速越快等收益；再如随机事件中根据人民状态会有不同的剧情选项。从不同的一整局都不会重复的随机事件，到物品制作合成以及城镇建设系统，再到支持多人合作游戏玩法，游戏的深度可能能让策略游戏爱好者 100h 都沉迷其中。此外，相比同类 4x 游戏来说，就 bgm 和图形西娅 2 算是其中的佼佼者。

相比前作而言，游戏在各种机制设定上尝试了很多的改变。如角色的统计数据变少，不是 23 个属性 和 9 种不同的遭遇挑战类型被精简为 15 个属性和 3 种挑战类型：身体（Physical）、精神（Mental）和意志（Spiritual）；再如资源系统的丰富，物品精华的加入：宝石精华木头精华等等，不过这点感觉稍微有点过；引入季节流动和天气影响；探索，科技树，随机事件也更为丰富；船舶航海功能的加入，让地图也更为辽阔。此外图形上有的很大提升也是值得肯定的点。

不过即使如此西娅 2 与前作上还是非常相似，至少本质上并没有什么大改观，各种意义上。游戏在增加各种系统深度设计的同时，也引入了很多累赘之物。就战斗系统来说，算是一大败笔。游戏以卡牌式对战来进行战斗，在战斗领域准备阶段双方花费行动点，互相放置角色卡牌并指定行动或单纯使用技能之类，总共有 8 轮准备阶段，之后才到战斗回合。角色卡牌的攻击方式各有不同，技能和武器都可以得到升级。该卡牌玩法的策略性主要体现在角色卡牌的放位和互相技能之间的交互，平衡性可玩性不作过多评价。但操作上实在是有些杂乱无章而又累赘，如果角色卡牌一多，玩家得点上个几十次才能真正进入战斗，一次战斗解决不了，可能还得一轮，非常浪费时间并且没什么意义。不过就个人观点，这玩法最主要的是来说不好玩。季节和天气带来的随机性影响，看起来增加游戏了可玩性但实在是不尽人意，这些机制并不能太好的带来什么乐趣，至少在游戏策略上不会产生丝毫的影响。

游戏缺少像样的新手教程。虽然初始界面也有教程 3 章，而进入游戏也有些操作提示，但相比游戏丰富的菜单和各种可点击图标相比还是太少，刚进游戏确有眼花缭乱之感，玩过 1 代可能上手会很快，对萌新来说非常不友好，当熟悉界面操作后估计早就过退款时间了233。

总结一下：
1、跟前作差别不大；2、游戏玩法复杂初期需耐心；3、好玩；4、某些操作设定多余

+ 非常有深度的策略玩法
+ 较为出色的图形和音乐
+ 支持多人合作
+ 内置冒险编辑器
~ 游戏教程并不完善
~ 无简体中文，需至少六级水平
- 吃内存严重，多因复杂的游戏机制
- 一些早期 ea 的 bug，优化也较差
- 过于累赘的战斗系统设计

author: {'steamid': '76561198061825518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 23353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4550, 'last_played': 1699713950}
review:
J'ai joué à Thea 2: The Shattering depuis que l'accès anticipé fut ouverte, dans l'espoir qu'il soit mieux que Thea: The Awakening. J'ai remarqué, du coup, beaucoup de changements depuis sa sortie et je peux désormais dire que c'est un jeu excellent MAIS avec des soucis quand même (il ne faut jamais mettre un 20/20 à un jeu de toute façon).

Je vais exposé beaucoup de points, dont certains seront peut-être ajustés après mon commentaire :

- Les graphismes : le jeu est joli et on est plongé dans une certaine détente visuellement parlant. Rares sont aujourd'hui les bugs graphiques. Quand il était sorti, les personnages que les joueurs possédaient ne correspondaient pas à leur miniature sur leur description. Cet exemple est un détail pour certains, pour d'autres c'est ce même détail qui améliore l'immersion dans le jeu.
- La difficulté : en fonction de l'équipe de départ (à l'heure ou je poste ce commentaire, on a beaucoup plus de possibilités pour faire un groupe de départ unique en fonction de la divinité slave qu'on a choisi), la difficulté peut être plus ou moins élevée, surtout que les joueurs peuvent modifiés la difficulté de la partie avant de la lancer, ce qui permet de gagner plus d'expérience et surtout des points divins qui permettent de débloquer des éléments permettant de créer son groupe de départ (un jeune orc, un jeune elfe, 50 matériaux, +10 de loyauté envers une ou plusieurs factions,...) . Parfois, il faut parcourir le monde des centaines de tours pour trouver des ressources suffisamment rares ET exploitables pour construire finalement notre village (ce qui diffère de Thea: The Awalkening où on a déjà un village attitré dès le 1er tour de jeu). Cette difficulté donne beaucoup de challenges aux joueurs.
- Le système de combat : Beaucoup plus complet que dans Thea The Awalkening. C'est toujours un système de jeu de cartes mais sur 4 lignes au total (2 pour le joueur, 2 pour l'adversaire). Il existe 3 types de défis : physique (pour tous les défis qui implique la vie des personnages), mentale (pour les réflexions mais aussi tous les défis de dialogues contre un groupe donné, pour l'intimider ou le convaincre par exemple) et magique (pour tous les défis lié aux enchantements notamment). Chaque personnage, du groupe du joueur ou de l'ennemi, est pratiquement unique avec des compétences qui lui sont propres. Plus le personnage a un niveau élevé, plus il est compétent dans un des 3 défis (c'est exceptionnel qu'il le soit sur les 3 en même temps).
- L'univers : La mythologie slave est très peu exploitée par les développeurs de jeux vidéos, ici il s'agit d'une chance de découvrir cette religion méconnue. Pour ma part, le jeu mérite de représenter plus de divinités, comme Vélès qui est le dieu du savoir ou encore Chernobog, le dieu du mal (ce qui pourrait varier le gameplay et les choix des joueurs dans beaucoup de situations). Il y a, dans le jeu, beaucoup de factions (presque inexistant dans le 1er Thea) où on peut devenir alliés comme ennemis jurés en fonction de nos choix et de nos échanges avec ces factions.
- Les mises à jour : Chaque mise à jour du jeu est importante car les développeurs mettent beaucoup de contenus qui varient beaucoup le gameplay et la difficulté (la mise à jour du 7 avril 2019 a ajouté plus de bâtiments à construire dans notre village en plus d'ajouter des variations de la qualités des objets mais aussi des ressources récoltées, ce dernier point n'était pas présent dans le 1er Thea).
- La langue et le prix : Malheureusement, à l'heure actuelle en tout cas, le jeu est disponible UNIQUEMENT en anglais. Pourtant, c'est un petit jeu de stratégie (MuHa Games est très peu connu dans le milieu des jeux vidéo) qui doit être mis en avant et donc être traduit en plusieurs langues (français, allemand, russe voire chinois traditionnel) par des traducteurs compétents (Malheur à ceux qui on très mal traduit les quêtes du 1er Thea, c'est d'ailleurs la communauté elle-même qui a dû faire l'effort de tout re-traduire pour que ce soit plus potable...). Pour le prix, je dirais qu'il fallait mieux l'acheter aujourd'hui qu'au début, mais après tout ce sont bien les premiers joueurs qui montrent les points à revoir pour les développeurs, d'où les nombreuses mises à jour.

Une évaluation conséquente de ma part, j'espère avoir été clair et que les développeurs puissent prendre en compte mon évaluation. Je continuerai à jouer à ce jeu encore et encore et bonne aventure !

April 11: The short review: Thea 1 is like the beta to this game. A ton of content added/changed. Where they improved in some areas they made other aspects more cumbersome/confusing. If you are interested in a strategy card game RPG Thea is great but buy the cheaper Thea 1 until this has progressed further in development. I know that I will continue to play this game and eventually figure it out read below.

Long review: OK wow, so where to begin. I have a few play-throughs on Thea 1 and a few hours on here. (enough to know what I’m talking about) First, I will outline the difference from Thea 1 then explain as if Thea 1 didn't exist for those who have not played it. I read many of the reviews of this game prior to purchasing. Some said it was better some said it was worse and some said it was the same. Although I didn’t get very far into the story line, I wouldn't say any of those things. 

     The idea is the same. You have a group of variously skilled civilians that are trying to survive in the unforgiving world of Thea gathering resources, researching and crafting buildings and items to improve the strength of your villagers and grow your group.to accomplish your end goals.

    The characters and game mechanics are drastically different from Thea 1. Instead of 23 attributes (sometimes confusing) and 9 different encounter challenge types EX: Fight, Tactical, Hunting, Intellect etc. it has been slimmed down to 15 attributes and 3 challenge types; Physical, Mental and Spiritual each with their own health bar.

In Thea 1 you start with one village center than cannot move and you build expedition teams to accomplish quest goals around the map. Thea 2 has a much more expanded map with boat building which allows you to travel between multiple islands. You don’t start with a settlement but you can create one from the start and eventually have more than one. Thea 2 also had multiplayer so you can team up with your friends.

    The resource system has been expanded to include 2 additional tiers of resources in addition to the original 36 from Thea 1 for a total of 54 different resources of 6 different types! EX: Wood, Leather, Metal etc. you can research and gather with different “essences” translating into traits for crafted items.  Wood has wood essence and gems have gem essence but special resources may have both. Maybe a little excessive in my opinion.

    Research in Thea came from crafting and encounters which made sense to me the more you crafted the higher your expertise resulting in more research. This has been updated in that you can now make your settlers generate research points. They have also added 3 tiers of each weapon type and accessory. This adds complexity and allows the use of higher-grade materials to make stronger items with more features. 

    The crafting system has also been updated and expanded. You are now limited to 2 crafters based on my current experience. This is very different that using 5 crafters and increases the time to craft an item. As mentioned earlier the different essences give you a variety of options when crafting items based on what you make it out of for example leather essence might give you the ability to increase mental abilities etc.

    Combat has also changed drastically. Besides having 3 different challenge types you now have initiative based on attack speeds. Instead of a line of cards placed in an order you have a board where you can line up your guys to attack opposing squares and choose battle or tactical abilities instead of that being predetermined. You can also play the same card twice at an increased cost in essence giving that card another action further down the timeline.

    Seasons and weather conditions have been added to give positive or negative effects.

    I was looking for a continuation of the original which I think was accomplished but I think the balance of the "improvements" traded complexity of too many attributes and encounter types to too many resources and a cumbersome research and crafting system instead of just steam lining everything and expanding on the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972785116', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1581538312}
review:
Thea 1 is a modern classic. If you want the most unique strategy game released since the 2003 version of Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic, you need to play Thea 1.

This sequel, however, I sadly cannot recommend. It seems the developers wanted to go mainstream, with less stylized graphics and a less unique combat system.

Now, the combat in Thea 1 was divisive (I found it brilliantly simple and innovative), so if you for some reason didn't like that combat system, or don't like manual combat in strategy games, by all means, go ahead and play Thea 2.

But to me, the combat system is the downfall of this sequel. It's cluttered, illogical, unnecessarily complex, and most important of all, not fun at all. I backed both Thea 1 and 2 on Kickstarter, and still love 1, but I'm going to skip this game and hope for the best with Thea 3. I can wait. I still have Thea 1 to play, and it's still amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109544340', 'num_games_owned': 1419, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2163, 'last_played': 1683930752}
review:
-edit-

Made a few additions to the review since it left EA today.
I marked them with -edit-

Thea 2 is the better game compared to the first release, but it's not without setbacks and difficulties.

Thea I wasn't completely polished on release, but the original Slavic fantasy lore, the fresh gameplay concepts and the bright,  pretty, pastel hand drawn artwork camouflaged some of the little annoyances in the first game.

While I think most of the design choices in Thea I were due to lack of funds and manpower it often resulted in maximum use of effort, creativity and workarounds to reach the main goals of their plans with the game.
Since everything was handpainted or constructed by the same small team, the artwork was consequent and everything in the game fits together. The card design, the icons, the UI, the story teller paintings and the map was completely in balance.
And instead of using streamlined, colorful, casual art, everything was sketchy and not mainstream.

Maybe this is the reason why the first Thea didn't get all the hype it actually deserved as a game.
Compare it to the old Disney movie Bambi. It makes you cry. It's all hand painted but it's made with so much attention for detail. Newer animations are made by computers and I clearly see in the use of colors and animation that some of the ancient crafts are replaced by robotic mainstream art.

In Thea II, from a technical point of view I really believe the whole game will fit the mass audience better. The resource icons and UI icons, the card icons and the menu buttons could all be sold in an asset store to be used in any casual mobile game the next few years, but imo it's a missed oppertunity to do again what they did with Thea I. Be original.

While the button and resource icon artwork is way to casual for me, it's done steady. Luckily in the story teller and for villager portraits they still use the handpainted artwork as in Thea I and it delivers some memorable characters.

From a technical point of view and from the developers point of view I believe Thea II is a more advanced game on a more advanced engine. It's Thea I on steroids. The terrain is dynamic, with seasons and weather effects. But it's also much darker then in Thea I. Day/night and season switches doesn't make this any better. Prepare for less brightness in Thea II.
The 3d models of the characters are mediocore at best, the monsters are good. There is a lack of zooming the map so it's sometimes hard to see every detail. I hope a zoom functionality will be added in EA.
The assets on the terrain that represents the resources are made with as much realism as possible at the cost of being able to distinct them from the terrain itself as a player. This causes you have to enable the resource button overlay. It shows you the huge resource icons on top of the terrain at the cost of the actual terrain itself.
Both modes are not very convenient to play with, but this as well might be caused by the lack of zooming in/out the map.
A minimap is added on the road, but it only shows player position on the map. It doesn't have filters yet.

Thea II isn't Thea I, so the main element of surprise is already gone. It doesn't help me that everything you can research in game is already discovered and visible at forehand for the player. Another element of surprise is removed and I think it's done to make the game more streamlined and accessible. I wish there was a complete survival mode that was hiding everything you can encounter in mid and late game to have my surprises back.

I have two major complains about the way the UI works. 

1. I cannot use my left mouse button to move the map. I have to use my middle mouse button instead.

2. I can use right click to give move orders for selected groups, but I have to left click them first to activate them which automatically brings up a huge selection circle with a move order. I want to be able to select my group without the circle, by using tab or another key and right click to move. The is in my way how I want to play the game sometimes and that keeps annoying even after 36 hours I have in the game at the moment of writing.

-edit-
I can use TAB to focus on a group and right click to move them.

There is also missing a split button in menu's where I have to exchange resources between groups. but that is minor compared to the ones I noticed before.

The game map is very VERY large, the amount of resources, events, encounters and story elements are countless. You can play for days, hundreds of hours (I was following a streamer for a few weeks) without seeing 20 % of the map.
Since English isn't my mother tongue I have a harder time to read and understand all the texts in quests and story of the game while in Thea I the more simplistic way of writing helped me to understand better what was going on.
There is also much involved in the quests and stories in Thea II like gods, darkness, demons and even complete factions and this all is so detailed with so many text that it's hard for me to get and to keep my head around it.
There is a logbook added in the version I play now, but it isn't populated with data yet. I hope it will soon.

-edit-
The logbook is populated with information now.

While there is a tutorial build in mentioning the very basic working of the game, even as a frequent Thea I player I had a hard time to find out how many of the mechanism works exactly. There are so many icons, so many relations between skills, essences, abilities and different kind of events and I miss a simple overview with all data present at once to see all the relations between the different numbers and buttons.

It's often unclear to me how fate, morale and sickness effects me on the map or in card battles. It's a lot of clicking between menu's to see a complete overview of characters and stats with information when any battle start and you have to make a choice what kind of event to use to play out the battle.

Also building a town and assign some of my heroes/villagers to a new expedition group made me wonder how the two groups support each other in battle. For example far away from town the villagers from the town group were involved in battle together with my expedition group, but when my town was attacked the expedition group didn't came to help. Again after 30 + hours such an important concept should be more clear.

-edit-
There is some tutorial information added about this subject. Within certain amount of hexes, the folks in the town come to help in battles/events.

The new cardbattle adds more tactical play and positioning places a role now. On the other hand the UI use a large part of the screen at the cost of room for the cards themselves.
There are many cardgames released outside Thea in the meantime and I think the ruleset is interesting enough even for veterans. But compared to a game of Hearthstone, Magic or Gwynt it feels too slow. The animation is too slow, there is a wait time for (beautiful) effects, you cannot drag cards into play and there is cooldown time for the end turn button.
The cardgame should be improved in being more fast and accurate otherwise many will simple use autobattle for the minor fights.

While the character art on the cards overall is good, it feels lazy that none of them have a unique background, border or design. All cards are actually the same. For Thea III I hope this will be improved. They should also have some lore information on zooming imo.

Thea I will be in my top 3 all time favorites for now and Thea II should improve more (even maybe into a Thea III) to get any position in my all time top 10 list for the moment.

But Thea II is a fantastic game for newcomers to the series and veterans who have seen most of their wished fulfilled in this edition of the game. It's streamlined, it's hardcore difficult if you want it to be, the UI has a major update, the new terrain engine is neat, the music is lovely and it's full with content to play hundreds of hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072194837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2265, 'last_played': 1671905867}
review:
Good strategy game.

Combat is more complicated and less intuitive than in Thea 1, but when you get the basic rules it has deepness. I managed to win battles without taking any damage despite the auto-resolver suggestion that I will lose it completely. It is fun and when I finished the game it felt like accomplishment.

Also, combat has no randomness, so it is basically not a card game, it is kind of chess which I end-up liking. 

Game is not fully finished yet, I had one game freeze and one minor bug during my 40-hours of gameplay.

I consider this purchase a well spent $20. Thanks Devs!

review:
新手上手直接把难度调满略有难度，但是自定义难度可调，会简单很多很多。玩过1代就好理解不少。
另外这是个跑团游戏，最高难度翻车是常态，有点耐心还是很有意思的。一条命才是正确的游戏玩法，SL会很无聊。
虽然这个游戏世界设定很不错，但没中文会很难受。
目前游戏剧情还是比价单调，事件很多和1代类似甚至相同。一局到后期会很无聊，天神，特性解锁了感觉也没改变多少游戏方式。
致命bug还是有不少，待完善。
游玩提示
开局有个好出生地，找到合适的落脚地，决定你这局天堂还是地狱。
人口是基础，科技是第一生产力。
搞好各族关系能获得各种特殊种族特殊职业。
法师是战斗力最全面的主力。
部分职业有性别限制，同职业也可能有2种强弱形态

最后，这是个好游戏。玩一局可以打发不少时间~

author: {'steamid': '76561198020395175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1559757401}
review:
I enjoyed playing the first one, Awakening, and I like almost everything about this one better. Keep in mind it is Early Access, and there are things that need polishing. I do think the game is good enough to enjoy as-is if you keep in mind it's not finished.

Compared to the first game, 
Pros:
-Fewer stats on characters (this is mostly good)
-Characters level with choices at each level
-Research feels less random, you can choose to focus on it
-Many more character classes
-The Village feels more reliant on crafted items. In first version you got so much loot you really didn't need to make your own weapons.
-You start with no village, you get to find a good spot and set up where you want to. This is fun for experienced players, but I think it would be easy for beginners to start without wood or food and screw up their game.
-Your children are in the combats, and they can fight (badly). This is grim, and you usually don't play their cards in order to protect them, but you are tempted at times. 
-The children are individuals that transform when they grow up. There's a lot of depth there, and I felt they were more fleshed out than in the first game. I really liked the growing up part and mating of male-females who go off together in the woods.
-There is more variety to everything. Weapons, resources, etc.
-Graphics are a big jump up. I can actually see what I'm walking on!
-Boats! Lots of boats you can build and explore with.

Cons: (Keep in mind, this is Early Access April 2019, these will definitely improve)
-Right now, the combat system is a mess. Mostly, the interface needs work. You have to click to select character card. Move mouse to chase the selected card across the screen, click second time to select attack option. Then, you have to click to place that guy on the map. There are 8 setup rounds that you must click through as well. If you have 10 characters, we're talking about 40 clicks to set up the fight! None of these clicks can be skipped. 
Why not have the characters start with likely options pre-selected? Or remember the one you chose last time? Why not pop them down on the board in a logical spot right away, then allow player to move them with drag and drop if they wish? That could get you down to one click instead of 3 per card. 
And also, for God's sake, don't make us click end turn setup buttons over and over when we've already placed all our characters!
-The story is ragged right now. This will definitely improve, but it doesn't yet feel like you're on a path like in the first game. 
-Some of the interface elements like mouse scroll and map-dragging for point of view aren't operating yet. 
-You also can't click the group flag, you have to click on the hex they are in to bring up radial menu.

Suggestion:
-Reduce Combat setup steps.
-I'm hoping for some kind of a doom count-down (optional) where bigger and bigger attacks coming at your village every 50 turns or so, pressing you to finish the game by turn X. Kind of like Antares attacks in MOO2. 

To summarize, it's a reasonable buy if you liked the first one. Might be to hard to figure out everything if you're new to the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045131425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 33384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18427, 'last_played': 1686677106}
review:
Thea 2 is an absoloutely astounding game that could be released to day and still be well worth your time. Throughout the EA the developers have meen very attentive of their community and constantly listened to even the smallest bit of feedback and attempted to incorporate it. Is the game finished? no, I hope not, as they have yet to add the very immersing narration of Thea I. Is it playable? absoloutely, in truth I have already logged double the hours I have in the first installment. So I encourage you to buy it.

Now for the specifics. Thea 2 is not a city builder or an economy mangement game. Instead it endavours to be a classical RPG with a Slavyan setting. Many people are turned off by the combat mechanics, as was I initially, but once you figure out the colour-coding and other basics its quite straight forward. Finally, the developers are insanely active, so most complaints and problems are tackled.
