author: {'steamid': '76561197989504801', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1638491035}
review:
Review based on Thea 2: The Shattering - Early Access (however, according to the Devs and their Roadmap, there isn't a lot to do about my complaints).

"DON'T DO IT, SON."

Being a great fan of the original one Thea: The Awakening (if you haven't played it yet, please do), I decided to back up this project in its Early Access and after having problems playing it - horrible performance, I got baffled by the direction the developers took the game and how the reviews here are too passive for its changes and mistakes. Spent a few hours trying to make it work (under 10-15fps) and because of that, Steam didn't allow me to refund it. Bummer. I would play it with different ideas in mind. Always check the negative reviews first.

- Decided to read about the rest of the game play and provide some insight to people who are going to buy the game. -

1. The first part, though obvious, it's necessary: comparison with Thea 1 - you are going to have more fun with the first one. No other way to describe it. They managed to spin the first one's fun progression with some weird idea of extra micromanagement and randomness while removing some key elements of its complexity because they thought it was streamlined. Oh dear.

2. Characters, start and combat: as you've seen through Screenshots and videos, combat has changed. The different ways to deal with enemies (challenges) have been lowered to three types who are reigned by way less atributes than the first game. Leveling up now is "random" (respecting a formula) which provides awkward results. Starting the game is different as you pick a god and try to select good traits. Strange. And oh, the combat screen now deals card in different ways, being so different you won't like it at all (though I see people trying to justify it all the time). Slow-pacing, dealing the same cards again and trying to worry about a lot of factors (that you have to figure on your own - damage, speed of the attack, type of the attack and its range, etc.) ends up only being tiresome, forcing most players to just auto-resolve conflicts (and apparently it's still bugged for some people). Sadly there's no way they will back-up and try to save the style from the Awakening.

3. World map and crafting/gathering: they managed to get more mixed results here. Creating a progression based on "islands" and factions ended up being tiresome as the enemies either grow too strong quickly for no reason (and you become the classic victim with no fault on your own - with people saying "git gud" on Discussions) or you are forced to do even more deadly choices. Moving around becomes a fest of End Turns of no actual results and creating a village becomes mostly troublesome for some advancement requirements and extra events. Crafting/Research has become randomized and mostly useless (and only two people can do a task per time, with diminished results after the first item value - WHAT.THE). Basically, some of their 4X key elements are dead in the water. I liked the weather and season changes. Zoom-out, please.

4. Story and other RPG elements. I didn't get too far but as I've read, the progression will severely make you suffer through any idea of endgame and Roleplay situations. The game is still missing the charismatic voice-over from the previous game too.

5. Performance (weird situation): the change to somewhat more 3D models and map, as some new features (weather and seasons, for example) ended up having an overall performance impact as it sucks memory out of your head to tolerate some things. I still appreciate things as a 2D alternative to move things around as the strategic view from Civ games (also helping those with old machines).

Conclusion: don't do it, son. Don't buy it. At least yet: Let's see what happens.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998388812', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 7310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3123, 'last_played': 1629230504}
review:
I was cautious but optimist about buying Thea 2 in early access, but pleasantly surprised!  Really looking forward to the full release of this game.  Plenty of small things and balance changes to make out for the developers, but overall the game plays very much like the first game.  There are some great improvements:  You choose where to put your village (if you even make one at all!), new combat system is better in my opinion, and there are weather effects now!  The crafting system that was so excellent from the first game remains mostly unchanged.  The game feels and plays great, all changes have been improvements.

If you've never played the original Thea, basically your'e playing the first part of a Civ game, but for the entire game.  Also add mythological creatures, RPG lore/storytelling, random events, crafting, equipping each villager to fight, leveling up each villager, and trying to save the world from a cataclysmic event, with the help of your god.  You choose which god your villagers worship at the start of the game, and it effects lots of RPG elements throughout gameplay.  Honestly the original and this game are totally worth buying, go get them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097073485', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 8495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3968, 'last_played': 1695619883}
review:
If you haven't played the first game don't play this one as you won't appreciate this game in it's current state.

this game delivers a lot of new and interesting content like a bunch of new events and features.

however i feel like the negative part needs to be brought to peoples attention because these issues may ruin the experience for new players. 

my biggest issue is that when you get an event, you'll see that event hundreds of time. don't get me wrong this can be really fun as i once had a run were i had 10+ banshees and another were i managed to make all of my children into goblins or demons. however there is an event that costs you the game if it infinitely loops and that is the event were you lose 20% (I may be wrong on the percentage) of your inventory, well i had this event trigger 5 times within 20 turns and it death spiralled a few turns later because of this.

another is the games difficulty is inconsistent and you'll have 100 turns of easy level 1-3 combats then it will spike to level 7 difficulty, then it rapidly spikes to level 9-10. to make matters worse the only way to tell the difficulty of story combats is entering the event chain that leads to said combat with most giving no option to leave unless you've failed the encounter so stack up on medics for your combat team because death will come.

lastly its nearly impossible to lose a character unless they're a child of course (evil laugh.) it took my whole party being brought to deaths door for one character to die.

other than these issues i enjoy playing this game, and i cant wait for new content.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997822333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 22326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7426, 'last_played': 1688016825}
review:
If you like strategy, role playing, tactics and turn based gameplay, this is the game for you. This game is very simple to get the hang of but grows in complexity the longer you play. The strategy portion of the game has you determining what bonuses you'd like to start with, if when and where to set up a village, which type of material to focus on collecting and what can be made with those materials. Role playing is largely text based conversation trees, the long repetitive ones let you skip to the end, different characters and abilities will open new choice options and different environments have different events. The writing is interesting and enjoyable with the setting based in eastern european mythology.  Combat (and other challenges) are decided by a card type game with a two dimensional layout rather than Thea, the awakening's 1 dimensional layout. Good tactics can result in defeating higher level opponents, poor tactics result in failure, and if you fail hard enough, permadeath.  All in all a very rewarding game that i can't recommend highly enough, and it's not even finished. I can't wait to see what new features will be added as the game development progresses. True testament to the power of good game design.  

Purchased the game for myself because i am a fan of the original, purchased a copy for my brother because it's a great game. 

TL;DR Excellent game for fans of turnbased tactical roleplaying with strategic elements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137005392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 31727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9867, 'last_played': 1687040200}
review:
I played the first Thea and loved it so of course I had to grab this Thea. I also am loving it but being that it is in Early Access still it is not without its flaws and bugs and crashes. I will mostly talk about the issues I see currently because I think that is what people really want to see when they read a review BUT please understand there is a lot to also love about Thea 2 and it has a lot of heart. So while I talk about some of my issues, understand overall I love this game and how it is progressing.

Combat - I like the combat system better in this one as opposed to Thea1 but it is SLOWWWWW takes forever to get through and NEVER use the autoresolve it is terrible. Often if I autoresolve I will get a failure but if I actually play out the combat I will get either a perfect or near perfect victory. Of course playing out the combat takes forever and it isn't very exciting graphically or strategy wise.

Crafting  - Not fun. Resources of any higher level are too hard to come by and never appear anywhere on the map even if you buy the ability to harvest them you'll never find them. At least in Thea1 if you bought the ability to harvest a resource at least one source would appear in the game. Then the amount of resources needed is really big to craft even simple stuff. On top of that all the resources give very similar outcomes and equipment tends to be uninteresting and doesn't matter much like it did in Thea 1. The extras that you could get on a piece of equipment from combining different resources in Thea1 made crafting not only way more important but a lot more interesting and fun.  Now its just kind of hard and time consuming and not very fun or interesting. Since a lot of the game in Thea1 and in this Thea centers around harvesting resources to make equipment I am hoping they will take a look at the system and overhaul it. Also peeve jewelry often weighs 20 to 40 pounds, who wears rings that weigh 20 lbs????

Maps - I am hoping they will provide a map editor or a way to influence maps but right now you have a bunch of islands and each island is mostly dedicated to a type of resource. Like one island will be mostly metals and another island mostly bones etc. Starting island has super basic supplies (if you're lucky) and you may find a place to make a village that has both wood and food resources if you're lucky... at least you get to choose I guess where you want to put your village or even if you want to have a village at all. Definitely hate boats...and hate that you MUST use them if you want to get any 2nd level resources for the most part. Would like boats better if they could carry more but right now the most weight I have seen it can carry is like 5200 pounds but really that is not enough if you base a village on the mainland and then use groups to go gather resources because the other islands have hard monsters so your gatherers will need lots of warriors to protect them and even if a boat has 20 strong warriors on it it can only carry 5200 lbs (which I can easily make in carried equipment alone).

Characters - I love the character portraits and they have some neat skills/spells but I really miss all the crazy skills and things characters had in old Thea. I get this is simplified but also not nearly as much variation and makes non warriors less useful.  The kids are adorable. I also like that my people randomly have babies and I have noticed it doesn't matter what sex the parents are I have had 2 males find a kid in the cabbage patch. Growing children up is hard.... and many fail and become scavengars not my favorite thing especially when I have spent time making sure the kids don't die or get kidnapped by various events throughtout the 40 days it takes them to become adults (I wish it was a little less time to become an adult). Also for some reason children can't wear jewelry and they can only carry less than a 100lbs so the only way to affect their path is to give them a pet that gives plusses to stats or level them up. Equipment doesn't help much to distinguish characters either. Also feel like you start with too few people.

Village - Nice that you don't have to have one but even if you do, I miss that what I used to build my village made it able to attract certain types of creatures to join me but that doesn't happen now. Also building villages is enormous resource haul and since you don't have access to good resources on the starter island makes it hard luckily from what I have seen doesn't do much to use great resources anyway...Buildings in villages should be more helpful like the school should open up new career paths or influence your kids to a particular path.

travel across the map - Very slow, especially if you have kids. They should invent carts like land boats but with no weight limit past what people can carry and let that speed up overland travel.

storyline - So far I like it but then Thea was always rich with good stories and events. Currently some events are super repetitious the one where the witch sends some little demon to suck on your cow's blood and the fish who needs to be put back in the water and the man who falls down a hole all happen too much but betting that changes when they get more added in. I love the random events and different side quests.

I like the new classes and that even other races have multiple classes. Again sometimes hard to get your child to grow up into one of them but satisfying when you do.

UI - It was clunky in Thea 1 and its still a little clunky in Thea 2 but improving.

Like that they added researching.

I think I like the new god system but can't really tell since getting god points to unlock stuff is stupid hard! But I do like that you can choose to add on special things.

Overall the game is playable to me, and the developers are amazing lots of updates and code fixes they seem really responsive and working hard and this is early access so I don't feel like any of the things I talked about disliking above are going to stay the exact same. There are bugs but as long as you save a lot they don't make the game unplayable and generally get fixed pretty fast. I love that they have an ingame system for reporting the ones you find and that it takes a screenshot for you. I totally recommend this game now IF you buy with the understanding that it is in Early Access, and if you love the Thea world or other games similar. Also unlike some early access games I don't worry about this not getting finished and released.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008011659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 27455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1757, 'last_played': 1697901213}
review:
Update 26/06/21: sadly the later stages of the game are horribly unbalanced, leading to the need to save/reload regularly - you might win one battle without a scratch only to be utterly wiped out the next turn.  Seems like something that can and should be fixed but just hasn't.

OK latest version (March 2020) is greatly improved - way more content, better balancing etc.  Still not perfect and not quite as good as the original (in my opinion) but well worth playing.  There's lots of interesting new content, the ability to start new towns is a big bonus, crafting is good too.  I would strongly advise turning on the Save options though -at the moment there are waaaay to many ways to have your entire party wiped out by a random event, so save and save often!  

I stand by my earlier review where I commented that the first release was in far too early a state to charge people money for - it wasn't a Beta so much as a half-assed prototype that didn't really work.  Hopefully the developers won't make the same mistake next time.

{old review: This is based on the version Hotfix 0370.  I'm a big fan of the original Thea, I've played and replayed it many times.  While Thea 2 shows some promise, it's really not ready to play - not even as early or pre-release.  There are quite a few bugs, which I don't mind too much, but the main problem is the content simply isn't there - you can get maybe a couple of hours of gameplay and then you get the same quests all over again.  Many key features, such as the minimap, aren't even working yet.  Perhaps worst of all, saved games don't work from one version to the next.  I think it's completely inappropriate to charge people for access to the game in this very, very early state.

Hopefully things will improve quickly.  For now I have to simply stop playing the game - that I paid full price for - and hope that the full release comes out very soon.  In the meantime, I would strongly advise against purchasing this game.  I'm going to go back to playing the original for now!}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016311011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 9800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3525, 'last_played': 1691251490}
review:
Es un juegazo pero esta en alpha. Empiezas sin poblado pero con una semilla para construirlo, también puedes convertir esta semilla en una anillo que te da bastantes stats si quieres ir vagando por ahí con toda tu prole. Pros:

- Gran árbol tecnológico parecido al del primer juego.
- El sistema de combate ha mejorado mucho con un tablero con varias posiciones.
- El mapa es enorme y hay varias islas, algunas de ellas con facciones orcas, goblins, demonios o elfos.
- Eventos con historias relacionadas con el primer juego, como la del enano y las rusalkas. 

Contras:

- A día de hoy no hay journal de misiones ni minimapa, lo cual hace que te tengas que ir acordando porque tienes que ir a la misión que suelen estar indicadas con una exclamación.
- No hay narrador como en el primer juego. El narrador molaba pero le han recortado.
-Cuando tienes varios grupos no sabes a que grupo le pasan los eventos. Esto es catastrófico si te encuentras a un dragón y no vas con tu grupo fuerte ya la has liado.

El juego es mejor que el primero y recomiendo a todo el mundo que se lo pueda permitir jugarlo pero aun le queda desarrollo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082571495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 12724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1033, 'last_played': 1590923196}
review:
It's atmospheric.

Indie dev and early access sure shows as a lack of slick and polish but Thea 2 is a really unique hybrid game. A fresh breath on the market, for that alone I already recommend it.

You control a small group of people and equip them with different weapons, armor etc. Walk around a hex map, sit down to camp and farm different materials and craft better gear. Random events pop up all the time with multiple ways to solve them. Your guys have different stats - physical, mental, magic, like - and "challenges" aka combats can often be resolved using these different stats.

So you can beat up bandits who ambush you or use smooth talk. Meet a witch and engage in a battle of wits or defend yourself against a hex - or just beat her up. It's really cool, although the combat system in itself stays the same - you just utilize different stats and abilities.
It gets deeper with certain options unlocking only when you have either enough stats for some action or even a specific class in your group.

UI is a bit clunky, especially as gathering and crafting plays such a prominent role in the game. Everything works, it's just not a very smooth experience.
Graphics are decent. Event images and characters are all great, the 3D aspect betrays the indie budget. It gets the job done, though and most of the time you'll be looking at the hand drawn pictures. Music is great and adds a lot to the atmosphere.
As early access title, the content is somewhat lacking but even so, there's plenty. Mostly you'll see some repeated events while chilling on your main island.

Thea 2 offers a lot of replayability as you can choose different starting bonuses and customize your game difficulty to a very high degree. The world is randomized and so are events and encounters.

From a technical & QoL POV Thea 2 could use some love. Other than that, it's really something else. A working hybrid formula that you won't regret getting if you're into survival/4X/RPG/card games/story heavy games.

review:
This game has come a long way since I first reviewed it. All progress has been positive I would say. It is rapidly shaping up to be the successor it should be and I know the developer will continue to support it even after its full release as they did the first game.

The card combat system has changed a lot from the first game, and I quite like it. It takes a bit to get your head around but lower difficulty settings let you experiment a little. Then when you get the grasp of it all, you can ramp it up. They have worked a lot on again providing truly scale-able difficulty that you can customise just to your liking, to get it as difficult or as easy as you desire.

The quests and stories are still enjoyable an immerse yourself in a slavic-folklore inspired world with impressive effect. It's suitably random enough, and there is plenty to explore.

In some ways the sense of threat to your town feels.. reduced, but there is lots of challenge in other ways, it just comes more from exploring generally.

I would heartily recommend this game and it is ready for wide-scale consumption now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039416752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 37918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19704, 'last_played': 1612455696}
review:
Je ne souhaite pas vous tromper, j’émets un avis positif mais par pure indulgence.
D’abord parce j’ai adoré la version précédente, autant dans son concept que dans son style. Et que cette version est en « early access », et donc on ne peut pas lui demander la lune.
D’autant qu’il est franchement prometteur, mais à l’heure où j’écris ces lignes, je ne peux pas dire que ce jeu est en « beta », ni même en « alpha ».
Parce qu’il manque énormément de choses, qu’il y a des bugs encore très nombreux, des fois même des régressions au fur et à mesure des majs (actuellement, il y a une régression qui limite la récolte des ressources en particulier la nourriture, ce qui qui fait littéralement crever de faim vos personnages dès le début de la partie…).
Mais je reviendrais sur ces points négatifs au cours de ma « review ».
Pour le très positif, il y a le système de combat. Je l’ai vu décrier dans les avis négatifs, et je comprends pourquoi.
Il est très complexe, le didacticiel réduit à son minimum syndical, et la description des pouvoirs des personnages et des armes n’aident en rien à évaluer leurs réelles possibilités.
Pourtant, on y trouve une réelle profondeur stratégique dont la découverte se fait au prix de la souffrance des tests…
Autre amélioration positive : le crafting.
Là encore, il y a d’excellentes idées, mais pour le moment, très mal exploitées.
Certaines classes d’objets sont littéralement inutiles voir nocives à fabriquer (donc perte totale de point de recherche à les développer).
A titre d’exemple, parmi les armes, les « haches » sont les plus inutiles à fabriquer par rapport aux « Epées deux mains » (vraiment les meilleures armes du jeu) ou aux « Maillets ».
Parmi les armes à distance, les « baguettes magiques » peuvent paraître sympas, mais elles sont clairement surclassées par les « Codex » (les livres de sort à 2 mains).
A petit niveau, ils donnent accès en même temps à « l’invocation de mort-vivant » et une « projection de glace » très utile, et à plus haut niveau, à la « chain lightning » et à la « ancien voice » (à mon avis les 2 pouvoirs de combat les plus puissants du jeu).
A contrario, les objets de la classe « Relic » peuvent se révéler complément néfaste à fabriquer. Le pouvoir « d’explosion de cadavre » qu’ils offrent, paraît cool, mais en réalité il va faire plus de mal à votre groupe qu’aux adversaires. Et finalement vous allez leur préférer les « Codex ».
On peut aussi déplorer que certains « craft » vont devenir des classiques de partie en partie tellement ils sont simples et utiles à fabriquer. Je citerais par exemple, l’armure lourde en « bois de dryade », ou ici encore certains « Codex » qui feront surement l’objet d’une véritable production en série tellement le rapport coût de production/puissance est écrasant.
Donc pour conclure, il y a beaucoup d’amélioration à apporter, peut-être des équilibrages et/ou plus de contenu à attendre.
Ce jeu est encore clairement perfectible…

review:
Very Promising but also a long way from being ready.

I enjoyed Thea the Awakening and this looks a more colourful sequel.
Graphics & gameplay looks great.
Event repetition and sluggish interface are negatives for me but that can be taken care of (even if I have to write my own events!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197974878428', 'num_games_owned': 482, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1675630812}
review:
Das Spiel ist immer noch relativ früh in der Entwicklung. An vielen Features wird noch gearbeitet, aber ich gebe bereits jetzt eine positive Bewertung aufgrund des Potentials, das das Spiel hat.

Der erste Teil des spiels hat mir viel Spaß gemacht, und was ich bisher vom zweiten Teil sehe spricht mich wieder sehr an. Das Ressourcen- und Crafting-System hat weitaus mehr Tiefe gewonnen. Das Kampfsystem mit dem Karten wurde komplett überarbeitet, und spielt sich sehr taktisch. Viele andere Dinge sind bereits verbessert worden oder werden im Laufe der Entwicklung noch verbessert. Die Änderungen zum ersten Teil gefallen mir bisher sehr, und ich bin gespannt darauf wie sich das Spiel noch entwickelt!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042157127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1581906916}
review: I really loved the first Thea game and spent many, MANY hours playing. I'm really excited for the second iteration. I've played about 8 hours so far, and while there are some definitely missing assets since it is in early access (no quest log, can't load a game while playing a game, no mini map, clunckly inventory, etc.) , overall the gameplay is very good. The combat mini card game is a bit different from the original Thea, so that took a little getting used to. I'm excited to see the game develop more fully and have the full features. I will likely spend many more hours playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014432648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1690316206}
review:
I wish I could give this a postive review, but this game so far has all the problems of the first game, made worse.
The first game was fantastic in content, and horrible in UI (information was never accessible when needed, or I need to dig into several menu steps to do things. This slowed down the game and it got more and more frustrating to play the better you got since you then needed to think and plan less).

Here's some examples:
1) Every combat animation is extremely slow. I cannot even find a menu option to speed this up. This is currently blocking my gameplay.
2) Overworld movent is slow, and does not display movement cost for a tile until I hove over it (holding down right mouse button to move should also provide this information for all visible tiles, currently it only does so for the tile I'm hovering over)
3) You need to wander around looking for a decent spot to build your town in. This is better than restarting a number of times till you get a decent map, but I really wish you started with the closest surroundings scouted so you just could walk 5-10 steps and build the town. After that the normal scout mechanics can apply.

I'll change this review to positive when most normal turns can be completed without using the right click context menu, the UI dynamically adjust to display infomation to what I'm doing, combat has a decent speed (ideally normal animations are speed up 2x, and a remove combat animation option exists as well) and an auto end turn feature is added. Hopefully all of this can be fixed during early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1547224624}
review:
I only played 15 minutes, but my experience with it was; 

-The game feels like a needlessly complicated Civilization clone
-The Card/Combat component is comprised of 8 rounds of "Preparation", followed by 2 turns of watching what happens. The combat is slow, watching the things that were set up trigger one at a time is unsatisfying, and nothing behaves intuitively. 
-The introduction / explanations are thematic and cute, but a slog with way too much reading. The game should explain itself, or the tutorial should be a way to engage the player. I felt like there were too many buttons with too many sequences of long text

👍 [u]Pros:[/u] 👍
Enjoyable Story
Fun card combat system
Interesting resource system
Multiple playstyles

👎 [u]Cons:[/u] 👎
Very Buggy
Lack of Content at the moment
References the first game

[h1]Overview[/h1] 
“Thea 2: The Shattering” is the sequel to “Thea: The Awakening.” Thea 2’s gameplay is similar to the first game. The player acts as a god’s chosen and they must survive a world in peril. To do so, resources must be gathered. At first, only basic resources are available. With research gained from the school and story events, the player is able to unlock more powerful resources which in turn create more powerful equipment. Similar to how the gameplay is based off of the first game and is expanded, so is the story. This is amazing for fans of the first game, but it makes playing this sequel as a standalone a bit irritating. For example, the story references “The Darkness” multiple times. The story is still interesting though, and is the main focus of the game. The other focus is combat which has been revamped from the first game. It feels like a much needed improvement. Finally, the sound and graphics are all fine for a 4x game as they aren’t the focus, but there are 4x games with better sound and graphics. 

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]

🎮 [u]Gameplay:[/u] 🎮
 
Resources
To survive in Thea, there are two main resources that every settlement must have, and they are a food source and wood. Thankfully, these basic resources are rather plentiful, but they aren’t the only resources that are necessary to combat the encroaching disaster. Leather, bones, magical gemstones, and eventually higher tier resources allow the creation of powerful armors and weapons. Variety is also important. The more types of foods available for the player’s citizens to eat, the higher their morale will be. High morale provides bonuses like health regeneration and extra movement speed on the world map. While higher tier resources can be gained through story events, they can’t be gained through gathering unless they are researched first. 

Research & Crafting
After each story event, and if the player has built a school in their village, the player will gain research points. Collect enough research points and the player’s civilization will gain a research level. This level can be spent on multiple categories such as food, weaponry, and resources. Resources can be collected out in the world, but only if the resource has been researched first. Once these resources are collected, they can be used in crafting. Food resources can be used in cooking new meals. Some meals start out unlocked at the beginning of the game, but others must be unlocked through the use of research levels. Weaponry and armor benefit the most from new, higher level resources as they greatly increase their abilities. New resources can also provide new spells, or if they are higher tier, they can upgrade old ones. Equipment, ultimately, is used to increase the stats of the player’s adventurers.

Stats, Titles, & Story Events
There are six stats in the game: strength, perception, knowledge, wisdom, mysticism, and destiny. These six stats are then put into three categories: health, sanity, and faith. These three categories are then used independently depending upon the situation that a player has found their party in. If the party is trying to convince another character to do something, then they will use the sanity category. Each character’s knowledge and wisdom then effects the strength of the attacks in combat. Going straight into combat isn’t always necessary though during story events. Sometimes, if a character has a certain title or is of a certain race, then new story options appear. For example, if the player’s party is speaking to some demons and there is a demon in the player’s party, a new option will appear as the demon better understands demon culture and will have a unique response. I liked this aspect of “Thea 2: The Shattering”, as it felt like the decisions I made to acquire the demon party member really paid off now that I could change the story with them. 

Combat, Leveling Up & Classes
Combat is sometimes inevitable during a conflict. The same goes for the player’s party. Combat is played using the player’s party characters as cards. Each character can attack, but based upon their weapon and the skill they have acquired through leveling up, they are able to use special abilities. The way that the card game works is that the player and their enemy take turns gaining two action points, with the player who went first only gaining one point on the first turn and the second player gaining one point at the end. A character card can then be played using one action point the first time it is used. Every time the card is used subsequently, it costs one more action point. This lead to many tough decisions for me during battle. Do I use the special abilities of multiple party members, or should I use only my strongest party member with increasing cost? The card combat is a big improvement over the first game’s, and I really enjoyed using my specialized characters to win battles.

⚙ [b]Overall:[/b]⚙
This is a fun strategy game that has a lot of potential, but it is difficult to recommend at the moment. Combat and story events are engaging, but there aren’t a ton of them yet. The bugs also don’t help when they get in the way.

📚 [u]Story:[/u] 📚
The story is one of the main draws of this game. The first game had a lot of excellent story moments to enjoy, so this game should too eventually. The problem is that right now, at the time of writing, there isn’t much story to enjoy. The story seems quite interesting, with the world falling apart at the seams, but there are only a few hours of content at the moment. Another problem that may occur for player new to the series is that the story mentions details about the first game’s story multiple times. The story that is there right now is high-quality work that is a constant choose your own adventure story with combat sprinkled in for variety. 

🎧 [u]Sound:[/u]🎧
The sounds are a bit cartoonish. Whenever something is being bitten, there is usually a “splat” sound effect. A few of the sound effects have been recycled from the first game. I personally feel that they are endearing as the Thea series is both comedic and dramatic. I would definitely suggest turning the sound down though, as loud “splat” sounds can really take a player by surprise, especially considering they seem to be louder than most of the other sounds. As for the music, it is the typical high fantasy orchestral soundtrack that one comes to expect.

📺 [u]Graphics:[/u] 📺 
The graphics in “Thea 2: The Shattering” combine high definition portraits with medium-quality three-dimensional models. The portraits art are astounding, and the large pieces with full background work are even better. These portraits are often used in battles and help to show the world during the text adventures that the player encounters. The 3d models are of varying qualities. The human models are good and often reflect their portraits. The monster models, mainly the insects look a bit jagged. As for the user interface, it takes a bit to figure out and it isn’t exceptionally intuitive. I played the first game which is why I knew how to create an exploration group, but for someone who has never played the game before, it wouldn’t make much sense. 

This product was reviewed with a key provided by the developer for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099428069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 57571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 8686, 'last_played': 1711384900}
review:
Безусловно на этапе выпуска игры в раннем доступе, не всё так гладко, как хочется тем, кто приобрёл игру, но в целом это достойное продолжение первой части, итак пройдёмся по плюсам, поскольку минусы не вижу смысла оценивать на этапе раннегог доступа:
- Теперь в игре есть дети разных рас, будь то орки, гоблины, эльфы, дварфы и конечно же люди) При этом Тея коварна и ребенок в процессе выбора может пойти не тем путём, который игрок избрал для него, порой превращаясь вообще в ребёнка другой расы вместо инициации или же в итоге принимает форму демона\нежити. Также теперь дети являются полноценными членами отряда со штрафом на обвес снаряжения, что впрочем не мешает использовать легкое оружие)
- Полностью переработанная система параметров (теперь при лвлапе дают выбрать один из трех параметров или двух навыков), боевая система (теперь подавляющее большиство оружия имеет множитель урона, привязанный к стату, а не как раньше, когда можно было лекарю дать лёгкий мегамеч и он будет крошить в салат всё живое), а также новая система испытаний
- Совершенно другая система крафта, теперь при крафте по выбору можно создавать оружие с элементом, а то и с несколькими, что очень сильно может разнообразить игровой процесс. Как и было сказано ранее, плоские бонусы к параметрам\урону теперь скорее исключение, обусловленное использованием определенных ресурсов и их сочетания, впрочем если уж приоткрывать завесу тайны, то [spoiler]использование в качестве основы (первый компонент) самоцветов даст плоский урон и позволит использовать его даже детям, поскольку самоцветы имеют минимальный вес среди всех ресурсов[/spoiler]
- Новая система генерации мира, теперь в игре мир разбит на биомы, которые располагаются на островах, при этом стартовый биом всегда стандартный [spoiler] в котором встречаются только ресурсы первого изучаемого тира и кроме людишек разве что гоблины, а эльфов, орков и дварфов ищи где хочешь) [/spoiler]
- Переработанная система деревни и крафта, теперь деревни на старте у Вас нету и можно либо её построить, либо жить без неё (потому что теперь для крафта не нужна деревня) [spoiler] а из кристалла, который выдают для постройки деревни, можно сделать кольцо с охерительными статами, несравнимыми ни с какой бижой, в общем кольцо всевластья) [/spoiler]
З.Ы. В общем можно залипнуть ооочень надолго, жду-недождусь работы над переводом, потому что честно говоря система событий такая же непростая, как и в первой части) Warning! в тексте есть спойлеры)

author: {'steamid': '76561198049936136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 47352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1689198965}
review:
I loved Thea: The Awakening, I have hundreds of hours playing, mostly spend in the event editor making stories to play in the game. My first heartbreak was when I inquired as to the lore and was put off because they were busy working on Thea 2 - so I put Thea 1 away and figured I would look into Thea 2. Then the heartbreak turned to devastation.
It seems to me that they've taken a great game idea and tried to add more bells and whistles, but in doing so they have killed the soul of something that was wonderful but only partially realized. Everything is different, from the artwork style, through the combat system and the crafting system. Really, all they needed to do is perhaps improve options within the event editor to provide more depth to stories and then continue with the storyline, but intstead they've changed things that didn't need changing and ended up ruining everything.
I've paid for it so I will continue to watch it's development but I am not very hopeful that they can save what was a beautiful game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979224516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1853, 'last_played': 1559789044}
review:
UPDATED for Release Version:

Current score 6/10 - Not easily recommended to anyone but those who love the series and want to see a 3rd.

Having played my first 1000+ turn VICTORY I am having a lot of trouble re-investing that time again to play for a chance at another one. That is a bad sign because this game starts with a decent amount of content temporarily locked and unlockable with subsequent playthroughs (even loses). I have lost interest in all of the unlockables because they just don't matter or change the game play in a meaningful way. Start with more Warriors, start with a decent piece of armor, more food etc. Sure, or play 50 turns and just build that armor, collect those resources, raise a child into whatever you want... those are not enticing unlocks for me personally.
There seems to be 2 basic ways to play this - Camping or Nomadic. Beyond the choice of "To Base or Not to Base" you will play through the same encounters, the same factions with the same agendas, the same islands with the same resources etc. I got roughly 300 turns into my second game since release and cannot bring myself to loading and playing it.
It seems to lack the primary elements of the games it's drawing inspiration from. In trying to be inspired but unique it's failed to make an impact in any way with me.
I'm bored after a few dozen hours or so and that's not a good sign.

Buyer beware. I wouldn't recommend but 'you do you boo'.


EA Score - 7/10 - Recommended to those who know it but Wishlist it for those who don't.

I never knew Thea existed before I found this EA version of Thea 2 but I am glad I bought it. I wouldn't say it's essential to try it in EA and I might do things differently now that I've had my taste and by differently I mean put it on my wishlist and buy at full release. 
The game has a lot of mechanics I am not used to and this (early early) EA is kind of bare bones for content - that translated means - everytime I fuck something up in a major way (which is how I learn) I have to go back to the start (which I really don't mind) but there are only TWO choices of Deities at this time. So now restarting has lost it's flavor whereas in Civ or Endless Legend, restarts offered a chance to try the early game with a new faction and often approach/playstyle; this game doesn't seem to have a huge variation in terms of early game.
I must mention again that I am completely new to Thea and all it's ideas and I am bad at it, like really bad at it (I think). Maybe you are meant to run away from more things rather than try and overcome everything but before the game gets too far in (200 turns-ish) I start to encounter enemies that I cannot fathom how I could beat at this point.
I have fun collecting random things and exploring the crafting system but the piece where different materials actually matter is missing so far - sure some wood is lighter than other wood but the 'elemental' properties of items don't seem to manifest their qualities in the finished products. This of course translates (to me anyway) pick 1 type of each resource and ignore the rest. I could be way off in this matter, like I said, I'm shitty at this game.
After all this trial and error I am left thinking a few things:
1) The game will be a lot better with more systems in place (inlcuding ease of access systems and info areas)
2) I will enjoy this game once someone writes a decent starter guide so I can figure out why I am always the suck
3) This game will be more than worth the money I paid at full release but for now it's on the shelf with just over 30hrs on it
4) The story seems like it will fade away after the first playthrough unless it gets a serious deepening and/or there are some choices/variations based on preference and starting options (haven't seen it all the way through but enough to know the general plot line) - caveat to this is that a 4k style game doesn't necessarily need a good story although this definitely presents like a pen and paper style rpg akin to PoE (in story/dialogue, not game play).

If you LOVE Thea - spend the money, why not? - the devs are super active on it and it seems earmarked as a solid full release. If you don't yet know the game series, I'd wishlist it and come back later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263097170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 58376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 953, 'playtime_at_review': 18145, 'last_played': 1711767914}
review:
[h1]Still Bugs and Balancing Issues, but already a great game[/h1]

Having played Thea 1, I had some idea of what to expect for this game, but many things are better. Graphics are amazing, though I'm still waiting for the ability to zoom out on the map so I can see more at once. The crafting/cooking system is improved, as is the resource tree in general. It comes with new, craftable high-level materials. The music is enjoyable enough that I often leave it on in the background if I am working on something.

The level up system is now not arbitrary, but allows you a choice of which stats or skills to improve.

The combat system has been overhauled: there are three main types of challenges: red/physical, yellow/mental, and purple/spiritual, each with their accompanying HP bar and pair of stats. There are also conceptual challenges in each color (black cards with colored edges), which are akin to internal struggles, where you cannot use equipment but as long as you win any damage you take is temporary. Autoresolve needs a little work as it tends to predict you getting hurt quite a bit more than you do, but you have the choice to resolve manually even after seeing auto's result, so it's okay.

Major things that are not yet implemented are: minimap, research tasks, and more than one ritual.

The major downfalls of this game so far are twofold: RNG will often try to ruin your day one way or another, whether it be giving you a difficult event too early or not allowing your child to grow up to the class you trained them for, or even not giving you more children at all. Second, there are quite a few balancing issues. For example, there are far more different types of melee weapons than anything else, yet they tend to be the least useful overall. Some classes are also far more useful than others, not just in battle, but in opening up new options during events. I expect this will improve with time, but for now, you'd do well to make sure you get a witch and a hunter as early as possible, and this will often require saving and reloading multiple times. There is also no male equivalent to the witch (yet?) so there's no point in training your human boys in mysticism.

Then there are, of course, also bugs. Quite a few, but I don't count this as a downfall because most aren't game-breaking, and the team is putting out patches roughly weekly to improve. It's Early Access, after all, so you can't expect it to be perfect. They also have a very handy feature in game where you can press F8 to report a bug and have it sent automatically together with game log info to help pinpoint it.

Played the first game over 200 hours, still have some achievements to finish and I enjoyed every moment of it.
The current game is even better, they listened to all we wanted sorted, it's still on early access and getting its tweaks and, for me, it beats most of the current completed games of the genre, its both enticing and not so easy to really make the best of it, lots of challenges and different gameplays to explore with each god.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993475888', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1545831626}
review:
[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Thea 2 brings us an interesting mixture of turn based adventure game, text quest, card battle game and light version of village management simulator. Game itself revolves around Slavic folklore, spiced up with some influence of western mythology and extra drops of random fantasy genre representatives. 

[h1]The story and in-game universe:[/h1]
Unfortunately game is still in development, so part of the content is locked so far. You’ll take a role of a chosen, who will represent one of the multiple gods for a choice. Game starts when you and your tribe gets dragged into a fight with some painful light, which hypnotizes both, humans and local demons alike. It’s worth mentioning that ancient Slavic culture revolved around pacts with magical creatures (named here as ‘demons’), so you’ll be forced to interact with them, by either signing various deals, or simply slaughtering poor creatures.

Every now and then you’ll face different places and have to play short text quests. Most of these quests offer 3 different solutions, either negotiating a peaceful way out, fighting, or something third, which relies on faith of your tribe members. Overall, game gives you that feeling of non-linear adventure, which is quite cool and helps to maintain interest even when most of the mechanics feel boring.

[h1]The gameplay: [/h1]
As it was already mentioned in introduction, Thea 2 represents a mixture of games, which, altogether, fulfil each other and add more diversity to a game.

Perhaps, the first mode that’s worth mentioning is basic survival on a global map, where you’ll spend most of the time. This part of the game is strongly turn based, just like in your Civilization games. You can either take a role of a nomad tribe, being all mobile, running through the map and quickly gathering needed materials, or you can settle down, build a talisman and create a village. At this very moment the only real difference between having a village and being a nomad is the fact that you can stock unlimited amount of supplies and have few more events, but hopefully things change in the future and we’ll see proper way of managing village, with building sawmills, local marketplace and stuff.

Quite often you’ll have to face various quests. Some of them may even include other parties, just like yours. Politics and interaction with said factions at this moment stands on quite basic level, but, again, game is in early access, so it’s a subject for a change and probably will be improved in the future. Still, you can talk to other parties and even try to convince them you’re friendly, or try to persuade them to have your point of view. Rather often persuading someone through mere dialogue window isn’t enough and this is where card game starts.

As I explained in storytelling part, I mentioned that there are 3 ways of solving the problem. Quite often you’ll have to rely on your characters’ stats in order to choose which approach you’ll go with, as each person has 3 different scales: Health, Sanity and Faith. If you wear specific items, you’ll have one of your bars increased. In the end, when you choose which approach to take, you’ll have to play a mini card game.  To my disappointment, 3 different types of fights are done in rather similar card game with almost the same set of rules. But other than that, game feels quite good. Oh and one more small thing: Your companions are mortal, so keep in mind that sometimes it’s way better to escape the fight, rather than losing a highly skilled soldier.

 [h1]Sound and Graphics:[/h1]
There isn’t much to tell about graphical aspect of the game. Neither good, nor bad. It looks like typical turn based game from a small company. I personally like the way it looks, especially compared to the visuals of the first game, but some people disliked texture quality.

The sound feels good even nowadays, as it provides large spectre of songs for global map events. They could’ve added some more songs for card battle events, though, but so far I can’t say that I was annoyed by in-game songs or sounds in general.

 [i]Now, let’s take a quick look at PRO’s and CON’s again. Keep in mind that game is in Early Access, so there will be some more negative aspects, but that shouldn’t really bother you a lot, as most of these issues are temporary:[/i]
[b]The PRO’s:[/b][list]
[*][b]Unique mixture of game genres and freedom of approach:[/b]
You can be a steppe nomad, or a village representative, or use mixed approach. You can choose your life path: Whether you want to fight someone with steel&blood, or negotiate, or be a quiet monk, beating everyone with their patience, it’s all up to you.
[*][b]Game has coop mode[/b]:
Yes, you can play the game together with your friends!
[*][b]Rare concept:[/b]
Personally I don’t know any other games about Slavic mythology.
[*][b]A lot of interesting references:[/b]
For example you can find a child in a cabbage, or it can be brought by the stork bird (this is what many Slavic children are told as explanation as of how do children are born) and many other things that’ll certainly make Slavic gamers smile.[/list]

[b]…and the CON’s:[/b][list]
 [*][b]Game updates may break savegame files:[/b]
As I mentioned before, game is in active development stage. Devs add and fix a lot of stuff, but that also means your savegame files can suffer from it. At least this is what happened during my first playthrough.
[*][b]Some characters lack description:[/b]
Did you know who Baba Yaga is? Typically, in Slavic folklore it’s an old witch who lives in a hut on chicken legs, flies the broom, or wooden mortar and, sometimes, eats human flesh. Not everybody is common with Slavic folklore. For such things game should have something like encyclopedia, as it revolves around these characters. And no, this isn’t some nitpicking: I never knew that Slavic mythology has dwarves, so it was a huge surprise when I first saw it. Furthermore, none of my friends mentioned they knew that dwarves are part of slavic mythology as well.
[*][b]A bit strange way of communication with some NPCs[/b]:
I met NPC party and tried to persuade them I had friendly intentions. In the end I had to ‘fight’ them on mental level and while I had just loss of mental health, I assume I just drove NPC party crazy, given the fact that their mental stability scale should’ve dropped below zero and made some party members insane or whatnot. That, together with some other minor things should be tweaked as they don’t quite fit in with game logic.
[*][b]Expanded tutorials[/b]:
Currently, tutorials explain how to play all three types of card games, but when you start playing, you realize it’s still quite unclear how to gather wood, create a village, etc. Truth to be said, game tries to help you via Theodore demon, who explains how things work, but his advice aren’t always clear, so you may mess some things up by not knowing certain game aspects. Maybe explaining how to play on global map should be done via separate extra tutorial…[/list]

[h1]The Conclusion:[/h1]
Clearly, game is going to be interesting and catchy. Even nowadays, while playing early access version, you already risk falling in love with it if you enjoy turn based games. Sure enough, some of the moments are still unpolished and undone, some bugs are present, but even with these issues, it’s really interesting to play a game where you choose your own adventure and meet unique characters from folklore fairy tales. And I’m not even telling about the fact that you may learn a lot of interesting things about Slavic culture this way.


[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321/]Follow our curator page,[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198062609598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 10396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1678866544}
review:
'This game isn't finished, there isn't as much ____ as the last game. yada yada yada.'  This game is going to be awesome.  The devs are doing a great job with it.  Just the level of consideration they give to the player is outstanding (i'm specifically talking about updates and update rollback).  I'm glad I paid full price for this game. I got so much enjoyment out of the last game that I wanted DLC or something. 

After further gameplay, this game is really hard to enjoy in it's current state.  Outside of enjoying helping the developers.  The balance is very off.  World generation is still way too big even with a small map.  Using ships is required, they should be more of a short cut. I don't like the new tech tree, it uses too many points to do too little.  Many resources that you have to purchase seem to be never showing up.  My party sometimes includes women and children from the village when they are several days travel from the village.  Progress seems to be limited by the number of children my village has and it is a very hard limit.  The RNG is very evil sometimes.  There is currently only one ritual that I can find.  Maybe add a fertility ritual. Also my little sylvia grew up to be a goblin tinkerer, you could keep that in and just add a "searching for your real dad' side quest.  Right now the quests don't seem to have a lot of options (people who are wounded son't react to healers, witches don't intervene in scenarios that call for magic).  There are far too few events, and WTF is up with that sad ass bear. I also  am not a fan of the new crafting mechanics or the available god point upgrades.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994607659', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 26426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3181, 'last_played': 1584689471}
review:
I'm already a huge fan of the previous game... and so far the game in developement is really look really bright!
So i'll focus on this... and make a review for the ones that played the first game!

The differences between games (yet):

-Starting:
  >Instead of choosing a god with stated bonus (and unlock with XP),
  you gain god point that you can spend to add character or item
  at the begining in 5 available slots.
  >You start with 4 character max  

-Buildings:
  >There is still a research tree (but not many different building yet), 
  but you actually need to build the village beforehand!
  >There is no attract bonus (Orc/demon/children...), rather, some
  usefull ones for secondaries (bonus research/xp each turn) for now!
  
-Characters:
  >Children are characters, not items, and you can point out ways
  to make them grow where you want
  >Instead of messy bunch of caracteristics, there is main ones, secondaries,
  and skills.
  >There is 2 differents level up, the first one give you to choose between 
  3 caracteristics, but the first one will give you 2 points, the second level
  up give you the choice between 2 skills.
  >There is 3 lifes bar, Health, Sanity, Faith. Having no Sanity/Faith remove 
  your character from activities/challenge it seems.
  >Some skills don't depend of your caracteristics, you can level it up 
  several times, it will improve in power!
  >Less slot for equipements, jewelerie is only one slot and no range weapon
  slot (it's a main weapon instead)

-Equipements:
  >There is no random crafting bonus with forge (or not yet)
  >There is affinity bonus (depending of the number of ressources and its quality) 
  and improved equipement bonus by adding up to two star (20% bonus) 
  unlocking it in the research tree
  
-Gathering:
  >Depend really on your main caracteristics
  >Two slots for gatherers (more with some building in the village only)
  >High tier ressources need to be crafted

-Crafting:
  >Cooking is sort out
  >Building is blend with crafting equipement
  >Rituals are new category (even there is only spiritual one yet)
  >Two slot only (more with some building in the village only), 
  but you can craft with your expeditions parties.

-Challenges:
  >I was never a fan of challenge in Thea 1, auto mode was more
  efficient. Here, it's the opposite... Auto resolution just make the 
  game faster, and half of the time, just doing it yourselves is way
  more efficient!
  >You can only play 7 card at the same time
  >I think challenges in Thea 2 are more simple, from the fact
  caracteristics are more readable, and less cards.
  >Skills are more readable in my opinion than Thea 1

-Experience/Research
  >Some Building can give you some each turn
  >No more XP cap for all characters, each one have it's own,
  and gain are from party/village groups (not for all)
  >Still some Research cap, but doesn't seem the threshold
  rise that much each level
  >Crafting doesn't give you research points

-New stuff
  >You can build a boat (3 types) to go to the sea or fish.
  >You encounter villages that features to offer (heal, gambling,
  trade, quest...), also parties from these villages. It imply also
  some kind of reputation dealing with them.
  >You can make a really powerfull ring out of your village gem,
  instead of the founding village totem.
  >Pets
  >Moral (0 to 100) with variety of food that help healing 


So, for now, except for the few bugs and crash, the game is really interesting. There is still a lot of missing features (like view some descriptions, map, diplomacy...), but the game is playable and enjoyable in this end december. It's way less a farming experience, more an adventure than Thea 1.

Can't wait to play it in it's final version!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982498132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 6487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2094, 'last_played': 1667635416}
review:
The game is presently in early access. There are bugs, there are crashes, but the game is still very, very fun.

I would say the game is similar to "They are Billions" in that there is a lot of trial and error with respect to your opener. Instead of hordes of zombies, you have a bunch of animals and demons that come knocking at your door asking if you'd like to come out and play and maybe give them some of your blood or spirit, just a little, it won't kill you - they don't think >:P

The game is a tad harder than the original Thea: Awakening. It's not possible to quickly ramp up with excellent gear; instead, it's dependent on what materials are available on your ISLAND. After securing a base, you'll eventually need to move to adjacent islands to make use of the resources. In the full game, it will be possible to build multiple bases to claim resources.

My recommendation to the new folks is to save, and save often. If you falter, just view your summary/progress and get some God Points to make the adventure easier the second time around :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197999854923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 14790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6717, 'last_played': 1581377048}
review:
Il faudrait que j'update depuis la sortie de l'EA, mais en attendant: comparativement à Théa 1 je ne recommanderai pas, par contre en tant que jeu seul, je recommanderai.

Eval du 09/02

Pour commencer niveau bugs/crashs et compagnie, personnellement en 35h de jeu(+1k tours) j'en ai quasiment pas eu, 3 crashs et 7 "bugs" (ou en réalité on ne voit pas le souci mais le jeu nous prévient qu'il y a eu un problème et qu'il vaut mieux redémarrer le jeu pour éviter que notre sauvegarde soit corrompue).
Dans ma dernière partie je n'ai eu ni l'un, ni l'autre.

Ensuite, en ce qui concerne la traduction, les développeurs ont dit qu'ils n'avaient pas les moyens de payer une team officielle. Comme pour le 1, des moyens sont mis à disposition pour les traducteurs "amateurs", sachant que la VF a déjà une team sur le coup (Où vous pouvez vous portez volontaire dit en passant), dont certains qui travaillaient aussi sur le 1 (Donc on peut s'attendre à la même qualité et continuité dans les termes). Au final, on aura bien une VF, mais cette dernière n'arrivera pas tout de suite, d'autant plus qu'ils devrontt eux aussi suivre les majs qui feront du rajout à retraduire. (De ce que j'ai compris la team FR prévoit de mettre un patch disponible avec un minimum, puis ultérieurement l'update en fonction de leurs avancées)
Avec l'arrivée du "Théopedia" en jeu, la trad risque de mettre encore plus de temps.

Pour ce qui est des majs qui "détruisent" les sauvegardes, ce serait bien de se renseigner : à chaque nouvelle maj, ils rajoutent le build de celle enlevée dans l'option prévue à cet effet pour qu'on puisse continuer notre partie. De plus, on peut cliquer sur "charger quand même" (où un truc dans le genre c'est en anglais ^^) et personnellement, sur les 3 majs où j'ai utilisé cette option, j'ai pu continuer ma partie sans le moindre souci, sauf changement majeur lors de la maj, la sauvegarde reste fonctionnelle.

Niveau combat, très prometteur, bien que différent du 1, je trouve ça drôle de voir que des gens disent que c'est incompréhensible alors que j'ai lâché le didacticiel car mon anglais était trop mauvais et que j'ai tenté direct le jeu. Au final, avec mes bases de Théa 1, bah ça va tout seul, on comprend vite comment ça marche.(Et sans la base Théa 1, il suffit d'un cerveau et d’un peu de logique pour comprendre)

Là où je trouve cela moins intéressant, c'est que pour le moment, si on fait un combat "Social/Foi" et qu'on perd, on ne peut pas enchaîner avec un combat classique comme dans le 1, car si une de nos 3 barres (Combat/Social/Foi) est vide, notre personnage ne peut pas être utilisé en combat, je pense et j'espère que cela sera modifier dans les majs à venir, afin de pouvoir comme dans le 1 essayer de convaincre des gens ou faire un rituel et si cela ne marche pas leur roulez dessus à gros coup de marteau ! 

Il y a des innovations assez amusantes au niveau des pouvoirs comme les sorts, l'invocation d'"entité" ; j'ai même obtenu [spoiler]un Gobelin Maître des bêtes, qui pouvais invoquer des abeilles ou des animaux sauvages[/spoiler]. Par contre, gros point négatif (enfin de mon point de vue) au niveau des animaux, dans le 1 on pouvait avoir des rats, des ours, des loups et bien d'autres. Ici ils ont été mis en tant que pet ("objet" équipable dans le slot de pet), donc on peut les invoquer en combat pour certains, mais d'autres ne donnent que des avantages passifs et je trouve cela moins fun que de l'avoir dans notre groupe comme une "personne" à part entière. (Pas si négatif finalement, certains peuvent être obtenus comme une personne (rat/loup trouvés pour le moment) d'autres ont des ressemblances (Bog Bie, beaucoup plus de démons 'mineurs' pour compenser), et sûrement d'autres que je n’ai pas encore vu.

L'Early Access se ressent au niveau du changement de gameplay d'une maj à l'autre, dans ma première partie les invocations étaient maîtres en nomade, maintenant c'est les sorts avec village, dans la prochaine ça changera sûrement : on voit qu'ils cherchent encore l'équilibre entre tous les éléments. 

Pour la personnalisation de départ, elle est désormais disponible, mais on ne peut pas choisir combien de cartes sont utilisables en combat, toujours limité à 7 pour l'instant, heureusement maintenant ils nous donnent les 7 plus adaptées au défi en cours (enfin nos cartes d’enfants ne se font plus massacrer pendant que nos guerriers les regardent en se tournant les pouces !), ni si on autorise les blessures négatives ou non (Bonjour le -30 pv !).

L'expérience de recherche a été implantée en rajoutant le Théopédia, une encyclopédie évolutive qui peut débloquer et offrir un gain de recherche avec la rencontre de monstres et terrains, On peut également faire de la recherche en y assignant des personnages. Cependant, on n'obtient toujours pas de points par le craft et il en faut beaucoup (en 1k tour, j’ai à peine fini 1/4 des recherches, ça coûte plus de 200 points pour le prochain niveau même si j’ai déjà tous les bâtiments et recettes : on n’en a donc plus besoin longtemps avant d’avoir fini la quête principale, ils rajouteront peut-être des quêtes narratives ultérieurement, autrement espérons qu'ils réduisent le coût d'un level).
 
Au niveau des 9 Dieux : bien qu'une partie du panthéon soit changé, on retrouve facilement les mêmes axes (nature, nuit, lumière, mort, savoir, combat, etc). Je suis pour le moment mitigé sur leurs "pouvoirs" : dans le 1, cela fonctionnait par palier (c’était des bonus passifs durables pour la plupart). 
Dans le 2, on choisit des cartes de démarrage actives (à l’exception de celle liée à notre dieu qui est un bonus passif) qui fournissent des avantages qu’on peut normalement obtenir plus tard. (Espérons qu'ils rajoutent des pouvoirs passifs : comme un bonus de statistique.)
Cela peut augmenter considérablement la rejouabilité, à voir comment le jeu évoluera avec l’ajout de nouvelles cartes (s’il y en a).
 
Dans la version précédente de cette évaluation, je vous disais que c'était plus axé nomade, bah maintenant le village est roi : une fois posé, vous n’avez même plus besoin de bouger pour finir la partie si vous avez pris un bon spot (et encore j'ai pris le premier qui me filait nourriture/bois/malachite ><). À noter que pour faire un village, il faut une graine particulière qu’on peut aussi utiliser pour faire un anneau surpuissant (et dans les ténèbres les lier), ce qui vous permet de rester nomade (on obtient 2 de ces graines au cours du jeu pour l’instant, ce qui pourrait évoluer).
Il est possible d'utiliser l'éditeur d'évènement pour en obtenir d'avantages.

Ils ont également rajouté un système de "loyauté" envers différentes factions qui pourrait devenir intéressant : pendant ma partie, j'en ai vu certaines qui ne possèdent pas de village (prémisses d’un recrutement racial semblable au 1 ?). 

Pour conclure, le jeu est plein de potentiels. Pour seulement 22€, je dirais : "à acheter les yeux fermés vu la durée de vie." Après, il ne faut pas oublier qu'il est en Early Access à l'heure actuel et qu’il y a donc beaucoup d'éléments qui ne sont pas encore implantés ou qui changent, ce qui peut donc amener des bugs lors des majs.

Si vous ne l'acheter pas les yeux fermés je dirais à acheter si une de ces conditions vous correspond :
- L'anglais ne vous pose aucun soucis de compréhension.
- Vous souhaitez soutenir les devs ou prévoyez d'acheter le jeu une fois la VF prête.
- Avez aimé le 1 et souhaité continuer à jouer dans cet univers.
- Aimez pouvoir jouer différente races ayant des classes spécifiques.
- L'aléatoire n'est pas votre ennemis.(Affecte le passage à l'âge adulte : choix classes/obtenir un démon.)

Ne pas acheter si une de ces conditions vous correspond :
- N'appréciez pas que le jeu change d'une mise à jours à l'autre.
- N'aimez pas lire.
- Voulez un jeu en Français.
- N'aimez pas la gestion et le tour par tour.(Ainsi que passer des tours en attendant que certaines tâches ce finissent)
- L'aléatoire est votre ennemis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035564601', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1544867647}
review:
Brief content for the lazy: THEA: THE AWAKENING was better
Краткое содержание для ленивых: THEA: THE AWAKENING была лучше

Perhaps, Thea 2: The Shattering will like to those who have not played in the first part. For me, as a fan of the first part, the game lost a decent piece of what I loved the first part, without bringing anything good. Slavic punk was replaced by something very very strange. An excellent system of card battles was replaced with a fucking hybrid Hearthstone and MTG. The art on the cards looks much worse than the first part, I understand that they were trying to improve by adding color but ... it did not work. Yes, this is an alpha version and still can change for the better, but without these changes for me this game is lost. She's not bad, she just stopped pleasing the eye.

Возможно, Thea 2: The Shattering зайдет тем, кто не играл в первую часть. Для меня, как фаната именно первой части, игра утратила приличный кусок того, за что я любил первую часть, при этом не привнеся ничего хорошего. Славянский панк заменили чем-то совсем уж невнятным. Стройную систему карточных столкновений непонятно зачем заменили на хуёвый гибрид Hearthstone и MTG. Арты на картах смотрятся сильно хуже первой части, я понимаю, что их пытались улучшить добавлением цвета но... не стоило. Да, это альфа-версия и все еще может измениться в лучшую сторону, пока же для меня эта игра потеряна. Она не плохая, просто перестала радовать глаз.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060651858', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1595367104}
review:
EDIT: Some time has passed, so I'll now change some text in my review, not the rating, it still sucks.



I've been a huge fan of the first Thea and was filled with joy, when i saw, there was another part in developement, but my joy was impersistent.

PROS:
- beautiful new environment
- cards now have colourful drawings instead of the grey sketches
- movement looks a lot smoother
- some quests tell the changes of quests you solved in the first Thea
- even if i said, i hate more complexity, the crafting now seems a lot more logical
- a lot more chields than in The Awakening
- individual level ups for every character
- other NPC factions, acting independent from the player
- diplomacy is now a thing

CONS:
- still way more difficult than "The Awakening", my personal advance feels slowed very drastically, therefore i I really lose fun playing
- the new character attributes like wits, wisdom, etc. are just confusing and ruin the experience if you played the first part
- the overall effectiveness of BUILDINGS is too low
- After about 5 to 6 quests, the challenge level rises to an insane level, even though i individually equip every character with the best equipment at that point
- really dumb difficulty settings, that do not change much (I think)
- still, the gathering processes take way too long, even with about 4 well trained and equipped gatherers
- the quests involved so far seem plain without any creativity
-the story turns difficult very quickly and just seems boring


So at this state, i would NOT recommend Thea 2: The Shattering.
It is mostly boring and takes way too long. I just played for like an hour right now and i can't advance in any quest, cause my equip sucks and it would take years to gather materials for new stuff. The quests are....well, I skip most of the text.

Still, it can be turned into a really really REALLY decent game, IF, however, there comes a lot more content (which, i think, will) and if the devs may consider my PROS and CONS list and change some things i discribed there, take away too much complexity and further on. I think it should at least feel a LITTLE BIT like the old part.

Hoping, you turn this into a masterpiece, although i wont be playing, until you put more effort into it,

RammT

author: {'steamid': '76561198006737549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1684113506}
review:
So far so good!  The new combat system threw me at first, but now that I'm used to it I actually prefer it over the Thea 1 system.  

This game is very much in the Early Release/Alpha form.  There are some game ending crashes, quests that aren't quite working right, overpowered/underpowered classes, etc...  Everything you'd expect from a game still in development.  That being said, MuHa has been putting out patches faster than I've ever experienced for a game in Early Release.  Patches roughly every 2 - 3 days, each fixing multiple issue while also adding new things.  Whole mechanics have been changed between plays; the new cooking system surprised me when it showed up, but it's a huge improvement over the first one.  

All in all, this is a game I would recommend to anyone who likes a 4x game with rogue-lite components and a really enthralling mythos.  If you don't like experiencing the growing pains of an Early Release game, steer clear until either post-release or until it's in a later Alpha phase.  If you're willing to play through some bumps and enjoy helping a developer debug and grow their game, I give it a big thumbs up.

review:
как хороша первая часть, так же плоха вторая.

музыка уныла. вместо пафосной темы первой части будьте готовы к заунывным песнопениям. юнити тормознутый. генерация ресурсов на карте идиотская. жратва, древесина и ресурсы для крафта вместе практически не встречаются. ресурсы, расширяющие радиус сбора, доступны в самом конце игры, а бегать вашему отряду без создания базы долго нельзя, в связи с быстрым нарастанием сложности игры, и ограниченным размером инвентаря и самого поселения. вырисовывается совершенно вопиющий геймдизайнерский косяк. другим геймдизайнерским косяком является перегруженный и непонятный интерфейс. боевая система, которая и в первой то части не блистала, здесь доведена до полного абсурда.
