author: {'steamid': '76561198019095802', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 19517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19517, 'last_played': 1637727658}
review:
I've played this game a lot, and lately I've found myself thinking about what made it good, and where it fell short for me.

The game's primary draw for me definitely has to be its folklore and stylization, and to me the weakest point is overall UX. That's not to say there's not a lot more to it, but those are the things that largely shaped my experience.

I'm actually a bit disappointed there aren't more challenges that reward you for paying attention to the folklore. Thea was my first introduction to Slavic folklore, and while I've learned a lot more outside the game since then, the lore drew me in and I'd love to see it come up more often in challenges if there's a third game. Some of Thea's challenges relied on paying attention to the folklore, but mostly they were just unpredictable choose-your-own-adventure events where the "correct" choice was one you memorized over many playthroughs. Granted, folklore knowledge would be no less repetitive, but at least you'd learn something about folklore and not just memorize by rote which choice is optimal.

As for UX, there are probably a hundred ways that could be improved that I could list without breaking a sweat. Between the cryptic symbols, poorly displayed information, and the sheer number of clicks required to perform actions, I'm still surprised that I stuck with the game. I'm usually put off by any game in which part of the challenge is the interface.

I still, after hundreds of hours, cannot remember what materials will produce what equipment. It doesn't help that it's changed several times since the game's first release, but even if it hadn't, it's not logical or patterned in a way that lets you intuitively predict what things will be required for what stats. You just have to go through EVERY POSSIBLE PERMUTATION for every possible piece of gear and try to remember it all. 

I could go on a length about the combat, the crafting, the grind, and a few other notable features, but for now this will have to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057313606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 11831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2374, 'last_played': 1702750201}
review:
20/12/2018 puis 22/12/2018

Pas de raison d'infléchir. La fréquence des maj reflète la sortie beaucoup trop hative. Toujours pas de compatibilité pour les sauvegardes. Là ca devient ridicule, ne faudrait-il pas se focaliser sur l'essentiel, les joueurs qui doivent repartir de zéro tous les 2 jours. Enfin ceux qui  persistent, perso je dois avoir 45min de jeu dans les 5-6 derniers jours... ?!?

12/12/2018

J'ai adoré l'opus 1 et me suis précipité pour soutenir ce nouveau projet. 

Mais là faut quand même pas exagérer. 

Ok, oublions les combats très rapidement beaucoup trop difficiles, sinon incompréhensibles sans l'auto-résolve. Pourquoi pas, on peut charger et recharger les sauvegardes pour progresser si on le souhaite, on devient rapidement prudent. Et ca évoluera très certainement.

L'éditeur d'event ne fonctionne pas. Ou alors c'est très subtil comme effet...

Le PC finit régulièrement par ramer sévère, c'est insupportable.

Chaque nouvelle maj (comprenez corrections de bugs, allez voir les listes !) rend complètement inutilisables les précédentes sauvegardes, on repart de zéro à chaque fois...

Bref difficile de prendre du plaisir à jouer pour le moment, je le regrette. Vraiment très prometteur mais sauf dans un but de soutien financier, il est urgent d'attendre avant de claquer 20+ euros, le jeu n'est vraiment pas suffisamment terminé, bien au-delà du petit warning des devs au lancement... Mieux vaut surveiller les discussions et rythme des majs.

Enfin, OK, il faut du blé pour bosser. Mais l'image donnée par ce lancement beaucoup trop précipité est juste désastreuse. J'ai du mal à comprendre que les devs aient besoin de retours joueurs pour corriger certains bugs/crashes plutôt évidents dès que l'on approche les 30min de jeu... Ils ne jouent pas ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198007173349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4718, 'last_played': 1581521121}
review:
Огромный прогресс по сравнению с первой частью, значительно больше опций и в боевке, и в крафте. Обилие умений и скилов, а также возможность выбора опций при левелапе делают каждого персонажа уникальным чего не было в первой части.
Появилось множество тактик для боя за счет рейндж и мили рядов на поле, а так же новой сиситемой инициативы. Единственное маги кажутся сильнее обычных воинов милишников, и лучше себя показывают в разного рода боях, но не критично.
Очень радует возможность плавать на другие острова, совершенно разные локации, визуально и по наполнению что важно. Но теперь стало сложно пределится где строить свой город, так как локации одна другой интересней. Ах да город теперь можно строить где сами захотите, что очень круто. Можно играть кочевниками и вообще без города.
Визуально игра стала лучше, но стоит добавить больше кратность отдаления камеры, потому что неудобно быстро осматривать локацию.
В плане музыки и звука, как и в первой части все великолепно. 

Из минусов отметил бы странности с детьми и родителями, например были случаи когда ребенок рождался внезапно от двух мужчин. Ещё хуже когда например гоблин случайно затесавшийся в отряд в итоге наплодил кучу детей гоблинов, так что половина отряда стала гоблинами. Иногда родители гоблин-человек, а иногда и гоблин-и его же ребенок! то есть папа гоблин со своей же дочкой и тп, это бред имхо. Подсвечивание родителей благословлением надо убирать полностью, потому что нормально это все отслеживать игра все равно не сможет, в первой части этого не было и нормально жили.
В первых редакциях игра вылетала нещадно, но последние обновления сделало игру стабильной. 

Больше всего неудобств создает отсутствие журнала заданий и миссий, сама иконка есть, но ее пока не реализовали, вот это на мой взгляд надо делать в первую очередь, потому что обилие текста и квестовых развилок надо где то отслеживать и читать по необходимости. Не говоря уже о том, чтобы подсветить где чей квестовый маркер на карте, потому что сейчас абсолютно непонятно к какому квесту идешь по маркеру когда их несколько.

Несмотря на всю недоделаность в итоге в игре уже сейчас все равно куда больше контента чем в первой части, и дальше будет только добавлятся. 
Рекомендую всем любителям стратегий и рпг, единственный реальный минус игры - спать вы будете очень мало, потому что оторватся от новой Thea 2 крайне трудно. А с русской локализацией играть будет ещё комфортнее.
Покупкой игры очень доволен. Приятно наблюдать за работой разработчиков, всех благ им за такой шедевр. 
Оценка 10 из 10-ти с учетом, что доделают в итоге то что уже заложено, но руки пока не дошли.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973722840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 86832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1415, 'last_played': 1696442112}
review:
The game certainly has the makings to be as good as or better than it's predecessor.  The changes they made to the card game battles make Thea 2 a fresh new game that you get to learn how to play all over again. There are a few kinks still needing to be worked out, but the game is playable and enjoyable for sure. If you liked The: The Awakening, I can pretty much guarantee you will like this game as well.

 Most of the negative reviews seem to be centered around people being unable to figure out how to play. I picked it up pretty quick, so I will address some of these:

1. People complained they don't understand what the icons mean or how the skills function. Open up the equipment menu and hover over each stat icon and in this menu to see the tooltips. The significance of each is clearly explained here. It doesn't look like the tooltips have yet been implemented for every menu, but in eq. menu they are.

2. People complained they can't figure out the card game. There is some complexity to it, but the basics are pretty simple. There are two rows, melee and ranged. Cards playing melee moves must be placed in a melee row, with the exception of spear which can attack from ranged slots. The card will attack the melee row in front of that. If vacant, they will attack the ranged row. If both are vacant, they will attack the next closest spot. Some weapons attack multiple slots. Large blunt weapons attack the slot and all adjacent slots. Spears attack both melee and ranged when played in a melee spot, andm uch more.

3. People complained they didn't understand how to get an edge on non-combat challenges. So, there are three stat categories: physical, mental, and spiritual. When reviewing dialouge options, Physical are red (combat included). Mental are yellow. Spiritual are blue. Each has a primary and secondary attribute that factor into the damage for each type of challenge. Either a skill or appropriate weapon is needed to attack in full force. So a weapon attack in a mental or spirutual challenge cannot be made unless the character is equipped with a mental or spiritual weapon (such as a book or artifact). Beyond this, there are mental and spirutal abilities/skills that can allow you to make a strong attack without a weapon of that type. 

4. People complained they didn't understand the pros of building a village. The village allows you to build buildings that can greatly increase your crafting speed and item quality. It can serve as a great crafting hub, and also contains building options to improve other areas. Setting up a village also gives you a way to store a large amount of materials without affecting your adventuring party's movement ability. This becomes essential as you get further into the game.

All the pros:
-Variety of materials for foraging and crafting
-Lots of freedom in actions and dialogue
-Ton of different items to craft and equip
-Pets
-Fresh, interesting card combat game
-Active and hard working development team

In short, you should buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069606853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1526, 'last_played': 1638370185}
review:
I really really am trying to enoy this game as much as I enjoyed the first but it's very difficult to do so. So far I like many of the design choices made that really help improve the game over the first, such as being able to chose where to start your first village, if you even want to start one at all. In general I enjoy the time I spoend on the game but there is some serious glaring issues that take a lot of the fun out of it.

Firstly, the randomised recipes for items, buildings, meals etc. are a fun little idea and laregly don't cause an issue, but the starting meal recipe being randomised is such a pain sometimes. I ended up with a randomised recipe that excluded the two most common foods I have around me and the ones that are included are so far apart that it makes it nearly impossible to get a reliable amount of both to keep making food. This makes the food crafting even more annoying than it sometimes was in the first game.

Secondly, theft events. It is way too far for theft events to steal such a massive amount of your stuff. I had a Dwaren Thief event that stole just a chunk of everything I had including some pretty high tier tools and weapons I had only just gotten from another event and hadn't equipped yet. While some might say that is just good difficulty, sure it's difficult but it's also extremely frustrating to just have a huge amount of your stuff stolen like that without any actual chance to stop them besides learning the events off by heart and avoiding them. This is not to mention the few times I've started a game and had events of 2-3 difficulty that I just didn't have a chance of winning that then killed off one or two characters from wounds.

In it's current state I feel like the game needs some serious balancing done to it because currently it's often just a lesson in frustration and I end up closing out of the game mid session and contemplating just playing the first game again, which despite it's couple of flaws is at least a game I can enjoy. Hopefuly, with more work this game can become something I can enjoy, but for now it's not just missing features and got bugs, the balance is just off too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061957737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1559675291}
review:
The problems with this game are simple.

1. There is no good tutorial system for what is are rather complicated game mechanics. Stats are never explained, and the very brief explanation of the card game system leaves much to be desired. And, with the game being so new, I can't even find any third-party tutorials online. The game never explains the three different "health" bars (Health, Sanity, and Faith), and doesn't tell you how to heal those until your people are already suffering badly from the loss of them. 

2. It is riddled with bugs. In my first hour or so of gameplay, I came across more than a few of them, one of which ended up causing my party to entirely die off.

Note to Game Devs:
Explain how to play the game?! Please!? Online tutorials, anything? I want to play, but I don't know how!

review:
- Early Access Review -
I bought this game on early access and can say I've enjoyed it so far (25 hours currently). There are some minor bugs and annoyances, but I've not encountered a major or game-breaking bug so far. [I'm at turn 450 with my farthest game, worked fine]
The mechanics are a bit weird to pick up, not having played the first part, but after a few hours most has become clear. 
Some events feel a bit to frequent and the story-events could pop at some scripted turns (at my current game I waited about 100 turns until I got an event), but that was an exception.
The art is gorgeous, the story is fun to read and there are enough mechanics to keep one interested. Interested to see where this is going.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006553959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1544193407}
review:
J'ai plus de 410 heures de jeu sur Thea 1 donc je voyais Thea 2 comme quasiment incontournable, une évolution à avoir absolument.
Hmmm, bah pas vraiment, en fin de compte ce jeu est peut être amélioré graphiquement mais au combien fastidieux maintenant. 
Le nouveau système de Dieux est bizarre, passons, on click sans trop comprendre ce que l'on fait.
On se retrouve avec une toute petite équipe sur la carte: 2 guerriers, 1 ramasseur ?!? (Scavenger) et 1 Enfant ! 
Rien que pour obtenir un Village c'est minimum 50 tours !! Il va vous falloir recolter (mais vous n'avez pas de Récolteurs) et ça prend énormement de temps (tours). Ensuite vous êtes attaqués sans arrêt et c'est la que ça se corse :
le système de combat est incompréhensible, inutilement compliqué et mal foutu au possible ! 
Autant j'avais adoré les combats et surtout les différents types de combats dans Thea 1 autant la je suis paumé de chez largué !   ^^
Même le tutoriel vous largue :  il vous engage dans un combat que vous ne pouvez pas gagner !?!  incompréhensible je vous dis.
Vous pouvez (devez) "Cloner" vos cartes pour combattre sur une "ligne de temps différente" !?!  et vous ainsi que l'IA pouvez les posez n'importe ou sur le plateau de jeu : c'est à dire que l'on ne joue plus chacun son tour à la suite , une carte apres l'autre. c 'est compliqué à expliquer.  l'IA à tendance à poser des cartes à la fin ?!? je ne vois pas pourquoi ni l 'interet du truc. Pareil il y a maintenant 2 rangées de cartes , je suppose  une rangée "Mélée" une rangée "Distance"  !?!  heu oui mais encore ? 
Bon c'est de l'early acces et voila je me suis encore fait avoir une nouvelle fois !  :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198016742385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 31768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3106, 'last_played': 1706456238}
review:
Bonjour
Je suis à 35h de jeux au momment du message.

J'ai joué à Théa 1 (+200h)  et je trouve le jeux Théa 2 réussis avec des hic du à l'avant 1er.
Le jeux et en anglais mais un niveau d'anglais de 4 eme avec un peu de google traduction pour certain mots ça passe.
Par la suite un mode français sera fait par la communauté.

les points négatifs:

- Pour un nouveau joueur le fait que le jeux soit en Anglais peux etre déroutant lors des choix d'événement.
- Un manque de batiments pour améliorer son village ( actuellement 6 batiments).
- Pas de mini map (il y a l'emplacement en bas à gauche mais elle reste vide).
- Il n'y a pas de visuel pour suivre le gain d'expérience juste un cercle bleu qui augmentent.
- Actuellement nous ne pouvons pas réglé la difficulté dans le jeux.
- Pas d'indicatif sur l'optention de nouveau dieux.
- Petite limmitte au nbrs de carte que l'on débloque pour personalisé sont départ (actuelement juste 6/8 Par dieux)

Points neutres :
= Un multy à 3 joueurs, c est mieux que théa 1 où nous étions à 2 joueurs.  Mais 4 joueurs serai plus fun :D
= Des saisons 

Points Positifs :

+ On commence en nomade on peut choisir de faire toutes la partie en nomade (un item unique donnera un bonus). ou bien on peux choisir son emplacement de village.
+ Il y a un indicatif pour savoir quand les enfants deviendront grand.
+ Il y a des village sur la carte, où l'on peux marchander, avoir des quetes attaquer  etc ...
+Nous avons la possibilité de construire des bateaux pour explorer :D et chercher de nouvelles terre.
+ Un plus grand choix en ressources que dans Théa 1
+ Des nouvelles armes (ex: javelot, baguette, parchemin...) 
+ Utilisation de pouvoir magique dans les combats (invocation ou projectille).
+ Un choix de talent à chaque level up des personnage. 
+ Les personnage sont plus résistant à la mort que dans théa 1.
+ un personnage démon protége le village. 
+ La mécanique des combats reste bien faite. On sait où vas taper le personnage.
+ Un TUTO simple et efficace pour apprendre les bases sur les combats et événement.
+Les créateurs sont proche de la communauté et répondent rapidement au question.

autres:

Les premiers tour sont sur de la récolte de ressource et exploration. 
Le jeux augmente en difficulté à partir du tour 150 il faut s'organiser pour avoir un groupe ( 6 personnes) correcte avant le tour 100. 


Je recommande le jeux.
C est du JDR rienne sert à ce prendre la tête :D
Après le jeux restera plus fun en jouant avec des personnes.

Au plaisir de vous avoir aidé.
Bonne soirée.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999578415', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1581364394}
review:
Четыре месяца спустя, переждав пару десятков обновлений, решился снова запустить игру, и залип часов на 14. Все еще сыровато, но уже вполне играбельно. 

Отзыв на момент старта:
Крайне сырой продукт. Купил исключительно ради поддержки разработчиков. 

Я бы на месте авторов попридержал еще месяца три-четыре, а игрокам пока бы не советовал в нее играть - половина контента отсутствует, множество багов, постоянные вылеты и все такое. Плюс частые обновления ломают сейвы, и вдумчиво отыграть не получится. Впрочем, у авторов достаточно ресурсов и опыта, чтобы довести игру до ума. Будем ждать.

Впрочем, сейчас уже выглядит очень многообещающе. Из отличительных особенностей - завезли человеческий интерфейс, улучшеный графоний, и совершенно новую боевку. И хотя по ней есть вопросы, играется бодрее.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018843029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 260, 'playtime_forever': 8276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4356, 'last_played': 1584476248}
review:
Early Access Review
Yes it is still buggy, BUT!

This is simply a pure improvement of the first installment, and the developers are working in strides to make it ready. If you enjoyed the first game you really should get this one. You can now make multiple cities, diplomacy with other races and cities and you need to use boats to travel long distances across the oceans. The Game is simply better, well rather it will be.

Early access usually means it is buggy, and can crash BUT you can help the developers improve their work by finding the bugs and whatnot, and such a great title as this definatly is worth some aid.

The Developers take suggestions in consideration and the event editor of thea 1 is much better in Thea 2. There is no need to cheat with cheat engine or other devices as you can simply make events that boosts your attribute, materials and so on with ease.

But yes, the game is amazing and I cannot wait for it to be done, it is by all counts perfection, it is RPG, Management, city building, exploration and with an event editor that enables players to make complex stories for each others. It is simply amazing. But yes, still buggy but so so worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039424736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 50346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7445, 'last_played': 1687982671}
review:
The short answer:  If you like Thea, you'll like this game as well.  They've built on a lot of what made the first one great/unique and introduced a leveling/skills system that seems like a huge improvement over the first game so far.  The additonal depth added to the card system in the second game still needs some tweaking, but again the bones seem better than Thea 1.  As a huge fan of the first game (seriously go get that game), I like what I've seen so far from this one and recommend it.  This is a great game studio that is absolutely going to support this game.  Happy to contribute my money to supporting these kinds of developers when so many studios are pushing out reskins/clones/broken games.

A lot of reviews are complaining about bugs but the game is absolutely playable and enjoyable at this point and I've only encounted one bug that is an issue and the devs are patching it now.

Pros:
--Strong foundation built on top of what worked well in the first game
--Improved leveling system and skills provided agency and flavor that was missing somewhat in the first game.
--Great art style and a fun unique mythology
--Incredible modding potential and a built in event editor with full access to add/remove quests with a button click.
--HIGHLY responsive devs who are dedicated to making a great game.
--Tons of replay potential.

Cons:
--Gods feel a bit too flat right now but this is going to be fleshed out as EA goes on.
--Not enough character portraits/model but again being expanded on already (1 week in) in the EA.
--Balancing issues with some quests and classes.
--Buildings need more depth

author: {'steamid': '76561197981744495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3625, 'last_played': 1546707171}
review:
I enjoyed Thea: The Awakening. I have been looking forward for Thea 2. Now, it's finally here, though in Early Access. The game throws a lot at you at once, and, even as a veteran of Thea 1, I found myself lost at times. There are some fundmental gameplay design choices that make this game irritating and ultimately unenjoyable. 

I don't regret buying it. I was curious to see how the developers would grow as game designers based on the success of the first game. In my opinion, they did not. They took all of the more irritating gameplay mechanics from the first game, said "Hold my beer," and turned them up to 11 for the sequel. 

1. The new card based combat system is slower and even more of a chore, and is even less skippable, because the "random" outcome are ridiculously severe. 

2. The village has fewer buildings, fewer benefits, is constantly under attack, and is inferior to the village in the original game in almost every way. The only improvement is that players are not locked into a potentially crappy village site when they start the game.

3. The materials / research / crafting system seem way more jumbled and overcomplicated than they need be. It's just padding. I spend most of my games just clicking "Next Turn" because 90% of this game is just waiting for research and production (if you want to quest without full party wipes).

4. Quests - The main quest is not very good, and the sides quests / encounters are very frequent and highly repetitive. 

Still better than Fallout 76 though. And it is Early Access, so the game may improve. But I feel the developers have planted their flag on certain concepts and mechanics that make this game little more than a Level Up Simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042289187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1653097206}
review:
A lot of improvements on the original, which I'll list.

-Sailing is now a thing and you aren't on some everlasting continent, there are landmasses beyond the starting point which do contain more valuable resources.
-Game is much harder now, which is a great step up from the original where you'd become unstoppable after 150-200 turns, around these many turns in this game you would've just started to progress onto the main story (unless you just settle as soon as you've got the resources).
-The game is generally more colourful than the original, which is a great tie in given its slavic pagan roots.
-There's some nice quests that are related to ones in the original Thea.
-Gods feel genuinely diverse and unique.
-You can found more than one town, though the downside atm is that you can't name them, it will obviously be implemented at a later date.



Overall I'd reccomend buying it now even though it is in beta, the development team have done an incredible job of improving from the original formula and making it unique, they put a lot of time into patching the game, and even though it is incomplete anyone who has played the original I recommend you pick it up now, the changes are astonishing in contrast to the original (which I logged around 50 hours into).

Big round of applause to the development team, you've fleshed out something great and I cant wait to play the finished product.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127693581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1653736032}
review:
Первая часть была хороша.
Во второй части каких то принципиальных отличий по геймплею, относительно первой - нет.
Ничего не ухудшили, но и принципиального развития - нет.
Из приятных изменений относительно первой части:
-добавили выбор что качать при прогрессе персонажей по уровням.
-возможность конвертации одних ресурсов в другие (во вкладке приготовления пищи - seriously?!)
-возможность самому выбрать, где будет распологаться твое поселение.
-очень приятная кнопка Design, благодаря которой можно посмотреть какие эффекты будут иметь здания и предметы, изготовленные из разных материалов, даже если их у тебя в данный момент нет.
-наличие чужих поселений, с которыми можно воевать или торговать, пока это выглядит довольно бесполезным, но видимо, задел на будущее.
Из минусов могу отметить только не очень прозрачные механики и UI.
- например, как я уже сказал, конвертация одних материалов в другие находится во вкладке приготовления пищи - но зачем?!
- рандомный выбор, какими профессиями будут обладать дети при взрослении, одному и тому же ребенку при перезагрузке предлагаются на выбор разный набор профессий, не уверен, что это хорошее решение в дизайне, поскольку можно сохраниться и загружаться, пока тебе не предложат возможность нужной профессии, но ок.
- не очень понятно, что влияет на возможность появления новых членов общества и скорость их взросления.

Но это довольно минорные минусы. Игра хорошая, для тех кому понравилась первая часть - рекомендую.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119300941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1649804135}
review:
Tl;dr Gra jest świetna. Zasługuje na więcej rozgłosu.

Bierze najlepsze cechy z jedynki i eksploruje na ich polu:
+ ciekawa historia i wydarzenia losowe
+ słowiański klimat
+ dobry system craftingu
+ możliwość zrobienia z trzech prawie gołych zbieraczy i dziecka potężnego powerhouse'u

Dodaje swoje własne rozwiązania:
+ możliwość lokalizacji wioski; lub życia wagabundy
+ ułatwianie (mam nadzieję, że będzie także opcja utrudniania) rozgrywki przez wybór kart
+ kontrolowanie rozwoju postaci

To wszystko okraszone przyjaznym graczowi systemem biznesowym, zaangażowanym zespołem devów i nową oprawą graficzną.

Na tę chwilę widzę takie możliwości (zagrożenia):
- system craftingu - wolałbym, żeby rzadkie surowce szły bardziej w specjalne efekty zamiast zwiększać "czystą moc" przedmiotu
- UI - sporo do poprawy, czytelność interfejsu może nieco zmylić graczy bez doświadczenia w jedynce; proponuję dłuższy samouczek, możliwość zatrzymania tooltip'u na ekranie i opcję pomocy (księga, encyklopedia, spis najprzydatniejszych taktyk, surowców, rodzajów przeciwników itp.)
- grafiki - popieram kolegę przedmówcę, że powinny współgrać ze światem - być nieokrzesane, surowe. A co jeśli dało by się przełączać między opcją grafik kolorowych i czarno-białych dla postaci i potworów?
- balans rozgrywki - w tym szczególnie wyzwań socjalnych - chciałbym więcej statystyk pobocznych! Jak np. obchodzenie się ze zwierzętami (większy bonus od towarzyszy?); dążąc za trendem z jedynki, który był świetny.

Mam nadzieję, że gra zarobi na siebie, co pozwoli na jej dalszy rozwój. Ma ogromny potencjał.
Cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561197971106664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 3940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3919, 'last_played': 1574696262}
review:
I wasn t willing to make a negative review. I liked Thea 1 so much that it felt heretic to dump Thea 2. i even played the hours above trying to get in... impossible. I gave up. Freezed the game to wait for changes i tought needed in the updates....well, they did not come.
Combat is a slow hassle, really don t know how someone find it fun. No dynamism at all, and low strategic to the point thea 1 combat is at the same level. So no real strategy and this time no dynamism...
The system of island is quite  boring  on the long run. Too much fragmentation. Unviable for "anchored ones" and well more of the same for "walkers".
Also many uncompreensible blindness to weaknesses and uncompletion that let many wondering . All reported by players.
I waited some month to see if it would evolve....but it didn t... in the direction needed.
Seems the creators had an idea in Thea 1 but lost all good creativity in Thea2 creating a featured game but with lackluster and cranky piled ideas.... 
In paper all those looks good, but the execution fails, not so rare in game industry. a pity.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991745199', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1706860829}
review:
TLDR: an enormous improvement from the first game. 

Pluses:
- Battle system is rather complex and the learning curve is quite steep. However, the information is presented rather well and after several battles more and more stats start making sense how they actually work.
- The world map now has islands. In order to get to them you need to build yourself a ship. Thus your party can actually become sort of pirates if you wish. Each island contains it's own ecosystem with resources that can be hard to find on other islands. 
- NPC villages are diverse and often one can be found on each island. Quite a lot of interactions are available. Starting from visiting a tavern, through getting quests and finishing on sieges. 
- Managing your party might not seem as an easy task at first due to great amount of data being thrown at you at once. However, a little patience will make wonders and soon after the stats being displayed will start making sense. 
- The devs actually managed to create a decent game immersion, which is nice. Moral decisions will affect your parties later in the game.
- Combat is now carried out on 3 different plain. Regular flesh and bones, magic and diplomatic. IMHO this is actually great. No longer do you need to grind your characters and buff them with random stuff. Equipping a character now requires some though.

Minuses:
- Since this is still early acces, mind that some bugs are to be expected. They are not, however, game-breaking and 97% of the time the game is very stable.
- Some game mechanics affet the fluency of the game. Luckily those 'lags' don't last for too long. The longest I experinced was ~1 second. 
- None of the dialouges are narrated. This might put some players off. However the first game had some narration, thus we might expect that narration in this game will be added later. 
- Few divine bonuses upon party creation at the moment of writing this review. 

Overall I'd go with 9/10. 
Despite the early access stage I'm already happy with all the content and improvements in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109831282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 18201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1650, 'last_played': 1686425314}
review:
Thea: The Awakening was one of my all time favorite games that I just randomly stumbled upon one day and Thea 2 seemes to capture all of the things I loved about the first game and then expands into a few of the criticisms I had but never got around to writing. Here is a quick list of pros and cons from the first week of early access:

Pros:
-The dev team is great and even has a discord that they are releatively active in. They are really committed to making quick fixes for this EA it seems
-The game is fully playable and has relatively few issues currently it seems to only be missing a few features from what could be considered a complete game
-You can build where you want your town to be after you explore which is a huge improvement from the first game
-Ships are a thing now in this game so there is more than just the island you start on

Cons:
-Due to frequent updates and a few bugs here and there you might get an incompatible save and have to start over
-the progression system for gods doesnt seem to be in yet or at least is not fully integrated 
-there is no variable zoom on the map which makes looking at the whole world a bit difficult
-some clickable elements are not currently working (like scroll arrows to see all the resources gathered in a turn)

Overall it has been a very enjoyable time playing and im excited to see more from it soon

Post release review:
Of the small quality of life things that I mentioned in my E.A. review the only one that was not added was a variable zoom on the scroll wheel. The tool tips and minimap are now much better and display all the information I would deem necessary but are still somewhat simplistic. There is now difficulty settings you can play around with to better suit your experience to how you like to play which is a major plus. The devs have also added numerous new mechanics and interactions that have made the game really stand out to me as remarkably different than Thea 1. At this point i think the only thing i really want that is missing is the ability to get more than 2 town seeds so I can fully conquer the world and start a pseudo economy around different resources.

Post Wrath of the Sea FreeLC review:
The interface of the game does its job relatively well. They did add variable zoom on your group in one of the patches along the road which was a welcome addition for me as the default camera was pretty tight. The Wrath of the Sea content is REALLY end game and makes the sea quite dangerous depending on your settings. I liked a fast, aggressive  world pace so I am often assaulted by Challenge 10-11 krakens once you get up to turn 100 or so. You still can't get more than 2 town seeds which is disappointing but maybe a mod will come around to add a quest for more. The only other slight i have against the game is that some of the more interesting races are quite convoluted with how you get some of their unique classes (elves are really picky with stats which is added to the fact that you can only get 2 children per play through realistically). I would personally prefer if some of these odd stat requirements were explained in game but the mystery and chance is definitely a charm of the game so maybe it would take a way some of the magic that makes Thea so special. Overall this game has an enormous amount of content for a $20 game and is worth a buy any day of the week.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087813151', 'num_games_owned': 5538, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1543762401}
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[i]Thea 2: The Shattering[/i] is a mixture of multiple genres, including 4X, RPG, Card Game, Choose-Your-Adventure style with roguelike elements and crafting as well. The game is in Early Access at the moment and seems to be in the rather early stages. If you don't like an Early Access title and want to wait for a finished product, you should wait. If you have played the first game and want to help the developers create a good sequel, then this is your chance. The first game is good to teach you the basics, or if you really feel like it, you can jump in here and learn as well. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This game is rather complex and difficult to describe, please keep in mind that this description is hardly complete, but hopefully it will offer you some insights regarding the game to help you decide your next action (to buy or not to buy, of course).

All of the maps under go procedural generation, so no game will be the same.

The battles are turn-based and use cards, similarly to Thea 1. The battles are broken into separate phases, and it will take some time to get used to and familiarize yourself with the steps.

The game does offer a few tutorials to show you the basics of the game. This is absolutely crucial because it takes some time to learn all of the complexities. (If you want to learn the basics on a polished game, the first game is a good option.)

The game can be played as single-player or multiplayer.

There are many options to choose from, and the game can be adjusted to how you wish to play.

In the beginning, you will choose which god you wish to follow. There are two to choose from, whereas the rest are locked in the beginning.

After that, you will be selecting individual traits that you think would help you with your quest. Through more god points, you can unlock some new traits as well. The points are accumulated through playing the game.

You will be choosing among three classes for your main character, warrior, craftsman, and child--the last of which can grow up and you can choose specialties afterwards. If you have both males and female characters in your group, you can get children as well.

Starting as a group, you need to find a suitable place for a settlement. You will need to manage food/fuel for your people and this is absolutely something you want to keep an eye on all of the time.

You can move around on the world map to other hexes, though you are limited by your movement points. You can setup camp, gather resources, build, etc. (In terms of building, you do not need all resources, one primary and one secondary is often enough.)

Individual hexes will contain resources, enemies, ruins, etc. You will need to perform appropriate actions according to what the hex contains in order to benefit the most from your turn. Sometimes enemies will move toward you as well during their turns. Some of time, you will get a pop-up choose-your-adventure screen and you will decide what you will end up doing.

Each member in your group can level up as well, so there are many aspects of the game to manage to keep track of.

When you use all of your movement points and have done everything you wished to do, you can end the turn.

There are many unlockable items in this game, from tech trees, resources, equipment, buildings, rituals, etc. You really need to play to understand the intricacies of the game.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Game is played with keyboard and mouse.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics are really nice. They are better than the first game.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
[i]Thea 2: The Shattering[/i] is a sequel to [i]Thea: The Awakening[/i] and is showing a lot of promise, even in Early Access. I have high hopes for the end result once everything is complete. There are plenty of things you should think of when deciding to buy in Early Access, and the developers have mentioned that perhaps your save files will not be compatible in between patches. There are some bugs and we should expect to see many updates. There are no achievements yet, they will be added later. As above, if you want to help the developers create a good sequel to the initial game, you definitely should jump in now. Otherwise, you may wish to wait for the final product.

I personally loved the first game and I am hoping this game brings the appropriate innovation and changes to warrant a new product. This game is more complex than the first and you should play the first to learn the basics and to enjoy a well-made game anyway. I would definitely recommend this game, but people need to be aware that it is still very early in early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036542076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1552964261}
review:
This game is true early access, enough that I can't recommend it without reservations. I wonder how much I'll be playing it myself, at this time, due to the fact that I'm sooner save my enthusiasm for the game for its full-release version. After all,  you can only play a game for so many hours before you become bored of it, and wouldn't it be better to play the full thing?

That said, the first Thea was a brilliat gem, and I have complete faith that this will be also. The bones of a great game are there, without significantly updated combat mechanics, interesting challenges, and the world-building that made Thea so interesting in the first place. I don't know how to describe it, exactly, but unlike some games where randomness seems to determine the course of the game and it feels totally unfair and arbitrary, Thea builds a world where randomness and arbitrariness is a part of daily life, and everyone either lives with that reality or dies cursing it. So it doesn't feel forced - it's just part of the world environment.

The main strength of the game, for me, is that I like turn-based building games, but I dislike it when the stuff I'm managing gets so huge and over-whelming that I have no idea what's going on on the other side of the world. Thea is a deep-management game. Small decisions matter a lot, but you have a limited number of things and people and groups to worry about.

For anyone excited by this style of game and especially about the original, it's worth buying now and either poking around early and coming back to (as I may) or playing it through if you like and waiting for improvements later. For anyone else, the full version is bound to be worth it when it's ready. I have faith in MuHa games, and they've earned it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198319078045', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1558273918}
review:
Disappointing, and not worth the money at this point. Some parts are okay, like starting the game without a village and having to find a good spot to biuld one, however there are serious flaws with this at the moment. For example gathering resources takes a ridiclous amount of time as you can only use 2 people to gather each item, plus you only get 4 or 5 people to begin with, so even when you manage to get enough resources and build a town you can't go anywhere because you don't have enough people. Hopefully these are things that will be sorted out at some point so the game is much more playable from the start. 
Unfortunately for me the things I hate most about this game aren't things that are likely to be changed. The new art style is terrible and looks really childish, and I really, REALLY, hate the new combat system. I am only couple of hours in and I already find myself hitting the auto resolve - even if the outcome is bad - just so I don't have to play through the battles. At this point in time I really regret buying this game and wish I had spent the £17.99 it cost on something else.

Well the game has now been released and I still hate it. The voice acting is truly terrible - even worse than the first game - and all the things I hated are still the same. I really regret buying this as it is now just going to be uninstalled and never played, so a complete waste of money. Such a shame as I was really looking forward to this game coming out when it was first announced.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988355741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 8060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1249, 'last_played': 1582930045}
review:
На релизе первая часть была слабоиграбельной и не имела четких граней (сам пробовал). Многожанровость это большой риск в игрострое. Но ребята смогли ее отполировать на должном уровне. За что им большущее спасибо, ведь это уникальнейший экспириенс.

 Вторая же часть имеет точно такие же проблемы. В реалиях - первая часть лучше второй на данный момент. В перспективе - вторая должна стать улучшенной первой с бОльшим количеством возможностей. Русский язык + грамотная доработка и будет прекрасно. Пожелаю разработчикам успехов довести игру до релиза.

Что хочется чтобы переделали/добавили:
Дубли карт в бою рушат тактику боя и смысл численного превосходства. 
Крафт стал не таким уникальным, как в первой части, где каждый материал давал свои доп. уникальные свойства. 
Деревня стала какой то совсем неважно частью игры и построек критически мало. 
Побольше портретов персонажей было бы замечательно, особенно для детей.
Вернуть логова монстров или сделать альтернативы.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030400300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2388, 'last_played': 1607663212}
review:
Жутко забагованая дичь, иногда приходится по несколько раз перезаходить в игру что бы то что не хотело работать вдруг заработало, но получать удовольствие от игры это не мешает.
Появился у меня сын (айст принес, угу). С самого рождения я воспитывал его как воина. Дал ему большой (маленький и легкий) меч, качал силу, брал во все сражения что бы сражался с папкой и мамкой и учился бить ворожин всяких. Заранее скрафтил ему на совершеннолетие пак брони и артефактов. И вот, настал день ритуала взросления и посвящения, день когда мой сын станет наконец воином. Но тут вмешивается божество, вихри магии или еще там что то, судьба меняется и бабах - мой сын качок превращается в сисястую голую крылатую гарпию.
10 русалок вампиров из 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998292162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 13434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2848, 'last_played': 1597097594}
review:
I should love this game, after all i was apart of the Kickstarter. You can find my uggly mug in the game and eventually you will be able to play a quest of my mind. But the truth is I dont, i dont get that Thea feeling.

Ignoring that this is EA and you can expect alot of bugs and chrases, i dont mind that at all. But the mechanics od the game has been totaly reworked as to the point where the game has lost its soul.

Resources food and gathering has been randomized. A big part of thea was gathering getting the better resources and makeing your equipment. I see no point in doing this at all in thea 2 there is little to no diffrence between a basic blade and something advanced.

The combat system has also been overhauled and i dont know if they have gotten to much insperation from games like Gwent, heart of stone and so on? But as said earlier your equipment dosent matter or how you play the battles so i find myself doing auto-solve 90% of the times and even at that accepting the poor outcomes.

There is alot more to say unfortnatley but what it comes down to they have overcomplicated thing so they make no point and need to be totaly re-balanced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053748477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 42161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3667, 'last_played': 1665956812}
review:
At the time I write this the game has been in early access for 2 days.
I'm guessing you've played Thea 1 so I will skip the game description and fast forward to the level of completion.

At this time, A LOT still needs to happen. Because at this time the game is nowhere near as good as it's predecessor,  important game mechanics like buildings seem not to do much of anything at all and the interface is less intuitive. 

So why the positive review?
Buying a game in early access is a purchase on good faith. So the real question is wether my trust is well placed or misguided. Two days out and we have seen 3 updates (during the weekend). Plus the fact that Thea 1 received a lot of support and free extra content after release and I'm guessing that my trust is well placed. This is a small indy developer that I would like to support.

What else to expect?
Well, the pretty black and white portraits are all gone. The artwork is still being worked on but I think I liked it better in charming black and white. The research tree seems to allow for a lot more specialisation. The Gods seem to have much more of an impact. Instead of a village you will start with only 3 people and a child and it seems to be a plausible option not to settle but instead command a band of travelling nomads (which I did not). And there seem to be more rpg elements.

All in all...
Not every change is always an improvement and at this time it's too early to tell. But the good news is that they didn't go for the quick bucks. There's some real changes. Mostly that makes me curious. And that's good, right? Because I would like to be an explorer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007042315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1553131875}
review:
Heya there.

First of all, I almost never leave reviews, but with the way Early Access goes in Steam, I wanted to come out and show my support for this team and their project.  Because I know some people scan through reviews I'll start with something easy to see:
GOOD GAME, UNIQUE MECHANICS, ONLY TO BECOME BETTER.

Alright, there, that's for the people who have better things to do with their time.  You and me now?  We're in this together if you keep reading.

I have been with the Thea series since the early access on Thea: The Awakening, and I will tell you what you will find here: The solid base from which something truly unique and fun will emerge.   But why?  Why do I say that?  From experience, the team knows how to take formats unused and lore untold in the major markets, and just turn what would so easily be a frustrating, confusing experience for most games into a smooth, uniquely enjoyable experience.

Fantastical resources?  Wonderful sense of scope without actually being too large?  Swords, spears and ancient artifacts of power?  Check!

Odd races?  Unique events?  Enough randomization and challenge to keep this being fun every time you come back?  Already check.  

This won't be the usual slog, but it's going to be a fun one, and as someone who has been the veteran of far too many games (help), let me tell you that this is one I have been looking forwards to, and now that I've tried the EA?  Will continue to watch the patchnotes eagerly for.

Buy it if you don't mind it being the sapling it is right now, but this baby's gonna become yet another World Tree in no time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032392270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 6794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1687814736}
review:
Compared to Thea 1:
+ Fresh content and quite a lot of it
+ Lots of different types of characters, races, biomes, sea travel
- Terrible UX, the UI is just not fun to use and completely overloaded. Also there are literally 0 options to change animation speeds etc for the game, and the combat speed makes the game laggy and the visuals buggy
- Crafting better materials is way too complex and grindy, it takes forever to craft high tier materials
- Having a base does not really pay off, if you just go around and crush enemies you get more resources and better items. Also you do not get XP from crafting anymore, really there is not much to gain from having a base
- Base buildings are boring now
- Crafting equipment is incredibly complex, you can't really guess what you get based
- Equipment is often not really useful, the custom skills are most of the time stronger than the attacks your items provide
- More experienced characters have a lot of duplicity of attacks and most (weak) attack skills you will just never use, they are just there because you had to teach them to your character
- Combat system is way too convoluted now, there is too many effects and too much to consider. I played a lot with it and it just does not get better the more I learn it, it is never really fun. Thea 1 had a learning curve but you could master combat, in Thea 2 you just grind for items and get better characters and that is how you master combat.
- Very imbalanced, the sea encounters give you amazing gear, everything else does not really

Overall I think they tried to pack too much into this game. I perceive it as unpolished and overloaded and imbalanced and that kills the fun for me. In Thea 1 I had to learn things the hard way, then optimize. This game has a hard beginning and then you just try to get stronger characters and equipment  for 200 turns - the end. I loved having a base, now I have most fun not having one because having one is just a chore without big benefits.

The art style and story are still good, the writing is fine too. I feel like they should have focused more on the core. Much is not always better. You can always add more when the core works, but here nothing really comes together and it transcends into chaos.

7/10 would play Thea 1 again

author: {'steamid': '76561197971400756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 16510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1685629186}
review:
Taking in to account this is an early access game in the truest sense, where it is essentially asking users to test features and work through mechanics that don't have all the quality of life ui features one would expect, so far I am liking what I see.

Thea 2 feels familiar enough in theme to the first game while also being brave enough to exlpore new mechanics to make it actually feel like a new game as oppossed to the "Ctl-c, Ctrl-v" so many games go for with sequels. The new card mechanics feel like a game of Hearthstone or Gwent in many ways, which works very well incorporated in to the larger strategic layer of navigating the map and many story elements of the game. The inclusion of cooperative encounters is a huge positive step from the previous game as I play this game with my wife the majority of the time. 

I won't go more in to detail than this since I only have 10 hours at this point and the game is clearly going to go through significant development. I can say from experience in the previous game and what I am seeing so far that this is a dedicated development team working on a labor of love, which really makes all the difference in the long run. You really only want to pick this up in early access if you want to help out in the development process by testing whatever mechanics are on focus and fiving feedback on bugs. If you are just trying to get an early playthrough, sit tight and wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077569868', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 18050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18050, 'last_played': 1684617074}
review:
KNOW THE GAME: It’s basically the same thing as the first Thea: a very unique blend between turn based strategy, roguelike and card game. You travel a slavian medieval apocalyptic world with a party of characters gathering resources, leveling up, building and crafting. Each grid you walk may trigger a random event. Then you try to figure out how to solve the events on a card battle, that may be based upon your characters strength, wits or magic skill. The world is deadly and unforgiving, each event may get or stronger or be your last. 
Disclaimer: many players coming from Thea 1 dislike the changes to the card battle game, because you can place the same character on the field more than one time. I have no problems with that, the battle is basically a simulation, and placing the character more than once simply means he is attacking or acting twice. 

HIGHLIGHTS: Thea the shattering already had endless possibilities. Now, think more classes, more races, more resources, more crafts, more stories, more events, more paths. They improved what was good.  

COULD BE BETTER: I would love to see a Thea 3 with and actual turn based grid strategy battle system. 

Graphics: 
🟩🟩⬛⬛⬛ 3 (simple)
Design & Artstyle
🟩🟩🟩🟩⬛ 3 (Good, hand-drawn)
Gameplay & Quality
🟩🟩🟩🟩⬛ 4 (Addictive)
Story
🟩🟩🟩🟩⬛ 4 (well done)
Content
🟩🟩🟩🟩🟩 5 (Endless roguelike)
Sound& Music
🟩🟩⬛⬛⬛ 2 (ok)

Final Verdict: They actually improved what was already good. Thumbs UP!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007683294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 4029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1589407653}
review:
The Devs have put in an impressive shift getting the game ready for release and while I'm giving this game a downvote I applaud their work overall.

Sadly this game has lost a lot of the first games charm, mainly due to clunky and odd mechanics which feel forced and out of place.

For instance the new combat features what the game calls 'clones' - how cloning technology fits into a high fantasy setting is beyond me, and the game makes no effort to explain or mesh with the games fiction. You can just duplicate your characters and that's that.

And a major change is starting the game nomadic, which is fine but a 'day' is 3 or 4 steps on the map which means you are constantly setting up camp and crafting projects etc, this is every few seconds. And for some reason your crafter can't remember what they were working on the day before and so must start again every day.

I'm going to give the game a play through after release and see if it can change my mind - on a recent forum thread almost every post started with words like "I hated it at first ..." so maybe pushing through the oddities is worth it. But if I was a dev I'd have warning bells going off with a game so close to release and seeing that sentiment repeated so often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102763655', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1647164146}
review:
Thea2 is a game with a lot of promise. It is currently in Early Access with plenty of bugs to be fixed including plenty of crashes, mainly in events. However, right now there is a patch coming out every single day with a plethora of fixes, so I have no doubt that the list of bugs will swiftly go down. 

One of the main things I like about Thea2 is that it is significantly different from Thea1, while still keeping the same spirit and atmosphere. Too often a sequel is simply a clone of the first part, with a few added features, but that is certainly not the case here.

I'd definitely recommend getting into this game, even though you might want to wait with some serious playthroughs until the game is less error-prone if that is something which ruins a game for you. Of course, there is a very good bug-reporting tool and you'll help the developers a great deal by playing and reporting bugs at this stage.

review:
Already a massive improvement over the initial Kickstarter. Looking at the progress the developer has made in a few months and the rate they're pumping out bugfixes, I'm fully confident the game will be ready and awesome in a few months.

The core game mechanics like gathering, crafting, and character development have improved significantly over Thea1. Almost everything in the game seems to be moddable, which is a huge plus.
There is still a lack of event variety, and there's plenty of bugs. Both of these are to be expected in an Early Access game.

To anyone interested in the game: read the Early Access message in full.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017188773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 19902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1685088339}
review:
You know normally I would never write a review on a game this early because it's not ready for it. But I am doing this to counterbalance those truly worrying people who give it a down vote because it's bare bones early access. If you're not going to give it a month to see what they can do then you're not giving it a fair chance. 

At the moment I'd put it in the barely playable category with the full understanding that it is only going to get better based on the last game and how it progressed. If you want to get involved then buy it and jump on the forums or on discord. I can see it's ambitious and trying to improve and expand on the old Thea and everything that's in it looks like it will be really good once more is implemented and balance is achieved. I don't really consider it to be a hugely expensive game and considering the state of some of the games lately this is a lot more honest a release than certain other companies.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998771711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 29141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1665898811}
review:
I get that people are frustrated with the bugs and all, and they may not think that things will get better since they've been burned by other games gone into early access the devs have given up on.

These devs aren't the type though. 

Seriously though, Thea 1 was a god damned masterpiece and was just as buggy at launch, but they quickly improved things. If you asked me 10 years ago if I'd be spending 200+ hours on a turn-based village simulating card game hybrid instead of Halo 12 or whatever, I'd have called you crazy, but they made it work, and Thea 2 is looking like it's going to be even better. They've improved the card game, which now requires a bit more strategy and thought to it, they've improved the auto-combat system, which will let you go into manual combat if you don't like the results, they've improved the character progression system, giving you a choice where shit's gonna go, and they've even improved on the random events, which now seem more detailed with even more branching paths.

So I gotta say: give em' a month before passing judgement. That should be more than enough time for them to fix things up, and help em' out along the way. Think of it this way: you'll essentially be getting a $50 game in the end for only $20 bucks + about $10 bucks of work helping to fix bugs. That there's a bargain deal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055468208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1675740050}
review:
Buyer beware - I would NOT consider this game to be "fully playable and mostly feature-complete." And if it is, it's really unfortunate. DO NOT puchase this game yet if you just want to play it. You may very well regret the purchase. Only buy in if you want to help the developers in making this the game it ought to be.

I loved Thea: The Awakening. It was a great game. So when I saw this up, for 10% off, plus another 10% from a coupon I got, I jumped on it. I knew Thea as a fantastic game, full of character, replayability, and great crafting. I figured this would be the same.

Currently, it's not, but I do hope it eventually will be. My favorite parts of Thea were the exploration, characters, and crafting. The world was interesting to explore and find new resources and events to take part in. There were so many different types of characters. A bunch of races, non-human characters. They had different abbilities and could affect your available choices in quests. All that is here, but not even halfway to the original Thea's level yet. There's a lot of potential. I've seen hints at various systems that could be cool. But it's just not there yet. I think it's going to take a lot longer than 6 months to reach the point that this game becomes a true successor to the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020143528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 12869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3990, 'last_played': 1649191202}
review:
Hi les gens...


A ce jour en pleine phase Beta...version 0.99999; Théa 2 ne serait tarder..Et c'est bien dommage!
Pourquoi? Parceque question réponse...dans le genre, je met juste un peu de couleure aux dessins et reprend toutes les quetes, en mode moins bien travaillé..de grosse chianlit dès le démarrage, avec l'implantation du village, qui est encore plus longue et moins parsemé d'évenement agréables..En gros; ce théa est largement plus dure en aléatoire, autant que finallement vous commencerez avec normalement 5 villageois, mais officiellement 4 (puisque il faut débloquer l'accés au 5eme)..en une première partie...
Tout est pareil à la version 1 le meme type d edieu qu'il vous faudra déblmoquer en niveau pour dans des parties longue et ici moins parcouru d'évenement..cela risque de paraitre ennyant...
Je vais etre clair; en plus de 5 parties, je ne suis jamais arrivé à dépassé le tour 100 autant qu'avec 4 villageois et des évenements en moyenne tous les 5/10 tours, je me suis peu motivé...
C'est à dire que Théa 1 est vachement plus sympathique...Le nombre de villageois et l'inventaire y sont bien plus développé...C'est simple ici tout est encore plus limité..moins de villageois, de combattants, d'évenements, de ressources..meme le village posséde une limite en poid ressources, ce qui est vraiment, mais vraiment chiant;...
J evais etre clair, en l'etat, ce 2 est un remake simpliste et coloré du 1..mais bien moins développé et à mon avis bien plus chiant/..Grosse déception...
Je cherche les points positifs/ et n'en vois pas...Le village posséde moins de batiment à produire/ les inventaires ont été diminué..Les combats sont identiques, voir mins fluides, en terme d'enchènements, la map est grande mais peu répèté de ressources...autant que le village s'implante pas vraiment sur des coins sympas en ressources.;essentiels...Et l'arbre des technologie (exactement le meme, à peu de chose près)...Bref, je ne vois absolument pa sou sont les nouveautés si ce n'est en moins..les évenements sont à l'identiques...
Bref, ceux , comme moi, qui vienne du 1..c'est un Remake lamentable et je vous conseil, en l'état de ne pas l'acheter....
La musique est sympas; mais cela ne suffit pas..à casser un ennui, qui vous prend dès le début autant que les 50 à 100 tour consiste à rester au camp pour crafter un village...Peu d'exploration possible à 4 villageois puisque la moindre combinaison de ressources oblige au moins 2 ressources différentes, mais des quantités, qui reste trop importante autant que vous avez toujours besoin de bois et de nourriture..en gros..il ne reste que 2 villageois pour Harvest, ce qui revient à etre long et pénible...Comme déja dit: c'est un remake du 1 mais en moins grand, en terme d'éuipe et d'objets..puisque poids en villages reste limité et le craft de peu d'objet pour les inventaire nous font amérement oublié combien le 2 ne vaut pas le 1...Perso, je comprend leur choix, et ce manque de continuité dans ce qui fut déja à l'époque un minimum....
Monsieur les développeurs sortez vous les doigts du cul/ ce théa 2 est un emerde simpliste et pour ce que j'en ai joué....meme votre apport en terme de "remasterisation des dessins en couleure est grossier voir pas assez bien fait pour qu'on en oublie tous les ingrédients dont on se sert plus...En fait, c'est comme si ,ils avaient dégrossit le rythme des crafts, des events et des combats..pour les étaler en tour autant que déja le 1 avec tous les parties nécessaire pour débloquer les niveaus des dieux offraient de stemps de jeu presque trop long en répètition/..Et les évenements sont selon moi, bien moins bien orienté, fait que ceux du 1...Bref; je le déconseil vraiment sérieusement et ceux qui voudraient, parce que tenté par une annonce..s'y essayer..je vous conseil sans détour le 1, qui reste bien plus complet et attachant puisque vous montez largement dans des équipes a plus de 40 villageois, alors qu'ici..on peine à passer à 5..jusqu'au tour au moins 150...Trop mauvais à mon gout!Pourquoi avoir fait un remake si peu sérieux..faudra m'expliquer....Mais bien sur..c'est gens ne rendront aucun compte! Pfff..
Allez le sgens perdez pas espoir...Un jour, on aura une suite plus sérieuse..parce qu'à mon sens..faudrait qu'il multiplie le contenue du 2 au moins par 2 si ce n'est 10 pour en faire réellement une suite meilleure..(et pas divisé par 2..resources/inventaires/objets/combats/villageois/batiments/ressources sur map/ et meme les lieux à visiter m'ont semblé moins nombreux)..Alors ceux qui me lisent me trouveront dure..Et ben sachez que je vous aurez prévenu: a ce jour, en version "in progress/beta"..Ils cachent au moins la moitié du contenue du 1 et si c'est un essai..meme la redondance d'un copier coller trop facile et colorié..ne donnepas vraiment la sensation d'une suite ou d'un renouveau..mais bien d'une pâle imitation..édulcoré et passable..allez-y pour voir..Mais sérieux faut m'expliquer ou est l'intérêt! quel ennuie, en l'état!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044958974', 'num_games_owned': 616, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 3532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1076, 'last_played': 1685275084}
review:
Played a fair amount of Thea 1 (about 50 hours), I am a fan of the game but not a huge "fan boy" so I will try keep the review as unbias as I can.

For Thea 1 fans: 
- Compared to Thea 1, Thea 2 is bare bone (hence early access so this was to be expected)
- Changed up the Gods in a better way, won't spoil it by going into detail
- Simplified character stats & skills in a good way, not a complex mess Thea 1 was.
- there are no gameplay or map generation options yet (2nd december 2018)
- The challenge system (or combat system if you like) is much better 
- The auto resolve is about the same, sometimes in your favor (wins you a challenge you would surely lose), sometimes not (destroys your party on a challenge you would surely win), but the best thing about it is that you do not need to take the result! you can choose to resolve manually if you do not like the auto resolve resolution.
- No need to be tied to a village! you can just wonder around and do your thing
- You can still have a village, it's now optional! and you get to pick where it goes!!! (this resolved a massive pain point for me with thea 1, I'm sure you will agree)
- The menus are so much better, much nicer to look and navigate (this is biggie for me)
- Unlike thea 1 where multiplayer was an afterthought and not that great (I still appreciate the devs effort and I did play at least 20 hours of multiplayer) Thea 2 multiplayer is built in nicely and works fine (so far)

For players new to Thea:
- keep in mind this is a Slavic survival game, it is brutal, you will be starting new games, a lot.
- it is early access, it has a great basis but it does lack content and is buggy
- The Devs are amazing, they listen to feedback/suggestions and fix bugs quickly, they patch often.
- Only buy if you are open to being part of an early access journey, willing to report bugs and be part of the development process or at least open minded enough not to smash this game with a negative review if you don't like it while it's in early access, wait to 1.0 to give it a decent chance
- if you are interested in a Slavic survival game, it may be worth buying Thea 1 and spending your time playing that until Thea 2 leaves it's early access stage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994090349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 12295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2023, 'last_played': 1632934886}
review:
It's early access... 
So yeah, there are bugs, it's not polished and there's some detail missing. 
Honestly I can't believe we're still seeing people pointing these things out and rating poorly on games clearly marked early access. 
Stop buying early access games, or accept that you're participating in the development of a game, not getting the finished product... 
[b]Anway...[/b]

Thea 2 isn't finished and that's obvious from a few hours of play. There is fantastic potential there though and as a massive fan of the original, I think that potential looks very exciting. From deeper crafting, more varied interactions to the ability to have multiple villages on the go. 
Add to that the fact that the Dev's actively respond on Discord. In fact I had one try and trouble shoot a co-op bug I was experiencing live over IM with me. 

I think, given a bit of time and work by the devs Thea 2: The Shattering will be equal to if not better than the original. It's well worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020091544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 31258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 795, 'playtime_at_review': 1302, 'last_played': 1711735072}
review:
Ich habe viele Stunden Thea 1 gezockt und wollte das sympathische Entwicklerstudio unterstützen, indem ich Thea 2 im early access kaufe, normalerweise warte ich immer auf Full Release um das Spiel dann komplett zu genießen. 

Aber nun zu meinem vorläufigen Fazit: 
Spieler die Thea 1 mochten, werden auch Thea 2 mögen, natürlich ist das Spiel noch in einer frühen Einwicklungsphase, viel Inhalt scheint  noch nicht implementiert zu sein und es gibt auch einige Bugs, ich hatte z.B. einen Fehler und konnte mein Savegame nicht laden nachdem ein wichtiger Held meiner Gruppe das zeitliche gesgnet hat, daraufhin erschien eine Fehlermeldung und der Ladescreen stoppte mit Fehlermeldung bei 79% . 
Trotzdem kann man sagen, dass das Spiel viel Spaß macht und das wohlbekannte "nur noch eine Runde" Gefühl sehr schnell aufkommt. 

Mein Englisch ist nicht so schlecht, trotzdem freue ich mich als deutscher Spieler natürlich auch auf die deutsche Übersetzung damit die Geschichte und Dialoge verständlicher werden, denn Thea ist auch ein Textlastiges Spiel und manche Dialoge sind schon recht Anspruchsvoll was die Anforderunge an die englischen Sprachskills angeht. ;-)
  
Das Spiel bekommt eine klare Kaufempfehlung von mir, wer Bugs und unkompletten Spieleinhalt nicht mag, sollte mit dem Kauf noch warten bis das Spiel weiter entwickelt wurde. Meiner Ansicht nach hätte das Entwicklerstudio noch etwas warten sollen mit dem Early Access release, damit hätte man sicherlich viele der schlechteren Bewertungen vermeiden können. Spieler kucken nunmal auf die Bewertungen und machen oft,- auch wenn es Early Access ist,  einen Bogen um Spiele mit schlechten Bewertungen selbst wenn die kürzlichen Bewertungen dagegen positiv sind.

Nachtrag 13.05.2019:
Das Spiel ist nun released und ich kann meine Kaufempfehlung nur nochmal deutlich unterstreichen. Ich habe die gesamte early access Phase mitgemacht und das Entwicklerteam war sehr fleißig, von den Bugs sind nur noch sehr sehr wenige übrig geblieben und das Spiel wurde was Inhalt und Story angeht nochmal weiterentwickelt und läuft wirklich sehr stabil. 
Wer rundenbasierte Fantasy Strategiespiele mag, kommt um Thea nicht herum. Für potentielle Spieler denen die kartenbasierten Herausforderungen nicht so zusagen gibt es auch die Option diese automatisch mit einem Klick zu lösen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039360037', 'num_games_owned': 1570, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1671968334}
review:
Zuerst einmal muss ich sagen, dass man diesem Spiel noch den early access anmerkt. Dabei liegt die Betonung sehr stark auf "noch". Ich habe den ersten Teil über 100 Stunden gespielt und sehr geliebt. Da war es anfangs genauso und die Entwickler patchten und entwickelten fleißig weiter. 
Die Neuerungen in diesem Spiel sehen alle schon sehr gut aus und machen Sinn. 
Dazu gehören:
 -die freie Wahl des Siedlungsplatzes, den man ja in Teil 1 schon geschenkt bekam
- das neue Kampfsystem, bei dem das Kartenspiel wesentlich komplexer und damit auch spaßiger ausfällt und
-die größeren Freiheiten bei der Charakterentwicklung und der Wahl der Startvorteile einer Gottheit.

Fazit: Es wurde an den richtigen Stellen angesetzt um den genialen 1. Teil noch zu toppen und die Entwickler sind auf dem besten Weg das zu erreichen. Wer ein anspruchsvolles RPG-Strategie-Survival sucht, kann ruhig zugreifen.
